<Question>
What is the gradient of this line?
\(5 x+3 y=15\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the coefficient of x represents the gradient even when a line is not in the form y = mx+c</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
What is the gradient of this line?
\(5 x+3 y=15\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, believes that when they get to ax = b, b is the solution</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
What is the gradient of this line?
\(5 x+3 y=15\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Compare sets of data using the range</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
The table shows the summary statistics from some girls and boys who took a test.
Who performed the most consistently? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Gender & Mean & Range \\
\hline Girls & \( 75 \) & \( 20 \) \\
\hline Boys & \( 60 \) & \( 40 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>The boys because their mean is lower</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a lower average means the data is more consistent</Misconception>

\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>The boys because their range is higher</Answer>

<Construct>Recognise the notation for parallel lines</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing parallel lines. Tom says these two lines are parallel ![Image of a grid of squares with 2 lines on it. One line goes two squares to the right and one square up. The second line goes four squares to the right and two squares up.]() Katie says these two lines are parallel ![Image of a grid of squares with 2 lines on it. One line goes two squares to the right and one square up. The second line goes two squares to the right and one square down.]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes two lines of the same length are parallel</Misconception>

<Construct>Prove statements involving multiples</Construct>
<Subject>Algebraic Proof</Subject>
<Question>
On what line is the first mistake when proving \( (n+1)^{2}-(n-1)^{2} \) is divisible by \( 4 \) ? \( n^{2}+2 n+1-\left(n^{2}-2 n+1\right) \quad \) Line \( 1 \) \( n^{2}+2 n+1-n^{2}-2 n+1 \quad \) Line \( 2 \) \[
2
\]

Line \( 3 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Line \( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores negative sign when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate missing lengths of shapes by geometrical inference, where the lengths given are in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of the shaded section of this composite shape made from rectangles? ![A composite shape made from two rectangles that form an "L" shape.  The base of the shape is horizontal and is 13cm long. The vertical height of the whole shape is 14cm. The horizontal width of the top part of the shape is 6cm. The vertical height of the top rectangle is 8cm. The right handed rectangle is shaded blue]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 48 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses an incorrect side length when splitting a composite shape into parts</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate missing lengths of shapes by geometrical inference, where the lengths given are in the same units</Construct>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
In which region would \( x+y=1 \) belong? ![A Venn diagram with two intersecting sets. The set on the right is 'Crosses the y-axis at (0,1)' and the set of the right is 'Has a positive gradient'. A is in the 'Crosses the y-axis at (0,1)' set only, B is in the intersection, C is in the 'Has a positive gradient' only and D is outside both sets.]()
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the coefficient of x represents the gradient even when a line is not in the form y = mx+c</Misconception>

<Construct>Use brackets to write function machines as calculations</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about the result of this Function Machine:
Jo says the output is: \( \frac{n}{5}+3 \)
Paul says the output is: \( \frac{n+3}{5} \)
Who is correct? ![A function machine showing an input of n and operations divide by 5 and add 3]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>Use brackets to write function machines as calculations</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about the result of this Function Machine:
Jo says the output is: \( \frac{n}{5}+3 \)
Paul says the output is: \( \frac{n+3}{5} \)
Who is correct? ![A function machine showing an input of n and operations divide by 5 and add 3]()
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

When \( h=10 \)
\(
\frac{h}{2}=
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>

\(
\frac{h}{2}=
\)

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for ascending quadratic sequences in the form ax² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\(
6,14,28,48,74, \ldots
\)

When calculating the nth-term rule of this sequence, what should replace the triangle?

nth-term rule: \( 3 n^{2} \)\( \color{red}\triangle \)  \(n\) \( \color{purple}\square \)

</Question>
<Answer>\[
+1
\]
(or just a + sign)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the differences between terms in a sequence, believes they can do so from right to left </Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for ascending quadratic sequences in the form ax² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\(
6,14,28,48,74, \ldots
\)

When calculating the nth-term rule of this sequence, what should replace the triangle?

nth-term rule: \( 3 n^{2} \)\( \color{red}\triangle \)  \(n\) \( \color{purple}\square \)

</Question>
<Answer>\( +3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the nth term rule for a quadratic sequence, believes they only need to use the first term to calculate the coefficient of n </Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(
p-5=\frac{1}{10}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p=\frac{6}{10} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding an integer to a fraction, thinks you add the integer to the numerator</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(
p-5=\frac{1}{10}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p=\frac{5}{50} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, multiplies instead of adding</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about solving inequalities.
Tom says \( -2 m>12 \) gives \( m>-6 \)
Katie says \( -2+m>12 \) gives \( m>14 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they can multiply/divide through by a negative number without changing the direction of the inequality</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the size of each interior angle in a regular polygon</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to calculate the size of each interior angle in a regular \( 20 \) sided shape

Tom says you can do \( \frac{18 \times 180}{20} \)

Katie says you can do \( 180-\frac{360}{20} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that interior and exterior angles are supplementary</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the size of each interior angle in a regular polygon</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to calculate the size of each interior angle in a regular \( 20 \) sided shape

Tom says you can do \( \frac{18 \times 180}{20} \)

Katie says you can do \( 180-\frac{360}{20} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the only way to find the interior angle of a regular polygon is to subtract the exterior angle from 180.</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
\(
0.095643
\)

What is this number rounded to \( 1 \) significant figure?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts leading zero as a significant figure</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
\(
0.095643
\)

What is this number rounded to \( 1 \) significant figure?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.09 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up when next digit is 5</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
\(
0.095643
\)

What is this number rounded to \( 1 \) significant figure?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.01 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When rounding up from a 9, does not add one on to the digit to the left</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems involving converting between fractions, decimals and percentages</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 100 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies the wrong part of a fraction model as the whole</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems involving converting between fractions, decimals and percentages</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 60 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes to complete a part whole model you select a value already given in the model</Misconception>

<Question>
The product of two numbers is \( -24 \).
What could the two numbers be?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \) and \( -8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out multiplication problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
The product of two numbers is \( -24 \).
What could the two numbers be?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -10 \) and \( -14 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that product means add rather than multiply</Misconception>

<Construct>Read values from piecewise functions</Construct>
<Subject>Other Graphs-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Tom is has correctly drawn the graph of the following function:
\(
y=\left\{\begin{array}{c}
3 \text { for } 0 \leq x<Q \\
P \text { for } 1.5 \leq x<4 \\
2.5 \text { for } 4 \leq x<7
\end{array}\right.
\)

What are the values of \( P \) and \( Q \) ? ![The graph is three separate horizontal lines. It goes from (0,3) to (1.5, 3), then (1.5, 2) to (4, 2) and the last section is from (4, 2.5) to (7, 2.5)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}P=1.5 \\ Q=2\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading value from graph, reads from the wrong axes.</Misconception>

<Construct>Read values from piecewise functions</Construct>
<Subject>Other Graphs-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Tom is has correctly drawn the graph of the following function:
\(
y=\left\{\begin{array}{c}
3 \text { for } 0 \leq x<Q \\
P \text { for } 1.5 \leq x<4 \\
2.5 \text { for } 4 \leq x<7
\end{array}\right.
\)

What are the values of \( P \) and \( Q \) ? ![The graph is three separate horizontal lines. It goes from (0,3) to (1.5, 3), then (1.5, 2) to (4, 2) and the last section is from (4, 2.5) to (7, 2.5)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}P=2 \\ Q=1\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading graph, chooses nearest marked value on axis instead of reading accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the net of a non-prism</Construct>
<Subject>Nets</Subject>
<Question>
This is the net of a... ![An image with an equilateral triangle in the centre. Connected to each of the three sides of the equilateral triangle are 3 more identical, equilateral triangles forming a larger triangle shape.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Triangle</Answer>
<Misconception>Names one of the faces of a 3D shape rather than the 3D shape name</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the net of a non-prism</Construct>
<Subject>Nets</Subject>
<Question>
This is the net of a... ![An image with an equilateral triangle in the centre. Connected to each of the three sides of the equilateral triangle are 3 more identical, equilateral triangles forming a larger triangle shape.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Triangular prism</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses pyramid with prism</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)(cx + d)</Construct>

<Question>
Alison is expanding these two brackets.
What should she get when she multiplies the two terms indicated by the arrows? ![The two brackets are (5p-4)(2p-3). The arrows are pointing at the -4 in the first bracket and the -3 in the second bracket.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)(cx + d)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Alison is expanding these two brackets.
What should she get when she multiplies the two terms indicated by the arrows? ![The two brackets are (5p-4)(2p-3). The arrows are pointing at the -4 in the first bracket and the -3 in the second bracket.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplies</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}-99p
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p+9)(p-9) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}-99p
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p+3 \sqrt{11})(p-3 \sqrt{11}) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the table of values for \( y=x^{2}-1 \) \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( 15 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Tom says the star could be \( 4 \)

Katie says the star could be \( -4 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the square of a negative will also be negative</Misconception>

The inner scale goes from 0 to 360 in an anti-clockwise direction. The angle is between one red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the protractor and goes anti-clockwise to the other red line that is half way between 330 and 340 (inner scale) and halfway between 210 and 200 (outer scale).
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 345^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Correct scale but wrong value on protractor reading.</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form a(x + b)² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
When Sarah completes the square, what should replace the star? \( 2 g^{2}-6 g-5 \equiv 2(g  \bigstar)^{2} \triangle \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \bigstar=-6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes the constant in the bracket is the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form a(x + b)² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
When Sarah completes the square, what should replace the star? \( 2 g^{2}-6 g-5 \equiv 2(g  \bigstar)^{2} \triangle \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \bigstar=-3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes that a is always half the x-coefficient. </Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form a(x + b)² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
When Sarah completes the square, what should replace the star? \( 2 g^{2}-6 g-5 \equiv 2(g  \bigstar)^{2} \triangle \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \bigstar=-\sqrt{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes the constant in the bracket is the square root of the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Answer>another triangle number</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes triangle numbers are formed differently to the correct way</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply mixed number fraction in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying mixed numbers, forgets to multiply the fraction</Misconception>

<Question>
\( 1 \frac{1}{2} \times 3 \frac{2}{3}=\bigstar\frac{3}{6} \) What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying mixed numbers thinks they add the integers</Misconception>

\( 1.4 \)

<Answer>\( \frac{1}{4} \)</Answer>

\( 1.4 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Not possible as it is greater than \( 1 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the range of the following numbers?
\[
0.31,0.30,0.331
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.021 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating the range does not reorder the data to find the largest number minus the smallest number</Misconception>

0.31,0.30,0.331
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.301 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting decimals with a different number of decimal places, lines up the digits incorrectly</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of volume or capacity</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is not a measure of volume?
</Question>
<Answer>Cubic metres</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that cubic means the same as cubed in units</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of volume or capacity</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is not a measure of volume?
</Question>
<Answer>Centimetres cubed</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that units of volume are usually cubed</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of volume or capacity</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is not a measure of volume?
</Question>
<Answer>Litres</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise litres as a unit of volume</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence? \( 4, \quad 10, \quad 14, \quad 24, \quad \ldots \)
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you add \( 6 \) to the previous term</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence? \( 4, \quad 10, \quad 14, \quad 24, \quad \ldots \)
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you double the previous term and add \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence? \( 4, \quad 10, \quad 14, \quad 24, \quad \ldots \)
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you multiply the previous term by \( 3 \) and subtract \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest 10</Construct>
<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 5050 \) rounded to the nearest \( 10 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest 10</Construct>
<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 5050 \) rounded to the nearest \( 10 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest 10</Construct>
<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 5050 \) rounded to the nearest \( 10 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5010 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that rounding must change the number</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(12 d-3=0\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( d=-\frac{1}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(12 d-3=0\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( d=4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Swaps the dividend and divisor in order to get an integer answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate time where speed and distance are in the appropriate units</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This displacement-time graph shows the start of Mo's journey home.

During that time he travelled at a speed of \( 4 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).
What are the coordinates of the marked point? ![The vertical axis of the graph is labelled Distance (m) and has a scale marked from 0 to 60 in even steps. The horizontal axis is labelled Time (secs) and has no scale marked on it. The graph is a straight line that goes from point (0,60) and touches the Time axis three squares from the origin (0,0).
The marked point is one square in on the Time axis and at 40 on the Distance axis.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (1,40) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Makes an assumption about the squares on a scale representing either 1 or 10</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate time where speed and distance are in the appropriate units</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This displacement-time graph shows the start of Mo's journey home.

During that time he travelled at a speed of \( 4 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).
What are the coordinates of the marked point? ![The vertical axis of the graph is labelled Distance (m) and has a scale marked from 0 to 60 in even steps. The horizontal axis is labelled Time (secs) and has no scale marked on it. The graph is a straight line that goes from point (0,60) and touches the Time axis three squares from the origin (0,0).
The marked point is one square in on the Time axis and at 40 on the Distance axis.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (10,40) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Makes an assumption about the squares on a scale representing either 1 or 10</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate time where speed and distance are in the appropriate units</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This displacement-time graph shows the start of Mo's journey home.

During that time he travelled at a speed of \( 4 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).
What are the coordinates of the marked point? ![The vertical axis of the graph is labelled Distance (m) and has a scale marked from 0 to 60 in even steps. The horizontal axis is labelled Time (secs) and has no scale marked on it. The graph is a straight line that goes from point (0,60) and touches the Time axis three squares from the origin (0,0).
The marked point is one square in on the Time axis and at 40 on the Distance axis.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (20,40) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes scales on graphs must match on both axes</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a trapezium where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
When calculating the area of this trapezium, what are the values of \( a \) and \( b \) in the formula? ![Diagram of a trapezium with its 2 parallel sides horizontal. The parallel sides are labelled as 9cm and 10cm. The lengths of the 2 non-parallel sides are labelled as 7cm and 7.5cm. The perpendicular height is labelled as 6cm.]() Area \( =\left(\frac{a+b}{2}\right) h \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7+7.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses slant heights instead of parallel sides to find area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a trapezium where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

The parallel sides are labelled as 9cm and 10cm. The lengths of the 2 non-parallel sides are labelled as 7cm and 7.5cm. The perpendicular height is labelled as 6cm.]() Area \( =\left(\frac{a+b}{2}\right) h \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7+6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses slant heights instead of parallel sides to find area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify fractions that simplify to a unit fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Simplifies integers when simplifying a mixed number</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify fractions that simplify to a unit fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following fraction in its simplest form: \( 6 \frac{3}{18} \)
</Question>
<Answer>Cannot be simplified</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand how to simplify fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just one linear variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following by collecting like terms.
\[
5 s-6 s+12 s-11 s
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 s \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In algebra, thinks it's ok to write (for example) 0x rather than just 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
When finding the range of a data set, what is the first step?
</Question>
<Answer>Write the numbers in ascending order.</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the median instead of the range</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
When finding the range of a data set, what is the first step?
</Question>
<Answer>Add all the numbers together.</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the mean instead of the range</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
When finding the range of a data set, what is the first step?
</Question>
<Answer>Write the numbers in ascending or descending order.</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the median instead of the range</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
This is the final stage of Lucy's solution to a quadratic equation.
What should replace the star?
\[
(h+4)(h-3)=0
\] \( h=\bigstar \) or \( h=3 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solutions of a quadratic equation are the absolute values of the constants in the factorised form</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
This is the final stage of Lucy's solution to a quadratic equation.
What should replace the star?
\[
(h+4)(h-3)=0
\] \( h=\bigstar \) or \( h=3 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes all quadratic equations have a solution of 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
The area of the trapezium on the right is \( 40 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \). ![A trapezium with the parallel sides a and b labelled with x+2 and x+4 and the perpendicular height x.]() Based on the information given, Adam writes this formula:
\(x^{2}+3 x=40\)

What are the two solutions to this equation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}x=8 \\ \text { and } \\ x=-5\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solutions of a quadratic equation are the constants in the factorised form</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>

Pattern 1 is a rectangle with a total of 6 circles surrounding it. Pattern 2 is 2 rectangles with a total of 10 circles surrounding it. Pattern 3 is 3 rectangles with a total of 14 circles surrounding it.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 42 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has multiplied the value of the first term by the the term being asked</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data</Construct>

<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
3,5,6,18,18,-4
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you don't need to numerically order the data before calculating the median</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
3,5,6,18,18,-4
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the median from a even dataset does not understand we must find the midpoint of the two values in the middle</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data</Construct>

<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
3,5,6,18,18,-4
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 18 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the mode instead of the median</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
When factorising \( x^{2}+5 x+6 \) we need two numbers that:
</Question>
<Answer>Add to give \( 6 \) and multiply to give \( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that to factorise a quadratic expression, to find two numbers that add to give the coefficient of the x term, and multiply to give the non variable term
</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
When factorising \( x^{2}+5 x+6 \) we need two numbers that:
</Question>
<Answer>Add to give \( 6 x \) and multiply to give \( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that to factorise a quadratic expression, to find two numbers that add to give the coefficient of the x term, and multiply to give the non variable term
</Misconception>

<Construct>Triple numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
If you triple \( 8 \) you get...
</Question>
<Answer>\( 38 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying just writes the numbers next to each other</Misconception>

<Construct>Triple numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
If you triple \( 8 \) you get...
</Question>
<Answer>\( 11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiples</Misconception>

<Construct>Triple numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
If you triple \( 8 \) you get...
</Question>
<Answer>\( 888 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to triple, writes the digit out three times</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide algebraic fractions involving non-linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 2 \)
Which of the options is a correct second step to express the following as a single fraction?

\(
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{x-1}{6} \div \frac{x^{2}-1}{9} \\
= & \frac{x-1}{6} \times \frac{9}{x^{2}-1}
\end{aligned}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{9 x-1}{6 x^{2}-1} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide algebraic fractions involving non-linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 2 \)
Which of the options is a correct second step to express the following as a single fraction?

\(
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{x-1}{6} \div \frac{x^{2}-1}{9} \\
= & \frac{x-1}{6} \times \frac{9}{x^{2}-1}
\end{aligned}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{-1}{6} \times \frac{9}{x-1} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Incorrectly cancels what they believe is a factor in algebraic fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide algebraic fractions involving non-linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 2 \)
Which of the options is a correct second step to express the following as a single fraction?

\(
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{x-1}{6} \div \frac{x^{2}-1}{9} \\
= & \frac{x-1}{6} \times \frac{9}{x^{2}-1}
\end{aligned}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{x-1}{6} \times \frac{9}{(x-1)(x-1)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Factorises difference of two squares with the same sign in both brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Read an integer on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of B? ![A vertical number-line with 7 horizontal, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "-10" next to the bottom dash and "2" next to the top dash are the only numbers marked on the line. An arrow, labelled "B" is pointing at the middle dash. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading integers on a number line, assumes each dash is 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Read an integer on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of B? ![A vertical number-line with 7 horizontal, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "-10" next to the bottom dash and "2" next to the top dash are the only numbers marked on the line. An arrow, labelled "B" is pointing at the middle dash. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading integers on a number line, assumes each dash is 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Read an integer on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of B? ![A vertical number-line with 7 horizontal, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "-10" next to the bottom dash and "2" next to the top dash are the only numbers marked on the line. An arrow, labelled "B" is pointing at the middle dash. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts on in the wrong direction on a number line</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving full symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
The pictogram shows how many people came to watch a netball match.
What is the mean number of people at each game? ![A pictogram with a key showing a smiley face represents 12 people. Game 1 has 4 smiley faces, Game 2 has 2 smiley faces, Game 3 has 3 smiley faces and Game 4 has 1 smiley face.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know you can find the mean from a pictogram</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving full symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
The pictogram shows how many people came to watch a netball match.
What is the mean number of people at each game? ![A pictogram with a key showing a smiley face represents 12 people. Game 1 has 4 smiley faces, Game 2 has 2 smiley faces, Game 3 has 3 smiley faces and Game 4 has 1 smiley face.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When interpreting a pictogram, thinks each symbol stands for 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving full symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
The pictogram shows how many people came to watch a netball match.
What is the mean number of people at each game? ![A pictogram with a key showing a smiley face represents 12 people. Game 1 has 4 smiley faces, Game 2 has 2 smiley faces, Game 3 has 3 smiley faces and Game 4 has 1 smiley face.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 120 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating the mean from a list of data, adds up the numbers but does not divide</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a formula to describe a situation</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Sally the electrician charges a call-out fee of \( £ 40 \) and then \( £ 15 \) per hour that the job takes.

If a job takes \( n \) hours, which formula would help work out the cost \( (C) \) of hiring Sally?
</Question>
<Answer>\( C=15 n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not add on the constant in a worded substitution problem</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a formula to describe a situation</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Sally the electrician charges a call-out fee of \( £ 40 \) and then \( £ 15 \) per hour that the job takes.

If a job takes \( n \) hours, which formula would help work out the cost \( (C) \) of hiring Sally?
</Question>
<Answer>\( C=55 n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Combines variables with constants when writing a formula from a given situation</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a formula to describe a situation</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Sally the electrician charges a call-out fee of \( £ 40 \) and then \( £ 15 \) per hour that the job takes.

If a job takes \( n \) hours, which formula would help work out the cost \( (C) \) of hiring Sally?
</Question>
<Answer>\( C=40 n+15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gets their constants and coefficients the wrong way around when writing a formula from a given situation</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a description of a descending linear sequence in words, write some terms of that sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
If the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term of a sequence is \( 8 \) 
and the term-to-term rule is \( -2 \), 
what is the \( 7^{\text {th }} \) term in this sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the term after</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a description of a descending linear sequence in words, write some terms of that sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
If the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term of a sequence is \( 8 \) 
and the term-to-term rule is \( -2 \), 
what is the \( 7^{\text {th }} \) term in this sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence just gives the next term</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 3 digit integers by 2 digit integers using long multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
What is a correct way to set up this problem to solve it using long multiplication?
\[
426 \times 82
\]
</Question>
<Answer>![426 multiplied by 82 set out to perform long multiplication. 82 is written under 426. The 8 of 82 is under the 4 of 426 and the 2 of 82 is under the 2 of 426.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Hasn't lined up the place value columns when writing out the calculation</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 3 digit integers by 2 digit integers using long multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
What is a correct way to set up this problem to solve it using long multiplication?
\[
426 \times 82
\]
</Question>
<Answer>![426 multiplied by 82 set out to perform long multiplication. 426 is written in 3 columns with 400 in the first column, 20 in the second column and 6 in the third column. 82 is written underneath this, with 80 under 20 and 2 under 6.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Has partitioned the digits when doing long multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate an ascending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the first term of the sequence with the nth-term rule:
\[
5 n-7
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the nth term of a linear sequence, thinks the the first term is the coefficient in front of n.</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate an ascending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the first term of the sequence with the nth-term rule:
\[
5 n-7
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( -7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the first term in a sequence is the term before the sequence begins (0th term)</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate an ascending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the first term of the sequence with the nth-term rule:
\[
5 n-7
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the first term of a sequence must be 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a given ratio in the form 1:n </Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Kate and Isaac share some sweets in the ratio \( 3: 2 \)
What is this ratio in the form \( 1: n \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1: 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Attempts to simplify ratio by subtracting from both sides</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a given ratio in the form 1:n </Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Kate and Isaac share some sweets in the ratio \( 3: 2 \)
What is this ratio in the form \( 1: n \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1: 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying a ratio, divides one side of the ratio but multiplies the other side.</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify parallel lines with at least one equation written in another form</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following lines is not parallel to
\(y=3 x+5 \text { ? }\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 y=6 x-5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the coefficient of x represents the gradient even when a line is not in the form y = mx+c</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify parallel lines with at least one equation written in another form</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following lines is not parallel to
\(y=3 x+5 \text { ? }\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=3 x-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes lines are parallel if they have the same y intercept </Misconception>

<Construct>Identify parallel lines with at least one equation written in another form</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following lines is not parallel to
\(y=3 x+5 \text { ? }\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=3(1+x) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the coefficient of x represents the gradient even when a line is not in the form y = mx+c</Misconception>

<Construct>Recall and use the intersecting diagonals properties of a rhombus</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Quadrilaterals</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about the diagonals of quadrilaterals.
Tom says a kite has bisecting diagonals.
Katie says a rhombus has bisecting diagonals.
Who is correct? ![A pair of intersecting lines]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a kite has bisecting diagonals</Misconception>

<Construct>Recall and use the intersecting diagonals properties of a rhombus</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Quadrilaterals</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about the diagonals of quadrilaterals.
Tom says a kite has bisecting diagonals.
Katie says a rhombus has bisecting diagonals.
Who is correct? ![A pair of intersecting lines]()
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a kite has bisecting diagonals</Misconception>

<Construct>Recall and use the intersecting diagonals properties of a rhombus</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Quadrilaterals</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about the diagonals of quadrilaterals.
Tom says a kite has bisecting diagonals.
Katie says a rhombus has bisecting diagonals.
Who is correct? ![A pair of intersecting lines]()
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of bisect</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is part of a table of values for
\(y=x^{2}-2 x+1\)

What should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( -3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the square of a negative will also be negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>

<Question>

\(2 x>7\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x>4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes inequalities can only include integers</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>

<Question>
How should you write the solution to the following inequality?
\(2 x>7\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=3.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes solving an inequality gives a single value as a solution</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 18 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks finding a fraction of an amount means subtracting from that amount</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 144 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the denominator instead of dividing when finding a fraction of an amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 3 digit integers by 2 digit integers using Napier’s bones</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
Dave is trying to solve this problem using Napier's bones
What number does the circled digit represent? \( 356 \times 93 \) ![A Napier's bones grid, with 356 along the top and 93 down the side. From left to right on the top row, with / representing a diagonal line through through the box, the boxes read 2/7, 4/5, 5/4.  From left to right on the bottom row, the boxes read 0/9, 1/5, 1/8. The digit 5 is circled in the second box of the top row, which is in the column under the 5 of 356 and the row along from the 9 of 93.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the place value of answers from a Napier's bones calculation</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>

How many more potatoes were consumed on Sunday compared to Saturday? ![Chart of potatoes consumed with kilos against day of week]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 35 \mathrm{~kg} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads one point on a time series graph instead of all the values from a given time period</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}-16
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p-4)(p-4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Factorises difference of two squares with the same sign in both brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}-16
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p(p-16) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes only the first term needs to be divided when factorising an expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - c</Construct>

<Question>

\(
p^{2}-16
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Does not factorise</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise difference of two squares</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Grouped Data</Subject>
<Question>
The table below is a summary of the number of spots counted on \( 25 \) ladybirds. Calculate the mean number of spots per ladybird. ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
Number of spots\\ & Frequency 
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 6 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 7 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 8 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.96(2 d p) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mean is total frequency divided by sum of categories given</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Grouped Data</Subject>
<Question>
The table below is a summary of the number of spots counted on \( 25 \) ladybirds. Calculate the mean number of spots per ladybird. ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
Number of spots\\ & Frequency 
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 6 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 7 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 8 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40.25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes mean is total divided by number of groups</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Grouped Data</Subject>
<Question>
The table below is a summary of the number of spots counted on \( 25 \) ladybirds. Calculate the mean number of spots per ladybird. ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
Number of spots\\ & Frequency 
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 6 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 7 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 8 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.16 \) (2dp)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mean is total frequency divided by something</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out mental divisions when the answer leaves a remainder</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Sarah has some apples.
She shares them into \( 6 \) equal groups and there is one left over.
How many apples could she have?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 35 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the remainder is the difference between the dividend and the next biggest multiple</Misconception>

<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>

<Answer>\( -46 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting past zero, adds the absolute values and then writes the answer with a negative sign</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the nth term rule for descending integer linear sequences to find another term in a the sequence</Construct>

<Question>
What is the \( 15 \) th term of this sequence? \( u_{n}=1-3 n \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve coordinate geometry questions involving ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
![A straight line on squared paper. Points P, Q and R lie on this line. The leftmost end of the line is labelled P. If you travel right 4 squares and up 1 square you get to point Q. If you then travel 8 squares right and 2 squares up from Q you reach point R.]() What is the ratio of \( P Q: P R \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1: 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks ratios are written as 1:total</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve coordinate geometry questions involving ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
![A straight line on squared paper. Points P, Q and R lie on this line. The leftmost end of the line is labelled P. If you travel right 4 squares and up 1 square you get to point Q. If you then travel 8 squares right and 2 squares up from Q you reach point R.]() What is the ratio of \( P Q: P R \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1: 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>May have estimated when using ratios with geometry</Misconception>

\[
\text { 2426. } 951
\]

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2426.0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When rounding up from a 9, does not add one on to the digit to the left</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to one decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>

\[
\text { 2426. } 951
\]
What is this number rounded to \( 1 \) decimal place?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2426.9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to one decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
\[
\text { 2426. } 951
\]
What is this number rounded to \( 1 \) decimal place?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 36 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the index</Misconception>

\]

1,4,7,9,9

1,4,7,9,9
\]

<Misconception>When calculating the mean from a list of data, adds up the numbers but does not divide</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(
\frac{t-3}{2}=\frac{1}{8}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( t=6 \frac{1}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds or subtracts from numerator first when solving an equation with a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(
\frac{t-3}{2}=\frac{1}{8}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( t=1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding an integer to a fraction, thinks you add the integer to the numerator</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(
\frac{t-3}{2}=\frac{1}{8}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( t=3 \frac{1}{16} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Rearrange the following equation to make \( r \) the subject
\(g=2 r+3\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( r=\frac{g+3}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the inverse operations of addition and subtraction when rearranging equations</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Rearrange the following equation to make \( r \) the subject
\(g=2 r+3\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( r=g+3 \div 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misunderstands order of operations in algebraic expressions</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from km² to m²</Construct>
<Subject>Area Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 2 \mathrm{~km}^{2} \) is the same as _____ \( m^{2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2000000000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you cube the conversion factor when dealing with squared units</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify rational and irrational numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Recurring Decimals to Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these two numbers are rational?

\( \sqrt{36} \) and \( \sqrt{12} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a surd is a rational number if the number under the root is a square number</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify rational and irrational numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Recurring Decimals to Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these two numbers are rational?

\( \sqrt{36} \) and \( \sqrt{12} \)
</Question>
<Answer>Neither</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a surd is a rational number if the number under the root is a square number</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify rational and irrational numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Recurring Decimals to Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these two numbers are rational?

\( \sqrt{36} \) and \( \sqrt{12} \)
</Question>
<Answer>Both</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the definition of a rational number when it is a surd</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the circle when this expression is fully factorised? \( 3 a^{2}+2 a \equiv \bigstar(\triangle a+\bigcirc) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \bigcirc=2 a \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes only the first term needs to be divided when factorising an expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a linear graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
Use a graphing program (e.g. Desmos) to plot the following pairs of functions.
\[
y=3 \text { and } y=-2
\]

Tom says both functions are linear

Katie says both functions are vertical lines

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the equations of vertical and horizontal lines</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a linear graph from its shape</Construct>

\[
y=3 \text { and } y=-2
\]

Tom says both functions are linear

Katie says both functions are vertical lines

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the properties of a linear graph</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>Isosceles</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not link Pythagoras Theorem to finding distance between two points</Misconception>

How do you write this number in words?
\(
204050
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Two million and four thousand and fifty</Answer>

<Construct>Write 5 digit numbers and above as words</Construct>

<Question>
How do you write this number in words?
\(
204050
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Two hundred and four and fifty</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a space can be used to separate the thousands column from the hundreds column</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 1600 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying, treats digits in other columns as if they are units</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the relationship between different factors of a number</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>Equilateral triangle</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not use the associative property of multiplication to find other factors of a number</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the relationship between different factors of a number</Construct>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving non-linear variables</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
\(
x(3 x-5)+6(2 x-3) \equiv P x^{2}+Q x+R
\)

What is the value of \( R \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -23 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can add or subtract from inside brackets without expanding when solving an equation</Misconception>

x(3 x-5)+6(2 x-3) \equiv P x^{2}+Q x+R
\)

</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Use direct proportion to solve non-unitary missing amounts in problems (e.g. recipes)</Construct>
<Subject>Direct Proportion</Subject>
<Question>
Twelve rulers cost \( 96 p \).
How much do five rulers cost?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 89 p \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts rather than divides when scaling down in direct proportion problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Use direct proportion to solve non-unitary missing amounts in problems (e.g. recipes)</Construct>
<Subject>Direct Proportion</Subject>
<Question>
Twelve rulers cost \( 96 p \).
How much do five rulers cost?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 p \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds unit price but doesn't multiply up for number in question</Misconception>

<Construct>Use direct proportion to solve non-unitary missing amounts in problems (e.g. recipes)</Construct>
<Subject>Direct Proportion</Subject>
<Question>
Twelve rulers cost \( 96 p \).
How much do five rulers cost?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 4.80 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies up without finding unit price in proportion question</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from minutes to seconds</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
Order the times from shortest to longest.
A:  8 minutes
B:  8 minutes 40 seconds
C:  8 \(
\frac{1}{2}
\) minutes
D:  500 seconds 
</Question>
<Answer>\( B, D, C, A \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up shortest and longest when ordering times</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to one significant figure</Construct>

<Question>
Round this number to \( 1 \) significant figure:
\( 0.8532 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
Round this number to \( 1 \) significant figure:
\( 0.8532 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems involving converting between fractions, decimals and percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.6=\frac{3}{5}=? \% \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 35 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a percentage by writing the numerator followed by the denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems involving converting between fractions, decimals and percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.6=\frac{3}{5}=? \% \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a decimal with one significant figure is a multiple of 10 when converted to a percentage, regardless of place value</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent a linear inequality in the form x ≤ a or x ≥ b (and other sign arrangements) on a numberline</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following diagrams represents \( x<-1 \) or \( x \geq 2 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![Number line from -5 to 5. Closed circle at -1 with arrow to the left. Open circle at 2 with arrow to the right. ]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When representing an inequality on a numberline, assumes the filled and unfilled circles have the opposite meaning.</Misconception>

<Question>
What is the reciprocal of \( -\frac{1}{3} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -0.333 \ldots \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has an incorrect assumption about the definition of a reciprocal</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the reciprocal of a fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
What is the reciprocal of \( -\frac{1}{3} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Correctly finds the reciprocal of a number, but believes it should be opposite in sign to the original number.</Misconception>

<Question>
What is the reciprocal of \( -\frac{1}{3} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Makes the number negative when asked to find the reciprocal</Misconception>

\(
a+6+a+j+5+j+j
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6+5+2 a+3 j \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand when like terms can be collected</Misconception>

<Construct>Read an integer on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>

<Question>
What is the value of B? ![A vertical number-line with 7 horizontal, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "-8" next to the bottom dash and "4" next to the top dash are the only numbers marked on the line. An arrow, labelled "B" is pointing at the dash that is 2 below the "4" label and 4 above the "-8" label. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading integers on a number line, assumes each dash is 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify parallel lines written in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about parallel lines.

Tom says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2 x}+\mathbf{3} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{3 x}+\mathbf{2} \) are parallel. 

Katie says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2 x}+\mathbf{3} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2 x}-\mathbf{3} \) are parallel.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes switching the gradient and y-intercept gives a parallel line</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify parallel lines written in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about parallel lines.

Tom says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2 x}+\mathbf{3} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{3 x}+\mathbf{2} \) are parallel. 

Katie says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2 x}+\mathbf{3} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2 x}-\mathbf{3} \) are parallel.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes switching the gradient and y-intercept gives a parallel line</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring multiplication or division, involving positive decimals</Construct>

<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(
0.15=0.5 p
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p=-0.35 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, subtracts instead of dividing</Misconception>
