<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(
0.15=0.5 p
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p=\frac{10}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate non linear real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Indirect (Inverse) Proportion</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following graphs is most likely to represent the change in journey time against average speed?
</Question>
<Answer>![A straight line graph starting at the origin and travelling right with a positive gradient.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the faster you travel the longer the time it will take</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate non linear real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Indirect (Inverse) Proportion</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following graphs is most likely to represent the change in journey time against average speed?
</Question>
<Answer>![A curved graph that starts at the origin. As you move right it travels steeply up, then levels off]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the faster you travel the longer the time it will take</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate non linear real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Indirect (Inverse) Proportion</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following graphs is most likely to represent the change in journey time against average speed?
</Question>
<Answer>![A straight line graph starting partway up the y-axis and travelling right with a negative gradient until it hits the x-axis.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a reciprocal graph can be a straight line</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the mode from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the number of pets a group of students owns.

What is the modal number of pets owned? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Number of pets & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the median instead of the mode</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the mode from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the number of pets a group of students owns.

What is the modal number of pets owned? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Number of pets & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mode is the frequency rather than the value/group</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the mode from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the number of pets a group of students owns.

What is the modal number of pets owned? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Number of pets & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes when identifying the mode you look at all values, not just frequencies, for the highest number</Misconception>

<Construct>Enlarge a shape, with a centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1, where the centre of enlargement lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Enlargement</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is enlarged by scale factor \( 3 \), with the centre of enlargement at \( (1,0) \).
What are the new coordinates of the point marked \( T \) ? ![A coordinate grid with the x-axis going from -1 to 10 and the y-axis going from -1 to 7.
3 points are plotted and joined with straight lines to form a triangle. The points are (1,1), (1,4) and (3,1). Point (3,1) is labelled as T.
Point (1,0) is also plotted.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (6,4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Added rather than multiplied by a scale factor</Misconception>

<Construct>Enlarge a shape, with a centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1, where the centre of enlargement lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Enlargement</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is enlarged by scale factor \( 3 \), with the centre of enlargement at \( (1,0) \).
What are the new coordinates of the point marked \( T \) ? ![A coordinate grid with the x-axis going from -1 to 10 and the y-axis going from -1 to 7.
3 points are plotted and joined with straight lines to form a triangle. The points are (1,1), (1,4) and (3,1). Point (3,1) is labelled as T.
Point (1,0) is also plotted.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (9,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Enlarges by the wrong centre of enlargement</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the range of this set of data?
\[
5 \mathrm{~cm}, 19 \mathrm{~cm}, 6 \mathrm{~cm}, 2 \mathrm{~cm}
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 19 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies the biggest value for the range</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the range of this set of data?
\[
5 \mathrm{~cm}, 19 \mathrm{~cm}, 6 \mathrm{~cm}, 2 \mathrm{~cm}
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the range is just the first value subtracted from the last value, without ordering</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the range of this set of data?
\[
5 \mathrm{~cm}, 19 \mathrm{~cm}, 6 \mathrm{~cm}, 2 \mathrm{~cm}
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 21 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>To find the range adds the biggest and smallest number rather than subtract</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the solution to a graphical inequality involving a single diagonal line</Construct>
<Subject>Graphing Linear Inequalities (Shading Regions)</Subject>
<Question>
Which inequality is represented by the shaded region? ![Graph showing four quadrants with a straight line going from the top left to the bottom right. The line goes through (-4, 4) (-3, 3) (-2, 2) and so on]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y>x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the lines y=x and y=-x</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the solution to a graphical inequality involving a single diagonal line</Construct>
<Subject>Graphing Linear Inequalities (Shading Regions)</Subject>
<Question>
Which inequality is represented by the shaded region? ![Graph showing four quadrants with a straight line going from the top left to the bottom right. The line goes through (-4, 4) (-3, 3) (-2, 2) and so on]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y<-x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Use brackets to write function machines as calculations</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Here is a function machine
\( input\Rightarrow +2 \Rightarrow \times 3 \Rightarrow output\)
The input is \( 5 \).
Which calculation gives the correct output?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \times 3+2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>Use brackets to write function machines as calculations</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Here is a function machine
\( input\Rightarrow +2 \Rightarrow \times 3 \Rightarrow output\)
The input is \( 5 \).
Which calculation gives the correct output?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5(3+2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In a function machine, confuses an operation with the input</Misconception>

<Construct>Use brackets to write function machines as calculations</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Here is a function machine
\( input\Rightarrow +2 \Rightarrow \times 3 \Rightarrow output\)
The input is \( 5 \).
Which calculation gives the correct output?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5+2 \times 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes order of operations does not affect the answer to a calculation</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a square, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>
<Subject>Square Roots, Cube Roots, etc</Subject>
<Question>
A square has an area \( 64 \mathrm{~mm}^{2} \)

What is the length of one side of the square?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16 \mathrm{~mm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Calculates perimeter when asked for area</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a square, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>
<Subject>Square Roots, Cube Roots, etc</Subject>
<Question>
A square has an area \( 64 \mathrm{~mm}^{2} \)

What is the length of one side of the square?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 32 \mathrm{~mm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds when calculating area instead of multiplying</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out the whole</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
The ratio of cars to bikes in a housing estate is \( 5: 2 \)
If there are \( \mathbf{7 0} \) cars, how many vehicles (cars and bikes) are there in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 72 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the number in the ratio is the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a linear graph solve f(x) = n</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
This is the graph of
\[
y=0.5 x-2
\]

According to the graph, what is the solution to:
\[
0.5 x-2=1
\] ![Graph showing straight line with y intercept (0,-2) and x intercept (4,0)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=-1.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks they solve mx + c = a, by substituting in the value of a for x and therefore calculating ma + c</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a linear graph solve f(x) = n</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
This is the graph of
\[
y=0.5 x-2
\]

According to the graph, what is the solution to:
\[
0.5 x-2=1
\] ![Graph showing straight line with y intercept (0,-2) and x intercept (4,0)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solution to mx + c = a is the x intercept of y = mx +c</Misconception>

<Construct>Use inequality notation to order a negative and a positive integer</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
One of these pairs of numbers does not fit 
the inequality \( d \leq h \)

Can you find which pair?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}d=4 \\ h=4\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand inequality notation</Misconception>

<Construct>Use inequality notation to order a negative and a positive integer</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
One of these pairs of numbers does not fit 
the inequality \( d \leq h \)

Can you find which pair?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}d=-4\\h=4\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand inequality notation</Misconception>

<Construct>Use inequality notation to order a negative and a positive integer</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
One of these pairs of numbers does not fit 
the inequality \( d \leq h \)

Can you find which pair?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}d=-2 \\ h=2\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand inequality notation</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a midpoint and a coordinate work out the position of the other coordinate, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about midpoints.
\( M \) is the midpoint between points \( P \) and \( Q \).

Tom says if you know the location of \( M \) only, then there is more than one possible location for \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \).

Katie says if you only know the locations of \( M \) and \( Q \), then there is more than one possible location for \( \mathrm{P} \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes there is more than one line which passes through a given pair of points</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a midpoint and a coordinate work out the position of the other coordinate, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about midpoints.
\( M \) is the midpoint between points \( P \) and \( Q \).

Tom says if you know the location of \( M \) only, then there is more than one possible location for \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{Q} \).

Katie says if you only know the locations of \( M \) and \( Q \), then there is more than one possible location for \( \mathrm{P} \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that one point is enough to specify a line</Misconception>

<Construct>Continue linear sequences expressed as patterns by drawing the next pattern</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
How many squares will the next term in this sequence have? ![A diagram showing the first 3 patterns in a sequence. 
Pattern 1 contains 3 squares in this arrangement :.  
Pattern 2 contains 5 squares in this arrangement ::.
Pattern 3 contains 7 squares in this arrangement :::.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for the next term in the sequence adds one to the last term given, despite the sequence not going up in ones.</Misconception>

Pattern 1 contains 3 squares in this arrangement :.  
Pattern 2 contains 5 squares in this arrangement ::.
Pattern 3 contains 7 squares in this arrangement :::.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not notice all changes in a sequence of visual patterns</Misconception>

<Construct>Express one quantity as a percentage of another mentally</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 50 \mathrm{~m} \) as a percentage of \( 5 \mathrm{~km} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 100 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has found the total as a percentage of the amount being asked</Misconception>

<Construct>Express one quantity as a percentage of another mentally</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 50 \mathrm{~m} \) as a percentage of \( 5 \mathrm{~km} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you need to just add a % sign to a number to make it a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Express one quantity as a percentage of another mentally</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 50 \mathrm{~m} \) as a percentage of \( 5 \mathrm{~km} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 100m and a km</Misconception>

<Construct>Sketch, or identify a sketch, of a line given in the form y = mx + c, where m is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Equation of a Line</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following sketches could represent \( y=4-2 x \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A straight line graph that crosses the x axis to the left of the origin and crosses the y axis below the origin.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that in y=mx+c, m is the y-intercept</Misconception>

<Construct>Sketch, or identify a sketch, of a line given in the form y = mx + c, where m is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Equation of a Line</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following sketches could represent \( y=4-2 x \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A straight line graph that crosses the x axis to the left of the origin and crosses the y axis above the origin.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that in y = mx+c, c is the gradient</Misconception>

<Construct>Sketch, or identify a sketch, of a line given in the form y = mx + c, where m is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Equation of a Line</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following sketches could represent \( y=4-2 x \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A straight line graph that crosses the x axis to the right of the origin and crosses the y axis below the origin.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that in y = mx+c, c is the gradient</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing factors

Tom says \( 3 \) is a common factor of \( 6 x \) and \( 9 y \)

Katie says \( x \) is a common factor of \( 6 x \) and \( 9 y \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to identify common factors from algebraic terms</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing factors

Tom says \( 3 \) is a common factor of \( 6 x \) and \( 9 y \)

Katie says \( x \) is a common factor of \( 6 x \) and \( 9 y \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to identify common factors from algebraic terms</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing factors

Tom says \( 3 \) is a common factor of \( 6 x \) and \( 9 y \)

Katie says \( x \) is a common factor of \( 6 x \) and \( 9 y \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to identify common factors from algebraic terms</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention?
\(
2 \div(3+a \times b)
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{3}+a b \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention?
\(
2 \div(3+a \times b)
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{b(a+3)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention?
\(
2 \div(3+a \times b)
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{a \times b+3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can omit the multiplication symbol in algebraic expressions</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
When finding the range of a data set, which step is never needed
</Question>
<Answer>Check the units of your answer</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes range does not need units</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
When finding the range of a data set, which step is never needed
</Question>
<Answer>Write the numbers in ascending or descending order.</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating the range does not reorder the data to find the largest number minus the smallest number</Misconception>

<Construct>Assign probabilities to single events using fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
A box contains \( 10 \) coloured counters.

\( 3 \) of the counters are pink

\( 3 \) of the counters are blue

The rest of the counters are green

What is the probability of choosing a green counter?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets the denominator in probability</Misconception>

<Construct>Assign probabilities to single events using fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
A box contains \( 10 \) coloured counters.

\( 3 \) of the counters are pink

\( 3 \) of the counters are blue

The rest of the counters are green

What is the probability of choosing a green counter?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that probabilities of an event occurring or not occurring must be equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the volume of a cuboid when the dimensions are given in different units</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give the volume of this cuboid? ![A cuboid with dimensions 60mm, 7cm and 5cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \times 5 \times 60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not convert measurements to have the same units before calculating area or volume</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the volume of a cuboid when the dimensions are given in different units</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give the volume of this cuboid? ![A cuboid with dimensions 60mm, 7cm and 5cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7+5+6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds when calculating volume instead of multiplying</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the circle when these two brackets are
expanded and simplified?

\(
(p-3)(p+3) \equiv p^{2} \color{purple}\triangle\) \(p\)\(\color{green}\bigcirc
\)

</Question>
<Answer>\(\color{green}\bigcirc\) = +0 
(no number term)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the constant in an expanded quadratic comes from adding the two numbers in the brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the circle when these two brackets are
expanded and simplified?

\(
(p-3)(p+3) \equiv p^{2} \color{purple}\triangle\) \(p\)\(\color{green}\bigcirc
\)

</Question>
<Answer>\(\color{green}\bigcirc\) = +9</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Add column vectors each containing two elements</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
\( \left(\begin{array}{l}2 \\ 3\end{array}\right)+\left(\begin{array}{c}-1 \\ 0\end{array}\right)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \left(\begin{array}{c}-2 \\ 0\end{array}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding column vectors, multiplies rather than adds</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Only recognises the positive form of a quadratic graph</Misconception>

</Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when calculating the area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply amounts of money up to £10</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Money</Subject>
<Question>
Alicia wants to buy some bottles of water.
Each bottle of water costs \( £ 1.65 \)
Alicia has \( £ 10 \) to spend.
What is the greatest number of bottles can she buy?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can go above an amount of money when finding how much of something you can buy</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities in one variable where the unknown appears on boths sides of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve
\[
3 n+2 \geq 4 n-5
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \geq n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities in one variable where the unknown appears on boths sides of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve
\[
3 n+2 \geq 4 n-5
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \geq n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities in one variable where the unknown appears on boths sides of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve
\[
3 n+2 \geq 4 n-5
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( n \geq 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they can multiply/divide through by a negative number without changing the direction of the inequality</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute into simple formulae given in words</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
A theme park charges \( £ 8 \) entry fee and then \( £ 3 \) for every ride you go on.
Heena goes on \( 5 \) rides.
How much does she pay in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 55 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Combines variables with constants when writing a formula from a given situation</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute into simple formulae given in words</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
A theme park charges \( £ 8 \) entry fee and then \( £ 3 \) for every ride you go on.
Heena goes on \( 5 \) rides.
How much does she pay in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not add on the constant in a worded substitution problem</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute into simple formulae given in words</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
A theme park charges \( £ 8 \) entry fee and then \( £ 3 \) for every ride you go on.
Heena goes on \( 5 \) rides.
How much does she pay in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not consider the variable when evaluating an expression that requires substitution.</Misconception>

<Construct>Increase a number by a given percentage mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>

<Question>
Increase \( 160 \) by \( 30 \% \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 190 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Added the values together instead of finding the percentage</Misconception>

<Subject>Percentage Increase and Decrease</Subject>
<Question>
Increase \( 160 \) by \( 30 \% \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 48 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Found the percentage but forgot to add to 100%</Misconception>

<Question>
Increase \( 160 \) by \( 30 \% \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4800 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks when finding a percentage you multiply by the percentage being asked</Misconception>

<Construct>Continue a sequence involving triangle numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Here are two consecutive triangle numbers: \( 153,171, \ldots \) What is the next triangle number in the sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 188 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the difference between triangle numbers decreases by 1 each time</Misconception>

<Construct>Continue a sequence involving triangle numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Here are two consecutive triangle numbers: \( 153,171, \ldots \) What is the next triangle number in the sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 189 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the difference between triangle numbers remains the same</Misconception>

<Construct>Continue a sequence involving triangle numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Here are two consecutive triangle numbers: \( 153,171, \ldots \) What is the next triangle number in the sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 324 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes to find the next traingle number you add the previous two numbers together i.e. Fibonacci</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems that combine addition and subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Written Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
At the start of the day, there was \( £ 1,456 \) in the till. \( £ 7,347 \) was taken and \( £ 4,377 \) was handed out. How much money was left?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 13,180 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes they add all values in a worded problem, thereby not interpreting the problem correctly</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems that combine addition and subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Written Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
At the start of the day, there was \( £ 1,456 \) in the till. \( £ 7,347 \) was taken and \( £ 4,377 \) was handed out. How much money was left?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 2,970 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In a worded problem, does not complete all calculations</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems that combine addition and subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Written Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
At the start of the day, there was \( £ 1,456 \) in the till. \( £ 7,347 \) was taken and \( £ 4,377 \) was handed out. How much money was left?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 10,268 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When talking about money "taken" in a retail context, thinks that means take-away rather than add</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a quadratic graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Graphs-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is an example of a quadratic graph?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph showing a straight line from top left to bottom right.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise a quadratic graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a quadratic graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Graphs-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is an example of a quadratic graph?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph showing a curve that starts in the bottom left, moves steeply up and right, levels off briefly, then continues steeply up and right.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses cubic and quadratic graphs</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a quadratic graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Graphs-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is an example of a quadratic graph?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph with two curves. One curve is in the positive x, positive y quadrant. It starts at the top close to the y axis, as we move right it drops very quickly towards the x axis then levels off to travel almost parallel to the x axis.
The other curve is in the negative x, negative y quadrant. It starts at the top left close to the x axis, as we move right it drops very quickly towards the y axis then becomes almost vertical to travel almost parallel to the y axis. ]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses reciprocal and quadratic graphs</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing this pair of simultaneous equations: \( \begin{array}{l}3 x-2 y=8 \\ 3 x+y=14\end{array} \) Tom says if you add the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Katie says if you subtract the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we add the equations.</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing this pair of simultaneous equations: \( \begin{array}{l}3 x-2 y=8 \\ 3 x+y=14\end{array} \) Tom says if you add the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Katie says if you subtract the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations thinks that identical terms in given equations can be eliminated by either adding or subtracting.</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to two significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
\(
180.5672
\)

What is the second significant figure in the number above?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the first significant value is the first non-zero digit number</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to two significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
\(
180.5672
\)

What is the second significant figure in the number above?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the first significant value is the first non-zero digit number</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to two significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
\(
180.5672
\)

What is the second significant figure in the number above?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies second decimal place value when asked for the second significant figure</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q \)s in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations?
\begin{array}{cc}
  Pair 1 & Pair 2 \\
\( 2p-4q=6 \) & \( 2p-4q=6 \)\\
\( 7p+4q=9 \) & \( 7p-4q=9 \)
\end{array}

</Question>
<Answer>Add Pair \( 1 \)
Add Pair \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we add the equations.</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q \)s in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations?
\begin{array}{cc}
  Pair 1 & Pair 2 \\
\( 2p-4q=6 \) & \( 2p-4q=6 \)\\
\( 7p+4q=9 \) & \( 7p-4q=9 \)
\end{array}

</Question>
<Answer>Subtract Pair \( 1 \)
Subtract Pair \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when eliminating a variable, regardless of the signs of the terms with matching coefficients, we subtract the equations</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that the factorised form of a quadratic is useful for finding where the curve crosses the x-axis</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
\( y=(x-3)(x-5) \) Where does this curve intercept the \( x \) axis?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes both the x and y co-ordinates of the x-intercept of a quadratic are derived from the constants in the factorised form.</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that the factorised form of a quadratic is useful for finding where the curve crosses the x-axis</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
\( y=(x-3)(x-5) \) Where does this curve intercept the \( x \) axis?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}(-3,0) \\ \text { and } \\ (-5,0)\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solutions of a quadratic equation are the constants in the factorised form</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that the factorised form of a quadratic is useful for finding where the curve crosses the x-axis</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
\( y=(x-3)(x-5) \) Where does this curve intercept the \( x \) axis?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}(3,5) \\ \text { and } \\ (-3,-5)\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes both the x and y co-ordinates of the x-intercept of a quadratic are derived from the constants in the factorised form.</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles on a straight line</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( k \) ? ![Three angles which meet to form a straight line. They are labelled 46 degrees, 115 degrees and k.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 46^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses vertically opposite angles with angles on a straight line</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles on a straight line</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( k \) ? ![Three angles which meet to form a straight line. They are labelled 46 degrees, 115 degrees and k.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 65^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misinterprets the meaning of angles on a straight line angle fact</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles on a straight line</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( k \) ? ![Three angles which meet to form a straight line. They are labelled 46 degrees, 115 degrees and k.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that angles on a straight line sum to 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean as an average from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
When calculating the mean of the following numbers which calculation will give the correct answer?
\[
0,1,3,4,7
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0+1+3+4+7 \div 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean as an average from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
When calculating the mean of the following numbers which calculation will give the correct answer?
\[
0,1,3,4,7
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1+3+4+7}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for the mean of a list of data, does not count any zeros in the data when working out what to divide by</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean as an average from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
When calculating the mean of the following numbers which calculation will give the correct answer?
\[
0,1,3,4,7
\]
</Question>
<Answer>None of them</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to calculate the mean</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from improper fractions to mixed number fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Convert this into a mixed number fraction:
\(
\frac{13}{5}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \frac{3}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes when changing an improper fraction to a mixed number you divide the numerator by 10, regardless of the denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from improper fractions to mixed number fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Convert this into a mixed number fraction:
\(
\frac{13}{5}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \frac{2}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the whole and remainder are the other way when changing an improper fraction to a mixed number</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from improper fractions to mixed number fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Convert this into a mixed number fraction:
\(
\frac{13}{5}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 13 \frac{1}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the number of wholes in a mixed number multiplies by the fraction part</Misconception>

<Construct>Use area to write algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
The area of these shapes are equal. Which of these is correct? ![An image of two rectangles. The top one is blue and has the dimensions - side length: 4 and base 3x -2. The bottom one is yellow and has the dimensions - side length: 2 and base 5x + 2.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 x-2=10 x+2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Use area to write algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
The area of these shapes are equal. Which of these is correct? ![An image of two rectangles. The top one is blue and has the dimensions - side length: 4 and base 3x -2. The bottom one is yellow and has the dimensions - side length: 2 and base 5x + 2.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8+6 x-4=4+10 x+4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Calculates perimeter when asked for area</Misconception>

<Construct>Use area to write algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
The area of these shapes are equal. Which of these is correct? ![An image of two rectangles. The top one is blue and has the dimensions - side length: 4 and base 3x -2. The bottom one is yellow and has the dimensions - side length: 2 and base 5x + 2.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4+3 x-2=2+5 x+2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds when calculating area instead of multiplying</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing mental multiplication strategies.
Tom says \( 15 \times 42=154 \times 2 \)
Katie says \( 15 \times 42=(15 \times 4)+(15 \times 2) \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the commutative property of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing mental multiplication strategies.
Tom says \( 15 \times 42=154 \times 2 \)
Katie says \( 15 \times 42=(15 \times 4)+(15 \times 2) \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the distributive property of multiplication</Misconception>

\frac{2}{3}-\frac{1}{10}=\frac{\bigstar}{30}
\)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 19 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to change the numerators when finding equivalent fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>

\(
\frac{2}{3}-\frac{1}{10}=\frac{\bigstar}{30}
\)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand inequality notation</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following shows " \( x \) is greater than or equal to \( 6 \) "?
</Question>
<Answer>\( x>6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When using inequality notation, thinks "greater than/less than or equal to" symbols are instead the "greater than/less than" symbols and vice versa</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand inequality notation</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following shows " \( x \) is greater than or equal to \( 6 \) "?
</Question>
<Answer>\( x \leq 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the volume of a cone where the dimensions are all given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Non-Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 2 \)

Jessica is trying to work out the volume of this cone. ![A cone with the slant height labelled 9cm, the perpendicular height labelled h and half the cone's base (forming a right angled triangle with the slant and perpendicular heights) is labelled 6cm.]() First she needs the perpendicular height.

Which of the following equations is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( h^{2}=9^{2}+6^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not rearrange the Pythagoras' Theorem formula accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the volume of a cone where the dimensions are all given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Non-Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 2 \)

Jessica is trying to work out the volume of this cone. ![A cone with the slant height labelled 9cm, the perpendicular height labelled h and half the cone's base (forming a right angled triangle with the slant and perpendicular heights) is labelled 6cm.]() First she needs the perpendicular height.

Which of the following equations is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( h^{2}=12^{2}-9^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When using Pythagoras to find the height of an isosceles triangle, uses the whole base instead of half</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply mixed number fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
1 \frac{2}{3} \times 2
\)
Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \frac{2}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying mixed numbers, forgets to multiply the fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply mixed number fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
1 \frac{2}{3} \times 2
\)
Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \frac{4}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a fraction by an integer, multiplies both numerator and denominator by the integer</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 5^{7} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has added the powers rather than multiplying them</Misconception>

\( \left(5^{4}\right)^{3}= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 125^{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has cubed the base number and the power</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>None of these options</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand laws of indices</Misconception>

<Construct>Follow simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
If you translate the star \( 2 \) squares left and \( 3 \) squares down, which letter do you land on? ![A set of axes: x-axis from 0 to 8, y-axis from 0 to 8. A yellow star is at point (4, 4). Point A is at (6, 1), Point B is at (2, 1), Point C is at (2, 2), Point D is at (1, 2). ]()
</Question>
<Answer>A</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses left and right</Misconception>

<Construct>Follow simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
If you translate the star \( 2 \) squares left and \( 3 \) squares down, which letter do you land on? ![A set of axes: x-axis from 0 to 8, y-axis from 0 to 8. A yellow star is at point (4, 4). Point A is at (6, 1), Point B is at (2, 1), Point C is at (2, 2), Point D is at (1, 2). ]()
</Question>
<Answer>D</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts the squares rather than the diagonals when reflecting in y=x or y=-x </Misconception>

\(

\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{x<-4\} \cup\{x>4\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

\(
x^{2}<16
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{x<4\} \)</Answer>

\]</Answer>

\[

<Construct>Recognise the angles on a straight line relationship</Construct>

![Two angles meeting on a straight line, labelled a degrees and b degrees]() Which of the following is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( a+b=360^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes angles on a straight line add to 360 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the angles on a straight line relationship</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
![Two angles meeting on a straight line, labelled a degrees and b degrees]() Which of the following is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( a=b \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Student thinks that any two angles along a straight line are equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the angles on a straight line relationship</Construct>

![Two angles meeting on a straight line, labelled a degrees and b degrees]() Which of the following is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( a+b=90^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 180 degrees in a full turn</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the first \( 4 \) terms of a linear sequence. ![A sequence of 4 patterns, that are the first 4 terms of a sequence. The first  pattern is a rectangle, made of 3 squares stacked vertically. The second  pattern is an L shape made of 4 squares, it is the same as the first pattern but with 1 square stuck to the right of the square that is at the bottom of the rectangle. The 3rd pattern is an L shape made of 5 squares. It is the same as the 2nd pattern but with 1 more square added to the right of the squares at the bottom. The 4th pattern is an L shape made of 6 squares. It is the same as the 3rd pattern but with 1 more square added to the right of the squares at the bottom ]() How many squares would be in the \( 10^{\text {th }} \) term?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks terms in linear sequence are in direct proportion</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 50.09-0.1= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50.99 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When “borrowing” during a subtraction problem, does not subtract one from the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 50.09-0.1= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50.08 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting decimals with a different number of decimal places, lines up the digits incorrectly</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the regions on a double Venn diagram given in set notation</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
Which element(s) is/are in \( P^{\prime} \) ? ![A diagram showing a Venn diagram of 2 circles. The left circle is for Set P and contains crisps in its left part, sweets in the intersection. The right circle is for set Q and contains pizza in its right part, sweets in the intersection. Outside of the circles it says chocolate.]()
</Question>
<Answer>crisps</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand set notation for complement (eg. A')</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the regions on a double Venn diagram given in set notation</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
Which element(s) is/are in \( P^{\prime} \) ? ![A diagram showing a Venn diagram of 2 circles. The left circle is for Set P and contains crisps in its left part, sweets in the intersection. The right circle is for set Q and contains pizza in its right part, sweets in the intersection. Outside of the circles it says chocolate.]()
</Question>
<Answer>sweets, pizza & chocolate</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the complement of a set includes any elements which are also in another set.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve a linear equation using a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Look at the function machine. ![An image of two function machines. The first function machine has x as the input. The first function is divide by 3 and the second is +4. The output is 5. The second function machine is the reverse of the first so now 5 is the input but the two function boxes have been left blank.]() What would be the correct steps to solve this equation?
\(\frac{x}{3}+4=5\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}\times 3 \\ -4\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reverse the order of operations when finding the input of a function machine</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent a linear inequality in the form a ≤ x ≤ b (and other sign arrangements) on a numberline</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which number line represents \( -3<x \leq 1 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A number line with a hollow circle above -3 and an arrow coming out of it over the numbers -4, -5 etc and a filled in circle above 1 with an arrow coming out of it over the numbers 2, 3, 4, 5 etc.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent a linear inequality in the form a ≤ x ≤ b (and other sign arrangements) on a numberline</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which number line represents \( -3<x \leq 1 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A number line with a filled in circle above -3 connected to a hollow circle above 1.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When representing an inequality on a numberline, assumes the filled and unfilled circles have the opposite meaning.</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 270° and 360°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
Which diagram shows an angle of \( 325^{\circ} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out a reflex angle. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, clockwise around to the red line that is half way between 160 and 150 (inner scale) and halfway between 20 and 30 (outer scale).]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring obtuse angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 270° and 360°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
Which diagram shows an angle of \( 325^{\circ} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out a reflex angle. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, clockwise around to the red line that is half way between 30 and 20 (inner scale) and halfway between 150 and 160 (outer scale).]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Chooses the correct scale when measuring angles on a protractor but starts from the wrong number when the angle is in between two labelled dashes</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out the first stage in an iteration solution</Construct>
<Subject>Trial and Improvement and Iterative Methods</Subject>
<Question>
The area of the rectangle on the right is \( 8 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \).

To find the value of \( x \), Sally uses:
\(x_{n+1}=\frac{8}{9}-\frac{x_{n}{ }^{3}}{9}\)

If \( x_{0}=0 \), what does \( x_{1} \) equal? ![A rectangle with the base labelled x and the perpendicular height labelled x^2 + 9]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{7}{9} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the subscript in iteration notation is the value to be substituted</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the properties of a rhombus</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Quadrilaterals</Subject>
<Question>
\( A B C D \) is a rhombus.
Which lines must be perpendicular? ![Tilted rhombus with top left vertex labelled A, top right vertex labelled B, bottom left vertex labelled D and bottom right vertex labelled C.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( A B \) and \( B C \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes adjacent sides of a rhombus are always perpendicular</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the properties of a rhombus</Construct>

\( A B C D \) is a rhombus.

</Question>
<Answer>\( A B \) and \( D C \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the meaning of parallel and perpendicular</Misconception>

\( A B C D \) is a rhombus.

</Question>
<Answer>None of them</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the properties of a rhombus</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a line segment, calculate the gradient where the gradient is a positive integer</Construct>

<Question>
What is the gradient of this line? ![A set of axes with a graph drawn on. The graph passes through the following points: (-3,-3) (-2,-2) (-1,-1) (0,0) (1,1) (2,2) and (3,3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the gradient of a line is given by an intercept</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a line segment, calculate the gradient where the gradient is a positive integer</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the gradient of a line includes the variable x</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Rearrange the following equation to make \( \omega \) the subject \( F=r \omega^{2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \omega=r F^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Rearrange the following equation to make \( \omega \) the subject \( F=r \omega^{2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \omega=\sqrt{r F} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Rearrange the following equation to make \( \omega \) the subject \( F=r \omega^{2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \omega=\frac{\sqrt{F}}{r} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reverse the order of operations when solving an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide mixed number fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
2 \frac{2}{3} \div 2
\)
Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \frac{2}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When the dividend is a mixed number and the divisor is an integer, thinks they only perform the calculation with the integers.</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide mixed number fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
2 \frac{2}{3} \div 2
\)
Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When the dividend is a mixed number and the divisor is an integer, thinks they only divide the fraction by the integer.</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide mixed number fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
2 \frac{2}{3} \div 2
\)
Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of time</Construct>

<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing units of time

Katie says \( \mathrm{km} / \mathrm{h} \) is a unit of time 
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Mistakes unit of speed for unit of time</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of time</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing units of time 
Tom says days is a unit of time 
Katie says \( \mathrm{km} / \mathrm{h} \) is a unit of time 
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Mistakes unit of speed for unit of time</Misconception>

Who is correct?

<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>

<Construct>Substitute negative integer values into formulae involving powers or roots</Construct>

\(
F=3^{a}
\)

What is the value of \( F \) when \( a=-5 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -243 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a negative power results in a negative answer</Misconception>

<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>

F=3^{a}
\)

</Question>
<Answer>\( -\frac{1}{243} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a negative power results in a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute negative integer values into formulae involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\(
F=3^{a}
\)

</Question>
<Answer>\( -15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has multiplied the base number and the power</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 3 digit integers by 1 digit integers using long multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
Charlotte is trying to solve this problem using long multiplication.

What should replace the star as the tens digit in her final answer? \( 538 \times 7 \) \begin{tabular}{r|r|r|r|}
\(\space\) & \( 5 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\( \times \) & \(\space\) & \(\space\) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\bigstar\) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to carry the tens when doing column multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 3 digit integers by 1 digit integers using long multiplication</Construct>

\(\space\) & \( 5 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\( \times \) & \(\space\) & \(\space\) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\bigstar\) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Tries to multiply within place value columns during column multiplication</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2(-2)^{2}-1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent an equation using a bar model</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing bar models. Tom says this bar model represents \( 5 x \) \begin{tabular}{l|l}
\hline \( 5 \) & \( x \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Katie says this bar model represents \( 5 x \) \begin{tabular}{l|l|l|l|l|}
\( x \) & \( x \) & \( x \) & \( x \) & \( x \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand bar modelling in algebra</Misconception>

Tom</Answer>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + c</Construct>

\(
y=x^{2}-1
\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1 </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Mo wants to solve this equation using the quadratic formula.
\(
5 h^{2}-3 h-2=0
\)

What total should replace the square? \( \begin{array}{l} \frac{ ?\pm \sqrt{9-(-40)}}{?} \\ = \frac{ ?\pm \sqrt{\square}}{?} \end{array} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -49 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative number, adds the absolute values and then writes the answer with a negative sign</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1 </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Mo wants to solve this equation using the quadratic formula.
\(
5 h^{2}-3 h-2=0
\)

What total should replace the square? \( \begin{array}{l} \frac{ ?\pm \sqrt{9-(-40)}}{?} \\ = \frac{ ?\pm \sqrt{\square}}{?} \end{array} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -31 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative number, subtracts the absolute value rather than adding it</Misconception>

<Construct>Use common conventions for labelling the sides of shapes</Construct>

\] Who do you agree with?

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{llllll}
\( \frac{2}{10} \) & \( \frac{9}{50} \) & \( \frac{9}{20} \) & \( 0.21 \) & \( \frac{1}{5} \) & \( \frac{19}{100} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which value is the outlier in this set of data?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{10} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an outlier is a value that does not fit the same characteristics as the other values</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{llllll}
\( \frac{2}{10} \) & \( \frac{9}{50} \) & \( \frac{9}{20} \) & \( 0.21 \) & \( \frac{1}{5} \) & \( \frac{19}{100} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which value is the outlier in this set of data?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{19}{100} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an outlier is the value in a data set with the biggest denominator, even if this value is close to the mean</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.21 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an outlier is a value that does not fit the same characteristics as the other values</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles around a point</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( x \) ? ![Angles around a point, split into 2 parts. One is labelled 310 degrees and the other x.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 310^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Incorrectly identifies angles as vertically opposite</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles around a point</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( x \) ? ![Angles around a point, split into 2 parts. One is labelled 310 degrees and the other x.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 90^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that angles around a point sum to 360</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles around a point</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( x \) ? ![Angles around a point, split into 2 parts. One is labelled 310 degrees and the other x.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 45^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Estimates angle rather than calculating</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following as simply as possible:
\(
\frac{(x+3)(x+5)}{(x+3)(x+10)}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{x+1}{x+2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misunderstands the concept of common factors in algebra</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following as simply as possible:
\(
\frac{(x+3)(x+5)}{(x+3)(x+10)}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{x^{2}+8 x+15}{x^{2}+13 x+30} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Expands when asked to simplify</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give you the total surface area of this cuboid in \( \mathrm{cm}^{2} \) ? ![A cuboid. The height is 4cm, the depth is 3cm and the width is 6cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (6 \times 4)+(6 \times 3)+(4 \times 3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating surface area, only includes visible faces</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give you the total surface area of this cuboid in \( \mathrm{cm}^{2} \) ? ![A cuboid. The height is 4cm, the depth is 3cm and the width is 6cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \times 4 \times 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds volume when asked for surface area</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give you the total surface area of this cuboid in \( \mathrm{cm}^{2} \) ? ![A cuboid. The height is 4cm, the depth is 3cm and the width is 6cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (6 \times 4) \times(6 \times 3) \times(4 \times 3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating surface area, only includes visible faces</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
1+2 \times(3-4)=
\]

Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1+2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
1+2 \times(3-4)=
\]

Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \times 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
1+2 \times(3-4)=
\]

Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>It doesn't matter: you get the same answer</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes order of operations does not affect the answer to a calculation</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring multiplication or division, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(
5 p=\frac{1}{10}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p=\frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem P: \( 4-5+6= \)
Problem Q: \( 4+5 \times 6= \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem P: \( 4-5 \)
Problem Q: \( 4+5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem P: \( 4-5+6= \)
Problem Q: \( 4+5 \times 6= \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem P: \( 5+6 \)
Problem Q: \( 4+5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs addition ahead of any other operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem P: \( 4-5+6= \)
Problem Q: \( 4+5 \times 6= \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem P: \( 5+6 \)
Problem Q: \( 5 \times 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Eliza is trying to work out if \( 82 \) is a term in the sequence \( 3 n+1 \)

Below is her working out. What conclusion should Eliza draw?

 \( \begin{aligned} 3 n+1 & =82 \\ 3 n & =81 \\ n & =27\end{aligned} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 27 \) is in the sequence and is the \( 82^{\text {nd }} \) term</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up term in a sequence and position of a term</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Eliza is trying to work out if \( 82 \) is a term in the sequence \( 3 n+1 \)

Below is her working out. What conclusion should Eliza draw?

 \( \begin{aligned} 3 n+1 & =82 \\ 3 n & =81 \\ n & =27\end{aligned} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 82 \) is not in the sequence because \( 27 \) is an integer</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the position of a sequence cannot be an integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Eliza is trying to work out if \( 82 \) is a term in the sequence \( 3 n+1 \)

Below is her working out. What conclusion should Eliza draw?

 \( \begin{aligned} 3 n+1 & =82 \\ 3 n & =81 \\ n & =27\end{aligned} \)
</Question>
<Answer>Eliza's method does not answer this question</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to calculate the position of a term in a sequence</Misconception>

<Answer>\( t+2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Incorrectly cancels what they believe is a factor in algebraic fractions</Misconception>

<Answer>\( t^{2}+t \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Simplifies a fraction by adding or subtracting the same amount from the numerator  and denominator</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{4} \div \frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about the best way to count the number of squares in Pattern \( 15 \).
Jo does: \( 15 \times 3+4 \)
Paul does: \( (15+2) \times 3-4 \)
Who is correct? ![The 3rd and 4th terms in a sequence of patterns. Each pattern is made from red squares. Pattern 3 is 11 squares: they are arranged as a rectangle, 3 squares high and 3 squares wide and then 2 more squares, 1 each side of the middle squares (vertically). Pattern 4 is 14 squares arranged as a rectangle, 3 squares high and 4 squares wide and then 2 more squares, 1 each side of the middle squares.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes nth term rules for patterns must be given in standard an + b form</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes nth term rules for patterns must be given in standard an + b form</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>

\(
\frac{3}{x-2}-\frac{5}{x}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3-5}{x-2-x} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 1 \)
Which of the options is a correct first step to express the following as a single fraction?
\(
\frac{3}{x-2}-\frac{5}{x}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3(x-2)}{x(x-2)}-\frac{5 x}{x(x-2)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand how to maintain equivalence in fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>

<Question>
STEP \( 1 \)

\(
\frac{3}{x-2}-\frac{5}{x}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 x-5(x-2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Removes the common denominator when making equivalent algebraic fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+4)(x+9) \) \( (x+4)(x+9) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>

<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+7)(x+18) \) \( (x+7)(x+18) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that add to give the coefficient of x</Misconception>
