<Construct>Identify the number of degrees in fractions of a turn</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
How many degrees are there in \( 1 \frac{1}{4} \) full turns?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 385^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a 1/4 of a whole is 25</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the number of degrees in fractions of a turn</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
How many degrees are there in \( 1 \frac{1}{4} \) full turns?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 125^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes there are 100 degrees in a full turn</Misconception>

<Construct>Find a negative reciprocal</Construct>
<Subject>Perpendicular Lines</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{2}{5} \times \star=-1 \) What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -\frac{2}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Round non-integers to the nearest 10</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{9 9 9 . 9 9 9} \) rounded to the nearest ten?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 990 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Round non-integers to the nearest 10</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{9 9 9 . 9 9 9} \) rounded to the nearest ten?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When rounding up from a 9, does not add one on to the digit to the left</Misconception>

<Construct>Round non-integers to the nearest 10</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{9 9 9 . 9 9 9} \) rounded to the nearest ten?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 900 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Add proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{2}{9}+\frac{1}{3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Add proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{2}{9}+\frac{1}{3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{9} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not consider the denominator when adding/ subtracting fractions. Adds/subtracts the numerator and makes the denominator the one with the highest value.</Misconception>

<Construct>Add proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{2}{9}+\frac{1}{3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of adds</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer decimal problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the order of operations
Tom says: \( 0.1-0.2 \div 0.3 \equiv 0.1-(0.2 \div 0.3) \)
Katie says: \( 0.1-0.2 \div 0.3 \equiv 0.2 \div 0.3-0.1 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer decimal problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the order of operations
Tom says: \( 0.1-0.2 \div 0.3 \equiv 0.1-(0.2 \div 0.3) \)
Katie says: \( 0.1-0.2 \div 0.3 \equiv 0.2 \div 0.3-0.1 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs subtraction right to left if priority order means doing a calculation to the right first</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer decimal problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the order of operations
Tom says: \( 0.1-0.2 \div 0.3 \equiv 0.1-(0.2 \div 0.3) \)
Katie says: \( 0.1-0.2 \div 0.3 \equiv 0.2 \div 0.3-0.1 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract fractions involving mixed number fractions with different denominators</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
2 \frac{2}{5}-\frac{1}{15}=2 \frac{1}{\bigstar}
\)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract fractions involving mixed number fractions with different denominators</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
2 \frac{2}{5}-\frac{1}{15}=2 \frac{1}{\bigstar}
\)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgot to simplify the fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract fractions involving mixed number fractions with different denominators</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
2 \frac{2}{5}-\frac{1}{15}=2 \frac{1}{\bigstar}
\)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes when simplifying a fraction you can divide the numerator and denominator by different values</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a positive integer </Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{9}^{x} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgotten that anything to the power of 0 equals 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a positive integer </Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{9}^{x} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgotten that anything to the power of 0 equals 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a positive integer </Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{9}^{x} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>The equation is undefined at this value</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgotten that anything to the power of 0 equals 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{x}{3}-5=12
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{x}{3}=17 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( x-5=36 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{x}{3}-5=12
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{x}{3}=17 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( x-5=36 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{x}{3}-5=12
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{x}{3}=17 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( x-5=36 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

\( 0.26-0.6= \)

<Answer>\( 0.34 \)</Answer>

\( 0.26-0.6= \)

<Answer>\( -0.44 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you subtract the smaller digit from the larger digit in column subtraction, regardless of position</Misconception>

\( 0.26-0.6= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.2 \)</Answer>

c
D]()

<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by using the denominator after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are discussing mental addition and subtraction strategies.

Jo says a good way to add \( 19 \) is to add \( 10 \), then another \( 10 \) and then subtract \( 1 \).

Paul says a good way to subtract \( 19 \) is to subtract \( 10 \), then another \( 10 \) and then add \( 1 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the effect of consecutive operations</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are discussing mental addition and subtraction strategies.

Jo says a good way to add \( 19 \) is to add \( 10 \), then another \( 10 \) and then subtract \( 1 \).

Paul says a good way to subtract \( 19 \) is to subtract \( 10 \), then another \( 10 \) and then add \( 1 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the effect of consecutive operations</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving fractions of symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
![A pictogram where one smiley face =8 people. Game 1 has 4 faces. Game 2 has 3 faces. Game 3 has 2 faces. Game 4 has 2.75 faces.]() The pictogram shows the number of people who went to watch a netball match.
How many people went to game 4?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts partial symbols as if they were whole on pictograms</Misconception>

How many people went to game 4?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores partial symbols on pictograms</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving fractions of symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
![A pictogram where one smiley face =8 people. Game 1 has 4 faces. Game 2 has 3 faces. Game 3 has 2 faces. Game 4 has 2.75 faces.]() The pictogram shows the number of people who went to watch a netball match.
How many people went to game 4?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.75 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When interpreting a pictogram, thinks each symbol stands for 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems involving converting between fractions, decimals and percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about percentages.
Jo says \( 52 \%=0.052 \)
Paul says \( 52 \%<\frac{20}{41} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides by 1000 instead of 100 when converting a percentage to a decimal</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify equivalent fractions when presented as numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Equivalent Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Complete the statement \( \frac{4}{6}=\frac{}{12} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{6}=\frac{2}{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Can identify the multiplier used to form an equivalent fraction but does not apply to the numerator</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify equivalent fractions when presented as numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Equivalent Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Complete the statement \( \frac{4}{6}=\frac{}{12} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{6}=\frac{4}{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand equivalent fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify equivalent fractions when presented as numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Equivalent Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Complete the statement \( \frac{4}{6}=\frac{}{12} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{6}=\frac{10}{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes equivalent fractions are formed with addition not multiplication</Misconception>

<Answer>Variable</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a term with a variable</Misconception>

<Answer>Expression</Answer>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the \( y \)-axis
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -5 to 5, y-axis from -2 to 2. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, -2), (4, -2), (3, -1). Point (3, -1) is labelled with the letter "P". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (0,-1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the \( y \)-axis
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -5 to 5, y-axis from -2 to 2. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, -2), (4, -2), (3, -1). Point (3, -1) is labelled with the letter "P". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-2,-1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the \( y \)-axis
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -5 to 5, y-axis from -2 to 2. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, -2), (4, -2), (3, -1). Point (3, -1) is labelled with the letter "P". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,-1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
![A grid of 7 squares across and 7 squares up. A red vertical line goes from the bottom to the top of the grid, it is 4 squares left from the edge of the grid. An orange rectangle (3 squares width and 2 squares height) is drawn to the left of the red line, with its right-hand side on the red line.  The bottom side of the rectangle is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid. The top right corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter P, which is 5 squares up from the bottom of the grid on the red line. The bottom right corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter Q, which is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid on the red line. ]() Tom and Katie are discussing reflections

Tom says if you reflect the rectangle in the vertical line, Point \( P \) stays in the same position

Katie says if you reflect the rectangle in the vertical line, Point \( Q \) stays in the same position
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected </Misconception>

<Construct>Convert ratios to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Kate and Isaac share some yoghurt in the ratio \( 2: 5 \).
Kate has \(_____\) of the total yoghurt
What fraction completes the sentence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When converting ratio to fractions, puts the other side of the ratio as the denominator rather than the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive non-integer values into formulae involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate the displacement \( (s) \), of a particle when initial velocity \( (u)=2.9 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \), final velocity \( (v)=3.5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \), and the time \( (t) \) taken is \( 5.2 \) seconds. \( s=\frac{1}{2}(u+v) t \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}s=\frac{1}{2}(2.9+3.5)+5.2 \\ s=8.4\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks two variables next to each other represent addition</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive non-integer values into formulae involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate the displacement \( (s) \), of a particle when initial velocity \( (u)=2.9 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \), final velocity \( (v)=3.5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \), and the time \( (t) \) taken is \( 5.2 \) seconds. \( s=\frac{1}{2}(u+v) t \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}s=\frac{1}{2}(2.9+3.5+5.2) \\ s=5.8\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks two variables next to each other represent addition</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 100 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Know that the probabilities of exhaustive events must sum to 1</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of an event occurring is \( \frac{2}{7} \).

What is the probability of the event not occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{7} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that probabilities of an event occurring or not occurring must be equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that the probabilities of exhaustive events must sum to 1</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of an event occurring is \( \frac{2}{7} \).

What is the probability of the event not occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gives probability as an integer instead of a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
\( (16)^{2}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring with dividing by 2</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
\( (16)^{2}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 32 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\(y=x^{2}+4\) \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( -6 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes addition comes before indices, in orders of operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\(y=x^{2}+4\) \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( -6 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -32 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the square of a negative will also be negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a parallelogram where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts half-squares as full squares when calculating area on a square grid</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape</Construct>
<Subject>Rotational Symmetry</Subject>
<Question>
Which quadrilateral has the highest order of rotational symmetry?
</Question>
<Answer>They each have the same order of rotational symmetry</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the number of sides gives the order of rotational symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>Read an integer on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 154 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading integers on a number line, assumes each dash is 2</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the correct way of writing:

\( m \) multiplied by \( n \), then add \( 5 \)

using algebraic convention?
</Question>
<Answer>\( m(n+5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not account for grammar when writing algebra e.g. ,then making a group</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the correct way of writing:

\( m \) multiplied by \( n \), then add \( 5 \)

using algebraic convention?
</Question>
<Answer>\( m \times n+5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can omit the multiplication symbol in algebraic expressions</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a transversal</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Line \( X Y \) is... ![A pair of parallel lines are drawn with the arrows pointing up to the left.
A straight red line, XY, is drawn so that it diagonally crosses the pair of parallel lines. The red line rises from X on the left up to Y.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Perpendicular</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes any lines that cross are perpendicular</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a transversal</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Line \( X Y \) is... ![A pair of parallel lines are drawn with the arrows pointing up to the left.
A straight red line, XY, is drawn so that it diagonally crosses the pair of parallel lines. The red line rises from X on the left up to Y.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Skew</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the term transversal</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
If we want to write
"\( m \) multiplied by \( m \) multiplied by \( m \)"
using algebra, this would be:
</Question>
<Answer>\( m \times m \times m \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can omit the multiplication symbol in algebraic expressions</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
If we want to write
"\( m \) multiplied by \( m \) multiplied by \( m \)"
using algebra, this would be:
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 m \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the index</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
If we want to write
"\( m \) multiplied by \( m \) multiplied by \( m \)"
using algebra, this would be:
</Question>
<Answer>\( \mathrm{mmm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes repeated letters instead of using index form of a variable</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
2,2,4,7,10,-15
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you don't need to numerically order the data before calculating the median</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
2,2,4,7,10,-15
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the median from a even dataset does not understand we must find the midpoint of the two values in the middle</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
2,2,4,7,10,-15
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you don't need to numerically order the data before calculating the median</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems that combine addition and subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
![Think of a number, then subtract \( 5 \), next divide by \( 8 \), next add 4, and finally multiply by \( 7 \).]() Jo says you can write this as:
\[
7\left(\frac{(n-5)}{8}+4\right)
\]
Paul says you can write this as:
\[
7((n-5) \div 8)+4
\]
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
A line has equation \( 4 x+3 y=5 \)
What is it's gradient?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation forgets to eliminate the coefficient in front of the variable in the last step</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
A line has equation \( 4 x+3 y=5 \)
What is it's gradient?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that for a line written in the form ax + by = c, a is the gradient</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
A line has equation \( 4 x+3 y=5 \)
What is it's gradient?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

\(2(n+3)\)

\hline\( n \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand bar modelling in algebra</Misconception>

\(2(n+3)\)

\hline
\end{tabular}]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand bar modelling in algebra</Misconception>

<Construct>Create a situation to match an algebraic expression</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which model does not correctly represent the following expression?
\(2(n+3)\)

<Answer>![\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|}

\hline
\end{tabular}]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise the distributive property</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons</Construct>
<Subject>2D Names and Properties of Shapes-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing regular polygons. Tom says this is a regular polygon ![A triangle with 3 equal sides and 3 equal angles]() Katie says this is a regular polygon ![A parallelogram with 2 pairs of parallel sides marked]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the word regular </Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons</Construct>
<Subject>2D Names and Properties of Shapes-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing regular polygons. Tom says this is a regular polygon ![A triangle with 3 equal sides and 3 equal angles]() Katie says this is a regular polygon ![A parallelogram with 2 pairs of parallel sides marked]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the word regular </Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a trapezium where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
When calculating the area of this trapezium, what is the value of \( h \) in the formula? Area \( =\left(\frac{a+b}{2}\right) h \) ![Trapezium with the slanted sides labelled 8cm and 7.5cm. The parallel sides labelled 3cm and 8cm. The perpendicular height labelled 7cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses slant height instead of perpendicular height to find area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a trapezium where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
When calculating the area of this trapezium, what is the value of \( h \) in the formula? Area \( =\left(\frac{a+b}{2}\right) h \) ![Trapezium with the slanted sides labelled 8cm and 7.5cm. The parallel sides labelled 3cm and 8cm. The perpendicular height labelled 7cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses slant height instead of perpendicular height to find area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a trapezium where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
When calculating the area of this trapezium, what is the value of \( h \) in the formula? Area \( =\left(\frac{a+b}{2}\right) h \) ![Trapezium with the slanted sides labelled 8cm and 7.5cm. The parallel sides labelled 3cm and 8cm. The perpendicular height labelled 7cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses base instead of height as h in area of a trapezium formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
![A grid of 7 squares across and 7 squares up. A red vertical line goes from the bottom to the top of the grid, it is 4 squares left from the edge of the grid. An orange rectangle (3 squares width and 2 squares height) is drawn to the left of the red line, with its right-hand side on the red line.  The bottom side of the rectangle is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid. The bottom left corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter P, which is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid and 3 squares to the left of the red line. The bottom right corner of the rectangle is marked with the letter Q, which is 3 squares up from the bottom of the grid on the red line. ]() Tom and Katie are discussing reflections

Tom says if you reflect the rectangle in the vertical line, Point \( P \) stays in the same position

Katie says if you reflect the rectangle in the vertical line, Point \( Q \) stays in the same position
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate which two integer values the decimal equivalent of a square root must lie between</Construct>
<Subject>Square Roots, Cube Roots, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Without using a calculator, which two integers must \( \sqrt{89} \) lie between?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 44 \) and \( 45 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses square rooting and halving the number</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
\frac{m}{6}-4=24
\)
Jo says you can write: \( \frac{m}{6}=28 \)
Paul says you can write: \( m-4=144 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation with a fraction, thinks you don't need to multiply every term on both sides when multiplying by the denominator </Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
\frac{m}{6}-4=24
\)
Jo says you can write: \( \frac{m}{6}=28 \)
Paul says you can write: \( m-4=144 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to solve linear equations involving fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form y = mx + c </Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{l|l|l|l}
\( x \) & \( \) & \( 0 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( -7 \) & \( -5 \) &  \( \color{gold}\bigstar\ \) \\
\end{tabular}
 This is a table of values for \( y=2 x+c \)
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that a pair of coordinates can be used to find missing parts of an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
John rotates rectangle \( A B C D 90^{\circ} \) clockwise from the centre \( (3,2) \). What error has he made? ![A positive, coordinate grid with two rectangles drawn on it. The rectangle labelled ABCD has the coordinates: A(1,3) B(1,5) C(2,5) and D(2,3). The other rectangle has the coordinates: (4,3) (6,3) (6,2) and (4,2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>He has translated by the vector \( \left(\begin{array}{l}3 \\ 2\end{array}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a shape translated would not change orientation</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
John rotates rectangle \( A B C D 90^{\circ} \) clockwise from the centre \( (3,2) \). What error has he made? ![A positive, coordinate grid with two rectangles drawn on it. The rectangle labelled ABCD has the coordinates: A(1,3) B(1,5) C(2,5) and D(2,3). The other rectangle has the coordinates: (4,3) (6,3) (6,2) and (4,2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>He has rotated \( 90^{\circ} \) anticlockwise</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up clockwise and anticlockwise</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point P? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 5, y-axis from -3 to 4. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 2), (4, 2), (3, 3). Point (2, 2) is labelled with the letter "P". The line y=2 is shown with a purple dashed line.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected </Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point P? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 5, y-axis from -3 to 4. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 2), (4, 2), (3, 3). Point (2, 2) is labelled with the letter "P". The line y=2 is shown with a purple dashed line.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,0) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected </Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point P? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 5, y-axis from -3 to 4. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 2), (4, 2), (3, 3). Point (2, 2) is labelled with the letter "P". The line y=2 is shown with a purple dashed line.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,-2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected </Misconception>

<Construct>Identify corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which angle is corresponding to angle \( p \) ? ![Image showing two parallel lines cut by a transversal creating two distinct angles around a point. On the left hand side the pink angle is labelled with A, vertically opposite this is the angle labelled p. On the right hand side, angle B is co-interior to p. Then lying on the same straight line as B is the angle labelled C. Vertically opposite angle C is the angle labelled D.]()
</Question>
<Answer>A</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses corresponding and vertically opposite angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which angle is corresponding to angle \( p \) ? ![Image showing two parallel lines cut by a transversal creating two distinct angles around a point. On the left hand side the pink angle is labelled with A, vertically opposite this is the angle labelled p. On the right hand side, angle B is co-interior to p. Then lying on the same straight line as B is the angle labelled C. Vertically opposite angle C is the angle labelled D.]()
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses co-interior and corresponding angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which angle is corresponding to angle \( p \) ? ![Image showing two parallel lines cut by a transversal creating two distinct angles around a point. On the left hand side the pink angle is labelled with A, vertically opposite this is the angle labelled p. On the right hand side, angle B is co-interior to p. Then lying on the same straight line as B is the angle labelled C. Vertically opposite angle C is the angle labelled D.]()
</Question>
<Answer>D</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses corresponding and alternate angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
John rotates hexagon \( \mathrm{ABCDEF}  90^{\degree} \) clockwise from the centre \( (5,4) \). What error has he made? ![A positive, coordinate grid with two L-shaped hexagons drawn on it. The hexagon labelled ABCDEF has the coordinates: A(2,4) B(2,1) C(4,1) D(4,2) E(3,2) and F (3,4). The other hexagon has the coordinates: (6,7) (3,7) (3,5) (4,5) (4,6) and (6,6)]()
</Question>
<Answer>He has translated by the vector \( \left(\begin{array}{l}5 \\ 4\end{array}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mistakes rotations for translations</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
John rotates hexagon \( \mathrm{ABCDEF}  90^{\degree} \) clockwise from the centre \( (5,4) \). What error has he made? ![A positive, coordinate grid with two L-shaped hexagons drawn on it. The hexagon labelled ABCDEF has the coordinates: A(2,4) B(2,1) C(4,1) D(4,2) E(3,2) and F (3,4). The other hexagon has the coordinates: (6,7) (3,7) (3,5) (4,5) (4,6) and (6,6)]()
</Question>
<Answer>He has rotated \( 90^{\circ} \) anticlockwise</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up clockwise and anticlockwise</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve coordinate geometry questions involving ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Co-ordinate Geometry with Straight Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Given that \( A C=3 A B \), what are the coordinates of \( C \) ? ![A straight line labelled y=2x-1 is drawn on a set of axes. Points A, B and C are all on the line. Point A is (2,3) and B is (5,9).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (14,27) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a ratio is part to part instead of part to whole</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve coordinate geometry questions involving ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Co-ordinate Geometry with Straight Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Given that \( A C=3 A B \), what are the coordinates of \( C \) ? ![A straight line labelled y=2x-1 is drawn on a set of axes. Points A, B and C are all on the line. Point A is (2,3) and B is (5,9).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (21,36) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find the length of a line segment from coordinates</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand:
\[
6(2-3 p)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8-18 p \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand:
\[
6(2-3 p)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2-18 p \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies second term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand:
\[
6(2-3 p)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 18 p-6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Express one quantity as a percentage of another mentally</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 16 \) out of \( 25 \) as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you just add a % sign to the numerator to make a fraction into a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 1 decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the mode of the following numbers?
\(
0.4, \quad \frac{1}{4}, \quad 2.5, \quad \frac{2}{5}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.4 \) and \( 2.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a percentage by placing a decimal point between the numerator and denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Given an equation, form  or identify related equations</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are talking about statements that can be made about the equation on the right. \( 2 x=y \) Jo says this is always true: \( 2 x+1>y \) 
Paul says this is always true: \( -2 x<y \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes -a is always smaller than a, ignoring the possibility that a is negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal place to percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.01+57 \%= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 57.1 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by 10 instead of 100 when converting decimal to percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal place to percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.01+57 \%= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 67 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by 1000 instead of 100 when converting a decimal to a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
The formula for the area of a triangle, \( A \), is
\(A=\frac{1}{2}(b \times h)\)

Rearrange this to make the height, \( h \), the subject. ![An image of a triangle with the base labelled b and the perpendicular height h.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( h=\frac{1}{2}(b \times A) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
The formula for the area of a triangle, \( A \), is
\(A=\frac{1}{2}(b \times h)\)

Rearrange this to make the height, \( h \), the subject. ![An image of a triangle with the base labelled b and the perpendicular height h.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( h=\frac{A}{2 b} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is trying to solve the equation on the right.
Here are his steps.

Which steps, if any, are correct? ![\[
27=9(1+k)
\]

Step \( 1 \quad 3=1+k \)

Step \( 2 \)
\[
2=k
\]]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only step \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they must expand brackets before solving an equation</Misconception>

\(
\frac{h}{3}=
\)

<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Identify parallel lines with at least one equation written in another form</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following lines is not parallel to
\[
y=-2 x+7 \text { ? }
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 y=-6 x-8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the coefficient of x represents the gradient even when a line is not in the form y = mx+c</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify parallel lines with at least one equation written in another form</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following lines is not parallel to
\[
y=-2 x+7 \text { ? }
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=2-2 x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When given the equation of a straight line, believes the first term always gives the gradient, even when the first term is actually c</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify parallel lines with at least one equation written in another form</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following lines is not parallel to
\[
y=-2 x+7 \text { ? }
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=2(1-x) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the coefficient of x represents the gradient even when a line is not in the form y = mx+c</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( P \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gives the vertex instead of the 3-letter angle notation</Misconception>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( Q P \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses 2 letters to describe an angle</Misconception>

<Construct>Label angles using correct 3-letter notation (e.g. angle ADB)</Construct>

Which of the following is a correct way to describe the marked angle? ![Trapezium PQRS with angle QPS highlighted in red]()
</Question>
<Answer>QPRS</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses more than 3 letters to describe an angle</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible:
\(
\frac{1}{s+1}-\frac{t}{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1-t}{2(s+1)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand equivalent fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible:
\(
\frac{1}{s+1}-\frac{t}{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1-s t}{2(s+1)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible:
\(
\frac{1}{s+1}-\frac{t}{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1-t}{s-1} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Reduce a ratio involving two numbers to its simplest form</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following ratio in its simplest form so both sides of the ratio are integers:
\(
\frac{1}{8}: \frac{1}{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4: 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that the order is important in a ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Reduce a ratio involving two numbers to its simplest form</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following ratio in its simplest form so both sides of the ratio are integers:
\(
\frac{1}{8}: \frac{1}{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2: 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not fully simplify ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the lower bound of a number rounded to 2 decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
A number, \( n \), has been rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places to give \( \mathbf{3 . 7 2} \)
What is the smallest \( n \) can be?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the lower bound of a number rounded to 2 decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
A number, \( n \), has been rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places to give \( \mathbf{3 . 7 2} \)
What is the smallest \( n \) can be?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.71 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand which place value is the one that determines if a number rounds up or down</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the lower bound of a number rounded to 2 decimal places</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.719 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand which place value is the one that determines if a number rounds up or down</Misconception>

<Construct>Match linear sequences to other representations, such as tables and graphs</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
![The first three terms of a sequence represented using boxes. The first term is made of 3 boxes arranged with 2 on the base and one box above the furthers left box. The second term is the same pattern as the first but with two additional boxes added to the left hand side of the shape, one on top of the other. The third pattern is the second pattern with an additional two boxes added to the left hand side of the shape, one above the other again.]() \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|c|}
\hline Position & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline Term & \(  \) & \( \bigstar \) & \(  \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What value should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up term in a sequence and position of a term</Misconception>

<Construct>Match linear sequences to other representations, such as tables and graphs</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
![The first three terms of a sequence represented using boxes. The first term is made of 3 boxes arranged with 2 on the base and one box above the furthers left box. The second term is the same pattern as the first but with two additional boxes added to the left hand side of the shape, one on top of the other. The third pattern is the second pattern with an additional two boxes added to the left hand side of the shape, one above the other again.]() \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|c|}
\hline Position & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline Term & \(  \) & \( \bigstar \) & \(  \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What value should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the term in a sequence is double the position value</Misconception>

![The first three terms of a sequence represented using boxes. The first term is made of 3 boxes arranged with 2 on the base and one box above the furthers left box. The second term is the same pattern as the first but with two additional boxes added to the left hand side of the shape, one on top of the other. The third pattern is the second pattern with an additional two boxes added to the left hand side of the shape, one above the other again.]() \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|c|}

<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the term after</Misconception>

<Construct>Follow simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>A</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses left and right</Misconception>

<Construct>Follow simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
If you translate the star \( 3 \) squares left and \( 2 \) squares down, which letter do you land on? ![Positive coordinate grid from 0 to 8 in the x and y directions with a gold star at (4,4), A at (7,2), B at (2,1), C at (2,2) and D at (1,2)]()
</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares.</Misconception>

<Misconception>Does not know that angles on a straight line sum to 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the longer one</Construct>

<Question>
These two shapes are similar (not drawn to scale).
What should replace the star? ![Two scalene triangles. The smaller one has sides 5cm and 4cm. On the bigger triangle, the side corresponding to the 5cm is 15cm, and the side corresponding to the 4cm is marked with a star.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Doubles side length for similar shape instead of using correct scale factor</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 14 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks adding the same value to each side makes shapes similar</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out division  problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Arrow pointing to the left showing -18  and 3 arrows pointing to the left showing -18 in 3 equal parts]() Tom and Katie are trying to write different calculations for the diagram shown.
Tom writes: \( 3 \times(-6)=-18 \)
Katie writes: \( \frac{(-18)}{3}=-6 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes dividing a negative by a positive gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out division  problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Arrow pointing to the left showing -18  and 3 arrows pointing to the left showing -18 in 3 equal parts]() Tom and Katie are trying to write different calculations for the diagram shown.
Tom writes: \( 3 \times(-6)=-18 \)
Katie writes: \( \frac{(-18)}{3}=-6 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Add two equations together to remove a variable </Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Eliza is trying to solve the pair of simultaneous equations below.

\( \begin{aligned} -6 g-2 h & = & -2 \\ g-2h & = & 10 \\ \end{aligned} \)

She decides to add them together.
What will she end up with?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 g=8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we add the equations.</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 4^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misreads scale</Misconception>

<Construct>Count backwards through zero starting from a positive integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
John's flat is on floor \( 4 \).

The gym is on floor \( -1 \).

How many floors does John need to go down to get from his flat to the gym? ![A vertical number line from -8 to 7 increasing in 1 digit increments]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts the starting number when counting backwards</Misconception>

<Construct>Count backwards through zero starting from a positive integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
John's flat is on floor \( 4 \).

The gym is on floor \( -1 \).

How many floors does John need to go down to get from his flat to the gym? ![A vertical number line from -8 to 7 increasing in 1 digit increments]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not count end number when counting</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
When \( h=10 \)
Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 h^{2}=300 \)
\( (3 h)^{2}=300 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
When \( h=10 \)
Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}3 h^{2}=900 \\ (3 h)^{2}=900\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies before applying a power </Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to one decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
\( 58.2684 \) to \( 1 \) decimal place is....
</Question>
<Answer>\( 58.2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

\( 58.2684 \) to \( 1 \) decimal place is....
</Question>
<Answer>\( 59.3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds incorrectly by changing multiple place values</Misconception>

<Construct>Fill in regions of a double Venn diagram with numbers from given information</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
\( \begin{array}{c}\xi=\{\text { integers between } 1 \\ \text { and } 10 \text { inclusive }\} \\ P=\{\text { odd numbers }\} \\ Q=\{\text { factors of } 30\}\end{array} \) ![A Venn diagram with two circles labelled P and Q. P without the intersection is labelled A, Q without the intersection is labelled C, the intersection of the two sets is labelled B, and outside the circles is labelled D.]() In which region does \( \mathbf{5} \) belong?
</Question>
<Answer>A</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that the intersection of a Venn diagram represents those belonging to both sets</Misconception>

<Construct>Fill in regions of a double Venn diagram with numbers from given information</Construct>

<Question>

P without the intersection is labelled A, Q without the intersection is labelled C, the intersection of the two sets is labelled B, and outside the circles is labelled D.]() In which region does \( \mathbf{5} \) belong?
</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that the intersection of a Venn diagram represents those belonging to both sets</Misconception>

\(

<Answer>\( \frac{1}{66} \) \( \frac{1}{66} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Simplifies a fraction by adding or subtracting the same amount from the numerator  and denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Plot two straight lines to find the solution to a pair of simultaneous equations</Construct>

<Question>
Which diagram shows the graphical solution to: \( \begin{array}{c}3 x+2 y=12 \\ y=3-x\end{array} \)
</Question>
<Answer>![A four quadrant plane. Y axis -15 to 30 and x axis -15 to 25. A blue line goes from bottom left to top right sloping upwards. It goes through (-10, -7) and (10, 12). A red line goes from bottom left to top right sloping upwards. It goes through (0, -6) and (10, 9) ]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an upward line has a negative gradient</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate a descending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>

<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing sequences
Tom says \( (\boldsymbol{n}+\mathbf{1})^{3} \) would produce a linear sequence.
Katie says \( 3-\frac{n}{3} \) would produce a linear sequence
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate a descending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>

Who is correct?

<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate a descending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>

Tom and Katie are discussing sequences

Katie says \( 3-\frac{n}{3} \) would produce a linear sequence
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes linear sequences cannot include fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
To make green paint, you mix blue paint with yellow paint in the ratio \( 5: 3 \).
What should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Blue & Yellow & Total \\
\hline \( \mathrm{1500 ml} \) & \( \bigstar \) 
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2500 \mathrm{ml} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up sides of a ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
To make green paint, you mix blue paint with yellow paint in the ratio \( 5: 3 \).
What should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Blue & Yellow & Total \\
\hline \( \mathrm{1500 ml} \) & \( \bigstar \) 
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1502 \mathrm{ml} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a difference of one part in a ratio means the quantities will differ by one unit</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
To make green paint, you mix blue paint with yellow paint in the ratio \( 5: 3 \).
What should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Blue & Yellow & Total \\
\hline \( \mathrm{1500 ml} \) & \( \bigstar \) 
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4500 \mathrm{ml} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In ratio question where one side of ratio is given, uses that as one part in ratio without dividing</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the sector angle on a pie chart for a given group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation is correct to find the number of degrees representing comedy in a pie chart showing the following information? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline Film Genre & Comedy & Romance & Action \\
\hline Number of teachers & \( 9 \) & \( 4 \) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 360 \div 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes to find the angle for a pie chart sector you calculate 360 divided by the frequency of that sector</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance travelled using a speed-time graph</Construct>

![A speed-time graph. At 6 seconds, the car is travelling at a speed of 8 metres per second. After 8 seconds, the car is travelling at a speed of 15 metres per second. ]() Here is a speed-time graph for a car.

Which of the following gives the best estimate for the distance travelled between \( 6 \) and \( 8 \) seconds?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 m \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when finding area under graph you can use the upper y value rather than average of upper and lower</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles on a straight line</Construct>

<Question>
What is the size of angle \( q \) ? ![A long straight line with two shorter lines joining it, but not crossing it. Where the line on the left joins it forms two angles, q on the left, 126 degrees on the right. Where the line on the right joins it forms two angles, the left is unmarked, 37 degrees on the right.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 37^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks angles which look the same on diagram will be equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles on a straight line</Construct>

Where the line on the left joins it forms two angles, q on the left, 126 degrees on the right. Where the line on the right joins it forms two angles, the left is unmarked, 37 degrees on the right.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 17^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misinterprets the meaning of angles on a straight line angle fact</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles on a straight line</Construct>

<Question>

Where the line on the left joins it forms two angles, q on the left, 126 degrees on the right. Where the line on the right joins it forms two angles, the left is unmarked, 37 degrees on the right.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 64^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When “borrowing” during a subtraction problem, does not subtract one from the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete missing number mental subtraction problems with numbers over 1000</Construct>

<Question>
A \( 4 \) digit number belongs in this box to make the calculation true
\(
\square-6027=1253
\)
What is the \( 4^{\text {th }} \) digit of the number that belongs in the box?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Nick wants to add \( 97 \) to a number.
Which one of the following methods would give him the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( +100 \) then \( +3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the effect of consecutive operations</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Nick wants to add \( 97 \) to a number.
Which one of the following methods would give him the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -100 \) then \( +3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of adds when answering worded problems </Misconception>

<Construct>Know that probabilities must lie between 0, impossible, and 1, certain</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of an event occurring is \( 0.9 \).

Which of the following most accurately describes the likelihood of the event occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>Certain</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a probability of 1 represents something that is certain</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that probabilities must lie between 0, impossible, and 1, certain</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of an event occurring is \( 0.9 \).

Which of the following most accurately describes the likelihood of the event occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>Unlikely</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a probability of 1 represents something that is certain</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that probabilities must lie between 0, impossible, and 1, certain</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of an event occurring is \( 0.9 \).

Which of the following most accurately describes the likelihood of the event occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>Impossible</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a probability of 0 represents something that is impossible</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a right-angled triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 67.5 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has used slant height and base to find area of a triangle rather than perpendicular height and base</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 810 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies all given dimensions when calculating an area</Misconception>

\hline

<Construct>Use the nth term rule of an ascending integer linear sequence to test whether a term belongs in the sequence or not</Construct>

Jo says \( \mathbf{1 4 9} \) is a term in the sequence.

Paul says \( \mathbf{1 5 0} \) is a term in the sequence.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

\(\bigcirc\bigcirc\bigcirc\)

\(\square\quad\square\quad\square\quad\square\quad\square\)
\(\bigcirc\bigcirc\bigcirc\bigcirc\bigcirc\)
\(\square\quad\square\quad\square\quad\square\quad\square\) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>

<Construct>Multiplication law of indices with positive integer powers and a different base number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are discussing \( 3^{2} \times 4^{2} \)
Jo says \( 3^{2} \times 4^{2}=12^{4} \)
Paul says \( 3^{2} \times 4^{2}=12^{2} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying numbers with different bases, multiplies the powers and multiplies the base numbers.</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiplication law of indices with positive integer powers and a different base number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are discussing \( 3^{2} \times 4^{2} \)
Jo says \( 3^{2} \times 4^{2}=12^{4} \)
Paul says \( 3^{2} \times 4^{2}=12^{2} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that multiplication can be broken down into factors</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
\( \begin{array}{llllll}\frac{8}{10} & \frac{41}{50} & \frac{7}{20} & 0.77 & \frac{4}{5} & \frac{79}{100}\end{array} \) Which value is the outlier in this set of data?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{41}{50} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an outlier is a value that does not fit the same characteristics as the other values</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
\( \begin{array}{llllll}\frac{8}{10} & \frac{41}{50} & \frac{7}{20} & 0.77 & \frac{4}{5} & \frac{79}{100}\end{array} \) Which value is the outlier in this set of data?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.77 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an outlier is a value that does not fit the same characteristics as the other values</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
\( \begin{array}{llllll}\frac{8}{10} & \frac{41}{50} & \frac{7}{20} & 0.77 & \frac{4}{5} & \frac{79}{100}\end{array} \) Which value is the outlier in this set of data?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{79}{100} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an outlier is the value in a data set with the biggest denominator, even if this value is close to the mean</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from days to seconds</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following would correctly calculate the number of seconds in \( 2 \) days?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \times 12 \times 60 \times 60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 12 hours in 1 day</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from days to seconds</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following would correctly calculate the number of seconds in \( 2 \) days?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \times 24 \times 60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converted hours to minutes instead of hours to seconds</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a translation using vector notation where at least one value is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following vectors describes how to get from point \( P \) to point \( Q \)? ![The image shows a square grid and 2 points, P and Q. Point P is 4 squares left and 2 squares up from point Q. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \left(\begin{array}{l}4 \\ 2\end{array}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a positive y value in a column vector means to move down rather than up </Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a translation using vector notation where at least one value is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following vectors describes how to get from point \( P \) to point \( Q \)? ![The image shows a square grid and 2 points, P and Q. Point P is 4 squares left and 2 squares up from point Q. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \left(\begin{array}{c}-2 \\ 4\end{array}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the movement of the top number in a column vector is vertical, and the bottom number is horizontal rather than the other way round</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, involving positive fractions</Construct>

\(
p-3=\frac{1}{12}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p=\frac{4}{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding an integer to a fraction, thinks you add the integer to the numerator</Misconception>

\(
p-3=\frac{1}{12}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p=\frac{3}{36} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, multiplies instead of adding</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute into simple formulae given in words</Construct>

<Misconception>Thinks halving is the same as multiplying by 2</Misconception>

<Subject>Simplifying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify fully (if possible):

\( \frac{18}{30} \)
</Question>
<Answer>Cannot be simplified</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand how to simplify fractions</Misconception>

<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of \( 4^{2} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Estimate the gradient at a point on a non-linear section of a real life graph</Construct>

<Question>

Which of the following is the best estimate for the gradient of the curve when \( t=6 \) ![The image is of a velocity-time graph. There is a straight line, a tangent, drawn so that it is touching the curve at t=6. The tangent goes through (2, 31), (6, 47) and (8,55). ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 46 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the difference between a value on a graph and the gradient of a graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Estimate the gradient at a point on a non-linear section of a real life graph</Construct>

\( x \) & \( -1 \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) &  & \( -1 \) & 
\end{tabular} This is a table of values for \( y=x^{2}-x+1 \) What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that subtracting a negative is the same as adding it's additive inverse</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>

\(4 x-5 y=20\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -\frac{4}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation where there is a negative sign in front of the variable and its equivalent value, assumes the variable has a negative value</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>Primary
Quantitative
data</Answer>

<Construct>Identify data which is qualitative or quantitative</Construct>
<Subject>Types of Data and Questionnaires</Subject>
<Question>
Leanne has written a questionnaire on the topic of holidays. One of her questions is,

"Describe how you feel when you are about to go on holiday."

What type of data is she collecting by asking this question?
</Question>
<Answer>Attribute data</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of attribute data</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>

\( m^{2}+6 m+1 \equiv(m \bigstar )^{2} \triangle \)
</Question>
<Answer>\(\bigstar =+6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes the constant in the bracket is the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\(\bigstar =+12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes the constant in the bracket is double the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer negative number problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>

<Answer>\( 2 \times(-2)-(-4) \times 4 \)</Answer>

Which calculation is equal to \( -20 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-5)^{2}+5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

Which calculation is equal to \( -20 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-42) \div(-2)+1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes dividing a negative by a negative gives a negative answer</Misconception>

\( (-5)+(-2)= \)

<Answer>\( -3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that adding a negative will increase the value of the original number</Misconception>

The graph is in three sections. The first section is a straight slanted line from (0,0) to (1, 4). The second section is a horizontal line from (1, 4) to (3, 4). The third section is a slanted line from (3, 4) to (5, 0).]()

<Construct>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape</Construct>

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not connect rotational symmetry to number of sides/vertices</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( (2 \times 7)+(4 \times 2)+(4 \times 7) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating surface area, only includes visible faces</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \times 4 \times 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds volume when asked for surface area</Misconception>
