\(52 \times 326\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline\( \times \) & \( 300 \) & \( 20 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 50 \) &  &  \( \bigstar \) & \\
\hline \( 2 \) &  & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Complete missing number mental addition problems with numbers over 1000</Construct>

<Question>

\(
258+\square=1162
\)
What is the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) digit of the number that belongs in the box?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete missing number mental addition problems with numbers over 1000</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
A \( 3 \) digit number belongs in this box to make the calculation true
\(
258+\square=1162
\)
What is the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) digit of the number that belongs in the box?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts the smallest digit from the largest digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>

<Question>
What should replace the circle when these two brackets are expanded and simplified?
\(
(p-5)(p+2) \equiv p^{2} \triangle p \bigcirc
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \bigcirc=-3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the constant in an expanded quadratic comes from adding the two numbers in the brackets</Misconception>

\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \bigcirc=+10 \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( (-2,5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks x = ? is the y axis</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
When \( h=5 \)
Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}3 h^{2}=75 \\ (3 h)^{2}=75\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}3 h^{2}=225 \\ (3 h)^{2}=225\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies before applying a power </Misconception>

\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?

\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying decimals, ignores place value and just multiplies the digits</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from kilometers to miles</Construct>
<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 1 \mathrm{~km} \approx 0.6 \) miles \( 4 \mathrm{~km} \approx \square \) miles
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.6 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Add fractions involving mixed number fractions with the same denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
1 \frac{2}{3}+\frac{1}{3}
\)
Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you add the number of wholes to the numerator when converting a mixed number to an improper fraction.</Misconception>

<Construct>Add fractions involving mixed number fractions with the same denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
1 \frac{2}{3}+\frac{1}{3}
\)
Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you add the whole to the numerators, ignoring denominators, when adding a mixed number to a proper fraction with the same denominator.</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the description of an algebraic term with powers, write the term using algebra </Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following using correct algebraic notation \( m \) multiplied by the cube of \( n \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (m n)^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has not realised that the answer may be changed by the insertion of brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the description of an algebraic term with powers, write the term using algebra </Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following using correct algebraic notation \( m \) multiplied by the cube of \( n \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( m n+3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks cubing a number means adding 3 to that number</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the description of an algebraic term with powers, write the term using algebra </Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following using correct algebraic notation \( m \) multiplied by the cube of \( n \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 m n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes cubing a number means you multiply it by 3</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
In which region would \( x^{2}-10 x-25=0 \) belong? ![A Venn diagram made up of two overlapping circles. One is labelled 'Factorises' and the other is labelled 'Has one solution equal to 0'.
A is in the 'Factorises' circle only, B is in the overlap of the two circles, C is in the 'Has one solution equal to 0' circle only, and D is outside the circles.]()
</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes all quadratic equations have a solution of 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Continue linear sequences expressed as patterns by drawing the next pattern</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the next pattern in this linear sequence? ![A sequence of 4 patterns. The first pattern is a rectangle, made of 3 squares stacked vertically. The second pattern is the same as the first pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 1. The 3rd pattern is the same as the second pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 2. The 4th pattern is the same as the 3rd pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 3.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![This pattern is the same as Pattern 4: it is made up of 9 squares as a 4 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then an extra square on top of the top left square of the rectangle.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not notice all changes in a sequence of visual patterns</Misconception>

<Construct>Continue linear sequences expressed as patterns by drawing the next pattern</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the next pattern in this linear sequence? ![A sequence of 4 patterns. The first pattern is a rectangle, made of 3 squares stacked vertically. The second pattern is the same as the first pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 1. The 3rd pattern is the same as the second pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 2. The 4th pattern is the same as the 3rd pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 3.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![This pattern is made up of 12 squares as a 5 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then 2 extra squares on top of the top left square of the rectangle.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not notice all changes in a sequence of visual patterns</Misconception>

<Construct>Continue linear sequences expressed as patterns by drawing the next pattern</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the next pattern in this linear sequence? ![A sequence of 4 patterns. The first pattern is a rectangle, made of 3 squares stacked vertically. The second pattern is the same as the first pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 1. The 3rd pattern is the same as the second pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 2. The 4th pattern is the same as the 3rd pattern but with 2 more squares added, to the right of the bottom 2 squares of Pattern 3.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![This pattern is made up of 12 squares as a 5 (width) by 2 (height) rectangle and then an extra square on top of the top left square of the rectangle, and one more square to the right of that one.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not notice all changes in a sequence of visual patterns</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The next rectangle has "− 1" written inside it, the next rectangle has "✕ 2" written inside it and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "8" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reverses the order of operations but does not apply the inverse operations when finding the input of a function machine</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The next rectangle has "− 1" written inside it, the next rectangle has "✕ 2" written inside it and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "8" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 14 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reverse the order of operations when finding the input of a function machine</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The next rectangle has "− 1" written inside it, the next rectangle has "✕ 2" written inside it and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "8" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reverse the order of operations when finding the input of a function machine</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}-5 p
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p+5)(p-5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}-5 p
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p+\sqrt{5})(p-\sqrt{5}) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise an arithmetic sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing arithmetic sequences.

Tom says this is an arithmetic sequence: \( 5,8,11,14,17, \ldots \)

Katie says this is an arithmetic sequence: \( 5,15,45,135,405, \ldots \)

Who is correct?

</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise an arithmetic sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing arithmetic sequences.

Tom says this is an arithmetic sequence: \( 5,8,11,14,17, \ldots \)

Katie says this is an arithmetic sequence: \( 5,15,45,135,405, \ldots \)

Who is correct?

</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise an arithmetic sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing arithmetic sequences.

Tom says this is an arithmetic sequence: \( 5,8,11,14,17, \ldots \)

Katie says this is an arithmetic sequence: \( 5,15,45,135,405, \ldots \)

Who is correct?

</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a fraction on a scale where the required number is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
What fraction is the arrow pointing to? ![An image of a numberline with 5 dashes. On the leftmost dash is the number 1/6. On the rightmost dash is the number 3/6. An arrow points to the 4th dash from the left]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading a dash on a number line does not take into account the number at the start or the width of each division</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a fraction on a scale where the required number is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
What fraction is the arrow pointing to? ![An image of a numberline with 5 dashes. On the leftmost dash is the number 1/6. On the rightmost dash is the number 3/6. An arrow points to the 4th dash from the left]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the arrow on a number line points to the middle value</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a fraction on a scale where the required number is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
What fraction is the arrow pointing to? ![An image of a numberline with 5 dashes. On the leftmost dash is the number 1/6. On the rightmost dash is the number 3/6. An arrow points to the 4th dash from the left]()
</Question>
<Answer>There is no such fraction</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise you can use equivalent fractions to break fractions up into smaller divisions</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert ratios to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
A lassi drink is made of yoghurt and water in the ratio \( 3: 1 \). What fraction of the drink is water?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gets order of ratio wrong</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert ratios to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
A lassi drink is made of yoghurt and water in the ratio \( 3: 1 \). What fraction of the drink is water?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When converting ratio to fractions, puts the other side of the ratio as the denominator rather than the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert ratios to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
A lassi drink is made of yoghurt and water in the ratio \( 3: 1 \). What fraction of the drink is water?
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the relationship between a ratio and fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Read values off a displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
How far away from home was Rachel at 12:15? ![A line graph with title "A graph to show the distance Rachel travels from her home on her daily run." 
The x-axis is titled "Time" and is labelled with times from 0800 to 1300 in steps of 1 hour, with the axis going half an hour beyond 1300.
The y-axis is titled "Distance from home (Km)" and the scale is from 0 to 8 in steps of 1km. The following points are plotted and joined together: (0800, 0), (0830, 2), (0900, 3.5),(1000, 6), (1030, 7), (1100, 7.5),(1230, 7.5),(1300, 4.5), (1330, 0).       
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \mathrm{~km} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a horizontal line on a distance time graph means a distance of 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using balancing</Construct>

One of these equations has no real solutions.
Which is it?
</Question>
<Answer>\( t^{3}=-27 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a number raised to a power will always give a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using balancing</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
One of these equations has no real solutions.
Which is it?
</Question>
<Answer>\( t-27=-27 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes 0 is not a real solution to an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>

She then has a second pick.
What is the probability the second pick is a red ball?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{7} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reduce the denominator when an item is not replaced in a probability question</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, with all positive integers</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x=0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solution to an equation with matching coefficients of variables on both sides will always be 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify parallel lines written in the form y = mx + c</Construct>

<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing parallel lines
Tom says \( y=2 x+5 \) and \( y=2 x-7 \) are parallel 
Katie says \( y=2 x+5 \) and \( y=3 x+5 \) are parallel
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes lines can be parallel by having the same y intercept OR gradient</Misconception>

<Answer>\( -\frac{4}{3} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Find a negative reciprocal</Construct>
<Subject>Perpendicular Lines</Subject>
<Question>
\( -\frac{3}{4} \times \star=-1 \) What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about the relationship between two parts (e.g. one part is worth 5 more than another), work out the whole</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Bill and Mischa share their profit in a ratio of \( 9: 5 \) Bill gets \( £ 72 \) more than Mischa. How much money did they receive altogether?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 112 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In ratio question where the difference between the sides is given, uses that as the total for one side instead</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about the relationship between two parts (e.g. one part is worth 5 more than another), work out the whole</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Bill and Mischa share their profit in a ratio of \( 9: 5 \) Bill gets \( £ 72 \) more than Mischa. How much money did they receive altogether?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 432 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In ratio question where the difference between the sides is given, uses that as one part without dividing</Misconception>

\( 3 \times 5 \times 20= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 28 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiples</Misconception>

<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
\( 3 \times 5 \times 20= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying multiples of ten and the answer requires an extra digit, leaves off that extra digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract fractions involving mixed number fractions with the same denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
1 \frac{2}{3}-\frac{1}{3}
\)
Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a fraction from a mixed number, assumes they just subtract the numerator from the integer of the mixed number</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract fractions involving mixed number fractions with the same denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\(
1 \frac{2}{3}-\frac{1}{3}
\)
Which of the following is a correct way to write the answer to this calculation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a fraction from a mixed number, assumes they subtract the numerator from the integer and the numerator of the mixed number</Misconception>

\( 503 \) \\
\( -\quad 98 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 415 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When “borrowing” during a subtraction problem, does not subtract one from the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract integers up to 3 digits using a written method where carrying is needed</Construct>
<Subject>Written Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>

\( 503 \) \\
\( -\quad 98 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 595 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts the smallest digit from the largest digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems that combine addition and subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Combining Operations</Subject>
<Question>
Summer buys a dress for \( £ 73 \) and two pairs of shoes for \( £ 41 \) each. 
She pays using a \( £ 40 \) gift voucher and some cash.

How much cash does she pay?
</Question>
<Answer>£195</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than subtracts when answering worded problems</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>

\(

\)

<Answer>\( 30000 \)</Answer>

\(
43075
\)

<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>

<Question>
What is the value of the \( 3 \) in the number below?
\(
43075
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not equate the value of a number with the place value column it is in</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise the following expression \( x^{2}+6 x+5 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+2)(x+3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that to factorise a quadratic expression, to find two numbers that add to give the coefficient of the x term, and multiply to give the non variable term
</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise the following expression \( x^{2}+6 x+5 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x(x+6)+5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks factorising a quadratic means factorising the variable terms into a single bracket, and leaving out the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>

What was his original number? ![A cartoon of a man, in this question called Kieran, wearing a shirt, tie, grey trousers and black shoes. He is thinking of a number, we can tell this because he has a thought bubble above his head with a '?' in it.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When using a function machine, confuses the input and the output.</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \frac{1}{72} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand a percentage is out of 100</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>None of these options</Answer>

\[

\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}-x+4 x+3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 4290 \)</Answer>

</Question>

<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 4296 \) rounded to the nearest \( 10 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between l and m³ </Construct>

<Question>
\[
100 \text { litres = }
\square \, cubic \, metres
\]
</Question>

<Misconception>Thinks 1l = 1 cubic metre</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between l and m³ </Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
\[
100 \text { litres = }
\square \, cubic \, metres
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks 10l = 1 cubic metre</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100 \) more than \( 72980 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 73,980 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding powers of 10 adds onto the wrong column</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100 \) more than \( 72980 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7,298,000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than adds when given the command word 'more'</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100 \) more than \( 72980 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 72,080 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Order negative decimals with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the depths below sea level of \( 3 \) creatures:
Starfish: \( -7 m \)
Shark: \( -9 m \)
Dolphin: \( -8.3 \mathrm{~m} \)
Arrange their depths in ascending order, starting with the deepest
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1^{\text {st }} \) Dolphin
\( 2^{\text {nd }} \) Shark
\( 3^{\text {rd }} \) Starfish</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the more digits a number has the greater it is, regardless of place value</Misconception>

<Construct>Order negative decimals with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the depths below sea level of \( 3 \) creatures:
Starfish: \( -7 m \)
Shark: \( -9 m \)
Dolphin: \( -8.3 \mathrm{~m} \)
Arrange their depths in ascending order, starting with the deepest
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1^{\text {st }} \) Starfish \( 2^{\text {nd }} \) Dolphin \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) Shark</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes negative numbers with a larger absolute value are greater</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the vertically opposite angles relationship</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
Which angle is vertically opposite to angle \( p \) ? ![A diagram with 3 lines. 2 of the lines go from the left to the right of the diagram, getting closer to each other on the right hand side (the lines are not parallel). The 3rd line cuts through these 2 lines from top left to bottom right. Where the lines cross near the top left of the diagram, 4 angles are made. The angle which is nearest the top left corner of the diagram is labelled "A". Clockwise from A, the other angles around this point are labelled "C", "B" and "p". Where the lines cross near the bottom right of the diagram, 4 angles are also made, only one of these is labelled (the angle that is nearest to the top left of the diagram): "D". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>A</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses vertically opposite angles with angles on a straight line</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the vertically opposite angles relationship</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
Which angle is vertically opposite to angle \( p \) ? ![A diagram with 3 lines. 2 of the lines go from the left to the right of the diagram, getting closer to each other on the right hand side (the lines are not parallel). The 3rd line cuts through these 2 lines from top left to bottom right. Where the lines cross near the top left of the diagram, 4 angles are made. The angle which is nearest the top left corner of the diagram is labelled "A". Clockwise from A, the other angles around this point are labelled "C", "B" and "p". Where the lines cross near the bottom right of the diagram, 4 angles are also made, only one of these is labelled (the angle that is nearest to the top left of the diagram): "D". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses vertically opposite angles with angles on a straight line</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square root of a number</Construct>

What is the value of the missing number? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{\( 13^{2} \)} \\
\hline\( \ldots \ldots \ldots \) & \( 12^{2} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Halves when asked to find the square root</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square root of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of the missing number? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{\( 13^{2} \)} \\
\hline\( \ldots \ldots \ldots \) & \( 12^{2} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the sum of 2 numbers, each squared first, is the same as adding the two numbers and then squaring the total</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \frac{3}{5} \)</Answer>

<Question>
Convert \( 3 \frac{1}{5} \) to an improper fraction.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{15}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to add the numerator when converting from a mixed number to an improper fraction </Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer</Construct>

<Question>
\( 7 \times \frac{1}{4}=7 \div ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know multiplying by a unit fraction is equivalent to: dividing by its denominator value</Misconception>

<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\( 7 \times \frac{1}{4}=7 \div ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing an integer by a fraction, thinks they can just multiply instead.</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\( 7 \times \frac{1}{4}=7 \div ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>Not possible</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know multiplying by a unit fraction is equivalent to: dividing by its denominator value</Misconception>

<Construct>Construct a triangle using Side-Side-Side</Construct>
<Subject>Construct Triangle</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about constructing triangles.

Tom says you can construct a triangle with lengths \( 11 \mathrm{~cm}, 10 \mathrm{~cm} \) and \( 2 \mathrm{~cm} \).

Katie says you can construct a triangle with lengths \( 8 \mathrm{~cm}, 5 \mathrm{~cm} \) and \( 3 \mathrm{~cm} \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that the sum of the two shorter sides must be greater than the third side for it to be a possible triangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Construct a triangle using Side-Side-Side</Construct>
<Subject>Construct Triangle</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about constructing triangles.

Tom says you can construct a triangle with lengths \( 11 \mathrm{~cm}, 10 \mathrm{~cm} \) and \( 2 \mathrm{~cm} \).

Katie says you can construct a triangle with lengths \( 8 \mathrm{~cm}, 5 \mathrm{~cm} \) and \( 3 \mathrm{~cm} \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that the sum of the two shorter sides must be greater than the third side for it to be a possible triangle</Misconception>

\( \frac{2}{7} \times ?=1 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{7} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks if you multiply a fraction by itself you get a whole</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving full symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
![Pictogram showing smiley faces, where each smiley face is worth 10 people. Game 1 has 5 smiley faces. Game 2 has 2 smiley faces. Game 3 has 3 smiley faces. Game 4 has 2 smiley faces.]() The pictogram shows how many people came to watch a netball match.
What is the mean number of people at each game?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When interpreting a pictogram, thinks each symbol stands for 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving full symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
![Pictogram showing smiley faces, where each smiley face is worth 10 people. Game 1 has 5 smiley faces. Game 2 has 2 smiley faces. Game 3 has 3 smiley faces. Game 4 has 2 smiley faces.]() The pictogram shows how many people came to watch a netball match.
What is the mean number of people at each game?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know you can find the mean from a pictogram</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving full symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
![Pictogram showing smiley faces, where each smiley face is worth 10 people. Game 1 has 5 smiley faces. Game 2 has 2 smiley faces. Game 3 has 3 smiley faces. Game 4 has 2 smiley faces.]() The pictogram shows how many people came to watch a netball match.
What is the mean number of people at each game?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 120 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating the mean from a list of data, adds up the numbers but does not divide</Misconception>

\)

<Answer>\( y x+b 3 \)</Answer>

\(

\)

<Answer>\( 3 b x y \)</Answer>

<Construct>Describe a descending linear sequence in words</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Which statement correctly describes this sequence?

\[
7,2,-3, \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>The first term is \( 7 \) and the term-to-term rule is \( +5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Goes the wrong direction in the sequence when identifying term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a descending linear sequence in words</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Which statement correctly describes this sequence?

\[
7,2,-3, \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>The first term is \( 7 \) and the position-to-term rule is \( -5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Describes term to term rules using position to term rules</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a descending linear sequence in words</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Which statement correctly describes this sequence?

\[
7,2,-3, \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>The first term is \( 12 \) and the position-to-term rule is \( -5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the first term in a sequence is the term before the sequence begins (0th term)</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when it is possible to factorise an expression into a double bracket</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Jo says when she is factorising \( x^{2}-4 x \) she tries to think of two numbers that multiply together to give \( -4 \) and add together to give \( 0 \)

Paul says when he is factorising \( x^{2}-\frac{4}{25} \) he tries to think of two numbers that multiply together to give \( -\frac{4}{25} \) and add together to give \( \frac{2}{25} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising into double brackets, believes the sum of the two values in the brackets equals bx rather than b</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which step of the balance diagram is incorrect? ![Image of an equation and three lines of working to solve it.
The equation is 4p+5=2p-9
Step A is 4p=2p-4
Step B is 2p= -4
Step C is p= -2]()
</Question>
<Answer>They are all correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Heads towards zero when subtracting from a negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sketch of a curve in the form (x + a)(x + b), work out its factorised form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following could be the equation of this curve? ![A quadratic curve with a minimum turning point at (-2, -1). The curve crosses the x axis at the points (-3,0) and (-1,0). It crosses the y axis at (0,3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x-1)(x-3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to swap the sign of roots when placing into brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sketch of a curve in the form (x + a)(x + b), work out its factorised form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following could be the equation of this curve? ![A quadratic curve with a minimum turning point at (-2, -1). The curve crosses the x axis at the points (-3,0) and (-1,0). It crosses the y axis at (0,3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x+1)(x-3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the link between the sign of the root and the sign in the bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sketch of a curve in the form (x + a)(x + b), work out its factorised form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following could be the equation of this curve? ![A quadratic curve with a minimum turning point at (-2, -1). The curve crosses the x axis at the points (-3,0) and (-1,0). It crosses the y axis at (0,3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x-1)(x+3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the link between the sign of the root and the sign in the bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{3}{7} \) of a group of students are boys.
What would be a possible ratio of boys to girls?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3: 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses the denominator when converting from fractions to ratio, rather than numerator.</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{3}{7} \) of a group of students are boys.
What would be a possible ratio of boys to girls?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3: 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When converting fractions to ratios, puts the other side of the ratio as the total of the numerator and denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{3}{7} \) of a group of students are boys.
What would be a possible ratio of boys to girls?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4: 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gets order of ratio wrong</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring multiplication or division, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:

\(
3 p=\frac{1}{12}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p=\frac{1}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( a, b \) and \( c \) are different numbers
\(
\frac{a}{b+c}=a \div(b+c)
\)
Is the above relationship...
</Question>
<Answer>never true</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that the numerator and denominator of fractions represent groupings and have the same order of priority as brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( a, b \) and \( c \) are different numbers
\(
\frac{a}{b+c}=a \div(b+c)
\)
Is the above relationship...
</Question>
<Answer>sometimes true</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that the numerator and denominator of fractions represent groupings and have the same order of priority as brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( a, b \) and \( c \) are different numbers
\(
\frac{a}{b+c}=a \div(b+c)
\)
Is the above relationship...
</Question>
<Answer>Need more information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that the numerator and denominator of fractions represent groupings and have the same order of priority as brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Which multiplication will help factorise \( x^{2}+33 x+32 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \times 16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Which multiplication will help factorise \( x^{2}+33 x+32 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \times 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
This is the final stage of Beth's solution to a quadratic equation.
What should replace the star?

\[
(h-8)(h+3)=0
\] \( h=\bigstar \) or \( h=-3 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solutions of a quadratic equation are the constants in the factorised form</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
This is the final stage of Beth's solution to a quadratic equation.
What should replace the star?

\[
(h-8)(h+3)=0
\] \( h=\bigstar \) or \( h=-3 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes both solutions of a quadratic will have the same absolute value, even when the graph is not symmetrical about the y axis</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
This is the final stage of Beth's solution to a quadratic equation.
What should replace the star?

\[
(h-8)(h+3)=0
\] \( h=\bigstar \) or \( h=-3 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes all quadratic equations have a solution of 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify questions involving a 2D right-angled triangle that require the use of the Tangent (tan) ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Right-angled Triangles (SOHCAHTOA)</Subject>
<Question>
Which ratio would you use to find the value of \( p \) ? ![A right-angled triangle with the angle labelled 32 degrees, the side adjacent to this is 6cm and the side opposite is p.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \operatorname{Sin} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses sin when tan is required</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify questions involving a 2D right-angled triangle that require the use of the Tangent (tan) ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Right-angled Triangles (SOHCAHTOA)</Subject>
<Question>
Which ratio would you use to find the value of \( p \) ? ![A right-angled triangle with the angle labelled 32 degrees, the side adjacent to this is 6cm and the side opposite is p.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Cos</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses cos when tan is required</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify questions involving a 2D right-angled triangle that require the use of the Tangent (tan) ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Right-angled Triangles (SOHCAHTOA)</Subject>
<Question>
Which ratio would you use to find the value of \( p \) ? ![A right-angled triangle with the angle labelled 32 degrees, the side adjacent to this is 6cm and the side opposite is p.]()
</Question>
<Answer>None of these</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand how to apply sohcahtoa</Misconception>

<Construct>Add algebraic fractions where the denominators are single terms and are not multiples of each other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible: \( \frac{t}{s}+\frac{2 s}{t} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{t^{2}+4 s^{2}}{s t} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When squaring a variable, believes they also need to square the coefficient</Misconception>

<Construct>Add algebraic fractions where the denominators are single terms and are not multiples of each other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible: \( \frac{t}{s}+\frac{2 s}{t} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{t+2 s}{s+t} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Add algebraic fractions where the denominators are single terms and are not multiples of each other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible: \( \frac{t}{s}+\frac{2 s}{t} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2 s t}{s+t} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding/subtracting fractions, adds/subtracts the denominators and multiplies the numerators</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>![2 function machines both with 4 rectangles in a row and joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first function machine has "p" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "✕ 2" written inside the next rectangle, "+ 3" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "3 + 2p" written inside it.
 The second function machine has "p" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has  "✕ 2" written inside the next rectangle, "+ 3"  written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "2(3 + p)" written inside it.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>![2 function machines both with 4 rectangles in a row and joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first function machine has "p" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "+ 3" written inside the next rectangle, "✕ 2" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "3 + 2p" written inside it.
 The second function machine has "p" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has  "✕ 2" written inside the next rectangle, "+ 3"  written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "2(3 + p)" written inside it.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is trying to solve the equation below.

Here are his steps.

Which steps, if any, are correct? ![An equation 15 =  2p - 4 on the first line. 
On the second line, Step 1 : 11 = 2p. 
On the third line, Step 2: 22 = p]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only step \( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>

Isaac is trying to solve the equation below.

Here are his steps.

Which steps, if any, are correct? ![An equation 15 =  2p - 4 on the first line. 
On the second line, Step 1 : 11 = 2p. 
On the third line, Step 2: 22 = p]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only step \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is trying to solve the equation below.

Here are his steps.

Which steps, if any, are correct? ![An equation 15 =  2p - 4 on the first line. 
On the second line, Step 1 : 11 = 2p. 
On the third line, Step 2: 22 = p]()
</Question>
<Answer>Both steps are correct</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of an isosceles triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give the area of this triangle? ![A triangle with the base labelled with 40cm, the perpendicular height 15cm and the slant height labelled with 25 cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{40 \times 25}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has used slant height and base to find area of a triangle rather than perpendicular height and base</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of an isosceles triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give the area of this triangle? ![A triangle with the base labelled with 40cm, the perpendicular height 15cm and the slant height labelled with 25 cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{40 \times 25 \times 15}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has multiplied base by slant height and perpendicular height to find area of a triangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of an isosceles triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would give the area of this triangle? ![A triangle with the base labelled with 40cm, the perpendicular height 15cm and the slant height labelled with 25 cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{20 \times 15}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Halves base but still divides product by 2 when finding area of a triangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a translation using vector notation where at least one value is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Which vector correctly describes the translation that maps object \( Q \) onto object \(P \)? ![The image shows a set of axes and two congruent trapezia P and Q. Trapezium P has vertices at (1, 7), (2, 9), (4, 9), (5, 7). Trapezium Q has vertices at (4, 2), (5, 4), (7, 4), (8, 2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \left(\begin{array}{c}5 \\ -3\end{array}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the movement of the top number in a column vector is vertical, and the bottom number is horizontal rather than the other way round</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a translation using vector notation where at least one value is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Which vector correctly describes the translation that maps object \( Q \) onto object \(P \)? ![The image shows a set of axes and two congruent trapezia P and Q. Trapezium P has vertices at (1, 7), (2, 9), (4, 9), (5, 7). Trapezium Q has vertices at (4, 2), (5, 4), (7, 4), (8, 2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \left(\begin{array}{c}3 \\ -5\end{array}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, goes from the image to the original</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the equation of a line when given a positive gradient and a point on the line</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Equation of a Line</Subject>
<Question>
A line has a gradient of \( 2 \) and passes through the point \( (1,1) \) 
The equation of this line could be...
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=2 x+1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes  c, in y=mx+c, will be the y value of the coordinate given despite the x coordinate not being 0.</Misconception>

<Construct>Add amounts of money together to make a total between £1 and £10</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Money</Subject>
<Question>
Sunita wants to buy a sandwich and a tea.

How much money will she need? Joe's Café
Sandwich \( £3.25 \)
Pasty \( £ 2.99 \)
Cake \( £ 2.25 \)
Soup \( £ 3.19 \)
Tea \( £ 1.55 \)
Coffee \( £ 1.95 \)
Orange \( 89\)p
</Question>
<Answer>£5.70</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding powers of 10 adds onto the wrong column</Misconception>

<Construct>Add amounts of money together to make a total between £1 and £10</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Money</Subject>
<Question>
Sunita wants to buy a sandwich and a tea.

How much money will she need? Joe's Café
Sandwich \( £3.25 \)
Pasty \( £ 2.99 \)
Cake \( £ 2.25 \)
Soup \( £ 3.19 \)
Tea \( £ 1.55 \)
Coffee \( £ 1.95 \)
Orange \( 89\)p
</Question>
<Answer>£4.70</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the size of each interior angle in a regular polygon</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
The octagon below is regular. Find angle \( x \). ![A regular octagon (8 sided polygon). Each side is marked with a single dash to show that all sides are equal in length. One of the interior angles of the octagon is labelled with the letter "x".]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 22.5^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the interior angles of any polygon add up to 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the size of each interior angle in a regular polygon</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 45^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the interior angles of any polygon add up to 360</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a common factor involving numeric and algebraic components (e.g. 5a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
When this expression is fully factorised, what is left inside the brackets? \( 24 a b c^{2}-16 b^{2} c \equiv 8 b c(\square) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 a c \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a common factor involving numeric and algebraic components (e.g. 5a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
When this expression is fully factorised, what is left inside the brackets? \( 24 a b c^{2}-16 b^{2} c \equiv 8 b c(\square) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 a-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise multiplying a variable by itself results in a power of that variable</Misconception>

\hline
\end{tabular}]() How many circles will the next term in this sequence have?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only looks at the difference between one pair of terms when discerning the pattern</Misconception>

<Question>
\( 5 \) hours \( +500 \) minutes \( = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \) hours</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when changing from hours to minutes</Misconception>

\( 5 \) hours \( +500 \) minutes \( = \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 13 \) hours and \( 33 \) minutes</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when changing from hours to minutes</Misconception>

\[
y=5(x+1) ?
\]

"𝑥" is the first part, written on the left, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "✕ 5" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "+ 1" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to "y"]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

Which function matches the equation
\[
y=5(x+1) ?
\]
</Question>
<Answer>![A function machine which has 4 parts joined by arrows pointing from left to right. "y" is the first part, written on the left, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "+ 1" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to a rectangle that has "✕ 5" written inside it, followed by a horizontal arrow pointing to "𝑥"]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When writing a function as a function machine confuses the input and the output.</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify pairs of numbers that satisfy an equation with two unknowns </Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\( x+y=20 \) Which pair of numbers fits the equation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}x=10 \\ y=2\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Changes the given operation when substituting</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify pairs of numbers that satisfy an equation with two unknowns </Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\( x+y=20 \) Which pair of numbers fits the equation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}x=10 \\ y=-2\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>substitutes incorrectly</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify pairs of numbers that satisfy an equation with two unknowns </Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\( x+y=20 \) Which pair of numbers fits the equation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}x=-8 \\ y=12\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>substitutes incorrectly</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
How many months have an average temperature below 25⁰C ? ![A line graph with title "Monthly Average temperatures for Zakynthos, Greece. (⁰C)". 
The x-axis is labelled with the first letter of every month of the year and is titled "months". 
The y-axis is titled "Average temperature (⁰C)" and the scale is labelled from 18 to 34 in steps of 2. The following points are plotted and joined together: (J, 18), (F, 20), (M, 21), (A, 22), (M, 23), (J, 25), (J, 29), (A, 32), (S, 27), (O, 22), (N, 20), (D, 18).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to find data points below a certain value, gives the number of data points above this value</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
How many months have an average temperature below 25⁰C ? ![A line graph with title "Monthly Average temperatures for Zakynthos, Greece. (⁰C)". 
The x-axis is labelled with the first letter of every month of the year and is titled "months". 
The y-axis is titled "Average temperature (⁰C)" and the scale is labelled from 18 to 34 in steps of 2. The following points are plotted and joined together: (J, 18), (F, 20), (M, 21), (A, 22), (M, 23), (J, 25), (J, 29), (A, 32), (S, 27), (O, 22), (N, 20), (D, 18).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to find data points below a certain value, gives the number of data points above this value</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
How many months have an average temperature below 25⁰C ? ![A line graph with title "Monthly Average temperatures for Zakynthos, Greece. (⁰C)". 
The x-axis is labelled with the first letter of every month of the year and is titled "months". 
The y-axis is titled "Average temperature (⁰C)" and the scale is labelled from 18 to 34 in steps of 2. The following points are plotted and joined together: (J, 18), (F, 20), (M, 21), (A, 22), (M, 23), (J, 25), (J, 29), (A, 32), (S, 27), (O, 22), (N, 20), (D, 18).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Includes a data point with the value, when asked to find the number of data points below a value</Misconception>

<Construct>Label angles using correct 3-letter notation (e.g. angle ADB)</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following correctly describes the marked angle? ![An image of square ABCE with various triangles attached to it.  The marked angle is between the lines CE and EG.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( E \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gives the vertex instead of the 3-letter angle notation</Misconception>

<Construct>Label angles using correct 3-letter notation (e.g. angle ADB)</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following correctly describes the marked angle? ![An image of square ABCE with various triangles attached to it.  The marked angle is between the lines CE and EG.]()
</Question>
<Answer>FEC</Answer>
<Misconception>In 3 letter angle notation, gives a wider angle that contains the shaded angle</Misconception>

<Construct>Label angles using correct 3-letter notation (e.g. angle ADB)</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following correctly describes the marked angle? ![An image of square ABCE with various triangles attached to it.  The marked angle is between the lines CE and EG.]()
</Question>
<Answer>CGE</Answer>
<Misconception>Gives 3-letter angle notation in the wrong order</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Which multiplication will help factorise \( x^{2}+13 x+30 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \times 30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Which multiplication will help factorise \( x^{2}+13 x+30 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \times 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Which multiplication will help factorise \( x^{2}+13 x+30 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \times 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which option shows the fractions in order from smallest to largest?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{llll}\frac{3}{4} & \frac{1}{2} & \frac{2}{6} & \frac{1}{12}\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up smallest and largest when ordering fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which option shows the fractions in order from smallest to largest?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{llll}\frac{1}{2} & \frac{3}{4} & \frac{2}{6} & \frac{1}{12}\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ordered fractions by comparing denominators rather than using equivalent fractions.</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which option shows the fractions in order from smallest to largest?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{llll}\frac{1}{2} & \frac{1}{12} & \frac{2}{6} & \frac{3}{4}\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When comparing unit fractions believes that fractions with larger denominators are greater in size.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an odd numbered list of data</Construct>

<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
3,5,6,18,18
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the mean instead of the median</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an odd numbered list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
3,5,6,18,18
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the median for an odd numbered data set, find the midpoint of two values rather than giving the middle value</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 90 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the first multiple of a is 2a</Misconception>

<Construct>Can calculate missing coordinates in a geometric shape</Construct>

\((0,3),(4,-1),(2,-3),\)

What are the coordinates of the \( 4^{\text {th }} \) vertex?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (0,1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the sides of a rectangle must be horizontal and vertical, not diagonal</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators are all single terms</Construct>

\(
\frac{5}{x} \times \frac{2 y}{x^{2}}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5 x+10 y}{x^{2}} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to multiply fractions, uses the method for adding instead</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators are all single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write this as a single fraction as simply as possible:

\(
\frac{5}{x} \times \frac{2 y}{x^{2}}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{10 y}{3 x} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes cubing a number means you multiply it by 3</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract two equations together to remove a variable </Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is trying to solve the pair of simultaneous equations on the right.

\[
6 g+h=12
\]
\[
6 g-3 h=-3
\]

He decides to subtract the bottom equation from the top equation.
What will he end up with?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2 h=9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative number, subtracts the absolute value rather than adding it</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract two equations together to remove a variable </Construct>

Isaac is trying to solve the pair of simultaneous equations on the right.

\[
6 g+h=12
\]
\[
6 g-3 h=-3
\]

He decides to subtract the bottom equation from the top equation.
What will he end up with?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2 h=15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative number, subtracts the absolute value rather than adding it</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract two equations together to remove a variable </Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is trying to solve the pair of simultaneous equations on the right.

\[
6 g+h=12
\]
\[
6 g-3 h=-3
\]

He decides to subtract the bottom equation from the top equation.
What will he end up with?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 h=9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative number, subtracts the absolute value rather than adding it</Misconception>

<Construct>Compare the lengths of diagonal line segments without calculating the exact length</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about distance and coordinates. 

Tom says \( (3,-2) \) and \( (2,-3) \) are equidistant from the origin. 
Katie says \( (4,1) \) and \( (7,-2) \) are equidistant from the origin. 

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the sum of change in x and change in y gives the distance between points</Misconception>

<Construct>Compare the lengths of diagonal line segments without calculating the exact length</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about distance and coordinates. 

Tom says \( (3,-2) \) and \( (2,-3) \) are equidistant from the origin. 
Katie says \( (4,1) \) and \( (7,-2) \) are equidistant from the origin. 

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses negative and positive coordinates when working with graphs in four quadrants</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to an appropriate degree to estimate the answer to a calculation</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.243 \ldots \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a square, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>

What is the perimeter of the compound shape? ![A regular pentagon with a square joined along one edge]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 343 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that square root is found by dividing by 4</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a square, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>

<Answer>\( 112 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes lines inside the shape are included when finding perimeter</Misconception>

What is the length of each of its sides?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When given the perimeter of a regular polygon, subtracts instead of divides to find each side length</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the perimeter, work out a missing length requiring knowledge of the geometrical properties of the shape</Construct>

What is the length of each of its sides?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 96 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When given the perimeter of a regular polygon, multiplies instead of divides to find each side length</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the perimeter, work out a missing length requiring knowledge of the geometrical properties of the shape</Construct>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
![Squared paper with a horizontal line of reflection and a triangle. The horizontal base of the triangle is two squares above the line of reflection.]() Tom and Katie are arguing about how to reflect the object in the line of reflection. Who reflects it correctly? ![Tom does this: his reflected triangle is sitting upright the same as the original object. The base is 3 squares below the line of reflection.]() ![Katie does this: her reflected triangle is upside down compared to the original object. The base of the reflected triangle is on the line of reflection.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Translates rather than reflects across a line of symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

The base is 3 squares below the line of reflection.]() ![Katie does this: her reflected triangle is upside down compared to the original object. The base of the reflected triangle is on the line of reflection.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify or mark lines of symmetry on a shape</Construct>

<Question>
![A rectangle divided into 3 equal horizontal sections. The middle section is white and the other 2 sections are blue. In the centre of the white section are five 5-pointed blue stars in the same formation as the 5 dots on a dice. All the stars are in exactly the same orientation, with one point pointing directly upwards.]() How many lines of symmetry does this shape have?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot identify a line of symmetry in a simple shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
Below is data from a Hockey team's matches over the course of a season, showing the number of goals scored. How many matches did the team play? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Goals scored & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes total frequency in a table is found by counting rows</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
Below is data from a Hockey team's matches over the course of a season, showing the number of goals scored. How many matches did the team play? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Goals scored & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 28 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the total frequency is the overall total in a grouped table</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
Below is data from a Hockey team's matches over the course of a season, showing the number of goals scored. How many matches did the team play? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Goals scored & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes total frequency in a table is given by the sum of the categories given</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx - c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
If
\(
m^{2}+5 m-14 \equiv(m+a)(m+b)
\)
then \( a \times b= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the coefficent of x in an expanded quadratic comes from multiplying the two numbers in the brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx - c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
If
\(
m^{2}+5 m-14 \equiv(m+a)(m+b)
\)
then \( a \times b= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 14 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising into double brackets, believes the product of the constants in the brackets is of the opposite sign to the constant in the expanded equation.</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the order of operations
Tom says: \( 3+2-1 \equiv 3-1+2 \)
Katie says: \( 3+2 \times 1 \equiv 2 \times 1+3 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs addition ahead of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the order of operations
Tom says: \( 3+2-1 \equiv 3-1+2 \)
Katie says: \( 3+2 \times 1 \equiv 2 \times 1+3 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 180° and 270°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about the size of the marked angle.
Jo says it is \( 120^{\circ} \)
Paul says it is \( 60^{\circ} \)
Who is correct? ![Angle with a protractor over it showing 240 degrees]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>When using a 180 degree protractor to measure reflex angles gives the value of the acute or obtuse angle that is a complement to 360</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 180° and 270°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about the size of the marked angle.
Jo says it is \( 120^{\circ} \)
Paul says it is \( 60^{\circ} \)
Who is correct? ![Angle with a protractor over it showing 240 degrees]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not add on 180 degrees when using a protractor to measure a reflex angle</Misconception>

<Answer>\( t^{2}-16=0 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Find missing numbers in a fraction multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Barry has two fraction cards.
\( \frac{3}{7} \quad \square\)
The product of the cards is \( \frac{2}{5} \) What is the other card?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{29}{35} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to interpret a fraction worded problem </Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing numbers in a fraction multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Barry has two fraction cards.
\( \frac{3}{7} \quad \square\)
The product of the cards is \( \frac{2}{5} \) What is the other card?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{35} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to interpret a fraction worded problem </Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing numbers in a fraction multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Barry has two fraction cards.
\( \frac{3}{7} \quad \square\)
The product of the cards is \( \frac{2}{5} \) What is the other card?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{6}{35} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to interpret a fraction worded problem </Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the equation of a line with a negative gradient from an accurate drawing</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient as change in y over change in x</Subject>
<Question>
If you were to write the equation of this line in the form \( \boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{m} \boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{c} \), what is the value of \( \boldsymbol{m} \) ? ![Graph showing straight line with y intercept (0,0) and x intercept (0,0). Also goes through the point (6,-4)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -\frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading graph, chooses nearest marked value on axis instead of reading accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the equation of a line with a negative gradient from an accurate drawing</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( -\frac{3}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes gradient = change in x/change in y</Misconception>

<Misconception>Confuses square rooting and halving the number</Misconception>
