</Question>
<Answer>\( +9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, adds instead of dividing</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring multiplication or division, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Isaac's book. Isaac always records what operation he has done to both sides of the equation.

What operation should replace the star? ![A diagram showing the change from the equations 9y = to y = represented by a gold star]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \times 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring multiplication or division, with all positive integers</Construct>

<Answer>\( -9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, subtracts instead of dividing</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>

How many sweets does Heena get?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 17 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a difference of one part in a ratio means the quantities will differ by one unit</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify vertical translations in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions</Construct>
<Subject>Transformations of functions in the form f(x)</Subject>
<Question>
What transformation maps the graph of
\(y=f(x)\)
to the graph of
\(y=f(x)+1\)
</Question>
<Answer>Translation by vector
\(\left[\begin{array}{l}
0 \\
-1
\end{array}\right]\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes f(x) - a translates the function up a units</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify vertical translations in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions</Construct>

\(y=f(x)\)
to the graph of
\(y=f(x)+1\)

<Answer>Translation by vector
\(\left[\begin{array}{l}
1 \\
0
\end{array}\right]\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes f(x) + a translates the function right a units</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>

\[

\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( r=p+5 \div 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misunderstands order of operations in algebraic expressions</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>

\[
p=3 r-5
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( r=\frac{p-5}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the inverse operations of addition and subtraction when rearranging equations</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and three or more steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing rearranging \( p=\sqrt{5-q} \) to make \( q \) the subject Tom says a correct first line of working could be: \( p^{2}=5-q \) Katie says a correct first line of working could be: \( p+\sqrt{q}=\sqrt{5} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that the square root of an expression square roots each term in the expression, rather than square rooting the whole expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and three or more steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing rearranging \( p=\sqrt{5-q} \) to make \( q \) the subject Tom says a correct first line of working could be: \( p^{2}=5-q \) Katie says a correct first line of working could be: \( p+\sqrt{q}=\sqrt{5} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that the square root of an expression square roots each term in the expression, rather than square rooting the whole expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>

\(
p^{2}+2 p+3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p+2)(p+1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the constant in an expanded quadratic comes from adding the two numbers in the brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>

\(
p^{2}+2 p+3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p+3)(p+1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>

\(
p^{2}+2 p+3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p+3)(p-1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that add to give the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret the graphical solution to a pair of linear simultaneous equations from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Graphical Solution of Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
The cost of journeys from two taxi companies is shown on the diagram.

After how many miles is Company P more expensive than Company Q? ![A graph showing Cost (£) on the y axis and Distance (miles) on the x axis. Y axis from 0 to 30, each square goes up by 5,  and x axis from 0 to 6, each square goes up by 1. A blue line slopes upwards from left to right, from (0, 10). It is labelled 'Company Q'. A red line slopes upwards from left to right, from (0,0). It is labelled 'Company P'. Both lines go through (5, 20)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading value from graph, reads from the wrong axes.</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing ways to calculate \( 59 \times 4 \) mentally
Tom doubles \( 59 \) and then doubles the answer
Katie does \( 60 \times 4 \) and then subtracts \( 4 \) from the answer
Who would get the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think that the compensation strategy for the multiplication of 2 numbers is valid.</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing ways to calculate \( 59 \times 4 \) mentally
Tom doubles \( 59 \) and then doubles the answer
Katie does \( 60 \times 4 \) and then subtracts \( 4 \) from the answer
Who would get the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that doubling and then doubling again is not the same as multiplying by 4</Misconception>

<Question>
\[
1,8,27,64, \ldots
\]

What is the name given to this sequence of numbers?
</Question>
<Answer>The square numbers</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know what a square number is</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise cube numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\[
1,8,27,64, \ldots
\]

What is the name given to this sequence of numbers?
</Question>
<Answer>The odd numbers</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up odd and even numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise cube numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\[
1,8,27,64, \ldots
\]

What is the name given to this sequence of numbers?
</Question>
<Answer>The triangular numbers</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks cube numbers are triangular numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form a(x + b)² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
When Aaron completes the square, what should replace the triangle?
\(
3 g^{2}-18 g-7 \equiv 3(g-3)^{2} \triangle
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \triangle=-16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying out 2 or more brackets, does not multiply all the combinations of terms</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form a(x + b)² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
When Aaron completes the square, what should replace the triangle?
\(
3 g^{2}-18 g-7 \equiv 3(g-3)^{2} \triangle
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \triangle=-25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form a(x + b)² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
When Aaron completes the square, what should replace the triangle?
\(
3 g^{2}-18 g-7 \equiv 3(g-3)^{2} \triangle
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \triangle=-88 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes a coefficient of x^2 does not affect the value of the constant inside the bracket</Misconception>

<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 4 m \) is the same as ___ \( mm \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 10000mm in a metre</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not account for scale on diagram</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate missing lengths of shapes by counting squares</Construct>
<Subject>Perimeter</Subject>
<Question>
John is labelling the lengths of the sides of this shape. ![A hexagon with one side, length 3 squares, labelled 6cm. The side labelled with the gold star is 1 square in length.]() What should replace the star?

<Answer>\( 0.5 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Incorrect use of scale on a diagram</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring a scaling of one expression</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
What is a correct solution for the following pair of simultaneous equations:
\[4x+y=7\]
\[3x+2y=4\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}x=3 \\ y=-5\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring a scaling of one expression</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
What is a correct solution for the following pair of simultaneous equations:
\[4x+y=7\]
\[3x+2y=4\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}x=0.6 \\ y=4.6\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring a scaling of one expression</Construct>

<Question>
What is a correct solution for the following pair of simultaneous equations:
\[4x+y=7\]
\[3x+2y=4\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}x=10 \\ y=-33\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a surd in the form √a in a simplified form</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Surds</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify \( \sqrt{48} \) as much as possible
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16 \sqrt{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying surds, does not square root the largest square number that goes into the number under the surd before putting it in front of the surd</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \sqrt{12} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem P: \( 6 \div 3+5= \)
Problem Q: \( 6 \div 3 \times 5= \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem P: \( 3+5 \)
Problem Q: \( 3 \times 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from right to left regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem P: \( 6 \div 3+5= \)
Problem Q: \( 6 \div 3 \times 5= \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem P: \( 3+5 \)
Problem Q: \( 6 \div 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the order of operations, believes addition comes before division</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem P: \( 6 \div 3+5= \)
Problem Q: \( 6 \div 3 \times 5= \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem P: \( 6 \div 3 \)
Problem Q: \( 3 \times 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation would give you the area of the face of this cuboid labelled \( Q \) ('the top')? ![A cuboid with dimensions 6cm by 3cm by 4 cm. The top face Q is marked. It is a rectangle with dimensions 6cm by 3cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \mathrm{~cm} \times 3 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot identify the correct side lengths to use when asked to find the area of a face</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation would give you the area of the face of this cuboid labelled \( Q \) ('the top')? ![A cuboid with dimensions 6cm by 3cm by 4 cm. The top face Q is marked. It is a rectangle with dimensions 6cm by 3cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \mathrm{~cm} \times 4 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot identify the correct side lengths to use when asked to find the area of a face</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation would give you the area of the face of this cuboid labelled \( Q \) ('the top')? ![A cuboid with dimensions 6cm by 3cm by 4 cm. The top face Q is marked. It is a rectangle with dimensions 6cm by 3cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \mathrm{~cm} \times 4 \mathrm{~cm} \times 3 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds volume when asked for surface area</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 180° and 270°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of the marked angle? ![A 360 degree protractor with 2 red lines and a pink sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The outer scale goes from 0 to 360, clockwise. The angle is a reflex angle that is between the red line that is at 0 (outer scale) and 180 (inner scale) on the protractor and goes clockwise round to the red line that is half way between 200 and 210 (outer scale) and halfway between 340 and 330 (inner scale).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 345^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring reflex angles</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 215^{\circ} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{P} \) ? ![Four quadrant, coordinate grid with the reflection line y=-x drawn and a triangle. The triangle has coordinates: (-2,3) (-2,6) and (0,5). The point P is the coordinate (0,5)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-4,-1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{P} \) ? ![Four quadrant, coordinate grid with the reflection line y=-x drawn and a triangle. The triangle has coordinates: (-2,3) (-2,6) and (0,5). The point P is the coordinate (0,5)]()

<Answer>\( (-2,2) \)</Answer>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{P} \) ? ![Four quadrant, coordinate grid with the reflection line y=-x drawn and a triangle. The triangle has coordinates: (-2,3) (-2,6) and (0,5). The point P is the coordinate (0,5)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-4,5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reflects horizontally or vertically instead of across a diagonal line of symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>Add integers up to 4 digits using a written method where carrying is needed</Construct>
<Subject>Written Addition</Subject>
<Question>
What number should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) & \(5\) & \(4\)\\
\hline+ & \( 2 \) & \(\bigstar\)  & \(7\) & \(1\) \\
\hline \(\space\) & \(6\) & \(3\) & \(2\) & \(5\)
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Add integers up to 4 digits using a written method where carrying is needed</Construct>
<Subject>Written Addition</Subject>
<Question>
What number should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline & \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) & \(5\) & \(4\)\\
\hline+ & \( 2 \) & \(\bigstar\)  & \(7\) & \(1\) \\
\hline \(\space\) & \(6\) & \(3\) & \(2\) & \(5\)
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 96 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following as simply as possible: \( \frac{q^{2}+q-12}{q^{2}-2 q-3} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{q-4}{q-1} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following as simply as possible: \( \frac{q^{2}+q-12}{q^{2}-2 q-3} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{q-4}{-2 q-1} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that when you cancel identical terms from the numerator and denominator, they just disappear</Misconception>

<Question>
Calculate
\(
\frac{1}{6} \div 3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing fractions, does the reciprocal of the first fraction instead of the second</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>

<Question>
Calculate
\(
\frac{1}{6} \div 3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 18 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative </Misconception>

\(
\frac{1}{6} \div 3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing a fraction by an integer, divides the denominator by the integer</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x>1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When representing an inequality on a numberline, assumes the filled and unfilled circles have the opposite meaning.</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x \leq 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve basic introduction simultaneous equation problems, often involving shapes and symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Chris orders \( 2 \) cups of tea and a cake, and his bill comes to £1.40

Amy orders \( 4 \) cups of tea and a cake, and her bill comes to £2.20.

How much does one cup of tea cost?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 80 p \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation forgets to eliminate the coefficient in front of the variable in the last step</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
Bob recorded the number of cars he sold in one week.
How many cars did he sell altogether? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Colour & Frequency \\
\hline Blue & \( 3 \) \\
\hline Black & \( 2 \) \\
\hline Silver & \( 4 \) \\
\hline Red & \( 1 \) \\
\hline Other & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes total in a grouped table is found by counting rows</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
Bob recorded the number of cars he sold in one week.
How many cars did he sell altogether? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Colour & Frequency \\
\hline Blue & \( 3 \) \\
\hline Black & \( 2 \) \\
\hline Silver & \( 4 \) \\
\hline Red & \( 1 \) \\
\hline Other & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you do not include an "other" category when finding a total frequency</Misconception>

The bar chart shows the drinks sold in Caroline's Café on Monday and Tuesday last week.

Approximately how many Teas were sold on Tuesday? ![Composite bar chart with four bars, labelled Tea, Coffee, Hot Choc and Cans. Each bar has two sections, the lower one shows how many sold on Monday and the upper one showing Tuesdays sales. The vertical scale has 5 ticks between 0 and 50, 50 and 100 etc.
The Teas bar lower section is 1 tick below 50 on the vertical scale, and the whole bar's height is 2 ticks above 100 on the vertical scale.
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 62 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Interpret a bar chart</Construct>
<Subject>Block Graphs and Bar Charts</Subject>
<Question>
The bar chart shows the drinks sold in Caroline's Café on Monday and Tuesday last week.

Approximately how many Teas were sold on Tuesday? ![Composite bar chart with four bars, labelled Tea, Coffee, Hot Choc and Cans. Each bar has two sections, the lower one shows how many sold on Monday and the upper one showing Tuesdays sales. The vertical scale has 5 ticks between 0 and 50, 50 and 100 etc.
The Teas bar lower section is 1 tick below 50 on the vertical scale, and the whole bar's height is 2 ticks above 100 on the vertical scale.
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 120 \)</Answer>

<Question>
Which of the following is the square root of \( 81 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 162 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up square rooting and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise square roots</Construct>
<Subject>Square Roots, Cube Roots, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the square root of \( 81 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6561 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Squares when asked to find the square root</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about working out percentages of amounts.

Tom says to find \( 40 \% \) you divide by \( 100 \) and multiply by \( 4 \). 
Katie says to find \( 40 \% \) you divide by \( 5 \) and multiply by \( 2 \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that dividing by 100 gives 10%</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about working out percentages of amounts.

Tom says to find \( 40 \% \) you divide by \( 100 \) and multiply by \( 4 \). 
Katie says to find \( 40 \% \) you divide by \( 5 \) and multiply by \( 2 \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that dividing by 100 gives 10%</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about working out percentages of amounts.

Tom says to find \( 40 \% \) you divide by \( 100 \) and multiply by \( 4 \). 
Katie says to find \( 40 \% \) you divide by \( 5 \) and multiply by \( 2 \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Unable to equate a division and multiplication to a single division</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a Fibonacci sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing Fibonacci sequences.

Tom says this is a Fibonacci sequence: \( 1,1,2,3,5,8, \ldots \)

Katie says this is a Fibonacci sequence: \( 1,2,3,5,8,13, \ldots \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a Fibonacci sequence must start with 1, 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a Fibonacci sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing Fibonacci sequences.

Tom says this is a Fibonacci sequence: \( 1,1,2,3,5,8, \ldots \)

Katie says this is a Fibonacci sequence: \( 1,2,3,5,8,13, \ldots \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks it can't be called a sequence with a repeated number at the start</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a Fibonacci sequence</Construct>

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know what a Fibonacci sequence is</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{2}{7} \times 3=3 \div K \times L \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}K=2 \\ L=7\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a fraction by an integer, multiplies the denominator instead of the numerator</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer</Construct>

\( \frac{2}{7} \times 3=3 \div K \times L \)
</Question>
<Answer>Not possible</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can write a division as a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent written scenarios as ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
For every \( 2 \) marbles Karen has, Marty has \( 3 \).
Write the number of marbles Karen and Marty have as a ratio, with Karen's part first.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3\; : 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up sides of a ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent written scenarios as ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
For every \( 2 \) marbles Karen has, Marty has \( 3 \).
Write the number of marbles Karen and Marty have as a ratio, with Karen's part first.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2\; : 3\; : 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you need to include the total as well as the individual parts when asked to write a ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent written scenarios as ratios</Construct>

<Answer>\( 2\; : 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When writing ratio, writes total as one side</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x<-2.2, x>2.2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Selects y>a solutions instead of y<a solutions for a quadratic inequality</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out the whole</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>

If there are \( 80 \) cars, how many vehicles (cars and vans) are there in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 83 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the number in the ratio is the total</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>Remainders</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that factors are divisors which split the number into equal groups</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>Fractions</Answer>

<Answer>Multiples</Answer>

\)

</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts the smallest digit from the largest digit</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 108 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes lines inside the shape are included when finding perimeter</Misconception>

Jo</Answer>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using balancing</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
A student wishes to solve the equation below.

Which of the following is a correct next step?
\(
(d+3)^{2}-25=0
\)

Step \( 1 \)
\(
(d+3)^{2}=25
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( d+3=5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only considers the positive solution when calculating a square root</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using balancing</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
A student wishes to solve the equation below.

Which of the following is a correct next step?
\(
(d+3)^{2}-25=0
\)

Step \( 1 \)
\(
(d+3)^{2}=25
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( d+3=12.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the inverse of square rooting is halving</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using balancing</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
A student wishes to solve the equation below.

Which of the following is a correct next step?
\(
(d+3)^{2}-25=0
\)

Step \( 1 \)
\(
(d+3)^{2}=25
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( d^{2}=22 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can subtract from inside brackets without expanding when solving an equation</Misconception>

\(

\)

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misremembers the quadratic formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Estimate the size of obtuse angles using bearings</Construct>
<Subject>Bearings</Subject>
<Question>
An exam question asks students to estimate the size of the bearing on the right
Tom writes his answer as: \( 110\degree\)
Katie writes her answer as: \( 190\degree\)

Who would get all the marks for this question in the exam? ![An obtuse angle drawn in a clockwise direction from a vertical north line.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that an obtuse angle is between 90 and 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Estimate the size of obtuse angles using bearings</Construct>
<Subject>Bearings</Subject>
<Question>
An exam question asks students to estimate the size of the bearing on the right
Tom writes his answer as: \( 110\degree\)
Katie writes her answer as: \( 190\degree\)

Who would get all the marks for this question in the exam? ![An obtuse angle drawn in a clockwise direction from a vertical north line.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that an obtuse angle is between 90 and 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Estimate the size of obtuse angles using bearings</Construct>
<Subject>Bearings</Subject>
<Question>
An exam question asks students to estimate the size of the bearing on the right
Tom writes his answer as: \( 110\degree\)
Katie writes her answer as: \( 190\degree\)

Who would get all the marks for this question in the exam? ![An obtuse angle drawn in a clockwise direction from a vertical north line.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that an obtuse angle is between 90 and 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to two significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about rounding.

Tom says \( \mathbf{6 0 5 . 7 6} \) rounded to \( 1 \) significant figure is \( \mathbf{6 0 0} \)

Katie says \( \mathbf{6 0 5 . 7 6} \) rounded to \( 2 \) significant figures is \( \mathbf{6 0 0} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up when next digit is 5</Misconception>

</Question>

<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent a linear inequality with a single tail on a numberline</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following diagrams represents \( x \leq 1 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A number line with integers from -5 to 5 marked on, with x as the axis label. There is an empty circle above 1, with an arrow pointing to the left coming off it.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When representing an inequality on a numberline, assumes the filled and unfilled circles have the opposite meaning.</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete missing number mental addition problems up to 1000 </Construct>

<Question>
What number belongs in the box to make the calculation correct? \( 263+\square=900 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1163 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of algebraic expressions</Construct>

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to identify common factors from algebraic terms</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form ax² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
When factorised, \( 9 x^{2}-16 \) will become...
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 x(x-16) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes only the first term needs to be divided when factorising an expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form ax² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
When factorised, \( 9 x^{2}-16 \) will become...
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 x(3 x-16-) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes only the first term needs to be divided when factorising an expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form ax² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
When factorised, \( 9 x^{2}-16 \) will become...
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3 x+4)(3 x+4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Factorises difference of two squares with the same sign in both brackets</Misconception>

<Answer>\( -3 \)</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>\( -4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply surds by an integer</Construct>

<Answer>\( \sqrt{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a surd by an integer, adds the integer to the number under the surd</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \sqrt{27} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a surd by an integer, multiplies the integer with the number under the surd</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply surds by an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Operations with Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\(9 \times \sqrt{3}\)

Simplify, if possible.
</Question>
<Answer>Cannot be simplified</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that an integer multiplied by a surd can be simplified</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)²</Construct>

<Question>

\(
(3 y-4)^{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 y^{2}-16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they only need to multiply the first and last pairs of terms when expanding double brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)²</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand and simplify:
\(
(3 y-4)^{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 y^{2}+16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they only need to multiply the first and last pairs of terms when expanding double brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)²</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand and simplify:
\(
(3 y-4)^{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3 y-4)(3 y-4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes expanding a squared expression means writing it as a set of double brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a decimal by an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing multiplying decimals.

Tom says \( 5 \times 3.9=3 \times 5.9 \)

Katie says \( 5 \times 3.9=3.9 \times 5 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the commutative property of multiplication</Misconception>

Katie says \( 5 \times 3.9=3.9 \times 5 \)

</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>

<Construct>Describe the properties of an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
Which description describes an isosceles triangle?
</Question>
<Answer>A triangle with one right angle.</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses isosceles and right angle triangles</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the properties of an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
Which description describes an isosceles triangle?
</Question>
<Answer>A triangle with three sides of equal length and three equal angles.</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses isosceles and equilateral triangles</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the properties of an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
Which description describes an isosceles triangle?
</Question>
<Answer>A triangle with no sides of equal length and no equal angles.</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses isosceles and scalene triangles</Misconception>

Katie says the output is: \( 3(n-4) \)
Who is correct? ![A function machine with input n and operations subtract 4, multiply by 3]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think a factorised expression is equivalent to its multiplied out form</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence?
\[
4, \quad 10, \quad 28, \quad 82, \quad \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you add \( 6 \) to the previous term</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence?
\[
4, \quad 10, \quad 28, \quad 82, \quad \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you double the previous term and add \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

\( 0.00809 \)

<Answer>\( 0.01 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

\( 0.00809 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts leading zero as a significant figure</Misconception>

Katie says \( 3050 \) is greater than \( 3500 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not equate the value of a number with the place value column it is in</Misconception>

<Construct>Order integers with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to order integers

Tom says \( 5000 \) is greater than \( 4987 \)

Katie says \( 3050 \) is greater than \( 3500 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>When ordering integers, orders from the digits at the end of the number instead of the digits at the start</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the y-intercept of a line from an accurate drawing</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>

\[
y=x^{2} - 4 \quad \text { and } \quad y=x-4
\]

Tom says both functions are linear

Katie says both functions cross the \( y \)-axis at the same point

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the properties of a linear graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the y-intercept of a line from an accurate drawing</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>

\[
y=x^{2} - 4 \quad \text { and } \quad y=x-4
\]

Tom says both functions are linear

Katie says both functions cross the \( y \)-axis at the same point

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the constant only gives the y-intercept for linear graphs</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the size of each interior angle in a regular polygon</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to calculate the size of each interior angle in a regular \( 18 \) sided shape Tom says you can do \( \frac{20 \times 180}{18} \) Katie says you can do \( 360-\frac{180}{18} \) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an interior angle in a regular polygon can be found using 180(n+2)/n</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the size of each interior angle in a regular polygon</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Polygons</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to calculate the size of each interior angle in a regular \( 18 \) sided shape Tom says you can do \( \frac{20 \times 180}{18} \) Katie says you can do \( 360-\frac{180}{18} \) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an interior angle in a regular polygon can be found using 360 subtract (180 over number of sides)</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>

What is its gradient?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the gradient from the equation of a line in the form ax + by = c, believes b/a is the gradient</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
A line has equation \( 5 x+3 y=7 \)
What is its gradient?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation forgets to eliminate the coefficient in front of the variable in the last step</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
A line has equation \( 5 x+3 y=7 \)
What is its gradient?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that for a line written in the form ax + by = c, a is the gradient</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 1.6 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental division</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Teddy calculates the answer to \( 600 \div 25 \) mentally "There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in 100. I then multiplied \( 4 \) by \( 6 \) to get \( 24 \). So \( 600 \) divided by \( 25 \) is \( 24 \)" Teddy uses the same method to calculate \( 800 \div 25 \). Which of the following shows how he would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>There are \( 4 \) lots of \( 25 \) in \( 100 \) 
Then I multiplied \( 8 \) by \( 6 \) 
So the answer is \( 48 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not copy a given method accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to two decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
Two different numbers are equal to \( 4.37 \) to two decimal places.
The numbers could be....
</Question>
<Answer>\[
4.3728
\]
and
\[
4.3628
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds up instead of down</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to two decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
Two different numbers are equal to \( 4.37 \) to two decimal places.
The numbers could be....
</Question>
<Answer>\[
4.3751
\]
and
\[
4.3659
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the meaning of congruency</Construct>
<Subject>Congruency in Other Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing congruent shapes.
Tom says you can reflect a shape and it will still be congruent to the original.

Katie says you can rotate a shape and it will still be congruent to the original.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that shapes are congruent if they have the same size and shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the meaning of congruency</Construct>

Katie says you can rotate a shape and it will still be congruent to the original.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that shapes are congruent if they have the same size and shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a right-angled triangle from a description of the properties</Construct>

Statement 2. It must be an isosceles triangle
Which is true?
</Question>
<Answer>Statement \( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes isosceles triangles cannot have right angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a right-angled triangle from a description of the properties</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>Statement \( 2 \)</Answer>

\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\
\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>

Jo says \( p^{2}+16 p \equiv(p+4)(p+4) \)

Paul says \( p^{2}+16 p \equiv p(p+4) \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise</Misconception>

\[

\]

Tom says \( m \) could be \( 4 \)

Katie says \( m \) could be \( 3.75 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>

\[

\]

Tom says \( m \) could be \( 4 \)

Katie says \( m \) could be \( 3.75 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>When using inequality notation, thinks "greater than/less than or equal to" symbols are instead the "greater than/less than" symbols and vice versa</Misconception>

The shaded section is the top rectangle across the full width.]()

<Answer>\( 320 \mathrm{~m}^{2} \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( \begin{array}{r}\quad\space3152 \\ -809\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Lines up the digits incorrectly when doing a subtraction involving two numbers with a different amount of digits</Misconception>

<Misconception>Does not understand the value of zeros as placeholders</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{llll|l|l}
\( x \) & \( -1 \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) &  &  \( 3 \)  
\end{tabular} This is a table of values for \( y=x^{2}-x+3 \) What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks tables of values are symmetrical about (0,0)</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{llll|l|l}
\( x \) & \( -1 \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) &  &  \( 3 \)  
\end{tabular} This is a table of values for \( y=x^{2}-x+3 \) What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that subtracting a negative is the same as adding it's additive inverse</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + bx + c</Construct>

\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) &  &  \( 3 \)  
\end{tabular} This is a table of values for \( y=x^{2}-x+3 \) What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks 1 squared is 2</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving positive fractions</Construct>

\(

\)

<Answer>\( p=50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

\(

\)

<Answer>\( p=2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes the denominator is divided by the numerator</Misconception>

\(
10=\frac{5}{p}
\)

<Answer>There are no solutions</Answer>

<Construct>Recognise when an ascending sequence is linear</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing linear sequences.

Tom says this is a linear sequence: \( 1,2,4,7,11, \ldots \) 

Katie says this is a linear sequence: \( 1.2,1.4,1.6,1.8,2, \ldots \) 

Who is correct?

</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when an ascending sequence is linear</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing linear sequences.

Tom says this is a linear sequence: \( 1,2,4,7,11, \ldots \) 

Katie says this is a linear sequence: \( 1.2,1.4,1.6,1.8,2, \ldots \) 

Who is correct?

</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when an ascending sequence is linear</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing linear sequences.

Tom says this is a linear sequence: \( 1,2,4,7,11, \ldots \) 

Katie says this is a linear sequence: \( 1.2,1.4,1.6,1.8,2, \ldots \) 

Who is correct?

</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between cm and m</Construct>
<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 27 \mathrm{~cm}=\square \mathrm{m} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they can round when converting units</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between cm and m</Construct>

<Question>
\( 27 \mathrm{~cm}=\square \mathrm{m} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2700 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies when converting to a larger unit</Misconception>

\[

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators are all single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible:

\(
\frac{1}{s} \times \frac{2}{t}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{t+2 s}{s t} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to multiply fractions, uses the method for adding instead</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators are all single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible:

\(
\frac{1}{s} \times \frac{2}{t}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{s+t} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, adds the numerators and the denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators are all single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Express the following as a single fraction, writing your answer as simply as possible:

\(
\frac{1}{s} \times \frac{2}{t}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{s t} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, adds the numerators and multiplies the denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 18 \div 2+2 \times 2= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the order of operations, believes addition comes before division</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 18 \div 2+2 \times 2= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 22 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \frac{1}{9} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the \( 5 \) plants with these heights:
\[
23 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 17 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 40 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 25 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 31 \mathrm{~cm}
\]

Tom says if all the plants doubled in height, the range wouldn't change.

Katie says if all the plants grew by \( 12 \mathrm{~cm} \) each, the range wouldn't change.
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes if you changed all values by the same proportion the range would not change</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>

Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes if you changed all values by the same proportion the range would not change</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>

<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the \( 5 \) plants with these heights:

23 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 17 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 40 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 25 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 31 \mathrm{~cm}

Tom says if all the plants doubled in height, the range wouldn't change.

Katie says if all the plants grew by \( 12 \mathrm{~cm} \) each, the range wouldn't change.
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes if you add the same value to all numbers in the dataset the range will change</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>

<Question>

Pattern two consists of two central columns of three squares with one extra square either side. ]() There are \( 302 \) squares in Pattern \( 100 \). But if the shape changes to this: ![These patterns are the same as those in the first picture except that in each, the second block from each column of three has been removed. ]() How many squares would there be in Pattern \( 100 \) now?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 301 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only looks at the difference between one pair of terms when discerning the pattern</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The middle rectangle has "+¼" written inside it and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "8" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \frac{1}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. </Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of addition is multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sector angle on a pie chart, calculate the frequency of a group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
The pie chart shows the meal choices of guests at a wedding.

If there were \( 540 \) people at the wedding, which of the following would calculate how many people chose pork? ![A pie chart split into four parts, labelled with meal choices. The part for Beef is 150 degrees, Pork is 40 degrees and Other is 80 degrees. The angle for Vegetarian is labelled with a square right angle symbol.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{360}{40} \times 540 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a proportion of a whole is whole/part not part/whole</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sector angle on a pie chart, calculate the frequency of a group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
The pie chart shows the meal choices of guests at a wedding.

If there were \( 540 \) people at the wedding, which of the following would calculate how many people chose pork? ![A pie chart split into four parts, labelled with meal choices. The part for Beef is 150 degrees, Pork is 40 degrees and Other is 80 degrees. The angle for Vegetarian is labelled with a square right angle symbol.]()
</Question>
<Answer>You need more information</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes it is not possible to calculate the frequency for a pie chart sector despite being given enough information to do so</Misconception>

</Question>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
\frac{m}{4}-1=20
\)
Tom says you can write: \( \frac{m}{4}=21 \)
Katie says you can write: \( m-1=80 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
\frac{m}{4}-1=20
\)
Tom says you can write: \( \frac{m}{4}=21 \)
Katie says you can write: \( m-1=80 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
\frac{m}{4}-1=20
\)
Tom says you can write: \( \frac{m}{4}=21 \)
Katie says you can write: \( m-1=80 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to solve linear equations involving fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Know the bearings of North-West, North-East, South-West and South-East</Construct>
<Subject>Bearings</Subject>
<Question>
On what bearing is North-West? ![Shows a compass.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 270^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand direction of North East, North West, South East and South West cardinal points</Misconception>

<Construct>Know the bearings of North-West, North-East, South-West and South-East</Construct>
<Subject>Bearings</Subject>
<Question>
On what bearing is North-West? ![Shows a compass.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 045^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not measure bearing clockwise from the north line</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible: \( p^{2}-100 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p(p-10) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise difference of two squares</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible: \( p^{2}-100 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p-10)(p-10) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Factorises difference of two squares with the same sign in both brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible: \( p^{2}-100 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Does not factorise</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise difference of two squares</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing factors of \( \mathbf{1 2 y} \)
Tom says \( y \) is a factor of \( 12 y \)
Katie says \( 3 \) is a factor of \( 12 y \)
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the term factor</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing factors of \( \mathbf{1 2 y} \)
Tom says \( y \) is a factor of \( 12 y \)
Katie says \( 3 \) is a factor of \( 12 y \)
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes factors of algebraic terms/expressions will only be numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing factors of \( \mathbf{1 2 y} \)
Tom says \( y \) is a factor of \( 12 y \)
Katie says \( 3 \) is a factor of \( 12 y \)
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest 100</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{3 2 0} 050 \) rounded to the nearest hundred?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 320050 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>

<Construct>Prove statements involving multiples</Construct>
<Subject>Algebraic Proof</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following expressions is always a multiple of \( 5 \) if \( n \) is a positive integer.
</Question>
<Answer>\( n+5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes adding b to any integer gives a multiple of b</Misconception>

<Construct>Prove statements involving multiples</Construct>
<Subject>Algebraic Proof</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following expressions is always a multiple of \( 5 \) if \( n \) is a positive integer.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 n+3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they can find the nth term based on the first term only</Misconception>

<Construct>Prove statements involving multiples</Construct>
<Subject>Algebraic Proof</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following expressions is always a multiple of \( 5 \) if \( n \) is a positive integer.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 n+2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that an + b is still a multiple of a</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{4 5 . 6 2 8} \) rounded to one significant figure?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 45.6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to wrong degree of accuracy (decimal places rather than significant figures)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{4 5 . 6 2 8} \) rounded to one significant figure?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(\frac{5 x}{3}-1=-2\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( 5 x-3=-6 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{5 x}{3}=-3 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(\frac{5 x}{3}-1=-2\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( 5 x-3=-6 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{5 x}{3}=-3 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph, f(x), write down the solutions to f(x) = a</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
According to the graph, what is the approximate solution to
\(x^{2}-x-9=-6\) ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2-x-9 drawn on.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=-9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the y intercept when asked to read the solution to a quadratic equation from a graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph, f(x), write down the solutions to f(x) = a</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
According to the graph, what is the approximate solution to
\(x^{2}-x-9=-6\) ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2-x-9 drawn on.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=3.5, \quad x=-2.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Solves for y=0 instead of given y-value when reading from a quadratic graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 5, y-axis from -3 to 4. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 2), (4, 2), (3, 3). Point (3, 3) is labelled with the letter "P". The line y=1 is shown with a purple dashed line.
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 5, y-axis from -3 to 4. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 2), (4, 2), (3, 3). Point (3, 3) is labelled with the letter "P". The line y=1 is shown with a purple dashed line.
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,0) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 5, y-axis from -3 to 4. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 2), (4, 2), (3, 3). Point (3, 3) is labelled with the letter "P". The line y=1 is shown with a purple dashed line.
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,-3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![Image of a function machine. The function is subtract 3 and the output is 7]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 21 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of subtraction is multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![Image of a function machine. The function is subtract 3 and the output is 7]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![Image of a function machine. The function is subtract 3 and the output is 7]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding an input of a function machine thinks you apply the operations given rather than the inverse operation.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of this compound shape made with rectangles? ![Compound shape made of two rectangles with the sides labelled 15 cm, 12 cm, 7 cm and 7 cm. Two sides are unlabelled]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 154 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Makes an assumption about line segments being equal within a shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of this compound shape made with rectangles? ![Compound shape made of two rectangles with the sides labelled 15 cm, 12 cm, 7 cm and 7 cm. Two sides are unlabelled]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 180 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating the area of a rectilinear compound shape, calculates the are of the surrounding rectangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve a linear equation using a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
If I put the numbers \( 4 \) and \( 9 \) into this function machine, what comes out? ![Flow chart starting with instruction "In" inside a blue rimmed circle, then "+ 5" inside a red rimmed square, then "double" inside a red rimmed square and lastly,  "Out" inside a blue rimmed circle.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 81 \) and \( 196 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve a linear equation using a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
If I put the numbers \( 4 \) and \( 9 \) into this function machine, what comes out? ![Flow chart starting with instruction "In" inside a blue rimmed circle, then "+ 5" inside a red rimmed square, then "double" inside a red rimmed square and lastly,  "Out" inside a blue rimmed circle.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \) and \( -0.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When using a function machine, confuses the input and the output.</Misconception>

<Construct>Insert brackets to make a calculation correct</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Add brackets to this calculation to make the answer \( 7 \). \( 16-6+4 \div 2 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16-(6+4) \div 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Insert brackets to make a calculation correct</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Add brackets to this calculation to make the answer \( 7 \). \( 16-6+4 \div 2 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (16-6)+4 \div 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Insert brackets to make a calculation correct</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Add brackets to this calculation to make the answer \( 7 \). \( 16-6+4 \div 2 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16-6+(4 \div 2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form y = mx + c </Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a table of values for \( y=2 x+c \) What should replace the star? ![\begin{tabular}{l|l|l|c}
\( x \) & & \( 0 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( -5 \) & \( -3 \) & ఔ
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you can find missing values in a given table by treating the row as linear and adding on the difference between the first two values given.</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form y = mx + c </Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a table of values for \( y=2 x+c \) What should replace the star? ![\begin{tabular}{l|l|l|c}
\( x \) & & \( 0 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( -5 \) & \( -3 \) & ఔ
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that a pair of coordinates can be used to find missing parts of an equation</Misconception>

<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
How many rectangles would you need to shade so that \( 60 \% \) of this shape is shaded? ![A rectangle split into 20 equal parts]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumed each part of a fraction diagram is worth 10%</Misconception>

<Construct>Shade percentages of a shape where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
How many rectangles would you need to shade so that \( 60 \% \) of this shape is shaded? ![A rectangle split into 20 equal parts]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides rather than multiplies when scaling up in direct proportion problems</Misconception>

</Question>

<Construct>Represent the solution to a graphical inequality involving a combination of vertical, horizontal and diagonal lines</Construct>
<Subject>Graphing Linear Inequalities (Shading Regions)</Subject>
<Question>
The diagram on the right shows the lines \( 2=x+y \) and \( x=y \)

Which of the following coordinates satisfies the following inequalities?
\[
2<x+y \text { and } x<y
\] ![A graph showing all 4 quadrants. x axis from -2 to 5 and y axis from -3 to 5. A red line from top left sloping downwards to bottom right, going through 2 on the x axis and 2 on the y axis. A black line going from bottom left sloping upwards to top right. Going through 0 on the x axis and 0 on the y axis (only one intercept) ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (1,1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses inequality symbols with equality</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide integers of 3 or more digits using short division</Construct>
<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>
\[
3 \times \square=384
\]

Find the missing number.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 121 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing, ignores any remainders</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide integers of 3 or more digits using short division</Construct>
<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>
\[
3 \times \square=384
\]

Find the missing number.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1152 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does the original operation</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide integers of 3 or more digits using short division</Construct>
<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>
\[
3 \times \square=384
\]

Find the missing number.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 161 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem using written division (bus-stop method), does the calculation from right to left</Misconception>

Which shape has rotational symmetry order \( 2 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![Hexagon]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not connect rotational symmetry to number of sides/vertices</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

<Question>
What is the area of the shaded section of this composite shape made from rectangles? ![A composite shape that looks like a staircase going up from left to right, consisting of 3 steps. The full width of the diagram is 23m, the width of the first lower step is 7m, the width of the third top step is 6m. The full height of the diagram is 22m, the height os the first lower step is 5m, the height of the third top step is 8m. The shaded section is a rectangle which starts in the top left of the second (middle) step and finishes in the bottom right of the diagram.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 120 \mathrm{~m}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape</Misconception>
