<Construct>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
In which region would an isosceles triangle belong? ![Venn diagram with two circles labelled with 'exactly one line of symmetry' and 'rotational symmetry of order 3'. A is in the only exactly one line of symmetry region, B is in the intersection, C is in the only rotational symmetry of order 3 region and D is outside the two circles.]()
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the number of sides gives the order of rotational symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a surd in the form √a in a simplified form</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\(
\sqrt{75}=n \sqrt{3}
\)

What is the value of \( n \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying surds, does not square root the largest square number that goes into the number under the surd before putting it in front of the surd</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a surd in the form √a in a simplified form</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\(
\sqrt{75}=n \sqrt{3}
\)

What is the value of \( n \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 72 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying surds, adds the number on the outside of the surd to the number under the surd</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
The blue shape is rotated \( 90^{\circ} \) anticlockwise about \( (-2,2) \). Which shape gives the correct answer? ![A coordinate grid with 5 congruent shapes, one blue and 4 red, which are labelled A, B, C and D. The blue shape has vertices at (-3,5) (-3,4) (-2,4) (-2,3) and (-3,3). Shape A has vertices at (-1,2) (0,2) (1,2) (0,1) (-1,1). Shape B has vertices at (0,-2) (1,-2) (1,-3) (0,-3) (-1,-3). Shape C has vertices at (-4,-2) (-3,-2) (-3,-3) (-4,-3) (-5,-3). Shape D has vertices at (-4,2) (-3,2) (-3,1) (-4,1) (-5,1).]()
</Question>
<Answer>A</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up clockwise and anticlockwise</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
The blue shape is rotated \( 90^{\circ} \) anticlockwise about \( (-2,2) \). Which shape gives the correct answer? ![A coordinate grid with 5 congruent shapes, one blue and 4 red, which are labelled A, B, C and D. The blue shape has vertices at (-3,5) (-3,4) (-2,4) (-2,3) and (-3,3). Shape A has vertices at (-1,2) (0,2) (1,2) (0,1) (-1,1). Shape B has vertices at (0,-2) (1,-2) (1,-3) (0,-3) (-1,-3). Shape C has vertices at (-4,-2) (-3,-2) (-3,-3) (-4,-3) (-5,-3). Shape D has vertices at (-4,2) (-3,2) (-3,1) (-4,1) (-5,1).]()
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses negative and positive coordinates when working with graphs in four quadrants</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 900 clockwise or anticlockwise about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object</Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
The blue shape is rotated \( 90^{\circ} \) anticlockwise about \( (-2,2) \). Which shape gives the correct answer? ![A coordinate grid with 5 congruent shapes, one blue and 4 red, which are labelled A, B, C and D. The blue shape has vertices at (-3,5) (-3,4) (-2,4) (-2,3) and (-3,3). Shape A has vertices at (-1,2) (0,2) (1,2) (0,1) (-1,1). Shape B has vertices at (0,-2) (1,-2) (1,-3) (0,-3) (-1,-3). Shape C has vertices at (-4,-2) (-3,-2) (-3,-3) (-4,-3) (-5,-3). Shape D has vertices at (-4,2) (-3,2) (-3,1) (-4,1) (-5,1).]()
</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the centre of rotation is always the origin</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention?
\(
l \times 3 \times l \times l \times g \times g
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\(l3llgg\)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can simplify a term that involves powers</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention?
\(
l \times 3 \times l \times l \times g \times g
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( l 3 l^{2} g^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the commutative property of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention?
\(
l \times 3 \times l \times l \times g \times g
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 g g l^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can simplify a term that involves powers</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts leading zero as a significant figure</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the first three terms of a sequence \( \begin{array}{llll}94 & 86 & 78 & \ldots\end{array} \) Find an expression for the \( n \)th term of this sequence.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 n+86 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the nth term of a descending sequence will have a positive coefficient of n</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the first three terms of a sequence \( \begin{array}{llll}94 & 86 & 78 & \ldots\end{array} \) Find an expression for the \( n \)th term of this sequence.
</Question>
<Answer>\( -8 n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks terms in linear sequence are in direct proportion</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the output of this \( 2 \)-step function machine input \(x\rightarrow+ 10\rightarrow\) multiplied by 3\(\rightarrow\) output Tom says the output is \( \mathbf{3 x}+\mathbf{3 0} \)
Katie says the output is \( \mathbf{1 0}+\mathbf{3} \boldsymbol{x} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>

\( 4+12 \div(2+2)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs addition ahead of division</Misconception>

A is in only  'Line of symmetry at x = 3', B is in the intersection, C is in only 'y intercept is negative' and D is outside both sets.]()

<Answer>B</Answer>

What is \( \mathbf{9 8 9 . 9 8 9} \) rounded to the nearest ten?

<Answer>\( 980 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>

<Question>

\(
\frac{3 m+15}{m^{2}-2 m+15}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3 m}{m^{2}-2 m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that when you cancel identical terms from the numerator and denominator, they just disappear</Misconception>

<Answer>\( -\frac{1}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes gradient = change in x/change in y</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a line segment, calculate the gradient where the gradient is a negative integer</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( -1.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the gradient of a line is given by the x intercept</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph in the form (x + p)² + q, work out its completed the square form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Completing the Square Form</Subject>
<Question>
Sally wants to write the equation of the curve in the form \( y=(\boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{p})^{2}+\boldsymbol{q} \).
What is the value of \( \boldsymbol{p} \) ? ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2-2x-3 drawn on.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that in completed square form, the x co-ordinate of the turning point has the same sign as the constant in the brackets.</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph in the form (x + p)² + q, work out its completed the square form</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In completed square form, confuses the x and y coordinates of the turning point</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The middle rectangle has "Square root" written inside it and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "12" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the inverse of square rooting is doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The middle rectangle has "Square root" written inside it and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "12" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the inverse of square rooting is halving</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The middle rectangle has "Square root" written inside it and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "12" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding an input of a function machine thinks you apply the operations given rather than the inverse operation.</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles on parallel lines using corresponding angles</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( t=12^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes corresponding angles sum to 90 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a rectangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \times 20+8 \times 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of subtracts when using an area model for multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a rectangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
![A rectangle with one part shaded, labelled with dimensions 20, 8 and 6]() Which of the following calculations would correctly work out the area of the section shaded with a solid colour?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \times 14-8 \times 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding part of the area of a shape, subtracts from the side length before multiplying but still subtracts the unshaded area too.</Misconception>

Tom and Katie are discussing this bar model ![\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline \multicolumn{5}{|c|}{\( 205 \)} \\
\hline \( 41 \) & \( 41 \) & \( 41 \) & \( 41 \) & \( 41 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]() Tom uses the bar model to write:
\[
205 \div 5=41
\] Katie uses the bar model to write:
\[
205 \div 41=5
\]

</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than multiplies when using the product rule for counting</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the outcomes of more than one event</Construct>
<Subject>Combined Events</Subject>
<Question>
These are fair spinners

How many possible outcomes are there if they are spun together and both scores are recorded? ![Two spinners. One is a four-sided spinner with 4 equal sections labelled 1, 2, 3 and 4. One is a five-sided spinner with 5 equal sections labelled 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses all possible outcomes with options available</Misconception>

<Answer>\( y=x^{2}-2 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Frequency tables</Subject>
<Question>
Dave has recorded the number of pets his classmates have in the frequency table on the right. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Number of pets & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} How many people did Dave record the results of?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mistakes the number of rows for the total frequency in a frequency table</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Frequency tables</Subject>
<Question>
Dave has recorded the number of pets his classmates have in the frequency table on the right. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Number of pets & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} How many people did Dave record the results of?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds up the variable column when asked for total frequency</Misconception>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>"All circles are similar"</Answer>

<Construct>Identify whether two shapes are similar or not</Construct>
<Subject>Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these statements is false?
</Question>
<Answer>"All equilateral triangles are similar"</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that all regular shapes of a certain type will be similar</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify whether two shapes are similar or not</Construct>
<Subject>Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these statements is false?
</Question>
<Answer>"All regular decagons are similar"</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that all regular shapes of a certain type will be similar</Misconception>

<Construct>Find another power of 10 more than a given number</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 809,051 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Find another power of 10 more than a given number</Construct>

<Answer>\( 999,051 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding powers of 10 adds onto the wrong column</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 8,990,510,000 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer</Construct>

<Question>

Katie says \( \frac{1}{5} \times 9=\frac{9}{45} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a fraction by an integer, multiplies both numerator and denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Misconception>Believes that graphs of inverse proportion meet the axes</Misconception>

One is x+y=3, which goes through (0,3) and (3,0). The other is y=1 which is a horizontal line going through (0,1). Letter A is in the region that is under x+y=3 and above y=1. Letter B is in the region above both lines. Letter C is in the region that is under y=1 and above x+y=3. Letter D is in the region below both lines.]()

<Construct>Construct an angle of 60° using a ruler and a compass</Construct>
<Subject>Construct Triangle</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following best describes how to construct an angle of \( 60^{\circ} \) using a ruler and a pair of compasses?
</Question>
<Answer>- Draw a straight line with a ruler
- Set the compasses to a width at least the length of the line
- Draw an arc above the line and below from one end of the line
- Do the same from the other end of the line 
- Join up where the lines intersect</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes constructing a perpendicular gives an angle of 60 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>

<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
4(m-1)=20
\)
Tom says you can write: \( 4 m=21 \)
Katie says you can write: \( m-1=5 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

</Question>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph in the form (x + p)² + q, work out its completed the square form</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that in completed square form, they need to change the sign of the constant to get the turning point</Misconception>

Who is correct?
</Question>

Jo</Answer>

<Construct>Describe a reflection in a vertical line by drawing the line of reflection, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
![A grid of 8 squares across and 7 squares up.  A blue isosceles triangle, labelled "P", is drawn on the grid. Its corners are at points: 4 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid; 2 squares right and 3 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid; 2 squares right and 5 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid.   Another blue isosceles triangle (identical shape and size to P), labelled "Q", is also drawn on the grid. Its corners are at points: 6 squares right and 3 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid; 6 squares right and 5 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid; 8 squares right and 4 squares up from the bottom left corner of the grid.
A light blue vertical line, labelled "A" goes from top to bottom of the grid, 2 squares to the right of the left-hand side of the grid. A dark blue vertical line, labelled "B" goes from top to bottom of the grid, 4 squares to the right of the left-hand side of the grid. A green vertical line, labelled "C" goes from top to bottom of the grid, 5 squares to the right of the left-hand side of the grid. ]() Which is the correct line of reflection to map triangle \( \mathrm{P} \) to triangle \( \mathrm{Q} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>A</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a line of reflection must be touching the original shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide integers up to 2 digits using long division</Construct>
<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Starts at the wrong end of the dividend when dividing</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide integers up to 2 digits using long division</Construct>
<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>
When using long-division to solve this problem, what digit should replace the triangle to give the correct answer (quotient)? ![Division sum written out in Bus Stop format with dividend = 92, divisor = 4, the digits of the quotient are represented by a yellow star and a purple triangle.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing, confuses the remainder with the quotient</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive y value, find an x value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\[
2 x+3 y=12
\] \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) &  \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up the value of two terms when substituting</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Amy is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (1,-6) \) and \( (-5,2) \) She wants to use a formula.

Which formula should she use?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \left(\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}}{2}, \frac{y_{1}+y_{2}}{2}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses midpoint and distance between two points</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Amy is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (1,-6) \) and \( (-5,2) \) She wants to use a formula.

Which formula should she use?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-x_{1}} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the method for finding the gradient and length of a line segment</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that the probabilities of exhaustive events must sum to 1</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
A bag contains some strawberry sweets, some orange sweets and some blackcurrant sweets.

The probability of choosing a strawberry sweet is \( 0.8 \).

What is the probability of choosing an orange sweet?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that probabilities of an event occurring or not occurring must be equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that the probabilities of exhaustive events must sum to 1</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
A bag contains some strawberry sweets, some orange sweets and some blackcurrant sweets.

The probability of choosing a strawberry sweet is \( 0.8 \).

What is the probability of choosing an orange sweet?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that the probability of something not happening is 1 minus the probability of it happening</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems that combine addition and subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Combining Operations</Subject>
<Question>
Amy is collecting shells on the beach. She collected \( 16 \) shells on Monday. She collected \( 11 \) less shells on Tuesday than on Monday.
How many shells does Amy have altogether?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 27 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than subtracts when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>

<Question>
\( 12^{2}= \)

<Answer>\( 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate questions involving the power law of indices with negative integer powers</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{3}^{\boldsymbol{x}} \)
Tom says there is no value of \( x \) that can make \( y \) negative.
Katie says there is no value of \( x \) that can make \( y \) equal to \( 0 \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a negative power results in a negative answer</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( +3 x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores negative sign when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
The frequency table shows the grade achieved by some students in a maths exam.
How many more students achieved a grade \( 5 \) than a grade \( 1 \) ? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Grade & Frequency \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 10 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores a more than question and just states one of the values</Misconception>

What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 6, y-axis from -4 to 2. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 0), (4, 0), (3, 1). Point (3, 1) is labelled with the letter "P". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Answer>\( y \leq 18 \)</Answer>

\(-\frac{1}{3} y \leq-6\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( y \geq 2 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is 1 </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Vera wants to solve this equation using the quadratic formula.
\(
h^{2}+4=5 h
\)

What should replace the star? \( \frac{ \bigstar\pm \sqrt{?-?}}{?} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When using the formula to solve a quadratic equation, believes that a, b and c are always taken from the 1st, 2nd and 3rd terms, respectively, of the quadratic. </Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is 1 </Construct>

\(
h^{2}+4=5 h
\)

What should replace the star? \( \frac{ \bigstar\pm \sqrt{?-?}}{?} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise a quadratic must be in the form ax^2+bx+c=0 to be factorised</Misconception>

\[

\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( u=5 t-8 \)</Answer>

7 t-13=u(5+2 t)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( u=9 t-8 \)</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>always true</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks terms in linear sequence are in direct proportion</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>never true</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

What distance should replace the star? ![A graph showing Time in seconds on the x axis and Distance in metres on the y axis. A straight line is drawn from the origin to the point (10, \(\bigstar \))]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes distance is the area under the graph on a displacement time graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two independent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Combined Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 4 \) red balls and \( 3 \) yellow balls in a cup. ![The image shows the cup with the 4 red balls and 3 yellow balls.]() Kate picks a yellow ball out and then replaces it.

She then has a second pick.
What is the probability the second pick is also a yellow ball?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes the item has not been replaced in a probability question where it has actually been replaced</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two independent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>

She then has a second pick.
What is the probability the second pick is also a yellow ball?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes the item has not been replaced in a probability question where it has actually been replaced</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading decimals on a number line, assumes each dash is 0.1</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Dora calculates the answer to \( 12.3+4.5 \) mentally ![Image showing a cartoon girl with three thought bubbles above her head. The first bubble states 'I added the whole part first 12+4=16'. The second states 'I then added the decimal part 0.3+0.5=0.8'. The third bubble states 'I then added 16 and 0.8 to get 16.8.So 12.3+4.5=16.8']() Dora uses the same method to calculate \( 3.5+21.8 \). Which of the following shows how she would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}3+21=24 \\ 0.5+0.8=0.13 \\ 24+0.13=24.13\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding decimals, just adds the digits and ignores place value</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Dora calculates the answer to \( 12.3+4.5 \) mentally ![Image showing a cartoon girl with three thought bubbles above her head. The first bubble states 'I added the whole part first 12+4=16'. The second states 'I then added the decimal part 0.3+0.5=0.8'. The third bubble states 'I then added 16 and 0.8 to get 16.8.So 12.3+4.5=16.8']() Dora uses the same method to calculate \( 3.5+21.8 \). Which of the following shows how she would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}3.5+21=24.5 \\ 24.5+0.8=25.3\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not interpret the correct order of operations from a worded problem</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Dora calculates the answer to \( 12.3+4.5 \) mentally ![Image showing a cartoon girl with three thought bubbles above her head. The first bubble states 'I added the whole part first 12+4=16'. The second states 'I then added the decimal part 0.3+0.5=0.8'. The third bubble states 'I then added 16 and 0.8 to get 16.8.So 12.3+4.5=16.8']() Dora uses the same method to calculate \( 3.5+21.8 \). Which of the following shows how she would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}3+21=24 \\ 0.5+0.8=1.3 \\ 24+1.3=24.13\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores place value when adding a whole number and a decimal</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when calculating the area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest 1000</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
A distance has been rounded to the nearest \( \mathrm{km} \), giving \( 106 \) \( \mathrm{km} \).
Which of these values could the distance \( \underline{not} \) be?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 106220 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds up instead of down</Misconception>

Which of these values could the distance \( \underline{not} \) be?

<Answer>\( 105605 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions involving non-linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write this as a single fraction as simply as possible
\(
\frac{2}{m^{2}-4 m+3} \times \frac{m-3}{4}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2 m-6}{4 m^{2}-16 m+12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Expands when asked to simplify</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise an exponential graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a exponential function?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph with two curves, in the top right and bottom left quadrants. The top right curves starts up and right of the origin and travels steeply down and right, it then levels off to travel alongside the x-axis without touching it. The bottom left curve starts down and left of the origin, travels steeply up and left, it then levels off just below the x-axis without touching it.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses reciprocal and exponential graphs</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise an exponential graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a exponential function?
</Question>
<Answer>![A curved graph that starts in the top left, travels steeply down and right, turns to travel steeply up and right, to the origin, where it turns around to travel down and right again.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses cubic and exponential graphs</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise an exponential graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a exponential function?
</Question>
<Answer>![A curved graph, an upside down symmetrical U shape. It starts in the bottom left, travels steeply up and right, turns at a point on the y-axis above the origin and travels steeply right and down.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses quadratic and exponential graphs</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the regions on a double Venn diagram given in words</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
\( 60 \) people completed an online survey about the car they own.
The results are shown in the Venn Diagram.

How many people own a black car? ![A Venn diagram with two circles labelled Owns a 4x4 and Owns a Black Car. The number 27 is in the Owns a 4x4 only region, 15 is in the intersection, and 8 is in the Owns a Black Car only region.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the intersection on a Venn diagram represents the total of one set</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the regions on a double Venn diagram given in words</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
\( 60 \) people completed an online survey about the car they own.
The results are shown in the Venn Diagram.

How many people own a black car? ![A Venn diagram with two circles labelled Owns a 4x4 and Owns a Black Car. The number 27 is in the Owns a 4x4 only region, 15 is in the intersection, and 8 is in the Owns a Black Car only region.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to include the intersection value when asked for total value of a set in a Venn diagram</Misconception>

She starts at the number \( 24,993 \)
what is the next number she will say?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24,992 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts on by 1, when asked to count forward/backwards in a step other than 1</Misconception>

She starts at the number \( 24,993 \)
what is the next number she will say?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24,990 \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( 5 \) and \( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes numbers are divisible by numbers which sum to their factors</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify fractions that simplify to a non-unit fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about simplifying fractions.

Jo says you can never simplify a fraction if either the numerator or denominator is a prime number.

Paul says you will always be able to simplify a fraction if neither the numerator or denominator is prime.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes fractions with prime numerators cannot be simplified</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify fractions that simplify to a non-unit fraction</Construct>

<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about simplifying fractions.

Jo says you can never simplify a fraction if either the numerator or denominator is a prime number.

Paul says you will always be able to simplify a fraction if neither the numerator or denominator is prime.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

<Answer>\( (2,2) \)</Answer>

<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\[
\text { When } h=10 \text { and } j=4
\]

Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}h(j+2)=60 \\ h(2+j)=-60\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise addition is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{8 x}{5}=40
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( 8 x=8 \)
Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{x}{5}=5 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{8 x}{5}=40
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( 8 x=8 \)
Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{x}{5}=5 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing a fraction by an integer, divides both the numerator and denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete a sample space diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Combined Events</Subject>
<Question>
These spinners are spun and the two scores are added together.

Bob records the results in a sample space diagram.
How many cells would contain a score of \( 4 \) ? ![Two 6-sided spinners. Both spinners are split into 6 equal sections with the numbers 1, 3, 3, 5, 5, and 5 in them.]() \begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline & \( 1 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 5 \) & \( 5 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \)  \\
\hline \( 3 \)  \\
\hline \( 5 \)\\
\hline \( 5 \)  \\
\hline \( 5 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to consider all possible outcomes</Misconception>

Who is correct?

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are trying to calculate the answer to \( 19 \times 8 \)
Tom does this: \( 20 \times 8-1 \times 8 \)
Katie does this: \( 10 \times 8+9 \times 8 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the distributive property of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>

\(
p^{2}+4 p
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p-2)(p+2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}+4 p
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p+2)(p+2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise</Misconception>

<Construct>Use prime factor decomposition to find the Lowest Common Multiple of two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
Here is the completed Venn diagram from earlier in the quiz.
What calculation works out the lowest common multiple of \( 36 \) and \( 90 \) ? ![A Venn diagram showing the Prime factors of 36 set and the Prime factors of 90 set. There is a 2 in the prime factors of 36 set, there is 2, 3, 3 in the intersection and there is a 5 in the prime factors of 50 set.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \times 3 \times 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the calculations for HCF and LCM</Misconception>

<Construct>Use prime factor decomposition to find the Lowest Common Multiple of two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
Here is the completed Venn diagram from earlier in the quiz.
What calculation works out the lowest common multiple of \( 36 \) and \( 90 \) ? ![A Venn diagram showing the Prime factors of 36 set and the Prime factors of 90 set. There is a 2 in the prime factors of 36 set, there is 2, 3, 3 in the intersection and there is a 5 in the prime factors of 50 set.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \times 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>forgets to include the common factors when calculating the lowest common multiple</Misconception>

<Construct>Can read Roman numerals between 100 and 1000</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is this CCXLIX?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 271 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the value of a number given in roman numerals, adds the value of all letters together without considering the position of the letter.</Misconception>

<Construct>Can read Roman numerals between 100 and 1000</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is this CCXLIX?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 269 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the value of a number given in roman numerals, adds the value of all letters together without considering the position of the letter.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square root of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are discussing the table of values for \( \boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{x}^{2} \) \begin{tabular}{|l|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Jo says the star could be \( 16 \).
Paul says the star could be \( -2 \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>Squares when asked to find the square root</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal place to percentages</Construct>

<Question>
Write \( 0.07 \) as a percentage.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 70 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the value of zeros as placeholders</Misconception>

<Question>
Write \( 0.07 \) as a percentage.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.07 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you need to just add a % sign to a decimal to convert to a percentage</Misconception>

\[

\] ![A table with two rows and two columns. The top left box has 'x', top right has a star, the bottom left box has 'y', bottom right has '-1'. ]() What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up the value of two terms when substituting</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators involve linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write this as a single fraction as simply as possible: \( \frac{5}{x-3} \times \frac{x^{2}}{2 y} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{10 y}{x^{2}(x-3)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>when multiplying fractions multiplies by the reciprocal of the 2nd fraction instead</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators involve linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write this as a single fraction as simply as possible: \( \frac{5}{x-3} \times \frac{x^{2}}{2 y} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5 x^{2}}{x-6 y} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies second term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic fractions where the numerators and denominators involve linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write this as a single fraction as simply as possible: \( \frac{5}{x-3} \times \frac{x^{2}}{2 y} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5 x^{2}}{2 x y-3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Question>
What is the next term of this linear sequence?
\[
3,9,15,21, \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 22 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for the next term in the sequence adds one to the last term given, despite the sequence not going up in ones.</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem P: \( (4+5)^{2}= \)
Problem Q: \( 4+5^{2}= \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem P: \( 4+5 \)
Problem Q: \( 4+5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Problem P: \( (4+5)^{2}= \)
Problem Q: \( 4+5^{2}= \)

Which calculation should you do first in each problem?
</Question>
<Answer>Problem P: \( 5^{2} \)
Problem Q: \( 5^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(12 d-3=6 d+3\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( d=0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a number divided by itself equals 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(12 d-3=6 d+3\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( d=-1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(12 d-3=6 d+3\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( d=\frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

\( (-3)-5= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting from a negative thinks the answer must be positive</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline TVs & Frequency & TVs \( \times \) Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 5 \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 8 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 7 \) & \( 14 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) & \( 12 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 4 \) & \( 16 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} The table shows the numbers of TVs in the households of students in a class.

What does the "14" represent?
</Question>
<Answer>The total number of TVs in the \( 2 \) households</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the variable and frequency columns in a frequency table</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline TVs & Frequency & TVs \( \times \) Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 5 \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 8 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 7 \) & \( 14 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) & \( 12 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 4 \) & \( 16 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} The table shows the numbers of TVs in the households of students in a class.

What does the "14" represent?
</Question>
<Answer>The mean number of TVs in the \( 7 \) households</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the interpretation of the fx column in a frequency table</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a linear graph solve f(x) = n</Construct>

<Question>
This is a graph of
\(y=4 x-1\) ![A set of axes with y=4x-1 drawn on.]() Use the graph to solve
\(4 x-1=-3\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=0.25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solution to mx + c = a is the x intercept of y = mx +c</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \frac{3}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, multiplies both the numerator and denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a linear graph solve f(x) = n</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x=2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks they solve mx + c = a, by substituting in the value of a for x and therefore calculating ma + c</Misconception>

<Answer>\( y=(1-x)(5-x) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Answer>\( y=(x-1)(x+5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a positive x squared coefficient in a quadratic equation results in an n shaped graph</Misconception>

<Question>
![A number line going from -8 up to 7]() Asha's office is on level \( 7 \).
Her car is parked in the basement on level \( -2 \).

How many floors does Asha need to go down to get from the office to her car?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts the starting number when counting backwards</Misconception>

<Construct>Count backwards through zero starting from a positive integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![A number line going from -8 up to 7]() Asha's office is on level \( 7 \).
Her car is parked in the basement on level \( -2 \).

How many floors does Asha need to go down to get from the office to her car?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the difference between a positive number and a negative number is equal to the positive number</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)²</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following answers shows a correct expansion and simplification of the expression below? \( (x-4)^{2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}+16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they only need to multiply the first and last pairs of terms when expanding double brackets</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}-8 x-16 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Ron calculates the answer to \( 46+28 \) mentally "\( 46+20 \) is equal to \( 66 \). Then I am going to add on the \( 8\). \(66+8=74 \)" Ron uses the same method to calculate \( 37+56 \). Which of the following shows how he would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}37+6=43 \\ 43+50=93\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not copy a given method accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Ron calculates the answer to \( 46+28 \) mentally "\( 46+20 \) is equal to \( 66 \). Then I am going to add on the \( 8\). \(66+8=74 \)" Ron uses the same method to calculate \( 37+56 \). Which of the following shows how he would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}30+50=80 \\ 7+6=13 \\ 80+13=93\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not copy a given method accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Ron calculates the answer to \( 46+28 \) mentally "\( 46+20 \) is equal to \( 66 \). Then I am going to add on the \( 8\). \(66+8=74 \)" Ron uses the same method to calculate \( 37+56 \). Which of the following shows how he would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}7+6=13 \\ 30+13=43 \\ 43+50=93\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not copy a given method accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
What is the mean shoe size? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Shoe Size \( (\mathrm{s}) \) & Frequency \( (f) \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 6 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>B \( \quad 5.65 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mean is total divided by sum of categories given</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
What is the mean shoe size? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Shoe Size \( (\mathrm{s}) \) & Frequency \( (f) \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 6 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>C \( \quad \mathbf{1 . 5 0} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mean is total frequency divided by sum of categories given</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
What is the mean shoe size? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Shoe Size \( (\mathrm{s}) \) & Frequency \( (f) \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 6 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>D \( \quad 22.6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes mean is total divided by number of groups</Misconception>

<Construct>Count a number of objects</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\[
1,3,5,7, \ldots ?
\]

Which pattern matches the sequence above?
</Question>
<Answer>![A sequence of 4 patterns. The first pattern is 1 green dot. The second pattern is green dots arranged in a 2 by 2 square shape. The third pattern is green dots arranged in a 3 by 3 square shape. The fourth pattern is green dots arranged in a 4 by 4 square shape. ]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When given a linear sequence, cannot match it to a visual pattern</Misconception>

<Construct>Count a number of objects</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\[
1,3,5,7, \ldots ?
\]

Which pattern matches the sequence above?
</Question>
<Answer>![A sequence of 4 patterns. The first pattern is one small cube. The other patterns are larger cubes made from small cubes like the one in the first pattern: Pattern 2 is a cube of width 2; Pattern 3 is a cube of width 3; Pattern 4 is a cube of width 4.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When given a linear sequence, cannot match it to a visual pattern</Misconception>

<Construct>Count a number of objects</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\[
1,3,5,7, \ldots ?
\]

Which pattern matches the sequence above?
</Question>
<Answer>![A sequence of 4 patterns. The first pattern is one blue dot. The other patterns are triangles, made from blue dots like the one in the first pattern: Pattern 2 has 2 dots on the bottom and 1 dot above these; Pattern 3 is the same as Pattern 2 but with 3 extra dots that form a 3rd row at the bottom; Pattern 4 is the same as Pattern 3 but with 4 extra dots forming a 4th row at the bottom.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
Paige, Kaci and David want to find the area of the school playground. They each do it a different way. Who is correct? ![A compound shape making an L shape. The full width across the bottom is 9m, the partial width on the top is 5m. The full height on the left is 10m, the partial height on the right is 6m.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Paige: \( 10 \times 6+5 \times 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot identify the correct side lengths to use when asked to find the area of a face</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
Paige, Kaci and David want to find the area of the school playground. They each do it a different way. Who is correct? ![A compound shape making an L shape. The full width across the bottom is 9m, the partial width on the top is 5m. The full height on the left is 10m, the partial height on the right is 6m.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Kaci: \( 10 \times 5+9 \times 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify questions involving a 2D right-angled triangle that require the use of the Tangent (tan) ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Right-angled Triangles (SOHCAHTOA)</Subject>
<Question>
Which ratio would you use to find the value of \( \theta \) ? ![A right angled triangle with the two shorter sides marked as 7cm and 10cm. The angle opposite the 10 cm side is labelled with θ. The longest side of the triangle has no label.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Sin</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses sin when tan is required</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify questions involving a 2D right-angled triangle that require the use of the Tangent (tan) ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Right-angled Triangles (SOHCAHTOA)</Subject>
<Question>
Which ratio would you use to find the value of \( \theta \) ? ![A right angled triangle with the two shorter sides marked as 7cm and 10cm. The angle opposite the 10 cm side is labelled with θ. The longest side of the triangle has no label.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Cos</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses cos when tan is required</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify questions involving a 2D right-angled triangle that require the use of the Tangent (tan) ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Right-angled Triangles (SOHCAHTOA)</Subject>
<Question>
Which ratio would you use to find the value of \( \theta \) ? ![A right angled triangle with the two shorter sides marked as 7cm and 10cm. The angle opposite the 10 cm side is labelled with θ. The longest side of the triangle has no label.]()
</Question>
<Answer>None of these</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand how to apply sohcahtoa</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to one decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
Round \( 27.48 \) to one decimal place
</Question>
<Answer>\( 27.4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to one decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
Round \( 27.48 \) to one decimal place
</Question>
<Answer>\( 27 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find the Lowest Common Multiple to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Sophie is organising a charity hot dog sale.
There are \( 18 \) bread rolls in each packet.
There are \( 15 \) hot dogs in each packet.
Sophie buys exactly the same number of bread rolls as hot dogs.
What is the smallest number of each packet that Sophie can buy?

To solve this problem you need to work out the \( ___ \) of \( 18 \) and \( 15 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Product</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the word "product"</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find the Lowest Common Multiple to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Sophie is organising a charity hot dog sale.
There are \( 18 \) bread rolls in each packet.
There are \( 15 \) hot dogs in each packet.
Sophie buys exactly the same number of bread rolls as hot dogs.
What is the smallest number of each packet that Sophie can buy?

To solve this problem you need to work out the \( ___ \) of \( 18 \) and \( 15 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Sum</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the word "sum"</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find the Lowest Common Multiple to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Sophie is organising a charity hot dog sale.
There are \( 18 \) bread rolls in each packet.
There are \( 15 \) hot dogs in each packet.
Sophie buys exactly the same number of bread rolls as hot dogs.
What is the smallest number of each packet that Sophie can buy?

To solve this problem you need to work out the \( ___ \) of \( 18 \) and \( 15 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Highest Common Factor</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the use of LCM and HCF in real life examples </Misconception>

Katie</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>\( -1.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the gradient of a line is given by the x intercept</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems involving subtracting a period of time from a given end time</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
What time is \( 30 \) minutes before midnight?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 11: 30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes times in the afternoon as if they are morning on a 24 hour clock</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems involving subtracting a period of time from a given end time</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
What time is \( 30 \) minutes before midnight?
</Question>
<Answer>11:30 am</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that times just before midnight are "am" times</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for an ascending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the first five terms of a sequence ![\( \begin{array}{llllll}3 & 5 & 7 & 9 & 11 & \ldots\end{array} \)]() Find an expression for the \( n \)th term of this sequence.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks terms in linear sequence are in direct proportion</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for an ascending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the first five terms of a sequence ![\( \begin{array}{llllll}3 & 5 & 7 & 9 & 11 & \ldots\end{array} \)]() Find an expression for the \( n \)th term of this sequence.
</Question>
<Answer>Double, add \( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes nth term rule can be given in words</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out missing number subtraction problems involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Number line with -7 and -5 marked on it. From the -7 there is an arrow to the right labelled +5. Then there is an arrow pointing to the left labelled b and ending at -5.]() What is the value of \( b \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts the starting number when counting backwards</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving negative decimals</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(\frac{5 x}{3}-1=-2.4\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( 5 x-3=-7.2 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{5 x}{3}=-3.4 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{11} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, adds the numerators and the denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate: \( \frac{1}{8} \times \frac{1}{3} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{8} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides rather than multiplies </Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate: \( \frac{1}{8} \times \frac{1}{3} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{11} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, multiplies the numerator and adds the denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>

\[

\]

Tom says \( m \) could be \( 2.5 \)

Katie says \( m \) could be \( 3 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>

<Question>

\[
20 \geq 8 m
\]

Tom says \( m \) could be \( 2.5 \)

Katie says \( m \) could be \( 3 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>When using inequality notation, thinks "greater than/less than or equal to" symbols are instead the "greater than/less than" symbols and vice versa</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 2 m-2 m \)</Answer>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
9-8+5
\]
Jo and Paul are trying to make the calculation above equal to \( 6 \).
Jo says you can write it like this: \( 9-(8+5) \)
Paul says you can leave it like this: \( 9-8+5 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
9-8+5
\]
Jo and Paul are trying to make the calculation above equal to \( 6 \).
Jo says you can write it like this: \( 9-(8+5) \)
Paul says you can leave it like this: \( 9-8+5 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers order of operations questions with brackets as if the brackets are not there</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
9-8+5
\]
Jo and Paul are trying to make the calculation above equal to \( 6 \).
Jo says you can write it like this: \( 9-(8+5) \)
Paul says you can leave it like this: \( 9-8+5 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)</Misconception>

Katie</Answer>

\hline

<Construct>Perform calculations with temperature when given in the same units</Construct>

</Question>

hotter than
\[
-5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores the negative sign</Misconception>

<Construct>Perform calculations with temperature when given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>

<Answer>\( 2^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is \( 7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) colder than
\[
-5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up colder and hotter when comparing temperatures</Misconception>

\[

\]

</Question>
<Answer>\( 7+6 \)</Answer>

\[
10-8 \times 7+6=
\]

</Question>
<Answer>\( 10-8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
10-8 \times 7+6=
\]

Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>It doesn't matter: you get the same answer</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes order of operations does not affect the answer to a calculation</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just one linear variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify, if possible:
\[
z+5
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 z \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that two letters together, or a number and letter together, are multiplying</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just one linear variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify, if possible:
\[
z+5
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( z^{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes addition of terms and powers of terms are equivalent e.g. a + c = a^c</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify or mark lines of symmetry on a shape</Construct>
<Subject>Line Symmetry</Subject>
<Question>
Which shape has a line of symmetry? ![A Trapezium above the label "A"; A shape which is a circle with a 90 degree sector removed above the label "B"; A crescent (moon) shape above the label "C"; the words "All of them" above the label "D".]()
</Question>
<Answer>A</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes lines of symmetry must be vertical or horizontal</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 270° and 360°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of the marked angle? ![A 360 degree protractor with 2 red lines and a pink sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The inner scale goes from 0 to 360 anti-clockwise. The angle is a reflex angle that is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the protractor, anti-clockwise to the red line that is half way between 280 and 290 (inner scale) and halfway between 260 and 250 (outer scale).
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 255^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring reflex angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{P} \) ? ![Four quadrant, coordinate grid with the reflection line y=x drawn and a triangle. The triangle has coordinates: (0,1) (0,3) and (-3,2). The point P is the coordinate (0,3)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (0,2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reflects horizontally or vertically instead of across a diagonal line of symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>

The middle rectangle has "-4" written inside it and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "11" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?

<Answer>\( -7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 44 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of subtraction is multiplication</Misconception>

\(1-0.4 x=0\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solution of mx + c = 0 is x =0</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a linear graph solve f(x) = 0</Construct>

\(y=1-0.4 x\) ![A set of axes with y=1-0.4x drawn on.]() Use the graph to solve
\(1-0.4 x=0\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they solve mx + c = 0 by substituting in x = 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a linear graph solve f(x) = 0</Construct>

<Construct>Represent a linear inequality in the form a ≤ x ≤ b (and other sign arrangements) on a numberline</Construct>

<Question>
Which number line represents \( -1 \leq x<3 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![Number line with numbers from -5 to 5. Above the -1 is a blue, filled circle with an arrow to the left. Above the 3 is an open, unfilled circle with an arrow to the right.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Represent a linear inequality in the form a ≤ x ≤ b (and other sign arrangements) on a numberline</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which number line represents \( -1 \leq x<3 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![Number line with numbers from -5 to 5. Above the -1 is an open,  unfilled circle and above the 3 is a green, filled circle. The two circles are joined by a horizontal line.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When representing an inequality on a numberline, assumes the filled and unfilled circles have the opposite meaning.</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand:
\[
3(p-1)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 p-1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand:
\[
3(p-1)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( p-3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies second term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Expand:
\[
3(p-1)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 p-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When expanding brackets, multiplies out the first term correctly but adds together the number outside the bracket with the second term inside the bracket.</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 3 m+2 \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( 6 m+1 \)</Answer>

![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left has "input" written above it and "3m + 1" written inside it. </Question>
<Answer>\( 6 m+3 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Nick wants to subtract \( 199 \) from a number.
Which one of the following methods would give him the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( +200 \) then \( +1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the effect of consecutive operations</Misconception>

<Answer>\( -200 \) then \( -1 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline TVs & Frequency & TVs \( \times \) Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 8 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 8 \) & \( 16 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) & \( 12 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} The table shows the numbers of TVs in the households of students in a class.

What does the "16" represent?
</Question>
<Answer>The mean number of TVs in the \( 8 \) households</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the interpretation of the fx column in a frequency table</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret numbers in a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline TVs & Frequency & TVs \( \times \) Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 8 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 8 \) & \( 16 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) & \( 12 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 8 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} The table shows the numbers of TVs in the households of students in a class.

What does the "16" represent?
</Question>
<Answer>The total number of TVs in the \( 2 \) households</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the variable and frequency columns in a frequency table</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about rounding.

Jo says \( \mathbf{9 9 . 9 6} \) rounded to \( 1 \) significant figure is \( \mathbf{1 0 0} \)

Paul says \( \mathbf{9 9 . 9 6} \) rounded to \( 1 \) decimal place is \( \mathbf{1 0 0} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>When rounding to decimal places and the only digits after the decimal point will be zeros, just gives the integer as the answer.</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and three or more steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing rearranging \( t=\sqrt{u+9} \) to make \( u \) the subject
Tom says a correct first line of working could be: \( t=\sqrt{u}+3 \)
Katie says a correct first line of working could be: \( t^{2}=u+9 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that the square root of an expression square roots each term in the expression, rather than square rooting the whole expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and three or more steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>

Tom says a correct first line of working could be: \( t=\sqrt{u}+3 \)
Katie says a correct first line of working could be: \( t^{2}=u+9 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that the square root of an expression square roots each term in the expression, rather than square rooting the whole expression</Misconception>

\( 0.5 \div 2= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of divides</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = ax² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\[y=3 x^{2}\] \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0.3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.81 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = ax² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>

\[y=3 x^{2}\] \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0.3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Question>

\( 95365 \)

<Answer>\( 10000 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
Round this number to \( 1 \) significant figure:
\( 95365 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 90000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 20.15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

What is \( 20.15349 \) rounded to \( 3 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20.253 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds incorrectly by changing multiple place values</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1 </Construct>
