\(
3 h^{2}-10 h+4=0
\)

What should replace the circle? \( \frac{? \pm \sqrt{?-?}}{\bigcirc} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misremembers the quadratic formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1 </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Vera wants to solve this equation using the quadratic formula.
\(
3 h^{2}-10 h+4=0
\)

What should replace the circle? \( \frac{? \pm \sqrt{?-?}}{\bigcirc} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a variable next to a number means addition rather than multiplication</Misconception>

\)

<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Recognise when to find a factor to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Emma has \( 24 \) cakes to give away to her friends.
To work out what numbers of friends Emma could give equal amounts of cake to without having any cakes left over, Emma needs to know the ___ of \( 24 \)
</Question>
<Answer>digits</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise when to find a factor from a worded question</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find a factor to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Emma has \( 24 \) cakes to give away to her friends.
To work out what numbers of friends Emma could give equal amounts of cake to without having any cakes left over, Emma needs to know the ___ of \( 24 \)
</Question>
<Answer>multiples</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses factors and multiples</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find a factor to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
Emma has \( 24 \) cakes to give away to her friends.
To work out what numbers of friends Emma could give equal amounts of cake to without having any cakes left over, Emma needs to know the ___ of \( 24 \)
</Question>
<Answer>reciprocal</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise when to find a factor from a worded question</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
The table below is a summary of the number of spots counted on \( 20 \) ladybirds. Calculate the mean number of spots per ladybird. ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}

Number of Spots & Frequency \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 6 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 7 \) & \( 12 \) \\
\hline \( 8 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.2(1 \mathrm{dp}) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mean is total frequency divided by sum of categories given</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
The table below is a summary of the number of spots counted on \( 20 \) ladybirds. Calculate the mean number of spots per ladybird. ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}

Number of Spots & Frequency \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 6 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 7 \) & \( 12 \) \\
\hline \( 8 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 32.75 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes mean is total divided by number of groups</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
The table below is a summary of the number of spots counted on \( 20 \) ladybirds. Calculate the mean number of spots per ladybird. ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}

Number of Spots & Frequency \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 6 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 7 \) & \( 12 \) \\
\hline \( 8 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6.5(1 \mathrm{dp}) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
How would you describe the movement to get from the star to the triangle? ![Positive coordinate grid from 0 to 5 in the x and y directions with a gold star at (1,4) and a purple triangle at (4,3)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \) squares right,
\( 1 \) square down</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares.</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
How would you describe the movement to get from the star to the triangle? ![Positive coordinate grid from 0 to 5 in the x and y directions with a gold star at (1,4) and a purple triangle at (4,3)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \) squares down,
\( 1 \) square right</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, identifies the correct number of jumps but mixes up the directions .</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
When factorising \( x^{2}+6 x+8 \) we need two numbers that:
</Question>
<Answer>Add to give \( 6 x \) and multiply to give \( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising into double brackets, believes the sum of the two values in the brackets equals bx rather than b</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
When factorising \( x^{2}+6 x+8 \) we need two numbers that:
</Question>
<Answer>Add to give \( 8 \) and multiply to give \( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that to factorise a quadratic expression, to find two numbers that add to give the coefficient of the x term, and multiply to give the non variable term
</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify and represent sets using set notation</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the probability spinner

Tom says the sample space can be written as: \( S=\{1,2\} \)

Katie says the sample space can be written as: \( S=\{1,1,2,2,2\} \)
Who do you agree with? ![Circle divided into 5 equal sections. 2 sections labelled with a blue number 1. 3 sections labelled with a red number 2.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a sample space should show repeated outcomes, not just unique possible outcomes.</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name a formula</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most appropriate word to describe: \( A=\frac{b h}{2} \) ![A triangle with base labelled b and height labelled h.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Equation</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a formula with an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name a formula</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most appropriate word to describe: \( A=\frac{b h}{2} \) ![A triangle with base labelled b and height labelled h.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Variable</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a variable with a formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Determine if a given point lies on a line</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about points on the line
\[
y=2 x-3
\]

Tom says \( (5,7) \) lies on the line \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2} \boldsymbol{x}-\mathbf{3} \)

Katie says \( (-5,-7) \) lies on the line \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2 x}-\mathbf{3} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtracting a positive number from a negative number makes the answer less negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) &   
\end{tabular} This is a table of values for \( 4 x+2 y=10 \) 
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) &   
\end{tabular} This is a table of values for \( 4 x+2 y=10 \) 
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes 0 multiplied by a number gives the number</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) &   
\end{tabular} This is a table of values for \( 4 x+2 y=10 \) 
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up the value of two terms when substituting</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute a solution back into the remaining equation and find the second solution</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is halfway through solving a pair of simultaneous equations, one of which is below.

\(
2 j-k=-10
\)

Isaac found that \( k=8 \)
What does \( j \) equal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( j=1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes dividing a negative by a positive gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute a solution back into the remaining equation and find the second solution</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is halfway through solving a pair of simultaneous equations, one of which is below.

\(
2 j-k=-10
\)

Isaac found that \( k=8 \)
What does \( j \) equal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( j=9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores the negative signs when adding positive and negative numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - bx - c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about factorising. Tom says \( x^{2}+5 x+6 \equiv(x+3)(x+2) \) 
Katie says \( x^{2}-5 x-6 \equiv(x-3)(x-2) \) 
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 90 \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( 92 \)</Answer>

What is the \( 5^{\text {th }} \) number he says?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -28 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts on in the wrong direction on a number line</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing this sequence. ![The first 3 patterns in a sequence are shown. The first pattern is a blue rectangle with 6 yellow circles attached to its perimeter: 2 circles on each of the longer sides and 1 circle on each of the shorter sides. 
Pattern 2 is made up of 2 blue rectangles, attached together in a row by their short edges. There are also 10 yellow circles in this pattern, attached to the perimeter of the rectangles: 2 circles on every longer side of each rectangle and 1 circle on each of the two free shorter sides (i.e. that are not attached to the other rectangle). 
Pattern 3 is made up of 3 blue rectangles, attached together in a row by their short edges. There are also 14 yellow circles in this pattern, attached to the perimeter of the rectangles: 2 circles on every longer side of each rectangle and 1 circle on each of the two free shorter sides (i.e. that are not attached to another rectangle).]() Tom says the number of circles in the \( 10^{\text {th }} \) term will be 
double the number of circles in the \( 5^{\text {th }} \) term.

Katie says the number of rectangles in the \( 10^{\text {th }} \) term will be 
double the number of rectangles in the \( 5^{\text {th }} \) term.

Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes there is a multiplicative relationship between values of terms in a linear sequence e.g. 10th term is double 5th term</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the relationship between parts of a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about the information on the right.

Tom says there are \( 9 \) times as many students as teachers.

Katie says one in ten people are teachers.
Who is correct? On a school trip, the ratio of teachers to students is:
teachers : students
\(
1: 9
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that in the ratio 1:n the total number of parts would be 1+n </Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the relationship between parts of a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about the information on the right.

Tom says there are \( 9 \) times as many students as teachers.

Katie says one in ten people are teachers.
Who is correct? On a school trip, the ratio of teachers to students is:
teachers : students
\(
1: 9
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that in a ratio 1:n that one part of the ratio would be n times bigger than the one part</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the relationship between parts of a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about the information on the right.

Tom says there are \( 9 \) times as many students as teachers.

Katie says one in ten people are teachers.
Who is correct? On a school trip, the ratio of teachers to students is:
teachers : students
\(
1: 9
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that in the ratio 1:n the total number of parts would be 1+n </Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out the first stage in an iteration solution</Construct>
<Subject>Trial and Improvement and Iterative Methods</Subject>
<Question>
\(
x_{n+1}=10-\frac{1}{x_{n}}
\)

Using a starting value of \( x_{1}=4 \), what is the value of \( x_{2} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9.8974 \ldots \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the term after</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph in the form (x + p)² + q, work out its completed the square form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Completing the Square Form</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this curve? ![A set of axes with a quadratic graph drawn on. The graph is y=x^2 translated 2 squares to the left and 5 squares down.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x+2)^{2}+5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can square root a negative number</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph in the form (x + p)² + q, work out its completed the square form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Completing the Square Form</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this curve? ![A set of axes with a quadratic graph drawn on. The graph is y=x^2 translated 2 squares to the left and 5 squares down.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x-2)^{2}+5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can square root a negative number</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph in the form (x + p)² + q, work out its completed the square form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Completing the Square Form</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this curve? ![A set of axes with a quadratic graph drawn on. The graph is y=x^2 translated 2 squares to the left and 5 squares down.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x-2)^{2}-5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that in completed square form, the x co-ordinate of the turning point has the same sign as the constant in the brackets.</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify perpendicular lines written in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Perpendicular Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following lines is perpendicular to
\[
y=2 x+1 \text { ? }
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=2 x-1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the meaning of parallel and perpendicular</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify perpendicular lines written in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Perpendicular Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following lines is perpendicular to
\[
y=2 x+1 \text { ? }
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=2 y+1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes switching the x and y variables in a linear equation gives a perpendicular line</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify perpendicular lines written in the form y = mx + c</Construct>

<Question>
Which of the following lines is perpendicular to
\[
y=2 x+1 \text { ? }
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=\frac{1}{2} x-3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the gradients of perpendicular lines are reciprocals of the same sign</Misconception>

<Question>

Tom says \( 82 \times 4<320 \)
Katie says \( 41 \times 8>320 \)
Without calculating the exact answers, who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes rounding numbers down would give an overestimate</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of a number</Construct>

<Question>

All numbers have an even number of factors because factors come in pairs

Tom says a counter-example is \( 24 \)

Katie says a counter-example is \( 16 \)

</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Chooses an example when asked for a counter-example</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 less than a given number</Construct>

<Question>
What number is \( 100 \) less than \( 325,076 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3250.76 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides rather than subtracts when given the command 'less than'</Misconception>

<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 325,176 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than subtracts when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 less than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 324,076 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a power of 10, subtracts from the wrong column</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve coordinate geometry questions involving ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>

\[
A B: B C \text { ? }
\] ![A line AC which is 10 units long. B is on it so that AB:BC is 1:2]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1: 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks ratios are written as 1:total</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when a square root is a surd and when it is not</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Surds</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is not a surd?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{45} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a surd will simplify to a whole number and not longer be a surd if the number under the surd is a square number</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{47} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a surd will simplify to a whole number and not longer be a surd if the number under the surd is a square number</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>

\(
3 \times 5+4-2
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs addition ahead of multiplication</Misconception>

\(
3 \times 5+4-2
\)

<Question>

\(
3 \times 5+4-2
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape</Construct>
<Subject>Rotational Symmetry</Subject>
<Question>
![This shape is a line drawing of 2 ellipses whose centres, marked with a black dot, are lined up, but one ellipse is at right angles to the other.]() What is the order of rotational symmetry of this shape?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find order of rotational symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the order of rotational symmetry of a shape</Construct>
<Subject>Rotational Symmetry</Subject>
<Question>
![This shape is a line drawing of 2 ellipses whose centres, marked with a black dot, are lined up, but one ellipse is at right angles to the other.]() What is the order of rotational symmetry of this shape?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find order of rotational symmetry</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find order of rotational symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a missing term of a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{lclclclc|c|} \hline \(\bigstar\) & \( \;\) & 712 & \( \;\) &  \( \;\)\end{tabular} A descending linear sequence has a constant difference of \( 22 \) and the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term is \( 712 \).
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 734 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the next term</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a missing term of a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>

<Question>
\begin{tabular}{lclclclc|c|} \hline \(\bigstar\) & \( \;\) & 712 & \( \;\) &  \( \;\)\end{tabular} A descending linear sequence has a constant difference of \( 22 \) and the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term is \( 712 \).
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 690 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the next term</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a missing term of a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{lclclclc|c|} \hline \(\bigstar\) & \( \;\) & 712 & \( \;\) &  \( \;\)\end{tabular} A descending linear sequence has a constant difference of \( 22 \) and the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term is \( 712 \).
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 668 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you subtract rather than add when finding the previous term in a descending linear sequence</Misconception>

<Subject>Written Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
\( 4514-328= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4214 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts the smallest digit from the largest digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows how much a block of ice melted over time. ![A line graph with the x-axis titled "Time (minutes)". The x-axis scale is labelled from 0 to 5 in steps of 1 minute.
The y-axis is titled "Water depth (cm)" and the scale is labelled from 0 to 12 in steps of 2. The following points are plotted and joined together: (0, 0),(1,1),(2, 3),(3, 6),(4, 9),(5, 10).      
]() What was the difference between the first minute and third minute?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not include units in answer.</Misconception>

This graph shows how much a block of ice melted over time. ![A line graph with the x-axis titled "Time (minutes)". The x-axis scale is labelled from 0 to 5 in steps of 1 minute.
The y-axis is titled "Water depth (cm)" and the scale is labelled from 0 to 12 in steps of 2. The following points are plotted and joined together: (0, 0),(1,1),(2, 3),(3, 6),(4, 9),(5, 10).      
]() What was the difference between the first minute and third minute?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the command word 'difference'</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to work out the answer to \( \frac{5}{6}-\frac{1}{3} \)
Tom says you could change both denominators to \( 6 \)
Katie says you could change both denominators to \( 18 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a common denominator can only be the lowest common multiple</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to work out the answer to \( \frac{5}{6}-\frac{1}{3} \)
Tom says you could change both denominators to \( 6 \)
Katie says you could change both denominators to \( 18 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a common denominator must always be the two denominators multiplied together</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to work out the answer to \( \frac{5}{6}-\frac{1}{3} \)
Tom says you could change both denominators to \( 6 \)
Katie says you could change both denominators to \( 18 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand equivalent fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Change an integer base number to another integer base number with a positive integer power</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about powers.
Jo says \( 9^{4}=3^{8} \)
Paul says \( 9^{4}=3^{2} \times 3^{2} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you multiply matching bases when carrying out a multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Change an integer base number to another integer base number with a positive integer power</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about powers.
Jo says \( 9^{4}=3^{8} \)
Paul says \( 9^{4}=3^{2} \times 3^{2} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks powers with different bases cannot be equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret horizontal sections of a displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows how far Jodie is from home whilst she is out on a walk.
What might the horizontal represent? ![The image is a distance-time graph. The graph is in three sections. The first section starts at (0,0) and is a sloped line with positive gradient. The second section is a horizontal line. The third section is a sloped line with negative gradient that ends when it touches the Time axis.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Jodie is accelerating</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses rest and movement on a distance time graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret horizontal sections of a displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows how far Jodie is from home whilst she is out on a walk.
What might the horizontal represent? ![The image is a distance-time graph. The graph is in three sections. The first section starts at (0,0) and is a sloped line with positive gradient. The second section is a horizontal line. The third section is a sloped line with negative gradient that ends when it touches the Time axis.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Jodie is walking away from home</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses rest and movement on a distance time graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret horizontal sections of a displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows how far Jodie is from home whilst she is out on a walk.
What might the horizontal represent? ![The image is a distance-time graph. The graph is in three sections. The first section starts at (0,0) and is a sloped line with positive gradient. The second section is a horizontal line. The third section is a sloped line with negative gradient that ends when it touches the Time axis.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Jodie is walking towards home</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses rest and movement on a distance time graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>

<Question>
Expand \( 4(3 c+2) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 c+6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When expanding brackets, multiplies out the first term correctly but adds together the number outside the bracket with the second term inside the bracket.</Misconception>

<Question>
Expand \( 4(3 c+2) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 c+2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from hours to minutes</Construct>

<Question>
A school trip lasted \( 5 \) hours and \( 25 \) minutes. How long is this in minutes?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 525 \) minutes</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when changing from hours to minutes</Misconception>

<Question>
A school trip lasted \( 5 \) hours and \( 25 \) minutes. How long is this in minutes?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5.25 \) minutes</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when writing minutes as decimals</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds unit amount but doesn't multiply up</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pie chart</Construct>

<Question>
The pie chart shows colours of motorbikes in a shop.

There are \( \mathbf{3 0} \) more blue bikes than white. How many bikes are there altogether? ![Pie chart with 8 equal sections. One section is black, one white, three green and three blue.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 240 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using long multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
Which working out is correct for $72 \times 36$?
</Question>
<Answer>![ Long multiplication for 72 multiplied by 36 with incorrect working and incorrect final answer. First row of working is incorrect: 4 2 2. Second row of working is incorrect: 2 7. Final answer is incorrect: 4 4 9.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits multiply to 10 or more during a multiplication problem, does not add carried value to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using long multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
Which working out is correct for $72 \times 36$?
</Question>
<Answer>![ Long multiplication for 72 multiplied by 36 with incorrect working and incorrect final answer. First row of working is correct: 4 3 2. Second row of working is incorrect: 2 1 6. Final answer is incorrect: 6 4 8.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not write the place holder zero when doing column multiplication</Misconception>

<Subject>Block Graphs and Bar Charts</Subject>
<Question>

How many cups of coffee were sold on Wednesday? ![A dual bar chart showing number of cups of tea and coffee sold Monday to Thursday. On Monday 25 teas and 38 coffees sold, Tuesday 10 teas and 45 coffees, Wednesday 25 teas and 30 coffees, Thursday 43 teas and 40 coffees.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading graph, chooses nearest marked value on axis instead of reading accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing mental addition and subtraction strategies.

Tom says a good way to add \( 9 \) is to add \( 10 \) and then subtract \( 1 \).

Katie says a good way to subtract \( 9 \) is to subtract \( 10 \) and then subtract \( 1 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the effect of consecutive subtractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental subtraction</Construct>

<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing mental addition and subtraction strategies.

Tom says a good way to add \( 9 \) is to add \( 10 \) and then subtract \( 1 \).

Katie says a good way to subtract \( 9 \) is to subtract \( 10 \) and then subtract \( 1 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the effect of consecutive operations</Misconception>

\)

\)

<Answer>\( 0.2975 \ldots \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the term after</Misconception>

\end{tabular} What should replace the star?

<Construct>Perform calculations with temperature when given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Which statement about the temperatures \( -7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) and \( 5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is \( 2^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) 
colder than 
\( -7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that 7 and -7 are different</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 5^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) is \( 12^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \) 
colder than 
\( -7^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up colder and hotter when comparing temperatures</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring no scaling of expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the following pair of simultaneous equations: \( \begin{array}{l}3 x+2 y=14 \\ 2 x+2 y=10\end{array} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}x=4 \\ y=2\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, believes that when they get to ax = b, b is the solution</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify command words that mean addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
For which of these questions would you calculate \( 50+25 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>Decrease \( 50 \) by \( 25 \).</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than subtracts when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify command words that mean addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
For which of these questions would you calculate \( 50+25 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>Find the product of \( 50 \) and \( 25 \).</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than multiplies when asked for a product</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify command words that mean addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
For which of these questions would you calculate \( 50+25 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>How many \( 25 \) s are there in \( 50 ? \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than divides when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The middle rectangle has "square root" written inside it and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "16" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 32 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the inverse of square rooting is doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>

<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding an input of a function machine thinks you apply the operations given rather than the inverse operation.</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{1}{5} \) of the counters in a bag are blue.
\( \frac{3}{10} \) of the counters are red.
\( \frac{1}{2} \) of the counters are purple.
Which of these show the ratio of blue : red : purple? ![An image of a bag]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1: 3: 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses numerators to convert fractions to ratio despite different denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{1}{5} \) of the counters in a bag are blue.
\( \frac{3}{10} \) of the counters are red.
\( \frac{1}{2} \) of the counters are purple.
Which of these show the ratio of blue : red : purple? ![An image of a bag]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5: 10: 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses the denominator when converting from fractions to ratio, rather than numerator.</Misconception>

<Construct>Construct frequency tables</Construct>
<Subject>Frequency tables</Subject>
<Question>
Dave has recorded the number of pets his classmates have in the frequency table on the right. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Number of pets & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} If Dave wanted to work out the total number of pets own by his classmates, what would be a useful column to include?
</Question>
<Answer>Number of pets \( \div \) Frequency</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides instead of multiplies when calculating total frequency</Misconception>

<Construct>Construct frequency tables</Construct>
<Subject>Frequency tables</Subject>
<Question>
Dave has recorded the number of pets his classmates have in the frequency table on the right. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Number of pets & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} If Dave wanted to work out the total number of pets own by his classmates, what would be a useful column to include?
</Question>
<Answer>Number of pets + Frequency</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplies when calculating total frequency</Misconception>

<Construct>Construct frequency tables</Construct>
<Subject>Frequency tables</Subject>
<Question>
Dave has recorded the number of pets his classmates have in the frequency table on the right. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Number of pets & Frequency \\
\hline \( 0 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 6 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} If Dave wanted to work out the total number of pets own by his classmates, what would be a useful column to include?
</Question>
<Answer>Number of pets -
Frequency</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts rather than multiplies when calculating total frequency</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to two significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the numbers is the same when rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places or to \( 2 \) significant figures?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15.983 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to wrong degree of accuracy (decimal places rather than significant figures)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to two significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the numbers is the same when rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places or to \( 2 \) significant figures?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.0199 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the first significant value is the first non-zero digit number</Misconception>

<Construct>Round the elements of a calculation to one significant figure to perform an estimation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Julie wants to estimate the answer to this calculation by rounding each number to \( 1 \) significant figure.

\[
0.5841 \times 36.3
\]

What number should replace \( \mathbf{0 . 5 8 4 1} \) in her estimation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds up instead of down</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify questions involving a 2D right-angled triangle that require the use of the Tangent (tan) ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Right-angled Triangles (SOHCAHTOA)</Subject>
<Question>
Which ratio would you use to find the value of \( \theta \) ? ![A right angled triangle with the two shorter side lengths given as 7cm and 10cm. The length of the longest side of the triangle is not given. The interior angle of the triangle that is opposite the 10cm side is labelled θ.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Sin</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses sin when tan is required</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify questions involving a 2D right-angled triangle that require the use of the Tangent (tan) ratio</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>Cos</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses cos when tan is required</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>None of these</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand how to apply sohcahtoa</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
James and Cameron are watching a film. They pause it with one seventh left to watch.

What is the ratio of how much they have watched to how much the have yet to see? ![An image of a television]()
</Question>
<Answer>7:1</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses the denominator when converting from fractions to ratio, rather than numerator.</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to ratios</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>1:6</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 23 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding, just writes the digit to the right of the number without considering place value</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
If \( h=3 \) what is the value of \( 2+h \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of adds</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
If \( h=3 \) what is the value of \( 2+h \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>We cannot tell because \( h \) is a variable.</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a variable must remain unknown and cannot be substituted with a value</Misconception>

\(
p^{2}-4
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p(p-2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise difference of two squares</Misconception>

Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}-4
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p-2)(p-2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Factorises difference of two squares with the same sign in both brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{x-6}{2}=10
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{x}{2}=16 \)
Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( x-6=5 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds or subtracts from numerator first when solving an equation with a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{x-6}{2}=10
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{x}{2}=16 \)
Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( x-6=5 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 11 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Calculate the perimeter of a rectilinear shape by adding lengths expressed in the same units</Construct>

The vertical height of the whole shape is 22m. The horizontal width of the top part of the shape is 6m. The horizontal width of the first step is 7m. The vertical height of the bottom rectangle is 5m.  The vertical height of the top rectangle is 8m.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 86 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Convert from improper fractions to mixed number fractions</Construct>

<Question>
Convert \( \frac{11}{5} \) to a mixed number.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \frac{1}{11} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses the numerator of an improper fraction as the denominator of the equivalent mixed number</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \frac{33}{15} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds an equivalent improper fraction when asked for a mixed number</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \) remainder \( 1 \)</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the area of a parallelogram finds base x perpendicular height but divides the answer by 2 </Misconception>

<Answer>\( 3.9 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Given an equation, form  or identify related equations</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about statements that can be made about the equation on the right. \( x=y-4 \) Tom says this is always true: \( 2 x>y-4 \) 
Katie says this is always true: \( x>y-5 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just two linear variables</Construct>

<Question>
Simplify, if possible:
\[
c+a
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( c a \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses collecting like terms with multiplication</Misconception>

<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify, if possible:
\[
c+a
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( a c \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that two letters together, or a number and letter together, are multiplying</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just two linear variables</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify, if possible:
\[
c+a
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( c^{a} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes addition of terms and powers of terms are equivalent e.g. a + c = a^c</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret linear sections of real life graphs</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
The graph on the right shows the mass of sand in a bucket over time

What might the horizontal section represent? ![A graph with time (secs) on the horizontal axis and mass (g) on the vertical axis. The graph starts at the origin, travels in a straight line up and right, travels horizontally, then travels in a straight line down and right back to the x-axis, more steeply than the start. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Sand is being added to the bucket</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a horizontal line can show a constant rate of change</Misconception>

</Question>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving fractions of symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
This pictogram shows the different types of music Bob has in his music collection.

How many Blues CDs does Bob have? ![A pictogram showing the number of CDs Bob has in his musical collection. Pop has 3 and a half symbols, rock has 2 symbols, blues has 2 and a quarter symbols, jazz has 3 and a quarter symbols and classical has 1 and three-quarter symbols. Each symbol represents 4 CDs.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8.25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When counting partial symbols on pictogram, uses the fraction rather than the amount it represents</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving fractions of symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
This pictogram shows the different types of music Bob has in his music collection.

How many Blues CDs does Bob have? ![A pictogram showing the number of CDs Bob has in his musical collection. Pop has 3 and a half symbols, rock has 2 symbols, blues has 2 and a quarter symbols, jazz has 3 and a quarter symbols and classical has 1 and three-quarter symbols. Each symbol represents 4 CDs.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When interpreting a pictogram, thinks each symbol stands for 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Shade percentages of a shape where the percent is an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
How many rectangles would you need to shade so that \( 22 \% \) of this shape is shaded? \begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 22 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand a percentage is out of 100</Misconception>

<Construct>Shade percentages of a shape where the percent is an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
How many rectangles would you need to shade so that \( 22 \% \) of this shape is shaded? \begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 44 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than divides</Misconception>

<Construct>Shade percentages of a shape where the percent is an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
How many rectangles would you need to shade so that \( 22 \% \) of this shape is shaded? \begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|l|}
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline & \(\space\) & \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) &  \(\space\) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>Not possible</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand a percentage can be applied to something not out of 100</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 1 decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \frac{3}{5} \) as a decimal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by using the denominator after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 1 decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \frac{3}{5} \) as a decimal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by using only the numerator after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 1 decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \frac{3}{5} \) as a decimal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.35 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by placing all values of the fraction after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a trapezium, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
The area of this trapezium is
\(
30 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}
\)
What measurement should replace the star? ![A trapezium with 8cm and a star on the parallel sides, and the perpendicular height is 5cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses formula for area of a parallelogram when finding the area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a trapezium, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
The area of this trapezium is
\(
30 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}
\)
What measurement should replace the star? ![A trapezium with 8cm and a star on the parallel sides, and the perpendicular height is 5cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.75 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you multiply parallel sides to find the area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a trapezium, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
The area of this trapezium is
\(
30 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}
\)
What measurement should replace the star? ![A trapezium with 8cm and a star on the parallel sides, and the perpendicular height is 5cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the formula for area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
The ratio of adults to children at a party is \( 1\;: 4 \)
There are \( 20 \) adults.
How many children are there?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up sides of a ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
The ratio of adults to children at a party is \( 1\;: 4 \)
There are \( 20 \) adults.
How many children are there?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Shares equally instead of in given ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{24}{x}=6
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( 24=6 x \) 

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( 24=\frac{x}{6} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation with x in the denominator, thinks the inverse operation is to make it the numerator on the other side</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{24}{x}=6
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( 24=6 x \) 

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( 24=\frac{x}{6} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation with x in the denominator, thinks the inverse operation is to make it the numerator on the other side</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
\frac{24}{x}=6
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( 24=6 x \) 

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( 24=\frac{x}{6} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to solve linear equations involving fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving positive decimals</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(\frac{3 x}{2}+1=1.6\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{3 x}{2}=0.6 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( 3 x+2=2.12 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you write the carried value in the number rather than adding it to the next place value column</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving positive decimals</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(\frac{3 x}{2}+1=1.6\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{3 x}{2}=0.6 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( 3 x+2=2.12 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing written division strategies.

Tom says \( 918 \div 34=934 \div 18 \)

Katie says \( 918 \div 34=34 \div 918 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
Which is the correct point for E when reflected in the line \( x=-1 \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -5 to 5, y-axis from -5 to 3. Four points are plotted and joined to make a rectangle: (1,1), (3, 1), (3, 3) and (1,3). Point (3, 3) is labelled with the letter "E". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>(-3, 3)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reflects in an axis, instead of the given mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
Which is the correct point for E when reflected in the line \( x=-1 \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -5 to 5, y-axis from -5 to 3. Four points are plotted and joined to make a rectangle: (1,1), (3, 1), (3, 3) and (1,3). Point (3, 3) is labelled with the letter "E". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>(3, -3)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reflects in an axis, instead of the given mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
Which is the correct point for E when reflected in the line \( x=-1 \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -5 to 5, y-axis from -5 to 3. Four points are plotted and joined to make a rectangle: (1,1), (3, 1), (3, 3) and (1,3). Point (3, 3) is labelled with the letter "E". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>(3, -5)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks x = ? is a horizontal line through ? </Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic terms, involving non-linear versions of the same letter (e.g. 4a2 x 2a)</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following expressions is equivalent to:
\(
\left(2 p^{2}\right)^{3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 p^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that when raising a variable with a coefficient to a power, only the coefficient is affected by the power</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise perpendicular lines</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing this pair of lines
Tom says they are equal length
Katie says they are perpendicular
Who do you agree with? ![Two blue lines, each with a little red line marked across them. The blue lines don't touch each other, but they are closer together at one end.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of perpendicular</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise perpendicular lines</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing this pair of lines
Tom says they are equal length
Katie says they are perpendicular
Who do you agree with? ![Two blue lines, each with a little red line marked across them. The blue lines don't touch each other, but they are closer together at one end.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know what dashes on the sides of shapes mean</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![Image of a function machine. The function is add one third, and the output is 7]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding an input of a function machine thinks you apply the operations given rather than the inverse operation.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![Image of a function machine. The function is add one third, and the output is 7]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{7}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of addition is multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![Image of a function machine. The function is add one third, and the output is 7]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 21 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of addition is division</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out division  problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( n \times 5 \geq \frac{n}{5} \) If \( n \) can represent any number, is the statement above...
</Question>
<Answer>always true</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out division  problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( n \times 5 \geq \frac{n}{5} \) If \( n \) can represent any number, is the statement above...
</Question>
<Answer>never true</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive non-integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following statements is true when \( n=1.5 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 n<n+5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the inequality:
\(-3>p-1\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p<-4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks subtracting a negative makes your answer smaller</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the inequality:
\(-3>p-1\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p>-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the sides of an inequality can be switched without changing the direction of the sign</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply two decimals together with the same number of decimal places</Construct>

<Question>
\( 0.6 \times 0.4= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplies</Misconception>

\( 0.6 \times 0.4= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying decimals, divides by the wrong power of 10 when reinserting the decimal</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 0.024 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the numerator</Construct>

<Answer>\( x \)</Answer>

<Construct>Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the shorter one</Construct>
<Subject>Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Rectangle \( \mathrm{P} \) has been enlarged by a scale factor of \( 1.5 \) to give rectangle \( \mathrm{Q} \).

What length should replace the star? ![Two rectangles, the smaller labelled P and the larger labelled Q. Q has width 9cm and length 12cm. The length of P is marked with a star.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10.5 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracted rather than divided by a scale factor</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the shorter one</Construct>
<Subject>Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Rectangle \( \mathrm{P} \) has been enlarged by a scale factor of \( 1.5 \) to give rectangle \( \mathrm{Q} \).

What length should replace the star? ![Two rectangles, the smaller labelled P and the larger labelled Q. Q has width 9cm and length 12cm. The length of P is marked with a star.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise the corresponding sides in similar shapes or enlargements</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form x(x + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about how to solve this equation:
\(
x^{2}-9 x=0
\)

Jo says one solution is \( x=0 \)

Paul says one solution is \( x=3 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks x^2 - a^2x is a valid form of difference of two squares</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the regions on a double Venn diagram given in words</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
\( 60 \) people completed an online survey about the car they own.
The results are shown in the Venn Diagram.

How many people own a \( 4 \times 4 \) ? ![A Venn diagram with two circles labelled Owns a 4x4 and Owns a Black Car. The number 27 is in the Owns a 4x4 only region, 15 is in the intersection, and 8 is in the Owns a Black Car only region]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 27 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to include the intersection value when asked for total value of a set in a Venn diagram</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the regions on a double Venn diagram given in words</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
\( 60 \) people completed an online survey about the car they own.
The results are shown in the Venn Diagram.

How many people own a \( 4 \times 4 \) ? ![A Venn diagram with two circles labelled Owns a 4x4 and Owns a Black Car. The number 27 is in the Owns a 4x4 only region, 15 is in the intersection, and 8 is in the Owns a Black Car only region]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the intersection on a Venn diagram represents the total of one set</Misconception>

<Construct>Use brackets to write function machines as calculations</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Here is a function machine ![Input \( \rightarrow-2 \rightarrow\times 5 \rightarrow \) Output]() The input is \( 7 \).
Which calculation gives the correct output?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7-2 \times 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes order of operations does not affect the answer to a calculation</Misconception>

<Construct>Use brackets to write function machines as calculations</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Here is a function machine ![Input \( \rightarrow-2 \rightarrow\times 5 \rightarrow \) Output]() The input is \( 7 \).
Which calculation gives the correct output?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7(5-2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In a function machine, confuses an operation with the input</Misconception>

<Construct>Use brackets to write function machines as calculations</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Here is a function machine ![Input \( \rightarrow-2 \rightarrow\times 5 \rightarrow \) Output]() The input is \( 7 \).
Which calculation gives the correct output?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \times 5-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the total number of combinations in a given scenario by using the product rule for counting where duplicates are considered different</Construct>
<Subject>Systematic Listing Strategies</Subject>
<Question>
Jumbo Restaurant has \( 34 \) choices of starters, \( 92 \) choices of main course, and \( 27 \) choices of dessert.
Sally wants a starter, main course and dessert.

Which of the following calculations would correctly work out the total possible combinations of available to Sally?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 34+92+27 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than multiplies when using the product rule for counting</Misconception>

<Construct>Read the graphical solution to a pair of linear simultaneous equations from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Graphical Solution of Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
According to the graph, what are the solutions to the simultaneous equations? ![The image is of a set of axes with two straight lines drawn on. The red line goes through the points (0,6) and (3,0). The blue line goes through the points (0,3) and (6,0)and the two lines cross at (2,2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=3, \quad y=6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations graphically, they think the solutions are the y-intercepts</Misconception>

<Construct>Read the graphical solution to a pair of linear simultaneous equations from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Graphical Solution of Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
According to the graph, what are the solutions to the simultaneous equations? ![The image is of a set of axes with two straight lines drawn on. The red line goes through the points (0,6) and (3,0). The blue line goes through the points (0,3) and (6,0)and the two lines cross at (2,2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=6, \quad y=3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations graphically, they think the solutions are the x-intercepts</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just two linear variables</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are talking about which term could replace the star in this addition pyramid.
Jo says it could be: \( f \)
Paul says it could be: \( g \)
Who is correct? ![A diagram showing 3 rows of boxes. the bottom row has 3 boxes, containing a star, and empty box and 2g from left to right. The next row up contains two boxes, overlapping the joins of the boxes below. The left one contains 4f+6g, the right one is empty. The top row is one box, centered over the join of the two below, it is empty.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes an addition pyramid works in a different way to how it actually does</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just two linear variables</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>

Jo says it could be: \( f \)
Paul says it could be: \( g \)

The next row up contains two boxes, overlapping the joins of the boxes below. The left one contains 4f+6g, the right one is empty. The top row is one box, centered over the join of the two below, it is empty.]()

<Answer>Only
Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes an addition pyramid works in a different way to how it actually does</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![2 arrows pointing to the right. + 7 in the first arrow. divide by 2 in the second arrow]() The rule above is used to generate a term-to-term sequence.
If the third term is \( 9 \), what is the first term?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the definition of term or term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![2 arrows pointing to the right. + 7 in the first arrow. divide by 2 in the second arrow]() The rule above is used to generate a term-to-term sequence.
If the third term is \( 9 \), what is the first term?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the term after</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by using only the numerator after the decimal point</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>

<Construct>Solve basic introduction simultaneous equation problems, often involving shapes and symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Chris orders \( 3 \) cups of tea and a cake, and his bill comes to £3.10

Amy orders \( 5 \) cups of tea and a cake, and her bill comes to \( £ 4.50 \).
How much does one cup of tea cost?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 90 p \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations, thinks they can ignore one of the variables</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve basic introduction simultaneous equation problems, often involving shapes and symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Chris orders \( 3 \) cups of tea and a cake, and his bill comes to £3.10

Amy orders \( 5 \) cups of tea and a cake, and her bill comes to \( £ 4.50 \).
How much does one cup of tea cost?
</Question>
<Answer>E1</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve basic introduction simultaneous equation problems, often involving shapes and symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Chris orders \( 3 \) cups of tea and a cake, and his bill comes to £3.10

Amy orders \( 5 \) cups of tea and a cake, and her bill comes to \( £ 4.50 \).
How much does one cup of tea cost?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 1.40 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation forgets to eliminate the coefficient in front of the variable in the last step</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has used slant height and base to find area of a triangle rather than perpendicular height and base</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (px + a)(qx + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve this quadratic equation:
\(
(5 x+2)(2 x-5)=0
\)

Tom says one solution is: \( x=\frac{2}{5} \)

Katie says one solution is: \( x=-\frac{5}{2} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the sign of solutions in a quadratic equation is always the same as the constant term</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (px + a)(qx + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve this quadratic equation:
\(
(5 x+2)(2 x-5)=0
\)

Tom says one solution is: \( x=\frac{2}{5} \)

Katie says one solution is: \( x=-\frac{5}{2} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the solution to ax + b = 0 is x = -a/b</Misconception>

<Answer>\( <> \)</Answer>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a linear expression by taking out a single numeric common factor (e.g. 6)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise fully \( 18 a-12 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2(9 a-6) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that they can fully factorise an expression by taking out any common factor, not just the HCF</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a linear expression by taking out a single numeric common factor (e.g. 6)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise fully \( 18 a-12 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 18(a-6) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising into single brackets, factorises the first term correctly but subtracts the number outside the bracket with the second term in the expression to find the second term in the bracket</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.05 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 0.058 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Continue a sequence involving triangle numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 256 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes to find the next traingle number you add the previous two numbers together i.e. Fibonacci</Misconception>

<Construct>Continue a sequence involving triangle numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Here are two consecutive triangle numbers: \( 120,136, \ldots \) What is the next triangle number in the sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 151 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the difference between triangle numbers decreases by 1 each time</Misconception>

<Construct>Continue a sequence involving triangle numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
