</Question>
<Answer>\( 152 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the difference between triangle numbers remains the same</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - bx - c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the correct factorisation of:
\(
x^{2}-x-6
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x-3)(x-2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - bx - c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the correct factorisation of:
\(
x^{2}-x-6
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+3)(x-2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Assign probabilities to single events using percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
This four-sided spinner is fair.
What is the probability of spinning a \( 2 \) ?
Give your answer as a percentage ![A four sided spinner labelled with 1, 2, 3 and 4]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts fraction to percentage by multiplying the denominator by 10</Misconception>

<Construct>Add proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
The fractions in the two circles below add to give the fraction in the circle above.

What should replace the question mark? ![Fractions 3/5 and 1/4 in two separate circles, both linked to a third circle above.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{9} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Add proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
The fractions in the two circles below add to give the fraction in the circle above.

What should replace the question mark? ![Fractions 3/5 and 1/4 in two separate circles, both linked to a third circle above.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{20} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding fractions, changes to common denominator but leaves numerators the same</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a term in an ascending integer linear sequence, use the nth term rule to find its position in that sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the first \( 4 \) terms of a sequence \( \begin{array}{lllll}11 & 15 & 19 & 23 & \ldots\end{array} \) What position in the sequence is the number \( 67 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16.75 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you multiply the constant difference by the term number to get the term value</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}+100 p
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p-10)(p+10) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise</Misconception>

p^{2}+100 p
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p+10)(p+10) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>

<Question>

\(
p^{2}+100 p
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Does not factorise</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a quadratic without a non variable term, can not be factorised</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
A point, \( Q \), has coordinates \( (-3,3) \)
The point is reflected in the line \( y=-x \)
What are the new coordinates of point \( Q \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes reflection in y = -x changes sign of x coordinate only</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
A point, \( Q \), has coordinates \( (-3,3) \)
The point is reflected in the line \( y=-x \)
What are the new coordinates of point \( Q \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-3,-3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes reflection in y = -x changes sign of y coordinate only</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

<Question>
A point, \( Q \), has coordinates \( (-3,3) \)
The point is reflected in the line \( y=-x \)
What are the new coordinates of point \( Q \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,-3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes reflection in y = -x switches x and y coordinates</Misconception>

<Answer>Parallel</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>Pentagon</Answer>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for ascending quadratic sequences in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\(10,21,34,49,66, \ldots\)

When calculating the nth-term rule of this sequence, 
what should replace the triangle?

nth-term rule: \( n^{2} \)\( \color{red}\triangle \)  \(n\) \( \color{purple}\square \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the differences between terms in a sequence, believes they can do so from right to left </Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for ascending quadratic sequences in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\(10,21,34,49,66, \ldots\)

When calculating the nth-term rule of this sequence, 
what should replace the triangle?

nth-term rule: \( n^{2} \)\( \color{red}\triangle \)  \(n\) \( \color{purple}\square \)
</Question>
<Answer>\[
+1
\]
(or just a + sign)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the nth term rule for a quadratic sequence, believes that the coefficient of n is half the second difference</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret and carry out mental division using a bar model</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 200 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Estimated when not appropriate</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret and carry out mental division using a bar model</Construct>
<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>
Find the value of \( P \). ![Horizontal green bar divided into 5 equal sections. Each section is labelled with a "P". Curly bracket shows that 3 of the sections sum to 615.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 123 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the amount given is for the whole rather than a part</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret and carry out mental division using a bar model</Construct>
<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>
Find the value of \( P \). ![Horizontal green bar divided into 5 equal sections. Each section is labelled with a "P". Curly bracket shows that 3 of the sections sum to 615.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1845 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies instead of divides to find one part given the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Given an x value, find the corresponding y value from a non-linear graph</Construct>
<Subject>Cubics and Reciprocals</Subject>
<Question>
Here is the graph of
\(
y=\frac{4}{x}
\)

What is the value of \( y \) when \( x=-1 \) ? ![A graph with two curves. Y axis from -5 to 5 and x axis from -5 to 5 marked in increments of 1.  One curve is in the positive x, positive y quadrant. It starts at the top close to the line x = 1, as we move right it drops very quickly towards the x axis then levels off to travel almost parallel to the line y =1. It goes through (1, 4) (2,2) and (4,1).  One curve is in the negative x negative y quadrant. It starts at the top left of the quadrant almost parallel to y = -1, then we move right and it curves downwards towards the y axis then levels off to travel almost parallel to the x = -1 line. It goes through (-4, -1) (-2, -2) and (-1,-4)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes dividing a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 1013 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot estimate the relative volume order, for different objects</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of horizontal lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x=-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the equations of vertical and horizontal lines</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of horizontal lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this line? ![The diagram shows a pair of axes, x and y ranging from -6 to 5 horizontally and -3 to 4 vertically. There is a horizontal line that passes through the y axis at -2. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=-2 x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Includes the x variable when giving the equation of a horizontal line</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of horizontal lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this line? ![The diagram shows a pair of axes, x and y ranging from -6 to 5 horizontally and -3 to 4 vertically. There is a horizontal line that passes through the y axis at -2. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x y=-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the equation for a horizontal line is in the form xy = a, where a is the y intercept</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name an identity</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most appropriate name for this:
\(p-3 \equiv-(3-p)\)
</Question>
<Answer>Equation</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses an equation with an identity</Misconception>

<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most appropriate name for this:
\(p-3 \equiv-(3-p)\)
</Question>
<Answer>Expression</Answer>
<Misconception>
Has incorrect belief about the meaning of "expression"</Misconception>

<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>

\(p-3 \equiv-(3-p)\)

<Construct>Identify the outcomes of a single event</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>

How many possible outcomes are there if it is spun once? ![A hexagonal shaped spinner with 6 equal sections labelled 1, 3, 3, 5, 5 and 5.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses all possible outcomes with options available</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the outcomes of a single event</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
This is a fair spinner.

How many possible outcomes are there if it is spun once? ![A hexagonal shaped spinner with 6 equal sections labelled 1, 3, 3, 5, 5 and 5.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to consider all possible outcomes</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the outcomes of a single event</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
This is a fair spinner.

How many possible outcomes are there if it is spun once? ![A hexagonal shaped spinner with 6 equal sections labelled 1, 3, 3, 5, 5 and 5.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1,3 \) or \( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Lists outcomes rather than counts how many outcomes</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{3}-8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they only need to multiply the first and last pairs of terms when expanding double brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the output of this 2-step function machine ![A two step function machine with x as the input. The first functions is x5 and the second function says 'subtracted from 8'. The output is blank.]() Tom says the output is \( \mathbf{5} \boldsymbol{x}-\mathbf{8} \)

Katie says the output is \( \mathbf{8}-\mathbf{5} \boldsymbol{x} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Has not noticed the difference between 'subtract' and 'subtract from'</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>

Katie says the output is \( \mathbf{8}-\mathbf{5} \boldsymbol{x} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>

<Answer>D</Answer>

<Construct>Identify and represent sets using set notation</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the probability spinner

Tom says the sample space can be written as: \( S=\{5,6\} \)

Katie says the sample space can be written as: \( S=\{5,5,6,6,6\} \)
Who do you agree with? ![A circle divided into 5 equal sections. 3 of the sections are labelled with a purple number 6. 2 of the sections are labelled with a blue number 5.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a sample space should show repeated outcomes, not just unique possible outcomes.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>

<Question>

A is in the x+5.3 is less than or equal to 0 circle only.
B is in the overlap of the two circles.
C is in the -(5.3+x)/2 is great than 0 circle only.
D is outside both circles.]()
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes greater than/less than symbols include end values</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
A taxi company has a \( £ 1.50 \) fixed charge and then charges \( 60 p \) per mile. Sam correctly sketches a graph to show the cost of different length journeys with the company. Which of the following graphs would best match Sam's sketch?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph with distance on the horizontal axis and cost on the vertical axis. The graph starts at a point on the positive vertical axis and travels horizontally right.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a horizontal line can show a constant rate of change</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
A taxi company has a \( £ 1.50 \) fixed charge and then charges \( 60 p \) per mile. Sam correctly sketches a graph to show the cost of different length journeys with the company. Which of the following graphs would best match Sam's sketch?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph with distance on the horizontal axis and cost on the vertical axis. The graph starts at the origin and travels in a straight line right and upwards.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes that a graph always starts at the origin</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for the curve y = x3 + c</Construct>
<Subject>Cubics and Reciprocals</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the table of values for \( \boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{x}^{\mathbf{3}} \) \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( 27 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Tom says the star could be \( 3 \).

Katie says the star could be \( -3 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks multiplying two or more negative numbers together always gives a positive answer, regardless of how many negative numbers there are in the sum</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the circle when these two brackets are expanded and simplified?
\(
(p+5)(p-4) \equiv p^{2} \triangle p \bigcirc
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \bigcirc=+1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the circle when these two brackets are expanded and simplified?
\(
(p+5)(p-4) \equiv p^{2} \triangle p \bigcirc
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \bigcirc=+20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 less than a given number</Construct>

<Question>
What number is \( 100 \) less than \( 876,099 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 876.099 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides rather than subtracts when given the command 'less than'</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 less than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100 \) less than \( 876,099 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 875,099 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a power of 10, subtracts from the wrong column</Misconception>

<Question>
\( 50.09 \div 0.1= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50.009 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the value of zeros as placeholders</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 500.09 \)</Answer>

<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 50.09 \div 0.1= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5.009 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes dividing by 0.1 is the same as dividing by 10</Misconception>

<Construct>Change decimals of hours into minutes</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.6 \) hours \( = _____\) minutes
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 10 minutes in an hour</Misconception>

<Construct>Change decimals of hours into minutes</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.6 \) hours \( = _____\) minutes
</Question>
<Answer>\( 60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when changing from hours to minutes</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles around a point</Construct>

<Question>
What is the size of angle \( x \) ? ![Angles around a point split into two parts, one is labelled 290 degrees and the other x]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 290^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Incorrectly identifies angles as vertically opposite</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles around a point</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( x \) ? ![Angles around a point split into two parts, one is labelled 290 degrees and the other x]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that angles around a point sum to 360</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using angles around a point</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>

What is the size of angle \( x \) ? ![Angles around a point split into two parts, one is labelled 290 degrees and the other x]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 45^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that angles around a point sum to 360</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify pairs of numbers that satisfy an equation with two unknowns </Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\[
x+y=8
\]
Which pair of numbers fits the equation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}x=10 \\ y=2\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Changes the given operation when substituting</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify pairs of numbers that satisfy an equation with two unknowns </Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\[
x+y=8
\]
Which pair of numbers fits the equation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}x=8 \\ y=1\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Changes the given operation when substituting</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify pairs of numbers that satisfy an equation with two unknowns </Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\[
x+y=8
\]
Which pair of numbers fits the equation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}x=-8 \\ y=1\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>substitutes incorrectly</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just two linear variables</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following expression by collecting
like terms
\(6 x-2 y-x+3 y\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 x+5 y \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When collecting like terms, assigns positivity or negativity incorrectly.</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just two linear variables</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following expression by collecting
like terms
\(6 x-2 y-x+3 y\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 x+5 y \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When collecting like terms, treats subtractions as if they are additions</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just two linear variables</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following expression by collecting
like terms
\(6 x-2 y-x+3 y\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 x+y \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When collecting like terms, assigns positivity or negativity incorrectly.</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving non-linear variables</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following by collecting like terms. \( \frac{2}{3} k^{2}+\frac{1}{6} k^{2}-\frac{1}{3} k^{2}+\frac{5}{6} k^{2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 k^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When collecting like terms, assigns positivity or negativity incorrectly.</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving non-linear variables</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following by collecting like terms. \( \frac{2}{3} k^{2}+\frac{1}{6} k^{2}-\frac{1}{3} k^{2}+\frac{5}{6} k^{2} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{3} k^{2}+k^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think that a variable with no coefficient has a coefficient of 1.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
2, \quad 0.2, \quad 0.02, \quad 0.002
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.22 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the median from a even dataset does not understand we must find the midpoint of the two values in the middle</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\[
2, \quad 0.2, \quad 0.02, \quad 0.002
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.44 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when finding midpoint</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the mode from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the ages of people on a university running team.

What is the modal age? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|l|}
\hline Age & Frequency & \\
\hline \( 18 \) & \( 7 \) & \\
\hline \( 19 \) & \( 3 \) & \\
\hline \( 20 \) & \( 1 \) & \\
\hline \( 21 \) & \( 2 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 19.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the median instead of the mode</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the mode from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the ages of people on a university running team.

What is the modal age? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|l|}
\hline Age & Frequency & \\
\hline \( 18 \) & \( 7 \) & \\
\hline \( 19 \) & \( 3 \) & \\
\hline \( 20 \) & \( 1 \) & \\
\hline \( 21 \) & \( 2 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mode is the frequency rather than the value/group</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the mode from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the ages of people on a university running team.

What is the modal age? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|l|}
\hline Age & Frequency & \\
\hline \( 18 \) & \( 7 \) & \\
\hline \( 19 \) & \( 3 \) & \\
\hline \( 20 \) & \( 1 \) & \\
\hline \( 21 \) & \( 2 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 21 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes when identifying the mode you look at all values, not just frequencies, for the highest number</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using long multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
\( \begin{array}{r}\quad58 \\ \times 22 \\ \hline\end{array} \) What number will be in the ones/units column of the final answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has treated this like an addition problem and added the ones column.</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using long multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
\( \begin{array}{r}\quad58 \\ \times 22 \\ \hline\end{array} \) What number will be in the ones/units column of the final answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has written the value of the 'ones' column as the answer, withiut using the numbers in the question.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the midpoint between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
What is the midpoint of \( (4,3) \) and \( (1,-5) \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (5,-2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when finding midpoint</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the midpoint between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
What is the midpoint of \( (4,3) \) and \( (1,-5) \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>Impossible as you can't have a decimal coordinate</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that coordinates can be decimals</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate an ascending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the first term of the sequence given by this rule:
\[
4 n+3
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the nth term of a linear sequence, thinks the the first term is the coefficient in front of n.</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate an ascending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the first term of the sequence given by this rule:
\[
4 n+3
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the first term in a sequence is the term before the sequence begins (0th term)</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide algebraic fractions involving non-linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 3 \)

Which of the options is the final answer, expressed as simply as possible?
\(
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{3 x+1}{3} \div \frac{9 x^{2}-1}{12} \\
= & \frac{3 x+1}{3} \times \frac{12}{9 x^{2}-1} \\
= & \frac{3 x+1}{3} \times \frac{12}{(3 x-1)(3 x+1)}
\end{aligned}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{12}{9 x-1} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only applies a division to one of multiple terms in a numerator when simplifying an algebraic fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide algebraic fractions involving non-linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 3 \)

Which of the options is the final answer, expressed as simply as possible?
\(
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{3 x+1}{3} \div \frac{9 x^{2}-1}{12} \\
= & \frac{3 x+1}{3} \times \frac{12}{9 x^{2}-1} \\
= & \frac{3 x+1}{3} \times \frac{12}{(3 x-1)(3 x+1)}
\end{aligned}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4(3 x+1)}{(3 x-1)(3 x+1)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying an algebraic fraction, only looks for number factors</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide algebraic fractions involving non-linear expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 3 \)

Which of the options is the final answer, expressed as simply as possible?
\(
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{3 x+1}{3} \div \frac{9 x^{2}-1}{12} \\
= & \frac{3 x+1}{3} \times \frac{12}{9 x^{2}-1} \\
= & \frac{3 x+1}{3} \times \frac{12}{(3 x-1)(3 x+1)}
\end{aligned}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5}{3 x} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Simplifies a fraction by adding or subtracting the same amount from the numerator  and denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Round the elements of a calculation to one significant figure to perform an estimation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Julie wants to estimate the answer to this calculation by rounding each number to \( 1 \) significant figure.

\[
87.4 \times 0.3727
\]

What number should replace \( \mathbf{8 7 . 4} \) in her estimation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 87 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounded to wrong degree of accuracy (2sf not 1sf)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round the elements of a calculation to one significant figure to perform an estimation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Julie wants to estimate the answer to this calculation by rounding each number to \( 1 \) significant figure.

\[
87.4 \times 0.3727
\]

What number should replace \( \mathbf{8 7 . 4} \) in her estimation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 88 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round the elements of a calculation to one significant figure to perform an estimation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Julie wants to estimate the answer to this calculation by rounding each number to \( 1 \) significant figure.

\[
87.4 \times 0.3727
\]

What number should replace \( \mathbf{8 7 . 4} \) in her estimation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 80 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}+5 p+6
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p+6)(p+1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}+5 p+6
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p+6)(p-1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that add to give the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Josh and Lucy share some money in the ratio \( 3: 7 \)

Josh receives \( £ 84 \).

How much money does Lucy receive?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 58.80 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In ratio question where one side of ratio is given, treats that as the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Josh and Lucy share some money in the ratio \( 3: 7 \)

Josh receives \( £ 84 \).

How much money does Lucy receive?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 28 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds one part of a ratio but doesn't multiply that by the number of parts needed</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Josh and Lucy share some money in the ratio \( 3: 7 \)

Josh receives \( £ 84 \).

How much money does Lucy receive?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 36 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gets order of ratio wrong</Misconception>

<Construct>Order negative decimals with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the depths below sea level of \( 3 \) creatures:
Tuna: \( -2.6 m \)
Ray: \( -6 m \)
Ling: \( -1.5 \mathrm{~m} \)
Arrange their depths in ascending order, starting with the deepest
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1^{\text {st }} \) Tuna
\( 2^{\text {nd }} \) Ling
\( 3^{\text {rd }} \) Ray</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the more digits a number has the greater it is, regardless of place value</Misconception>

<Construct>Order negative decimals with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the depths below sea level of \( 3 \) creatures:
Tuna: \( -2.6 m \)
Ray: \( -6 m \)
Ling: \( -1.5 \mathrm{~m} \)
Arrange their depths in ascending order, starting with the deepest
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}1^{\text {st }} \text { Ling } \\ 2^{\text {nd }} \text { Tuna } \\ 3^{\text {rd }} \text { Ray }\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes negative numbers with a larger absolute value are greater</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Amy is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (2,-5) \) and \( (-7,1) \) She labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{cccc}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (2, & -5) & (-7, & 1)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) What does the first bracket equal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-5)^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative number from a positive number, uses a method which assumes one of the negative signs can be ignored </Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Amy is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (2,-5) \) and \( (-7,1) \) She labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{cccc}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (2, & -5) & (-7, & 1)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) What does the first bracket equal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (9)^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean as an average from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
What is the mean of this set of data?
\[
5, \quad 2, \quad 0, \quad 2, \quad 3
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for the mean of a list of data, gives the mode</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean as an average from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
What is the mean of this set of data?
\[
5, \quad 2, \quad 0, \quad 2, \quad 3
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for the mean of a list of data, does not count any zeros in the data when working out what to divide by</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>\(a \Rightarrow \times2  \Rightarrow -5\Rightarrow 2a-5\) 

\(a \Rightarrow \times2  \Rightarrow -5\Rightarrow 2(a-5)\) </Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>\(a \Rightarrow -5  \Rightarrow \times2\Rightarrow 2a-5\) 

\(a \Rightarrow -5  \Rightarrow \times2\Rightarrow 2(a-5)\) </Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>\(a \Rightarrow -5 \Rightarrow \times2 \Rightarrow 2a-5\) 

\(a \Rightarrow \times2  \Rightarrow -5\Rightarrow 2(a-5)\) </Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>Recall the formulae for the trigonometric ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Right-angled Triangles (SOHCAHTOA)</Subject>
<Question>
\(
\bigstar=\frac{\text { Hypotenuse }}{\text { Opposite }}
\)

What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sin (\theta) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses order of sides in a trigonometric ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Recall the formulae for the trigonometric ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Right-angled Triangles (SOHCAHTOA)</Subject>
<Question>
\(
\bigstar=\frac{\text { Hypotenuse }}{\text { Opposite }}
\)

What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \cos (\theta) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses cos when sin is required</Misconception>

<Construct>Recall the formulae for the trigonometric ratios</Construct>
<Subject>Right-angled Triangles (SOHCAHTOA)</Subject>
<Question>
\(
\bigstar=\frac{\text { Hypotenuse }}{\text { Opposite }}
\)

What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \tan (\theta) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses tan when sin is required</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing this pair of simultaneous equations: \( \begin{array}{l}3 x-2 y=15 \\ x+2 y=20\end{array} \) Tom says if you add the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Katie says if you subtract the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts simultaneous equations when addition is required</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing this pair of simultaneous equations: \( \begin{array}{l}3 x-2 y=15 \\ x+2 y=20\end{array} \) Tom says if you add the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Katie says if you subtract the two equations together you will eliminate a variable

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations thinks that identical terms in given equations can be eliminated by either adding or subtracting.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the whole amount, given a fraction of the amount</Construct>

<Question>

What is \( \frac{1}{8} \) of \( A \) ? ![A pink rounded rectangle with a capital A typed inside]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the part and the whole in fraction of an amount problems</Misconception>

\[
1,3,6,10, \ldots \text { ? }
\]

Which pattern matches the sequence above?
</Question>
<Answer>![A sequence represented using red circles arranged in a pattern so that the first term has one red dot and then an additional two dots are added underneath this one red dot for the second term. For the third term another two red dots are added underneath and for the fourth term, two more added underneath the previous pattern.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Raise a positive integer to a positive integer power</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about powers.
\( m \) and \( n \) are integers

Tom says there is no value of \( m \) that means \( 2^{m} \) ends in \( 0 \).
Katie says there is no value of \( n \) that means \( 5^{n} \) ends in \( 0 \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

<Construct>Use direct proportion to solve unitary missing amounts in problems (e.g. recipes)</Construct>

<Question>

How much does one bottle of water cost?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 28.80 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies up without finding unit price in proportion question</Misconception>

<Construct>Use direct proportion to solve unitary missing amounts in problems (e.g. recipes)</Construct>

Eight bottles of water cost \( £ 3.60 \).

How much does one bottle of water cost?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 3.53 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts rather than dividing to find unit price</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is greater than 100</Construct>

<Question>
What is \( 120 \% \) of \( 50 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>You cannot have percentages greater than \( 100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that you can have percentages greater than 100%</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate a positive fractional gradient between two coordinates where all values are positive</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Max is working out the gradient between these two points. He has worked out the lengths of the triangle.
What is the gradient? ![A coordinate grid with a right angled triangle drawn on it. The hypotenuse of the triangle is between the coordinates (1,2) and (7,5). The base of the triangle is labelled with 6 and the perpendicular height of the triangle is labelled with 3.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes gradient is the difference between the change in x and the change in y</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate a positive fractional gradient between two coordinates where all values are positive</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Max is working out the gradient between these two points. He has worked out the lengths of the triangle.
What is the gradient? ![A coordinate grid with a right angled triangle drawn on it. The hypotenuse of the triangle is between the coordinates (1,2) and (7,5). The base of the triangle is labelled with 6 and the perpendicular height of the triangle is labelled with 3.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes gradient = change in x/change in y</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate a positive fractional gradient between two coordinates where all values are positive</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Max is working out the gradient between these two points. He has worked out the lengths of the triangle.
What is the gradient? ![A coordinate grid with a right angled triangle drawn on it. The hypotenuse of the triangle is between the coordinates (1,2) and (7,5). The base of the triangle is labelled with 6 and the perpendicular height of the triangle is labelled with 3.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 18 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes gradient = change in y multiplied by change in x</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1 </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
One of these quadratic equations will give no real solutions.
Which one?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{-6 \pm \sqrt{12}}{-3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the discriminant must be a perfect square for an equation to have real solutions</Misconception>

Which one?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{-6 \pm \sqrt{1200}}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the discriminant must be a perfect square for an equation to have real solutions</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1 </Construct>

<Question>
One of these quadratic equations will give no real solutions.
Which one?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{-6 \pm \sqrt{0}}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a discriminant of 0 means there are no real solutions</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>![2 function machines both with 4 rectangles in a row and joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first function machine has "p" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "✕ 2" written inside the next rectangle, "−3" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "2p − 3" written inside it.
The first function machine has "p" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "✕ 2" written inside the next rectangle, "−3" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "2(p − 3)" written inside it.
]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

 The second function machine has "p" written inside the first rectangle on the left and "input" written above it; it has "✕ 2" written inside the next rectangle, "−3" written inside the next rectangle and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "2(p − 3)" written inside it.]()</Answer>

The other rectangle has width 7cm and height 9cm. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>

<Answer>\( 5070 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( 5007 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( 5700 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside contains a letter and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets: \( m(2 m-7) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 m-7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside contains a letter and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets: \( m(2 m-7) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 m^{2}-7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside contains a letter and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets: \( m(2 m-7) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 m-7 m \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you add the terms together when multiplying like terms.</Misconception>

<Construct>Add decimals with the same number of decimals places</Construct>

\( 0.8+0.2= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding decimals, just adds the digits and ignores place value</Misconception>

<Question>
\( 0.8+0.2= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding, just writes the digit to the right of the number without considering place value</Misconception>

<Construct>Add decimals with the same number of decimals places</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.8+0.2= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during addition of decimals, does not carry across decimal point to preceding digit.</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a bar chart</Construct>
<Subject>Block Graphs and Bar Charts</Subject>
<Question>
![A bar chart with blue vertical bars. The x-axis is titled "Fruits" and the y-axis is titled "Number of Children" and its scale is from 0 to 50 in steps of 10. The bars represent the following numbers of children: Banana, 30; Apple, 20; Kiwi Fruits, 30; Orange, 35; Pineapple, 10.]() \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline
Type of Fruit & Number of Children\\
\hline Banana & \(  \) \\
\hline Apple & \( 20 \) \\
\hline Kiwi & \( 30 \) \\
\hline Orange & \(  \) \\
\hline Pineapple & \( 10 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Using the bar chart, what two numbers are missing from the table?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \) and \( 40 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading graph, chooses nearest marked value on axis instead of reading accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 3 digit integers by 2 digit integers using long multiplication</Construct>

<Question>
What is a correct way to set up this problem to solve it using long multiplication?
\[
128 \times 26
\]
</Question>
<Answer>![128 multiplied by 26 set out to perform long multiplication. 128 is written in 3 columns with 100 in the first column, 20 in the second column and 8 in the third column. 26 is written underneath this, with 20 under 20 and 6 under 8.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Has partitioned the digits when doing long multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{t^{2}-t-12}{t-4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying an algebraic fraction, only looks for number factors</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify where negative non-integers lie on a number line</Construct>

Here is a number line: ![A horizontal number-line with 13 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. The 1st dash is labelled with "-6", the 3rd dash is labelled "-4", the 5th dash is labelled "-2", the 7th dash is labelled "0", the 9th dash is labelled "2", the 11th dash is labelled "4" and the 13th dash is labelled "6"    A red arrow, labelled with a question mark is pointing halfway between the 6th and 7th dashes. ]() Which of the following numbers could be indicated by the arrow?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -1.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts on in the wrong direction on a number line</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify where negative non-integers lie on a number line</Construct>

<Question>
Here is a number line: ![A horizontal number-line with 13 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. The 1st dash is labelled with "-6", the 3rd dash is labelled "-4", the 5th dash is labelled "-2", the 7th dash is labelled "0", the 9th dash is labelled "2", the 11th dash is labelled "4" and the 13th dash is labelled "6"    A red arrow, labelled with a question mark is pointing halfway between the 6th and 7th dashes. ]() Which of the following numbers could be indicated by the arrow?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -0.25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a quarter of 2 is 0.25</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out addition problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Diagram of a thermometer showing positive and negative temperatures, with an arrow labelled +9 going from -3 up to 6]() Which of the following calculations is represented on the thermometer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3+6=9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a negative number can be replaced with its positive equivalent when answering an addition problem from a numberline</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out addition problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Diagram of a thermometer showing positive and negative temperatures, with an arrow labelled +9 going from -3 up to 6]() Which of the following calculations is represented on the thermometer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6+9=-3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes we move down a number line when we add</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out addition problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Diagram of a thermometer showing positive and negative temperatures, with an arrow labelled +9 going from -3 up to 6]() Which of the following calculations is represented on the thermometer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3+6=9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the number of jumps between two numbers on a numberline represents the sum of those 2 numbers </Misconception>

<Construct>Use facts about interior angles in triangles with algebra to solve equations</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Find the value of \( x \). ![A triangle with the angles labelled: 4x, 2x - 12 and 4x + 42]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=33^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes angles in a triangle sum to 360 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Use facts about interior angles in triangles with algebra to solve equations</Construct>

<Question>
Find the value of \( x \). ![A triangle with the angles labelled: 4x, 2x - 12 and 4x + 42]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=21^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Miran says the following:

"It doesn't matter if you do \( \mathbf{7} \div \mathbf{1 4 0} \) or \( \mathbf{1 4 0} \div \mathbf{7} \), you get the same answer"

What do you think?
</Question>
<Answer>Miran is correct because division is commutative</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Miran says the following:

"It doesn't matter if you do \( \mathbf{7} \div \mathbf{1 4 0} \) or \( \mathbf{1 4 0} \div \mathbf{7} \), you get the same answer"

What do you think?
</Question>
<Answer>Miran is incorrect because division is commutative</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the meaning of the word commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Miran says the following:

"It doesn't matter if you do \( \mathbf{7} \div \mathbf{1 4 0} \) or \( \mathbf{1 4 0} \div \mathbf{7} \), you get the same answer"

What do you think?
</Question>
<Answer>Miran is correct because division is not commutative</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the meaning of the word commutative </Misconception>

Katie says \( \mathrm{mm}^{2} \) is a unit of area
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know units of area should be squared</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve comparison, sum and difference problems using information presented in pictograms</Construct>

<Question>

How many more Pop CDs does Bob have than Rock CDs? ![A pictogram showing the number of CDs Bob has in his musical collection. Pop has 3 and a half symbols, rock has 2 symbols, blues has 2 and a quarter symbols, jazz has 3 and a quarter symbols and classical has 1 and three-quarter symbols. Each symbol represents 4 CDs.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When counting partial symbols on pictogram, uses the fraction rather than the amount it represents</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve comparison, sum and difference problems using information presented in pictograms</Construct>

Pop has 3 and a half symbols, rock has 2 symbols, blues has 2 and a quarter symbols, jazz has 3 and a quarter symbols and classical has 1 and three-quarter symbols. Each symbol represents 4 CDs.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When interpreting a pictogram, thinks each symbol stands for 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the denominator</Construct>

<Answer>\( \frac{9 y^{2}}{6 y+3} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the denominator</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3 y}{2+y} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you can divide terms by different factors when simplifying an algebraic fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising the denominator</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3 y^{3}}{2 y^{2}+3 y} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you can divide terms by different factors when simplifying an algebraic fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the area of rectilinear shapes by counting squares</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What can you say about the areas of the two squares? ![Two squares drawn on a grid. The blue square is three grid squares wide, and the three grid squares long. The red square is drawn diagonally, so that each side goes through two grid squares from corner to corner.]()
</Question>
<Answer>The red square has a larger area</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts half-squares as full squares when calculating area on a square grid</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the area of rectilinear shapes by counting squares</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What can you say about the areas of the two squares? ![Two squares drawn on a grid. The blue square is three grid squares wide, and the three grid squares long. The red square is drawn diagonally, so that each side goes through two grid squares from corner to corner.]()
</Question>
<Answer>The areas are the same</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the diagonal of a square is the same length as the side of the square</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the area of rectilinear shapes by counting squares</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>It is impossible to say without measuring</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find area by counting squares on a grid</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( \frac{1}{20} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes decimal point can be ignored when given a decimal percentage to convert to a fraction</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\(\bigstar =-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes the constant in the bracket is double the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Use area to write algebraic expressions</Construct>

<Answer>\( x^{3}+9=8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Amy is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (2,-5) \) and \( (-7,1) \) She labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{cccc}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (2, & -5) & (-7, & 1)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) \( \sqrt{(-9)^{2}+(6)^{2}} \) What is the distance between the points?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -\sqrt{45} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the square of a negative will also be negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name a formula</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>

</Question>
<Answer>Equation</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a formula with an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name a formula</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>Variable</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a variable with a formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name a formula</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>

</Question>
<Answer>Expression</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses a formula with an expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Rearrange the following equation to make \( v \) the subject
\(F=\frac{v^{2}}{r}\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( v=r F^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Rearrange the following equation to make \( v \) the subject
\(F=\frac{v^{2}}{r}\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( v=\sqrt{\frac{F}{r}} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Rearrange the following equation to make \( v \) the subject
\(F=\frac{v^{2}}{r}\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( v=r \sqrt{F} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reverse the order of operations when solving an equation</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 10 centimetres in 1 mm.</Misconception>

</Question>

How many millimetres are there in \( 1 \) centimetre?

<Misconception>Thinks there are 1000mm in a centimetre</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing the order of operations
Tom says: \( 6+4-2 \equiv 4-2+6 \)
Katie says: \( 6+4 \times 2 \equiv 6 \times 4+2 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles in a right-angled triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about triangles.
Tom says a triangle can have two right angles.
Katie says only a scalene triangle can have a right angle.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not consider that all three angles in a triangle sum to 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles in a right-angled triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about triangles.
Tom says a triangle can have two right angles.
Katie says only a scalene triangle can have a right angle.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the properties of an isosceles triangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing calculations involving brackets
Tom says \( a(b+c) \equiv(b+c) \times a \)
Katie says \( a(b+c) \equiv a b+c \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing calculations involving brackets
Tom says \( a(b+c) \equiv(b+c) \times a \)
Katie says \( a(b+c) \equiv a b+c \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the identity symbol</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a decimal on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of A? ![A horizontal number-line with 11 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "-4" below the 2nd dash and "5" below the last dash are the only numbers marked on the line. An arrow, labelled "A" is pointing halfway between the 5th and 6th dashes. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -7.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When placing a negative number on a number line student assumes numbers with a greater absolute value are placed to the right.</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a decimal on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of A? ![A horizontal number-line with 11 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "-4" below the 2nd dash and "5" below the last dash are the only numbers marked on the line. An arrow, labelled "A" is pointing halfway between the 5th and 6th dashes. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading integers on a number line, assumes each dash is 2</Misconception>

<Construct>Express one quantity as a percentage of another mentally</Construct>

<Question>
What is \( 8 \) out of \( 20 \) as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 82 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a percentage by writing the numerator followed by the denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Express one quantity as a percentage of another mentally</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 8 \) out of \( 20 \) as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks they double the numerator to turn a fraction into a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside contains a letter and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
![A blue, rectangle with each side labelled. The left side is labelled x and the right side 8. The top side is labelled 2x + 4 and the base 3x - 4.]() Which of the following statements is incorrect?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 x+4=3 x-4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the properties of a rectangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside contains a letter and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
![A blue, rectangle with each side labelled. The left side is labelled x and the right side 8. The top side is labelled 2x + 4 and the base 3x - 4.]() Which of the following statements is incorrect?
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the properties of a rectangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
One of these equations has exactly one solution.
Which is it?
</Question>
<Answer>\( t^{2}-9=0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Factorises difference of two squares with the same sign in both brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a description of an ascending sequence using quadratics in words, write some terms of that sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![Square and then subtract \( 4 \)]() The first three terms of which sequence below is produced by this term-to-term rule?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3,9,5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When given a term to term sequence with multiple steps, applies one step per term</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a description of an ascending sequence using quadratics in words, write some terms of that sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![Square and then subtract \( 4 \)]() The first three terms of which sequence below is produced by this term-to-term rule?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3,-13,-173 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When given a term to term sequence with multiple steps, applies one step per term</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a description of an ascending sequence using quadratics in words, write some terms of that sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![Square and then subtract \( 4 \)]() The first three terms of which sequence below is produced by this term-to-term rule?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3,0,5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Describes term to term rules using position to term rules</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 5 \) red balls and \( 4 \) yellow balls in a cup ![A cup with 5 red and 4 yellow balls in it. All of the balls are the same size.]() Kate picks out two balls at the same time.

What is the probability at least one ball is red?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{20}{72} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not work out all possibilites when given an 'at least' question in probability</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 5 \) red balls and \( 4 \) yellow balls in a cup ![A cup with 5 red and 4 yellow balls in it. All of the balls are the same size.]() Kate picks out two balls at the same time.

What is the probability at least one ball is red?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{40}{72} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks they can just give the probability of the first event for a combined probability</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a parallelogram where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of the parallelogram? ![A parallelogram with length 7cm, perpendicular height (marked by a right angle) 3cm, and slanted height 4cm. Not to scale]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 22 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Calculates perimeter when asked for area</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a parallelogram where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of the parallelogram? ![A parallelogram with length 7cm, perpendicular height (marked by a right angle) 3cm, and slanted height 4cm. Not to scale]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 28 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has used slant height and base to find area of a parallelogram rather than perpendicular height and base</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a parallelogram where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of the parallelogram? ![A parallelogram with length 7cm, perpendicular height (marked by a right angle) 3cm, and slanted height 4cm. Not to scale]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 84 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies all given dimensions when calculating an area</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Jacob makes a conjecture: If you have two different numbers, \( P \) and \( Q \), the order you divide does not matter. \( P \div Q=Q \div P \) Is Jacob's conjecture...
</Question>
<Answer>Always true</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Jacob makes a conjecture: If you have two different numbers, \( P \) and \( Q \), the order you divide does not matter. \( P \div Q=Q \div P \) Is Jacob's conjecture...
</Question>
<Answer>Sometimes true</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is sometimes commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q s \) in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations? Pair \( 1 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
-5 p+2 q=12 \\
3 p-2 q=8
\end{array}
\) Pair \( 2 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
-5 p-2 q=12 \\
3 p+2 q=8
\end{array}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Subtract Pair \( 1 \)
Subtract Pair \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are different, we subtract the equations.</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows how much a block of ice melted over time. ![Chart of water depth (cm) against time (minutes)]() What was the difference between the second minute and fourth minute?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not include units in answer.</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows how much a block of ice melted over time. ![Chart of water depth (cm) against time (minutes)]() What was the difference between the second minute and fourth minute?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the command word 'difference'</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>

This graph shows how much a block of ice melted over time. ![Chart of water depth (cm) against time (minutes)]() What was the difference between the second minute and fourth minute?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has used the wrong data point on the graph</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( -10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( -16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between m and km</Construct>

<Question>
\( 4000 m \) is the same as ____ \(km\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 400 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 10m in a km</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between m and km</Construct>
<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 4000 m \) is the same as ____ \(km\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 400000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than divides</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between m and km</Construct>
<Subject>Length Units</Subject>
<Question>
\( 4000 m \) is the same as ____ \(km\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 100m and a km</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
![A coordinate grid with point V marked at (2,2) and point W marked at (-3,-1)]() Describe the movements to get from point \( \mathrm{V} \) to point \( \mathrm{W} \).
</Question>
<Answer>Left \( 4 \) squares, down \( 3 \) squares</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, miscounts when crossing an axis</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
![A coordinate grid with point V marked at (2,2) and point W marked at (-3,-1)]() Describe the movements to get from point \( \mathrm{V} \) to point \( \mathrm{W} \).
</Question>
<Answer>Right \( 5 \) squares, up \( 3 \) squares</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, goes from the image to the original</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
![A coordinate grid with point V marked at (2,2) and point W marked at (-3,-1)]() Describe the movements to get from point \( \mathrm{V} \) to point \( \mathrm{W} \).
</Question>
<Answer>Left \( 5 \) squares, up \( 3 \) squares</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, identifies the correct number of jumps but mixes up the directions .</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100 \) more than \( 28902 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2,890,200 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than adds when given the command word 'more'</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100 \) more than \( 28902 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 29,902 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding powers of 10 adds onto the wrong column</Misconception>

<Construct>Find 100 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 100 \) more than \( 28902 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 28,002 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Recall the correct formula to calculate the length of a non-hypotenuse of a right-angled triangle in a 2D Pythagoras questions</Construct>
<Subject>2D Pythagoras</Subject>
<Question>
A right-angled tringle has sides a, b, and \( c \) as shown.

Choose the formula for finding side a. ![Right-angled triangle with height a, base b and hypotenuse c.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( a=c-b \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that the square root of an expression square roots each term in the expression, rather than square rooting the whole expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from improper fractions to mixed number fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write \( \textbf{nineteen fifths} \) as a mixed number fraction.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \frac{1}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When converting from an improper fraction to a mixed number, adds on the part left to make the whole, rather than subtracting it</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from improper fractions to mixed number fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write \( \textbf{nineteen fifths} \) as a mixed number fraction.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 19 \frac{1}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes the numerator of an improper fraction as the number of wholes when converting to a mixed number</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from improper fractions to mixed number fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write \( \textbf{nineteen fifths} \) as a mixed number fraction.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{19}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confused mixed numbers with improper fractions</Misconception>
