<Question>
What is \( \frac{4}{5} \) as a decimal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by using the denominator after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 1 decimal place</Construct>

<Question>
What is \( \frac{4}{5} \) as a decimal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by using only the numerator after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 1 decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \frac{4}{5} \) as a decimal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.45 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by placing all values of the fraction after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand inequality notation</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these statements show that \( \mathrm{t} \) is greater than \( 9 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( t<9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand inequality notation</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these statements show that \( \mathrm{t} \) is greater than \( 9 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( t=9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses inequality symbols with equality</Misconception>

\(
\frac{3}{10}+ \frac{7}{1000}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 307 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that you can have a decimal percentage</Misconception>

\(
\frac{3}{10}+ \frac{7}{1000}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.7 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you just add a % sign to the numerator to make a fraction into a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from hours to minutes</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
Hannah's journey to camp is \( 3 \) hours and \( 26 \) minutes.
Tori's journey to camp is \( 204 \) minutes.
What is the difference in their journeys in minutes?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 122 \) minutes</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when changing from hours to minutes</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from hours to minutes</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
Hannah's journey to camp is \( 3 \) hours and \( 26 \) minutes.
Tori's journey to camp is \( 204 \) minutes.
What is the difference in their journeys in minutes?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 410 \) minutes</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of subtracts</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find the length of a line segment from coordinates</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up width and height of a rectangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|c|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( 4 \) &  \( \ \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\)
\end{tabular}

This is a table of values for \( x+2 y=8 \) What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation forgets to eliminate the coefficient in front of the variable in the last step</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}+5 p+4
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p+2)(p+3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that add to give the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}+5 p+4
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p+1)(p+5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the coefficent of x in an expanded quadratic comes from multiplying the two numbers in the brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Can calculate missing coordinates in a geometric shape</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
![A coordinate grid with a line segment from (0,2) to (3,1)]() The line segment is one side of a square.

Tom says a vertex of the square could be \( (2,-2) \).

Katie says a vertex of the square could be \( (1,5) \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a coordinate cannot be placed beyond the bounds of the grid shown</Misconception>

<Construct>Can calculate missing coordinates in a geometric shape</Construct>
<Subject>Naming Co-ordinates in 2D</Subject>
<Question>
![A coordinate grid with a line segment from (0,2) to (3,1)]() The line segment is one side of a square.

Tom says a vertex of the square could be \( (2,-2) \).

Katie says a vertex of the square could be \( (1,5) \).
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that if the horizontal and vertical measurements of a diagonal line segment switch it remains the same size</Misconception>

<Construct>Estimate the gradient at a point on a non-linear section of a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient as change in y over change in x</Subject>
<Question>
The graph shows information about the velocity, \( v \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \), of a parachutist \( t \) seconds after leaving a plane.

Which of the following is the best estimate for the gradient of the curve when \[t=8\]? ![A graph showing time in seconds on the x axis and velocity in metres per second on the y axis. A curve is shown with a tangent to the curve drawn in at (8,51). The tangent also passes through the point (0,40)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 51 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the difference between a value on a graph and the gradient of a graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Estimate the gradient at a point on a non-linear section of a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient as change in y over change in x</Subject>
<Question>
The graph shows information about the velocity, \( v \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \), of a parachutist \( t \) seconds after leaving a plane.

Which of the following is the best estimate for the gradient of the curve when \[t=8\]? ![A graph showing time in seconds on the x axis and velocity in metres per second on the y axis. A curve is shown with a tangent to the curve drawn in at (8,51). The tangent also passes through the point (0,40)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.72... \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes gradient = change in x/change in y</Misconception>

<Construct>Estimate the gradient at a point on a non-linear section of a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Gradient as change in y over change in x</Subject>
<Question>
The graph shows information about the velocity, \( v \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \), of a parachutist \( t \) seconds after leaving a plane.

Which of the following is the best estimate for the gradient of the curve when \[t=8\]? ![A graph showing time in seconds on the x axis and velocity in metres per second on the y axis. A curve is shown with a tangent to the curve drawn in at (8,51). The tangent also passes through the point (0,40)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6.375 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the difference between two points on a time series graph, only uses one of the points. </Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise visual representations of division times table facts</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
![Six groups of three dots]() Jo says the diagram above represents
\[
3 \div 18=6
\]
Paul says the diagram represents \( 6 \times 3=18 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
\(y= x^{2}+8x+2 \)

Write in the form
\( (x+a)^{2}+b \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+4)^{2}+2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square in the form (x - a)^2 + b, believes b = the original constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
\(y= x^{2}+8x+2 \)

Write in the form
\( (x+a)^{2}+b \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+8)^{2}+2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes the constant in the bracket is the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
\(y= x^{2}+8x+2 \)

Write in the form
\( (x+a)^{2}+b \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+4)^{2}-16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square in the form (x - a)^2 + b, believes b = -a^2 regardless of the original constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 2 decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{6}{25}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.625 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by placing all values of the fraction after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 2 decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{6}{25}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by using only the numerator after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 2 decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{6}{25}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6.25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by placing a decimal point between the numerator and denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Order decimals with a different number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
Which number is the greatest?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6.079 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When ordering integers, orders from the digits at the end of the number instead of the digits at the start</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out the first stage in an iteration solution</Construct>
<Subject>Trial and Improvement and Iterative Methods</Subject>
<Question>
\(x_{n+1}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{x_{n}+1}}\)

Using a starting value of \( x_{1}=0.5 \), what is the value of \( x_{2} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.7419 \ldots \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the term after</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret and carry out mental division using a bar model</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Estimated when not appropriate</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret and carry out mental division using a bar model</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 1680 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confusion over whether multiplication or division is the correct way to solve the problem.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(
-5=p+10
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p=5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, with all positive integers</Construct>

Solve the equation:
\(20 t-5=5 t+10\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( t=0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a number divided by itself equals 0</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>1:5</Answer>
<Misconception>Gets order of ratio wrong</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to ratios</Construct>

<Question>
James and Cameron are watching a film. They pause it with one sixth left to watch.

What is the ratio for how much they have watched to how much they have yet to see? ![An image of a television]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6: 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses the denominator when converting from fractions to ratio, rather than numerator.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is 1 </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Before Zain uses the quadratic formula to solve this equation, what must he do?
\(
p^{2}-16=p
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Square root everything</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise a quadratic must be in the form ax^2+bx+c=0 to find the values for the quadratic formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is 1 </Construct>

Before Zain uses the quadratic formula to solve this equation, what must he do?
\(
p^{2}-16=p
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Add \( 16 \) to both sides</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise a quadratic must be in the form ax^2+bx+c=0 to find the values for the quadratic formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is 1 </Construct>

\(
p^{2}-16=p
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Divide everything by \( p \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise a quadratic must be in the form ax^2+bx+c=0 to find the values for the quadratic formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean as an average from a list of data</Construct>

<Question>
When calculating the mean of the following numbers which calculation will give the correct answer?
\[
0,0,2,6,9
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0+0+2+6+9 \div 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not include brackets when required</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean as an average from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
When calculating the mean of the following numbers which calculation will give the correct answer?
\[
0,0,2,6,9
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2+6+9}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for the mean of a list of data, does not count any zeros in the data when working out what to divide by</Misconception>

\]
</Question>
<Answer>None of them</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to calculate the mean</Misconception>

<Question>
Which one of the following calculations would work out the number of hours in \( 5 \) weeks?

<Answer>\( 5 \times 7 \times 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 12 hours in 1 day</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from weeks to hours</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \times 5 \times 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 5 days in a week</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of three or more dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 5 \) red balls and \( 4 \) yellow balls in a cup ![A cup with 5 red and 4 yellow balls in it. All of the balls are the same size.]() Kate picks out three balls at the same time.

She wants to work out the probability all the balls are red.

What is the denominator of the final unsimplified answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than multiplies for combined probabilities</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of three or more dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 5 \) red balls and \( 4 \) yellow balls in a cup ![A cup with 5 red and 4 yellow balls in it. All of the balls are the same size.]() Kate picks out three balls at the same time.

She wants to work out the probability all the balls are red.

What is the denominator of the final unsimplified answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the denominator in a combined probablity will be the same as the denominator in the probability of the first event.</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 729 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reduce the denominator when an item is not replaced in a probability question</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute a solution back into the remaining equation and find the second solution</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Nick has almost solved a pair of simultaneous equations.
He just needs to find the value of \( y \).
He writes down:
\[
3-y=5
\]

What is the correct value of \( y \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation where there is a negative sign in front of the variable at the final stage, believes they can ignore it and treat it as if it's positive</Misconception>

<Answer>A</Answer>

<Construct>Understand the term mutually exclusive</Construct>

Picking a \( \mathrm{P} \) and a vowel are known as...
</Question>
<Answer>Independent events</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot identify mutually exclusive events</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>Probability events</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot identify mutually exclusive events</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing expressions
Tom says \( \frac{p}{q} \) is equivalent to \( \frac{q}{p} \)
Katie says \( p q \) is equivalent to \( q p \)
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing expressions
Tom says \( \frac{p}{q} \) is equivalent to \( \frac{q}{p} \)
Katie says \( p q \) is equivalent to \( q p \)
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing expressions
Tom says \( \frac{p}{q} \) is equivalent to \( \frac{q}{p} \)
Katie says \( p q \) is equivalent to \( q p \)
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplication is not commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret sloping linear sections of a displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows how far Jodie is from home whilst she is out on a walk.
What might the positive sloping section represent? ![A distance time graph formed by three line segments in the shape of a trapezium. The first line segment is upward sloping and starts at 0. The end of this line segment is connected to a horizontal line that is extending to the right. The third line connects this line to the x axis and has a relatively steep negative gradient.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Jodie is accelerating</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the gradient of a distance-time graph is the acceleration</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret sloping linear sections of a displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows how far Jodie is from home whilst she is out on a walk.
What might the positive sloping section represent? ![A distance time graph formed by three line segments in the shape of a trapezium. The first line segment is upward sloping and starts at 0. The end of this line segment is connected to a horizontal line that is extending to the right. The third line connects this line to the x axis and has a relatively steep negative gradient.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Jodie is walking towards home</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an upward slope on a distance-time graph means travelling back towards the starting point.</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret sloping linear sections of a displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows how far Jodie is from home whilst she is out on a walk.
What might the positive sloping section represent? ![A distance time graph formed by three line segments in the shape of a trapezium. The first line segment is upward sloping and starts at 0. The end of this line segment is connected to a horizontal line that is extending to the right. The third line connects this line to the x axis and has a relatively steep negative gradient.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Jodie has stopped walking</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes an upward slope on a distance-time graph means the movement has stopped</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify triangular numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\( 1,3,6,10,15,21,28 \ldots \) What is the name commonly given to this sequence of numbers?
</Question>
<Answer>The square numbers</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes square numbers are triangle numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify triangular numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\( 1,3,6,10,15,21,28 \ldots \) What is the name commonly given to this sequence of numbers?
</Question>
<Answer>The cube numbers</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks cube numbers are triangular numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify triangular numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\( 1,3,6,10,15,21,28 \ldots \) What is the name commonly given to this sequence of numbers?
</Question>
<Answer>The Fibonacci numbers</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes Fibonacci numbers are triangle numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Compare the lengths of diagonal line segments without calculating the exact length</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
![A coordinate grid with a line segment labelled K from (-1,2) to (4,3) and a line segment marked L from (-3,-4) to (-2,0)]() What can you say about line segments \( \mathrm{K} \) and \( \mathrm{L} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \mathrm{K} \) and \( \mathrm{L} \) are the same length</Answer>
<Misconception>Estimates the length of diagonal lines rather than working out based on horizontal and vertical measurements</Misconception>

<Construct>Compare the lengths of diagonal line segments without calculating the exact length</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
![A coordinate grid with a line segment labelled K from (-1,2) to (4,3) and a line segment marked L from (-3,-4) to (-2,0)]() What can you say about line segments \( \mathrm{K} \) and \( \mathrm{L} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>We don't have enough information without measuring them</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not believe the length of a diagonal line can be worked out based on horizontal and vertical measurements</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation would give you the area of the face of this cuboid labelled \( \boldsymbol{Q} \) ('the base')? ![An image of a cuboid, with the height marked as 7cm, the width as 4cm and the depth as 2cm. The bottom face is shaded red and marked Q. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \mathrm{~cm} \times 4 \mathrm{~cm} \times 7 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds volume when asked for surface area</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Surface Area of Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation would give you the area of the face of this cuboid labelled \( \boldsymbol{Q} \) ('the base')? ![An image of a cuboid, with the height marked as 7cm, the width as 4cm and the depth as 2cm. The bottom face is shaded red and marked Q. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \mathrm{~cm} \times 7 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot identify the correct side lengths to use when asked to find the area of a face</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the surface area of a cuboid where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \mathrm{~cm} \times 7 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot identify the correct side lengths to use when asked to find the area of a face</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate
\(
\frac{2}{5} \div 3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{6}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>when dividing a fraction by an integer, multiplies the numerator by the integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate
\(
\frac{2}{5} \div 3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{15}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing fractions, does the reciprocal of the first fraction instead of the second</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate
\(
\frac{2}{5} \div 3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{6}{15} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing a fraction by an integer, multiplies both the numerator and denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange a quadratic equation so that it is in the correct form to be factorised</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
What would be the most useful first step if we wanted to solve the following quadratic equation?

\(
x^{2}-5 x=6
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Add \( 5 x \) to both sides of the equation</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise a quadratic must be in the form ax^2+bx+c=0 to be factorised</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange a quadratic equation so that it is in the correct form to be factorised</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
What would be the most useful first step if we wanted to solve the following quadratic equation?

\(
x^{2}-5 x=6
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Divide by \( x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise a quadratic must be in the form ax^2+bx+c=0 to be factorised</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange a quadratic equation so that it is in the correct form to be factorised</Construct>

<Question>
What would be the most useful first step if we wanted to solve the following quadratic equation?

\(
x^{2}-5 x=6
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Square root both sides of the equation</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise a quadratic must be in the form ax^2+bx+c=0 to be factorised</Misconception>

<Misconception>Divided by 100 rather than 1000</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 609.000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds 3 decimal places rather than moving 3 places</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving non-linear variables</Construct>

\(

\)

What is the value of \( R \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving non-linear variables</Construct>

\)

What is the value of \( R \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can add or subtract from inside brackets without expanding when solving an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the equation of a line when given a positive gradient and a point on the line</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Equation of a Line</Subject>
<Question>
A line has a gradient of \( 4 \) and passes through the point \( (1,9) \). What is it's equation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=4 x+8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the y intercept is given by the difference between the x and y coordinates of any point on the line, not just the point (0, c) </Misconception>

<Construct>Work out the equation of a line when given a positive gradient and a point on the line</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Equation of a Line</Subject>
<Question>
A line has a gradient of \( 4 \) and passes through the point \( (1,9) \). What is it's equation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=4 x+9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes  c, in y=mx+c, will be the y value of the coordinate given despite the x coordinate not being 0.</Misconception>

27,64,125, \ldots
\]

<Answer>The odd numbers</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up odd and even numbers</Misconception>

<Answer>The square numbers</Answer>

<Answer>The triangular numbers</Answer>

Tom</Answer>

Tom and Katie are arguing about angle relationships on parallel lines.
Tom says allied (co-interior) angles are equal.
Katie says corresponding angles are equal.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks corresponding angles sum to 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Compare two pie charts</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
These pie charts show how people travel to work in two towns. The populations of the towns are given. In which town do more people travel to work by train? ![A diagram showing two pie charts and a key. The key consists of car, bike, walk and train. The pie chart for town A (population 2000) has 1/2 a pie chart for bike, 1/4 for car and two smaller sections for walk and train. The pie chart for town B (population 10 000) has a proportion just under 1/2 for bike, a section just over 1/4 for walk, and just under a 1/4 for train. The section for car is very small.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Town A</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the frequency represented by a pie chart sector can be judged visually, without considering the total it represents</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 0.0 \)</Answer>

\( 0.009753 \)

</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.01 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to wrong degree of accuracy (decimal places rather than significant figures)</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 0.0097 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 180° about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object </Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
![A pair of axes: x-axis is from -3 to 4; y-axis is from -4 to 4. A quadrilateral, labelled "P", is made by joining the following points, in order, with straight lines: (-3, 1), (-1, 1), (-1, 3), (-3, 4) and back to (-3, 1). The point (-1, 3) is marked with a red dot.
Also, the following points are plotted and labelled with the following letters: A (3, 1); B (1, -1); C (3, -1); D (1, -3).]() Shape \( \mathrm{P} \) is rotated \( 180^{\circ} \) through the origin.

Where will the red point be on the rotated shape?
</Question>
<Answer>A</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to rotate by 180 degrees rotates by 90 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 180° about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object </Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
![A pair of axes: x-axis is from -3 to 4; y-axis is from -4 to 4. A quadrilateral, labelled "P", is made by joining the following points, in order, with straight lines: (-3, 1), (-1, 1), (-1, 3), (-3, 4) and back to (-3, 1). The point (-1, 3) is marked with a red dot.
Also, the following points are plotted and labelled with the following letters: A (3, 1); B (1, -1); C (3, -1); D (1, -3).]() Shape \( \mathrm{P} \) is rotated \( 180^{\circ} \) through the origin.

Where will the red point be on the rotated shape?
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Rotates by the wrong center of rotation (not including the origin)</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 180° about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object </Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
![A pair of axes: x-axis is from -3 to 4; y-axis is from -4 to 4. A quadrilateral, labelled "P", is made by joining the following points, in order, with straight lines: (-3, 1), (-1, 1), (-1, 3), (-3, 4) and back to (-3, 1). The point (-1, 3) is marked with a red dot.
Also, the following points are plotted and labelled with the following letters: A (3, 1); B (1, -1); C (3, -1); D (1, -3).]() Shape \( \mathrm{P} \) is rotated \( 180^{\circ} \) through the origin.

Where will the red point be on the rotated shape?
</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Reflects instead of rotates</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of horizontal lines from a diagram</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( y=7 x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Includes the x variable when giving the equation of a horizontal line</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x=7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the equations of vertical and horizontal lines</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide two decimals with the same number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.2 \div 0.4= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than divides</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide two decimals with the same number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.2 \div 0.4= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise that the diameter is twice the radius</Construct>
<Subject>Parts of a Circle</Subject>
<Question>
If the diameter of a circle is \( 5.4 \mathrm{~cm} \), the radius is...
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10.8 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Doubles the diameter when finding the radius</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise that the diameter is twice the radius</Construct>
<Subject>Parts of a Circle</Subject>
<Question>
If the diameter of a circle is \( 5.4 \mathrm{~cm} \), the radius is...
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5.4 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses diameter and radius</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a formula to describe a situation</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Formula</Subject>
<Question>
A taxi driver charges an initial \( £ 2.50 \) plus \( £ 1.20 \) per mile travelled. Which of the following expressions is correct for the total cost, \( T \), of a journey of \( \boldsymbol{m} \) miles?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \mathrm{T}=2.50 \mathrm{~m}+1.20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gets their constants and coefficients the wrong way around when writing a formula from a given situation</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a formula to describe a situation</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Formula</Subject>
<Question>
A taxi driver charges an initial \( £ 2.50 \) plus \( £ 1.20 \) per mile travelled. Which of the following expressions is correct for the total cost, \( T \), of a journey of \( \boldsymbol{m} \) miles?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \mathrm{T}=1.20(2.50+m) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has made an order of operations mistake when writing a formula from a given situation</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a formula to describe a situation</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Formula</Subject>
<Question>
A taxi driver charges an initial \( £ 2.50 \) plus \( £ 1.20 \) per mile travelled. Which of the following expressions is correct for the total cost, \( T \), of a journey of \( \boldsymbol{m} \) miles?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \mathrm{T}=3.70 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Combines variables with constants when writing a formula from a given situation</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a right-angled triangle where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that the area of a triangle is half the area of the contatining rectangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest 1000</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 637 \) rounded to the nearest \( 1000 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 500 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest 1000</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 637 \) rounded to the nearest \( 1000 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form x(x + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about how to solve this equation: 

\(
x^{2}+4 x=0
\)

Tom says one solution is \( x=2 \)

Katie says one solution is \( x=0 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks x^2 - a^2x is a valid form of difference of two squares</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of volume or capacity</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
James has answered a question on volume. His answer is 8.5.
Behind the star he has written the units that he used.

\(
8.5 \,\bigstar
\)

Which of the following units is definitely wrong?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that units of volume are usually cubed</Misconception>

\(
8.5 \,\bigstar
\)

Which of the following units is definitely wrong?

<Answer>\( m^{3} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Identify a unit of volume or capacity</Construct>

\(
8.5 \,\bigstar
\)

Which of the following units is definitely wrong?
</Question>
<Answer>\( l \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise litres as a unit of volume</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete a symmetric figure with respect to a specific line of symmetry</Construct>
<Subject>Line Symmetry</Subject>
<Question>
Which image completes a symmetric figure using the red line of symmetry? ![A shape composed of coloured squares is drawn on the left side of a vertical line of symmetry]()
</Question>
<Answer>![The shape has been reflected in the line of symmetry, but the coloured squares are not in the corresponding places]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete a symmetric figure with respect to a specific line of symmetry</Construct>
<Subject>Line Symmetry</Subject>
<Question>
Which image completes a symmetric figure using the red line of symmetry? ![A shape composed of coloured squares is drawn on the left side of a vertical line of symmetry]()
</Question>
<Answer>![The shape has been translated right by 4 squares so that it is now on the right hand side of the line of symmetry, but has not changed orientation]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Translates rather than reflects across a line of symmetry</Misconception>

<Construct>Draw the net of a prism</Construct>

<Question>
This is an incomplete net for a triangular prism.

What shapes do you add to complete this net? ![An incomplete net of a triangular prism comprising a rectangle (landscape) and an equilateral triangle. These 2 shapes are attached to each other along one side (the righthand shorter side of the rectangle, which is the same length as the sides of the triangle). ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \) triangles</Answer>
<Misconception>Struggles to visualise nets of 3D shapes</Misconception>

<Construct>Draw the net of a prism</Construct>
<Subject>Nets</Subject>
<Question>
This is an incomplete net for a triangular prism.

What shapes do you add to complete this net? ![An incomplete net of a triangular prism comprising a rectangle (landscape) and an equilateral triangle. These 2 shapes are attached to each other along one side (the righthand shorter side of the rectangle, which is the same length as the sides of the triangle). ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \) rectangles</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses pyramid with prism</Misconception>

<Construct>Draw the net of a prism</Construct>
<Subject>Nets</Subject>
<Question>
This is an incomplete net for a triangular prism.

What shapes do you add to complete this net? ![An incomplete net of a triangular prism comprising a rectangle (landscape) and an equilateral triangle. These 2 shapes are attached to each other along one side (the righthand shorter side of the rectangle, which is the same length as the sides of the triangle). ]()
</Question>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
The area of the trapezium on the right is \( 12 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \). ![A trapezium with the parallel sides a and b labelled x -1 and x + 3 and the perpendicular height as x.]() Based on the information given, Adam writes this formula:
\(x^{2}+x=12\)

What are the two solutions to this equation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}x=4 \\ \text { and } \\ x=3\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solutions of a quadratic equation are the absolute values of the constants in the factorised form</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form (x + a)(x + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
The area of the trapezium on the right is \( 12 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \). ![A trapezium with the parallel sides a and b labelled x -1 and x + 3 and the perpendicular height as x.]() Based on the information given, Adam writes this formula:
\(x^{2}+x=12\)

What are the two solutions to this equation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}x=4 \\ \text { and } \\ x=-3\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the solutions of a quadratic equation are the constants in the factorised form</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of horizontal lines from a diagram</Construct>

<Question>
What is the equation of this line? ![A set of axes with a line drawn on. The lines passes through the points: (0,2) (1,2) (2,2) (3,2) and (4,2)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks x = ? is a horizontal line through ? </Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of horizontal lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this line? ![A set of axes with a line drawn on. The lines passes through the points: (0,2) (1,2) (2,2) (3,2) and (4,2)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=2 y \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the equation of a horizontal line is in the form x = ay, where a is the y intercept</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of horizontal lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this line? ![A set of axes with a line drawn on. The lines passes through the points: (0,2) (1,2) (2,2) (3,2) and (4,2)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=2 x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Includes the x variable when giving the equation of a horizontal line</Misconception>

The base of the shape is horizontal and is 11cm long. The vertical height of the whole shape is 12cm. The horizontal width of the top part of the shape is 5cm. The vertical height of the bottom rectangle is labelled 4cm. The top rectangle is shaded.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

<Question>
What is the area of the shaded section of this composite shape made from rectangles? ![A composite shape that makes a backwards "L" shape from 2 rectangles.  The base of the shape is horizontal and is 11cm long. The vertical height of the whole shape is 12cm. The horizontal width of the top part of the shape is 5cm. The vertical height of the bottom rectangle is labelled 4cm. The top rectangle is shaded.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 60 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Beileves you can use the full length when finding an area of part of a composite shape, when part of the length is needed</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx - c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
If
\(
m^{2}+3 m-28 \equiv(m+a)(m+b)
\)
then \( a \times b= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the coefficent of x in an expanded quadratic comes from multiplying the two numbers in the brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx - c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
If
\(
m^{2}+3 m-28 \equiv(m+a)(m+b)
\)
then \( a \times b= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 28 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising into double brackets, believes the product of the constants in the brackets is of the opposite sign to the constant in the expanded equation.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic inequalities from the graph of the quadratic</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Use the graph to approximate the solution to \( x^{2}+2 x-3<-3 \) ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2+2x-3 drawn on.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x<-2, x>0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Selects y>a solutions instead of y<a solutions for a quadratic inequality</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just one linear variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following by collecting like terms.
\[
4 x+6 x-3 x
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 x-3 x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When collecting like terms, only simplifies when there is an addition</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just one linear variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following by collecting like terms.
\[
4 x+6 x-3 x
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 13 x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When collecting like terms, treats subtractions as if they are additions</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the solution to one problem, deduce the answer to a related problem using the same operation</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing related calculations
Tom says if you know that \( 4122+426=4548 \), then \( 4122+428 \) must equal \( \mathbf{4 5 5 0} \)

Katie says if you know that \( 4122-426=3696 \), then \( 4122-428 \) must equal \( \mathbf{3 6 9 4} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that subtracting a larger number will give a smaller answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the solution to one problem, deduce the answer to a related problem using the same operation</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing related calculations
Tom says if you know that \( 4122+426=4548 \), then \( 4122+428 \) must equal \( \mathbf{4 5 5 0} \)

Katie says if you know that \( 4122-426=3696 \), then \( 4122-428 \) must equal \( \mathbf{3 6 9 4} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that adding a larger number gives a larger answer</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand what each part of a bar model represents as a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a trapezium where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Sally wants to calculate the area of this trapezium using the formula: Area \( =\left(\frac{a+b}{2}\right) h \) ![A trapezium with the parallel sides labelled 6cm and 2cm, the slant height labelled 7cm and the perpendicular height labelled 5cm.]() What is the values of \( h \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise the height of a trapezium as the perpendicular length between the parallel sides</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a trapezium where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Sally wants to calculate the area of this trapezium using the formula: Area \( =\left(\frac{a+b}{2}\right) h \) ![A trapezium with the parallel sides labelled 6cm and 2cm, the slant height labelled 7cm and the perpendicular height labelled 5cm.]() What is the values of \( h \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses slant height instead of perpendicular height to find area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a trapezium where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise the height of a trapezium as the perpendicular length between the parallel sides</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Nick wants to subtract \( 98 \) from a number.
Which one of the following methods would give him the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( +100 \) then \( +2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than subtracts when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Nick wants to subtract \( 98 \) from a number.
Which one of the following methods would give him the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -100 \) then \( -2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the effect of consecutive subtractions</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>The same length</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the arrows for parallel lines mean equal length</Misconception>

<Question>
The arrows tell us that these two sides are... ![Parallelogram PQRS with sides QR and PS labelled with arrows]()
</Question>
<Answer>Opposite</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>Equilateral</Answer>

<Construct>Identify that a problem needs to be solved using multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Problem 1: What is the product of \( 17 \) and \(32\)?
Problem 2: Each person in a group of \( 17 \) people owns \( 32 \) pieces of art. How many pieces of art does the group own in total?
Which of these problems needs multiplication to solve it?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Problem \( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise when to find a multiple from a worded question</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify that a problem needs to be solved using multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Problem 1: What is the product of \( 17 \) and \(32\)?
Problem 2: Each person in a group of \( 17 \) people owns \( 32 \) pieces of art. How many pieces of art does the group own in total?
Which of these problems needs multiplication to solve it?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Problem \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that product means add rather than multiply</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for an ascending fractional linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{7}{6}, \frac{4}{3}, \frac{3}{2}, \frac{5}{3}, \ldots \) When calculating the nth-term rule of this sequence, what should replace the star? ![Text: "nth-term rule:" followed by a star, n and a purple rectangle. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
\( input\Rightarrow(+1) \Rightarrow(\times2) \Rightarrow9\) What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 19 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reverses the order of operations but does not apply the inverse operations when finding the input of a function machine</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 19 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reverses the order of operations but does not apply the inverse operations when finding the input of a function machine</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reverse the order of operations when finding the input of a function machine</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal place to percentages</Construct>

<Question>
Convert this decimal to a percentage
\(
0.07
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.07 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you need to just add a % sign to a decimal to convert to a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal place to percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
Convert this decimal to a percentage
\(
0.07
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.7 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by 10 instead of 100 when converting decimal to percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal place to percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
Convert this decimal to a percentage
\(
0.07
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 70 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by 1000 instead of 100 when converting a decimal to a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the gradient of a line written in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Gradient and Intercept of a Line from the Equation</Subject>
<Question>
In which region would \( x-y=2 \) belong? ![A Venn diagram with two overlapping sets. The set on the left is 'Crosses the y-axis at (0,-2)' and the set on the right is 'Has a positive gradient'. A is in only 'Crosses the y-axis at (0,-2)' set, B is in the intersection, C is in only  'Has a positive gradient' set and D is outside both sets.]()
</Question>
<Answer>C</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the constant gives the y-intercept even when a line is not written in the form y = mx + c</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide a decimal by an integer</Construct>

\( 1, \quad 0.1, \quad 0.01 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.333 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you divide 1 by the number of values, rather than the total, when finding the mean</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems that combine addition or subtraction with multiplication</Construct>

How much do they have altogether?
Which calculation would not find the answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 2.80 \times 4-£ 0.04 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think that the compensation strategy for the multiplication of 2 numbers is valid.</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \frac{16}{9} \mathrm{~m}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies up without finding unit price in proportion question</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Interpret a bar chart</Construct>
<Subject>Block Graphs and Bar Charts</Subject>
<Question>
![A bar chart with blue vertical bars. The x-axis is titled "Fruits" and the y-axis is titled "Number of Children" and its scale is from 0 to 50 in steps of 10. The bars represent the following numbers of children: Banana, 30; Apple, 20; Kiwi, 30; Orange, 35; Pineapple, 10.]() \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Type of Fruit & Number of Children\\
\hline Banana & \( 30 \) \\
\hline Apple & \\
\hline Kiwi & \( 30 \) \\
\hline Orange & \\
\hline Pineapple & \( 10 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Using the bar chart, what two numbers are missing from the table?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \) and \( 30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading graph, chooses nearest marked value on axis instead of reading accurately</Misconception>

\[

<Construct>Substitute positive non-integer values into formulae involving no powers or roots where you need to find a value that is not the subject</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation forgets to eliminate the coefficient in front of the variable in the last step</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive non-integer values into formulae involving no powers or roots where you need to find a value that is not the subject</Construct>

<Answer>\( -8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation forgets to eliminate the coefficient in front of the variable in the last step</Misconception>

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>

\(t+3>-0.3\)

Jo says \( t \) could be \( -3.4 \)

Paul says \( t \) could be \( 3.4 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes negative numbers with a larger absolute value are greater</Misconception>

\[

\]</Answer>

<Construct>Recognise and use the law of distributivity</Construct>

<Question>

\(
7 \times 9=5 \times 9+2 \times 9
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Commutativity</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise the distributive property</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use the law of distributivity</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
What word do we use to describe the relationship:
\(
7 \times 9=5 \times 9+2 \times 9
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Factors</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes splitting a multiplication using the distributive property is the same as splitting it into factors</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use the law of distributivity</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>

\(
7 \times 9=5 \times 9+2 \times 9
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Associativity</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise the distributive property</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( (x+12) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising into double brackets, finds the sum of two values which give the non variable term in the expression rather than the product</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( (x-7) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the first three terms of a sequence ![\( \begin{array}{llll}98 & 92 & 86 & \ldots\end{array} \)]() Find an expression for the nth term of this sequence.
</Question>
<Answer>\( -6 n+92 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that in the nth term of a descending sequence, b is the difference between the term and the positive multiple of n</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the first three terms of a sequence ![\( \begin{array}{llll}98 & 92 & 86 & \ldots\end{array} \)]() Find an expression for the nth term of this sequence.
</Question>
<Answer>\( -6 n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks terms in linear sequence are in direct proportion</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Here are the first three terms of a sequence ![\( \begin{array}{llll}98 & 92 & 86 & \ldots\end{array} \)]() Find an expression for the nth term of this sequence.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 n+92 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the nth term of a descending sequence will have a positive coefficient of n</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the volume of a sphere, work out missing information</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Non-Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
A sphere has a volume of
\[
V \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \text {. }
\] ![A sphere with the radius labelled '?']() What is its radius?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt[3]{\frac{4 V \pi}{3}} \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the volume of a sphere, work out missing information</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Non-Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
A sphere has a volume of
\[
V \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \text {. }
\] ![A sphere with the radius labelled '?']() What is its radius?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt[3]{\frac{4 V}{3 \pi}} \mathrm{cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing by a fraction, switches to multiplication without also using the reciprocal</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the volume of a sphere, work out missing information</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Non-Prisms</Subject>
<Question>
A sphere has a volume of
\[
V \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \text {. }
\] ![A sphere with the radius labelled '?']() What is its radius?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3 \sqrt[3]{V}}{4 \pi} \mathrm{cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reverse the order of operations when solving an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Alisha is using cups and counters to help her solve an equation. Which would be the correct start to work it out? ![Three diagrams of equations shown with cups and counters. 
Step 1 is one cup plus four counters equals two cups and two counters.
Step 2 is four counters equals one cup plus two counters.
Step 3 is two counters equals one cup.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 x=6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Alisha is using cups and counters to help her solve an equation. Which would be the correct start to work it out? ![Three diagrams of equations shown with cups and counters. 
Step 1 is one cup plus four counters equals two cups and two counters.
Step 2 is four counters equals one cup plus two counters.
Step 3 is two counters equals one cup.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}x+4=2 x+2 \\ 3 x=6\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring no scaling of expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of simultaneous equations would have no solutions?
\begin{array}{ccc} 
Pair \( 1 \) & Pair \( 2 \) \\
\( 2 y-2 x=7 \) & & \( 2 x+2 y=7 \) \\
\( 2 x-2 y=7 \) & & \( 2 x-2 y=7 \)
\end{array}
</Question>
<Answer>Both Pair \( 1 \) and Pair \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes 0 is not a real solution to an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>

<Question>
\( \frac{6}{7} \times \frac{2}{3}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{9}{7} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses dividing fractions method for multiplying fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{6}{7} \times \frac{2}{3}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{8}{21} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, adds the numerators and multiplies the denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive non-integer values into expressions involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are discussing quadratic equations.

Jo says there is no value of \( x \) that can make \( (1-x)^{2} \) negative.

Paul says there is no value of \( x \) that can make \( 1-x^{2} \) positive.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive non-integer values into expressions involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are discussing quadratic equations.

Jo says there is no value of \( x \) that can make \( (1-x)^{2} \) negative.

Paul says there is no value of \( x \) that can make \( 1-x^{2} \) positive.
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the square of a negative will also be negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the circle when this expression is fully factorised? \( 9 y^{2}+4 y \equiv \bigstar(\triangle y+\bigcirc) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \bigcirc=4 y \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising into single brackets, only factors out the numerical values and forgets to factorise possible variables</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
![Graph titled height of rocket with Height in metres versus time in seconds]() How many metres did the rocket travel between \( 10 \) and \( 40 \) seconds?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that addition should be used when finding the difference between two values on a time series graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
![Graph titled height of rocket with Height in metres versus time in seconds]() How many metres did the rocket travel between \( 10 \) and \( 40 \) seconds?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the difference between two points on a time series graph, only uses one of the points. </Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
![Graph titled height of rocket with Height in metres versus time in seconds]() How many metres did the rocket travel between \( 10 \) and \( 40 \) seconds?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the difference between two points on a time series graph, only uses one of the points. </Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form ax² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following answers shows a correct factorisation of the expression below? \( 2 x^{2}-50 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2\left(x^{2}-25\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise difference of two squares</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form ax² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following answers shows a correct factorisation of the expression below? \( 2 x^{2}-50 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2(x-5)(x-5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Factorises difference of two squares with the same sign in both brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out subtraction problems involving two negative integers </Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( (-6)-(-8)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 14 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores the negative signs when adding positive and negative numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out subtraction problems involving two negative integers </Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( (-6)-(-8)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -14 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative number, subtracts the absolute value rather than adding it</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out subtraction problems involving two negative integers </Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( (-6)-(-8)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative thinks the answer must be negative </Misconception>

<Construct>Express one quantity as a percentage of another mentally</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
I increase \( £ 200 \) by \( 50 \% \).
Then, I increase the new amount by \( 10 \% \).
What percentage of the original amount do I have now?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 155 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In repeated percentage change, believes the second change is only a percentage of the first change, without including the original</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise cube numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these is a cube number?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks numbers are a multiple of their index</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise cube numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these is a cube number?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up square numbers and cube numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise cube numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these is a cube number?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks numbers are a multiple of their index</Misconception>

![An orange cube]() How many faces does this cube have?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the terms faces and edges</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![Two arrows in a line, both pointing right. The first one has '- 3' in it, the second one has 'x 5' in it. ]() The rule above is used to generate a term-to-term sequence.
If the third term is \( 35 \), what is the first term?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the term after</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![Two arrows in a line, both pointing right. The first one has '- 3' in it, the second one has 'x 5' in it. ]() The rule above is used to generate a term-to-term sequence.
If the third term is \( 35 \), what is the first term?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the definition of term or term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given output find the input of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
![Two arrows in a line, both pointing right. The first one has '- 3' in it, the second one has 'x 5' in it. ]() The rule above is used to generate a term-to-term sequence.
If the third term is \( 35 \), what is the first term?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the first term of a sequence must be 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to percentages containing 1 decimal place</Construct>

\(
\frac{27}{200}
\)

<Answer>\( 27 \% \)</Answer>
