<Construct>Convert from days to seconds</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following would correctly calculate the number of seconds in \( 1 \) day?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 \times 60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converted hours to minutes instead of hours to seconds</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from days to seconds</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following would correctly calculate the number of seconds in \( 1 \) day?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \times 60 \times 60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 12 hours in 1 day</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to three or more significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{2 . 5 0 6 7 1 0} \) rounded to three significant figures?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.507 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the value of zeros as placeholders</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to three or more significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{2 . 5 0 6 7 1 0} \) rounded to three significant figures?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers greater than 1 to three or more significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Significant Figures</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{2 . 5 0 6 7 1 0} \) rounded to three significant figures?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.00 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the sector angle on a pie chart for a given group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
A diver wants to make a pie chart of his trip. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & Frequency & Degrees \\
\hline Manta Ray & \( 16 \) & \( 180 \) \\
\hline Hammerhead & \( 4 \) & \( 45 \) \\
\hline Conger Eel & \( 12 \) & \( \mathrm{~F} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which one of these is a correct method for finding F?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 360-180+45 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not include brackets when required</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the sector angle on a pie chart for a given group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
A diver wants to make a pie chart of his trip. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & Frequency & Degrees \\
\hline Manta Ray & \( 16 \) & \( 180 \) \\
\hline Hammerhead & \( 4 \) & \( 45 \) \\
\hline Conger Eel & \( 12 \) & \( \mathrm{~F} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which one of these is a correct method for finding F?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{12}{20} \times 360 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes to find the proportion of a pie chart sector you do frequency/sum of other frequencies rather than frequency/overall total</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the sector angle on a pie chart for a given group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
A diver wants to make a pie chart of his trip. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline & Frequency & Degrees \\
\hline Manta Ray & \( 16 \) & \( 180 \) \\
\hline Hammerhead & \( 4 \) & \( 45 \) \\
\hline Conger Eel & \( 12 \) & \( \mathrm{~F} \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} Which one of these is a correct method for finding F?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{360}{32} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the degrees for 1 person rather than the required number of people for a pie chart sector</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the properties of an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
An isosceles triangle must have ...
</Question>
<Answer>no equal side lengths.</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses isosceles and scalene triangles</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the properties of an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
An isosceles triangle must have ...
</Question>
<Answer>one pair of parallel sides.</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the word parallel</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the properties of an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Properties of Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
An isosceles triangle must have ...
</Question>
<Answer>three equal angles.</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses isosceles and equilateral triangles</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 7, y-axis from -2 to 8. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 4), (4, 4), (2, 7). Point (2, 4) is labelled with the letter "P". The line y=4 is shown with a blue dashed line.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected </Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 7, y-axis from -2 to 8. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 4), (4, 4), (2, 7). Point (2, 4) is labelled with the letter "P". The line y=4 is shown with a blue dashed line.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected </Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 7, y-axis from -2 to 8. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 4), (4, 4), (2, 7). Point (2, 4) is labelled with the letter "P". The line y=4 is shown with a blue dashed line.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,-4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reflects in an axis, instead of the given mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive y value, find an x value in a table of values for lines in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\[
y=6 x
\] \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of subtraction is multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive y value, find an x value in a table of values for lines in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\[
y=6 x
\] \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>There is no possible solution</Answer>
<Misconception>Doesn't believe that when you divide by 0 the answer will always be 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a midpoint and a coordinate work out the position of the other coordinate, where at least one value is negative and at least one is a non-integer</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Here are two points and their midpoint.
What should replace the triangle? ![The image is a set of axes with three points marked. One point is (1,7). The midpoint is (-1, 0.5). The third point is given as (star, triangle), so the triangle is the y value of the point.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \Delta=-7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Given a line segment with a midpoint that is not the origin, assumes that the two end points will still have the same absolute value</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a midpoint and a coordinate work out the position of the other coordinate, where at least one value is negative and at least one is a non-integer</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Here are two points and their midpoint.
What should replace the triangle? ![The image is a set of axes with three points marked. One point is (1,7). The midpoint is (-1, 0.5). The third point is given as (star, triangle), so the triangle is the y value of the point.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \Delta=-6.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes midpoint calculation is just half of the difference</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand products of three binomials in the form (x + a)(x + b)(x + c)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Triple Brackets and more</Subject>
<Question>
Ori is expanding these three brackets:
\(
(x+2)(x-4)(x-7)
\)

He finds it helpful to split the first bracket and view the problem as follows:
\(
x(x-4)(x-7)+2(x-4)(x-7)
\)

He expands the brackets further. Before he simplifies, what are the terms than contain an \( x^{2} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}+7 x^{2} \\ +4 x^{2} \\ +2 x^{2}\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores negative sign when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify that a problem needs to be solved using multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would solve this problem?
Fred is monitoring the growth of his plant. The plant grew \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) every week for \( 35 \) weeks.
By how much did the plant grow in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 35 \div 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides rather than multiplies when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify that a problem needs to be solved using multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would solve this problem?
Fred is monitoring the growth of his plant. The plant grew \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) every week for \( 35 \) weeks.
By how much did the plant grow in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 35-7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts rather than multiplies when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify that a problem needs to be solved using multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would solve this problem?
Fred is monitoring the growth of his plant. The plant grew \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) every week for \( 35 \) weeks.
By how much did the plant grow in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 35+7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than multiplies when asked for a total</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
What fraction replaces the question mark? ![A bar split into 5 equal parts, with two shaded. One of the shaded parts is labelled with a question mark.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies the wrong part of a fraction model as the whole</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer decimal problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation should you do first?
\(
((0.5 \div(0.2+0.4)-0.3) \times 0.6)
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.5 \div 0.2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer decimal problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Which calculation should you do first?
\(
((0.5 \div(0.2+0.4)-0.3) \times 0.6)
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.3 \times 0.6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from right to left regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Insert brackets to make a calculation correct</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
12 \times 6-1+2
\]
Where do the brackets need to go to make the answer equal \( 36 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \times 6-(1+2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs subtraction in wrong order</Misconception>

<Construct>Insert brackets to make a calculation correct</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
12 \times 6-1+2
\]
Where do the brackets need to go to make the answer equal \( 36 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \times(6-1+2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)</Misconception>

<Construct>Insert brackets to make a calculation correct</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
12 \times 6-1+2
\]
Where do the brackets need to go to make the answer equal \( 36 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>Does not need brackets</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from right to left regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of three or more dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 4 \) red balls and \( 3 \) yellow balls in a cup ![A cup with 4 red and 3 yellow balls in it. All of the balls are the same size.]() Kate picks out three balls at the same time.

She wants to work out the probability all the balls are red.

What is the denominator of the final unsimplified answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than multiplies for combined probabilities</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of three or more dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 4 \) red balls and \( 3 \) yellow balls in a cup ![A cup with 4 red and 3 yellow balls in it. All of the balls are the same size.]() Kate picks out three balls at the same time.

She wants to work out the probability all the balls are red.

What is the denominator of the final unsimplified answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 343 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that choosing 2 items at once means the first item does not get replaced in a probability question</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of three or more dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 4 \) red balls and \( 3 \) yellow balls in a cup ![A cup with 4 red and 3 yellow balls in it. All of the balls are the same size.]() Kate picks out three balls at the same time.

She wants to work out the probability all the balls are red.

What is the denominator of the final unsimplified answer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 18 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than multiplies for combined probabilities</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}a\rightarrow\times 3\rightarrow+4\rightarrow4+3 a \\ a\rightarrow \times 3\rightarrow+4\rightarrow3(4+a)\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}a\rightarrow+4 \rightarrow\times 3\rightarrow4+3 a \\ a \rightarrow\times 3\rightarrow+4\rightarrow-3(4+a)\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given algebraic input, find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following pairs of function machines are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}a\rightarrow4 \rightarrow\times 3\rightarrow4+3 a \\ a\rightarrow+4\rightarrow\times 3\rightarrow3(4+a)\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify common multiples of three or more numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following numbers is a common multiple of \( 4,6 \) and \( 12 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses factors and multiples</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify common multiples of three or more numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following numbers is a common multiple of \( 4,6 \) and \( 12 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 18 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies a common multiple of two numbers when asked to consider a common multiple of three numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify common multiples of three or more numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following numbers is a common multiple of \( 4,6 \) and \( 12 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies a multiple of a number but not a common multiple of a group of numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out missing number subtraction problems involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( \fbox{-5} \) x\( \hspace{0.2cm} \fbox{4} = \hspace{0.2cm} \fbox{-12} - \hspace{0.2cm}\fbox{ ? } \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative number, subtracts the absolute value rather than adding it</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out missing number subtraction problems involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( \fbox{-5} \) x\( \hspace{0.2cm} \fbox{4} = \hspace{0.2cm} \fbox{-12} - \hspace{0.2cm}\fbox{ ? } \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -32 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiplication, division and power law of indices with positive integer powers</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
\(\frac{\left(5^{6}\right)^{4}}{5^{2}} \equiv 5^{n}\)

What is the value of \( n \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a power raised to a power leads to addition of the powers</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiplication, division and power law of indices with positive integer powers</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
\(\frac{\left(5^{6}\right)^{4}}{5^{2}} \equiv 5^{n}\)

What is the value of \( n \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes when dividing numbers with the same base you divide the powers, rather than subtracting</Misconception>

<Construct>Select the correct answer to an iteration question to the required degree of accuracy</Construct>
<Subject>Trial and Improvement and Iterative Methods</Subject>
<Question>
\(
x_{n+1}=10-\frac{1}{x_{n}}
\)

Using a starting value of \( x_{1}=4 \), what is the solution to \( x=10-\frac{1}{x} \) to \( 2 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9.8989 \ldots \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>

<Construct>Select the correct answer to an iteration question to the required degree of accuracy</Construct>
<Subject>Trial and Improvement and Iterative Methods</Subject>
<Question>
\(
x_{n+1}=10-\frac{1}{x_{n}}
\)

Using a starting value of \( x_{1}=4 \), what is the solution to \( x=10-\frac{1}{x} \) to \( 2 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9.75 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes substituting the starting value into an iteration formula immediately gives the solution</Misconception>

<Construct>Select the correct answer to an iteration question to the required degree of accuracy</Construct>
<Subject>Trial and Improvement and Iterative Methods</Subject>
<Question>
\(
x_{n+1}=10-\frac{1}{x_{n}}
\)

Using a starting value of \( x_{1}=4 \), what is the solution to \( x=10-\frac{1}{x} \) to \( 2 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9.9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (significant figures rather than decimal places)</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify factors of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Factors and Highest Common Factor</Subject>
<Question>
\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
      & Multiple of \( 4 \) & Not a multiple of \( 4 \) \\
\hline Factor of \( 60 \) & A & B \\
\hline Not a factor of \( 60 \) & C & D \\
\hline
\end{tabular} In which box should you place \( \mathbf{3 0} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>D</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the term factor</Misconception>

<Answer>\( n, 2 n, 3 n \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( 108 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence?
\[
2, \quad 5, \quad 14, \quad 41 \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you add \( 3 \) to the previous term</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence?
\[
2, \quad 5, \quad 14, \quad 41 \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you double the previous term and add \( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a term-to-term sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following term-to-term rule describes this sequence?
\[
2, \quad 5, \quad 14, \quad 41 \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>To get the next term you square the previous term and add \( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 100 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In ratio question where one side of ratio is given, treats that as the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>

She then has a second pick.

What is the probability the second pick is a red ball?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5}{9} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reduce the denominator when an item is not replaced in a probability question</Misconception>

\[
3,4,3,4,4
\]

<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for the mean of a list of data, gives the mode</Misconception>

\[
1,1,4,6,7,7
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When there are two modes, finds the mean of these values and gives that as the mode</Misconception>

\[
1,1,4,6,7,7
\]
</Question>
<Answer>There is no mode</Answer>

<Construct>Manipulate both equations so that they are in a form to be added or subtracted</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to get this pair of simultaneous equations in a form where they can eliminate \( y \) \(( 1)\)  \(-2 x+6 y=4 \)
\( (2)\)  \( x+2 y=8 \) Tom says you need to multiply equation \( (2) \) by \( 3 \).

Katie says you need to multiply equation \( (1) \) by \( 2 \) and multiply equation \( (2) \) by \( 6 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations, thinks they can't multiply each equation by a different number</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing ways to calculate \( 28 \times 15 \) mentally Tom does \( 28 \times 5 \) and then multiplies his answer by \( 3 \) Katie does \( 14 \times 15 \) and then doubles her answer Who would get the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that multiplication can be broken down into factors</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that fractions with larger denominators are greater in size</Misconception>

<Construct>Use angles around a point to form and solve algebraic equations</Construct>

<Answer>\( 2 f-20=180 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Use angles around a point to form and solve algebraic equations</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following equations is true based on the diagram? ![Angles around a point made up of two angles labelled: f and f-20]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( f^{2}-20=360 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks index notation represents repeated addition rather than repeated multiplication</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( f-20=f \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses vertically opposite angles and angles around a point</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \mathrm{GFH} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

<Question>

The point is reflected in the line \( y=-x \)

What are the new coordinates of point Q?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (4.4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a point on the line of reflection will stay the same when reflected </Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

<Answer>\( (-4,-4) \)</Answer>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

<Question>
A point, \( Q \), has coordinates \( (4,-4) \)

The point is reflected in the line \( y=-x \)

What are the new coordinates of point Q?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-4,4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes reflection in y = -x switches x and y coordinates</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>

\( 12 \div 2+1 \times 2= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the order of operations, believes addition comes before division</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 12 \div 2+1 \times 2= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 14 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Answer>C</Answer>

<Construct>Identify when rounding a calculation will give an over or under approximation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to estimate the answer to
\[
38.8745 \div 7.9302
\]

Tom says \( 40 \div 7.9302 \) would give an overestimate.

Katie says \( 38.8745 \div 8 \) would give an overestimate.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the larger the divisor, the larger the answer.</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify when rounding a calculation will give an over or under approximation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to estimate the answer to
\[
38.8745 \div 7.9302
\]

Tom says \( 40 \div 7.9302 \) would give an overestimate.

Katie says \( 38.8745 \div 8 \) would give an overestimate.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the larger the divisor, the larger the answer.</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify when rounding a calculation will give an over or under approximation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to estimate the answer to
\[
38.8745 \div 7.9302
\]

Tom says \( 40 \div 7.9302 \) would give an overestimate.

Katie says \( 38.8745 \div 8 \) would give an overestimate.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the larger the dividend, the smaller the answer.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the ages of people on a university running team.
To calculate the mean age, what is the most sensible heading for the third column? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|l|}
\hline Age & Frequency & \\
\hline \( 18 \) & \( 7 \) & \\
\hline \( 19 \) & \( 3 \) & \\
\hline \( 20 \) & \( 1 \) & \\
\hline \( 21 \) & \( 2 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>Age + Frequency</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplies</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the ages of people on a university running team.
To calculate the mean age, what is the most sensible heading for the third column? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|l|}
\hline Age & Frequency & \\
\hline \( 18 \) & \( 7 \) & \\
\hline \( 19 \) & \( 3 \) & \\
\hline \( 20 \) & \( 1 \) & \\
\hline \( 21 \) & \( 2 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>Age - Frequency</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of multiplies</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
This table shows the ages of people on a university running team.
To calculate the mean age, what is the most sensible heading for the third column? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|l|}
\hline Age & Frequency & \\
\hline \( 18 \) & \( 7 \) & \\
\hline \( 19 \) & \( 3 \) & \\
\hline \( 20 \) & \( 1 \) & \\
\hline \( 21 \) & \( 2 \) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>Age \( \div \)
Frequency</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides rather than multiplies </Misconception>

<Construct>Identify triangular numbers</Construct>

<Question>
\( 1,3,6,10,15,21,28 \ldots \) What is the name commonly given to this sequence of numbers?
</Question>
<Answer>The cube numbers</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks cube numbers are triangular numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify triangular numbers</Construct>

<Question>
\( 1,3,6,10,15,21,28 \ldots \) What is the name commonly given to this sequence of numbers?
</Question>
<Answer>The Fibonacci numbers</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes Fibonacci numbers are triangle numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Manipulate both equations so that they are in a form to be added or subtracted</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Sandeep wants to eliminate \( l \) from these simultaneous equations.
\(\begin{array}{l}
2 l+3 m=13 \\
3 l+4 m=17
\end{array}\)

First he will transform both of them to get them in an appropriate form.
Which of the following is a correct transformation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}6 l+9 m=13 \\ 6 l+8 m=17\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations, thinks you only transform the algebraic terms, rather than the whole equation.</Misconception>

<Construct>Manipulate both equations so that they are in a form to be added or subtracted</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Sandeep wants to eliminate \( l \) from these simultaneous equations.
\(\begin{array}{l}
2 l+3 m=13 \\
3 l+4 m=17
\end{array}\)

First he will transform both of them to get them in an appropriate form.
Which of the following is a correct transformation?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}6 l+3 m=13 \\ 6 l+4 m=17\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations, thinks you only transform the term that is being eliminated, rather than the whole equation.</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method</Construct>

<Question>
If you use the grid method to calculate \( 27 \times 42 \) what should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline\( \times \) & \( 20 \) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline \( 40 \) & \(\space\) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\)\\
\hline \( 2 \) & \(\space\) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 47 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplies</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method</Construct>

<Question>
If you use the grid method to calculate \( 27 \times 42 \) what should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline\( \times \) & \( 20 \) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline \( 40 \) & \(\space\) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\)\\
\hline \( 2 \) & \(\space\) & \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 28 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying involving a multiple of 10, gives an answer 10 times smaller than it should be</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, involving negative integers</Construct>

<Question>
Solve the equation:
\[
-3=p+12
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( p=9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using long multiplication</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you write the carried value in the number rather than adding it to the next place value column</Misconception>

<Construct>Division law of indices with positive integer powers and the same base number</Construct>

<Question>
Simplify (if possible):
\(
6^{9} \div 6^{3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes when dividing numbers with the same base you divide the powers, rather than subtracting</Misconception>

<Construct>Division law of indices with positive integer powers and the same base number</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify (if possible):
\(
6^{9} \div 6^{3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing numbers with the same base divides the base numbers and the powers</Misconception>

<Construct>Division law of indices with positive integer powers and the same base number</Construct>

<Question>
Simplify (if possible):
\(
6^{9} \div 6^{3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1^{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing numbers with the same base correctly subtracts the powers but divides the base numbers.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve a non-linear equation using a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which function machine will solve the equation \( x^{2}+5=14 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>![A function machine showing x as the input then +5 then squaring to give 14 as the output. Then a reverse function machine underneath showing 14 (the output) now as the input square root and then -5]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not follow the arrows through a function machine, changes the order of the operations asked.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve a non-linear equation using a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which function machine will solve the equation \( x^{2}+5=14 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>![A function machine showing 14 as the input then squaring and +5 to give the output]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve a non-linear equation using a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Which function machine will solve the equation \( x^{2}+5=14 ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>![A function machine showing x as the input then x2 then +5 to give 14 as the output. Then a reverse function machine underneath showing 14 (the output) now as the input  -5 and then divide by 2]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to two significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about rounding.

Tom says \( \mathbf{0 . 0 3 4 5 6} \) rounded to \( 2 \) significant figures is \( \mathbf{0 . 0 3} \)

Katie says \( 0.03456 \) rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places is \( \mathbf{0 . 0 3} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to wrong degree of accuracy (decimal places rather than significant figures)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to two significant figures</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about rounding.

Tom says \( \mathbf{0 . 0 3 4 5 6} \) rounded to \( 2 \) significant figures is \( \mathbf{0 . 0 3} \)

Katie says \( 0.03456 \) rounded to \( 2 \) decimal places is \( \mathbf{0 . 0 3} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (significant figures rather than decimal places)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round non-integers to other non-integer values (e.g. 0.02)</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{1 . 5 1 6} \) rounded to the nearest \( \mathbf{0 . 0 5} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.55 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds up instead of down</Misconception>

<Construct>Round non-integers to other non-integer values (e.g. 0.02)</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to Decimal Places</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \mathbf{1 . 5 1 6} \) rounded to the nearest \( \mathbf{0 . 0 5} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.52 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too little)</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 2 \)

Which of the options is a correct second step to express the following as a single fraction?
\(
\begin{array}{c}
\frac{9}{x+3}-\frac{2}{x} \\
=\frac{9 x}{x(x+3)}-\frac{2(x+3)}{x(x+3)}
\end{array}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{9}{3}-\frac{2(3)}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Incorrectly cancels what they believe is a factor in algebraic fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 2 \)

Which of the options is a correct second step to express the following as a single fraction?
\(
\begin{array}{c}
\frac{9}{x+3}-\frac{2}{x} \\
=\frac{9 x}{x(x+3)}-\frac{2(x+3)}{x(x+3)}
\end{array}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{9}{x+3}-\frac{2}{x} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand how to subtract algebraic fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract algebraic fractions where the denominators are linear expressions, eg (x + 5) and (x - 3), and the numerators are single terms</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
STEP \( 2 \)

Which of the options is a correct second step to express the following as a single fraction?
\(
\begin{array}{c}
\frac{9}{x+3}-\frac{2}{x} \\
=\frac{9 x}{x(x+3)}-\frac{2(x+3)}{x(x+3)}
\end{array}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{9 x-2(x+3)}{x(x+3)-x(x+3)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert ratios to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
A lassi drink is made of yoghurt and water in the ratio 5:1. What fraction of the drink is water?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When converting ratio to fractions, puts the other side of the ratio as the denominator rather than the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert ratios to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
A lassi drink is made of yoghurt and water in the ratio 5:1. What fraction of the drink is water?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gets order of ratio wrong</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert ratios to fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
A lassi drink is made of yoghurt and water in the ratio 5:1. What fraction of the drink is water?
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the relationship between a ratio and fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of subtraction</Construct>

“It doesn't matter if you do \( 81-53 \) or \( 53-81 \), you get the same answer."

What do you think?
</Question>
<Answer>Miran is correct because subtraction is commutative</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of subtraction</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Miran says the following:

“It doesn't matter if you do \( 81-53 \) or \( 53-81 \), you get the same answer."

What do you think?
</Question>
<Answer>Miran is incorrect because subtraction is commutative</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the meaning of the word commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of subtraction</Construct>

“It doesn't matter if you do \( 81-53 \) or \( 53-81 \), you get the same answer."

What do you think?
</Question>
<Answer>Miran is correct because subtraction is not commutative</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the meaning of the word commutative </Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x \leq-1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When representing an inequality on a numberline, assumes the filled and unfilled circles have the opposite meaning.</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the volume scale factor of similar shapes given the length scale factor</Construct>
<Subject>Length, Area and Volume Scale Factors</Subject>
<Question>
![Two cuboids. Cuboid P has width 5cm, and cuboid Q has width 15cm.]() Shape P and Shape Q are similar.

What is the volume scale factor to get from Shape \( P \) to Shape \( Q \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \times 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that the volume of an enlarged shape is the volume of the original multiplied by the cube of the scale factor of the lengths.</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \times 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that the volume of an enlarged shape is the volume of the original multiplied by the cube of the scale factor of the lengths.</Misconception>

<Answer>\( x=2 \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( \frac{4}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Gives the probability out of the number of non-successes rather than the total</Misconception>

<Misconception>Writes the numerator and the denominator the wrong way round in a probability</Misconception>

<Subject>Straight Line Graphs-Others</Subject>
<Question>

<Misconception>Believes linear graphs can be curved</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a linear graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Straight Line Graphs-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a linear function?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph that starts in the top left, drops steeply down as you move right, briefly levels off, then steeply up back to the same level as the starting point, forming a symmetrical U shape.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes linear graphs can be curved</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a linear graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Straight Line Graphs-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a linear function?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph with two curves. One curve is in the negative x, positive y quadrant. It starts at the bottom left close to the x axis, as we move right it rises very quickly towards the y axis then levels off to travel almost parallel to the y axis.
The other curve is in the negative y, positive x quadrant. It starts at the bottom left close to the y axis, as we move right it rises very quickly towards the x axis then becomes almost horizontal to travel almost parallel to the x axis. ]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses linear and reciprocal graphs</Misconception>

<Construct>Order negative decimals with a different number of digits</Construct>

Tom says \( -12>-9 \)

Katie says \( -0.401>-0.41 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes negative numbers with a larger absolute value are greater</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 80 \% \) of \( 300 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that dividing by 100 gives 10%</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets: \( -3(m-2) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 m+6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a single term over a bracket where the term on the outside is a number and the inside contains a linear expression</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Multiply out the brackets: \( -3(m-2) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 m-6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
\[
x^{2}-5 x+8 \equiv(x-b)^{2}+1.75
\]
What is the value of \( b \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square, believes the constant in the bracket is the coefficient of x</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>
<Subject>Completing the Square</Subject>
<Question>
\[
x^{2}-5 x+8 \equiv(x-b)^{2}+1.75
\]
What is the value of \( b \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6.25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square in the form (x - a)^2 + b, believes b is the difference between a and the constant of the original quadratic</Misconception>

<Construct>Round decimals to the nearest whole number</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Jane measures the length and width of her rectangular classroom as \( 9.1 \mathrm{~m} \) and \( 11.7 \mathrm{~m} \).
Which calculation will give the best estimate of the area?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \times 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds every number up when estimating</Misconception>

<Construct>Round decimals to the nearest whole number</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Jane measures the length and width of her rectangular classroom as \( 9.1 \mathrm{~m} \) and \( 11.7 \mathrm{~m} \).
Which calculation will give the best estimate of the area?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \times 11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify percentages of a shape where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Fractions of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What percentage of this shape is shaded? ![A bar split into 5 equal parts. 3 parts are shaded.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumed each part of a fraction diagram is worth 10%</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify percentages of a shape where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Fractions of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What percentage of this shape is shaded? ![A bar split into 5 equal parts. 3 parts are shaded.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand a percentage is out of 100</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify percentages of a shape where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>

<Question>
What percentage of this shape is shaded? ![A bar split into 5 equal parts. 3 parts are shaded.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 55 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Estimated when not appropriate</Misconception>

<Construct>Express pictorial representations of objects as a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
What is the ratio of rectangles to circles? ![A diagram showing 5 blue rectangles and 4 red circles]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5: 4: 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you need to include the total as well as the individual parts when asked to write a ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Express pictorial representations of objects as a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
What is the ratio of rectangles to circles? ![A diagram showing 5 blue rectangles and 4 red circles]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4: 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up sides of a ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Express pictorial representations of objects as a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
What is the ratio of rectangles to circles? ![A diagram showing 5 blue rectangles and 4 red circles]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5: 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When writing ratio from diagram, writes total as one side</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand inequality notation</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these statements show that \( \mathrm{j} \) is smaller than \( 5 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( j=5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses inequality symbols with equality</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand inequality notation</Construct>
<Subject>Inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these statements show that \( \mathrm{j} \) is smaller than \( 5 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \mathrm{j}>5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive non-integer values into formulae involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate the time taken \( (t) \) for a a particle to travel with acceleration \( (a)=4.1 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2} \), initial velocity \( (u)=2.8 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \) and final velocity \( (v)=8.7 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \) \( t=\frac{1}{a}(v-u) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}t=\frac{1}{4.1}+(8.7-2.8) \\ t=6.14\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a variable next to a number means addition rather than multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive non-integer values into formulae involving powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate the time taken \( (t) \) for a a particle to travel with acceleration \( (a)=4.1 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2} \), initial velocity \( (u)=2.8 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \) and final velocity \( (v)=8.7 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1} \) \( t=\frac{1}{a}(v-u) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}t=4.1 \times(8.7-2.8) \\ t=24.19\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, multiplies the denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise perpendicular lines</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
![An image of 8 line segments on a square grid. AB is a vertical line measuring 4 units. CD is a diagonal line, with a positive gradient of 1.5. EF is a vertical line measuring 3 units. GH is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -4/6. IJ is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -3. KL is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 1/3. MN is a vertical line measuring 6 units. OP is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 6/4.]() Which line segment is perpendicular to IJ?
</Question>
<Answer>EF</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the meaning of perpendicular and vertical </Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise perpendicular lines</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
![An image of 8 line segments on a square grid. AB is a vertical line measuring 4 units. CD is a diagonal line, with a positive gradient of 1.5. EF is a vertical line measuring 3 units. GH is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -4/6. IJ is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -3. KL is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 1/3. MN is a vertical line measuring 6 units. OP is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 6/4.]() Which line segment is perpendicular to IJ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \mathrm{MN} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the meaning of perpendicular and vertical </Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute numbers into a SUVAT equation to work out distance</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\( s=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2} \) What is the value of \( S \) when
\[\begin{array}{l} a=4 \\ u=3 \\ t=5\end{array}\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 625 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When a variable in an expression has a power, thinks the power applies to the whole expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Work out: \( \frac{5}{7}-\frac{1}{4} \) Give your answer in the simplest form.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{27}{28} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of subtracts</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Work out: \( \frac{5}{7}-\frac{1}{4} \) Give your answer in the simplest form.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Work out: \( \frac{5}{7}-\frac{1}{4} \) Give your answer in the simplest form.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{7} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to change the numerators when finding equivalent fractions</Misconception>

\(
T=k^{4}
\)

What is the value of \( T \) when \( k=-3 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -81 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute negative integer values into formulae involving powers or roots</Construct>

\(
T=k^{4}
\)

What is the value of \( T \) when \( k=-3 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has multiplied the base number and the power</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following answers shows a correct factorisation of the expression below? \( x^{2}-9 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x(x-9) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise difference of two squares</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - c</Construct>
<Subject>Difference of Two Squares</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following answers shows a correct factorisation of the expression below? \( x^{2}-9 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x-3)^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the factorised form of repeated roots and the difference of 2 squares</Misconception>

Which of the following answers shows a correct factorisation of the expression below? \( x^{2}-9 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Cannot be factorised</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise difference of two squares</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \frac{7}{12} \)</Answer>

\(
\frac{2}{x}+\frac{3}{x}
\)

<Answer>\( \frac{5 x}{x^{2}} \)</Answer>

\(
\frac{2}{x}+\frac{3}{x}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{6}{x^{2}} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to add fractions uses the method for multiplying fractions instead.</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the reciprocal of an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
What is the reciprocal of \( 7 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -\frac{1}{7} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Correctly finds the reciprocal of a number, but believes it should be opposite in sign to the original number.</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the reciprocal of an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
What is the reciprocal of \( 7 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Makes the number negative when asked to find the reciprocal</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the line of symmetry of curves in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>

<Question>
This is the graph of \( y=(x+4)(x-2) \) ![\( W \)]() What is the equation of the line of symmetry?
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=-1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the equations of vertical and horizontal lines</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following as simply as possible: \( \frac{6 p-9}{6 p-3} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{p-3}{p-1} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you can divide the variables and the numerical values by different numbers when simplifying an algebraic fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer fraction problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{3}= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5}{18} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Answer fraction problems that require the use of BIDMAS</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( \frac{1}{3}+\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{3}= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{9} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form x(x + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve this equation, giving all solutions:
\(
k^{2}-8 k=0
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}k=-8 \\ \text { or } \\ k=8\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks x^2 - a^2x is a valid form of difference of two squares</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form x(x + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve this equation, giving all solutions:
\(
k^{2}-8 k=0
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( k=8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they can divide by a variable without checking whether it could equal zero</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sector angle on a pie chart, calculate the frequency of a group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
The pie chart shows the favourite subjects of children at a school.

If \( 18 \) students chose Science, how many chose French? ![A pie chart split into four parts, labelled with school subjects. The part for Mathematics is 144 degrees, Science is 36 degrees, English is 72 degrees and French is 108 degrees.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 36 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the angle in a pie chart sector is equal to the frequency</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sector angle on a pie chart, calculate the frequency of a group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
The pie chart shows the favourite subjects of children at a school.

If \( 18 \) students chose Science, how many chose French? ![A pie chart split into four parts, labelled with school subjects. The part for Mathematics is 144 degrees, Science is 36 degrees, English is 72 degrees and French is 108 degrees.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 108 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the angle in a pie chart sector is equal to the frequency</Misconception>

<Construct>Perform subtraction calculations using standard form</Construct>
<Subject>Standard Form</Subject>
<Question>
\( \left(3 \times 10^{4}\right)-\left(2 \times 10^{5}\right)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.7 \times 10^{-5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a negative power results in a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Perform subtraction calculations using standard form</Construct>
<Subject>Standard Form</Subject>
<Question>
\( \left(3 \times 10^{4}\right)-\left(2 \times 10^{5}\right)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \times 10^{-1} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating with numbers in standard form, just applies the operation to the number and the power separately</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the net of a prism</Construct>
<Subject>Nets</Subject>
<Question>
This is the net of a... ![An image of six connected rectangles. The six rectangles are 3 lots of identical rectangle pairs. There is a central rectangle with identical rectangles attached to the left and right of it. It then has identical rectangles attached to its top and bottom sides. Below the rectangle attached to the bottom side is another attached rectangle which is identical to the central rectangle.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Rectangle</Answer>
<Misconception>Names one of the faces of a 3D shape rather than the 3D shape name</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the net of a prism</Construct>
<Subject>Nets</Subject>
<Question>
This is the net of a... ![An image of six connected rectangles. The six rectangles are 3 lots of identical rectangle pairs. There is a central rectangle with identical rectangles attached to the left and right of it. It then has identical rectangles attached to its top and bottom sides. Below the rectangle attached to the bottom side is another attached rectangle which is identical to the central rectangle.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Cube</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up cubes and cuboids</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the net of a prism</Construct>
<Subject>Nets</Subject>
<Question>
This is the net of a... ![An image of six connected rectangles. The six rectangles are 3 lots of identical rectangle pairs. There is a central rectangle with identical rectangles attached to the left and right of it. It then has identical rectangles attached to its top and bottom sides. Below the rectangle attached to the bottom side is another attached rectangle which is identical to the central rectangle.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Rectanglebased pyramid</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses pyramid with prism</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify parallel lines written in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about parallel lines. 
Tom says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{5} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{7} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{3 x + 7} \) are parallel. 
Katie says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{5} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{7} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{5} \boldsymbol{x}-\mathbf{2 2} \) are parallel. 
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes lines are parallel if they have the same y intercept </Misconception>

<Construct>Identify parallel lines written in the form y = mx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about parallel lines. 
Tom says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{5} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{7} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{3 x + 7} \) are parallel. 
Katie says \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{5} \boldsymbol{x}+\mathbf{7} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{5} \boldsymbol{x}-\mathbf{2 2} \) are parallel. 
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes lines can be parallel by having the same y intercept OR gradient</Misconception>

\(
0.4=\frac{2}{5}< \_\_\_\_
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand inequality notation</Misconception>
