<Construct>Recognise a reciprocal graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Cubics and Reciprocals</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a reciprocal function?
</Question>
<Answer>![A curved graph that starts just above the x-axis on the left and travels right and very gradually up. Just before it reaches the y-axis it travels more steeply up and right, going through a point on the y-axis above the origin and continually steeply rising up and right. ]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses reciprocal and exponential graphs</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a reciprocal graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Cubics and Reciprocals</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a reciprocal function?
</Question>
<Answer>![A curved graph that starts in the top left, travels steeply down and right, turns to travel steeply up and right, to the origin, where it turns around to travel down and right again.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>confuses cubic and reciprocal graphs</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a reciprocal graph from its shape</Construct>
<Subject>Cubics and Reciprocals</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is most likely to be the graph of a reciprocal function?
</Question>
<Answer>![A curved graph, an upside down symmetrical U shape. It starts in the bottom left, travels steeply up and right, turns at a point on the y-axis above the origin and travels steeply right and down.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses reciprocal and quadratic graphs</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the angles around a point relationship</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the relationship between these two angles? ![\( \theta \)]()
</Question>
<Answer>They are equal</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses vertically opposite angles and angles around a point</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the angles around a point relationship</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the relationship between these two angles? ![\( \theta \)]()
</Question>
<Answer>They are parallel</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the word parallel</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the angles around a point relationship</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Angle Facts (straight line, opposite, around a point, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is the relationship between these two angles? ![\( \theta \)]()
</Question>
<Answer>They add together to make \[180\degree\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes angles around a point sum to 180</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are not multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following fractions would lie between \( \frac{1}{5} \) and \( \frac{1}{4} \) on a number line?
</Question>
<Answer>There are no fractions between these two</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes unit fractions with a difference of 1 in the denominator have no other fractions between them</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( a, b \) and \( c \) are different numbers
\(
\frac{a+b}{c}=(a+b) \div c
\)
Is the above relationship...
</Question>
<Answer>never true</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can write a division as a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( a, b \) and \( c \) are different numbers
\(
\frac{a+b}{c}=(a+b) \div c
\)
Is the above relationship...
</Question>
<Answer>Need more information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can write a division as a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the meaning algebraic terms with no powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which statement correctly describes the following algebraic expression?
\(
3+a b
\)
</Question>
<Answer>"Add \( \mathrm{a} \) and \( \mathrm{b} \) then add three."</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks two variables next to each other represent addition</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the meaning algebraic terms with no powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which statement correctly describes the following algebraic expression?
\(
3+a b
\)
</Question>
<Answer>"Add three to a and then multiply by b."</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the meaning algebraic terms with no powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which statement correctly describes the following algebraic expression?
\(
3+a b
\)
</Question>
<Answer>"Add three to \( \mathrm{b} \) and then multiply by a."</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a trapezium, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
The area of this trapezium is \( 45 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \). What would the perpendicular height, \( h \), of the trapezium be? ![A trapezium with the parallel sides a and b labelled as 10cm and 5cm and the perpendicular height labelled with h]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( h=4.5 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the base and perpendicular height when calculating the area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a trapezium, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
The area of this trapezium is \( 45 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \). What would the perpendicular height, \( h \), of the trapezium be? ![A trapezium with the parallel sides a and b labelled as 10cm and 5cm and the perpendicular height labelled with h]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( h=3 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when calculating the area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the area of a trapezium, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
The area of this trapezium is \( 45 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \). What would the perpendicular height, \( h \), of the trapezium be? ![A trapezium with the parallel sides a and b labelled as 10cm and 5cm and the perpendicular height labelled with h]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( h=9 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the base and perpendicular height when calculating the area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the cube of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
\( 3^{3}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds the index to the number</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the cube of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
\( 3^{3}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the index</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the cube of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
\( 3^{3}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 33 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes the index as a digit on the end of a number</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of vertical lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this line? ![A graph showing a vertical line going through a number on the x axis. The number is one box to the right of -10, where there are 5 boxes between 0 and -10.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=-9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes every dash on a scale represents an increase of 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of vertical lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
What is the equation of this line? ![A graph showing a vertical line going through a number on the x axis. The number is one box to the right of -10, where there are 5 boxes between 0 and -10.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=-8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the equations of vertical and horizontal lines</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)(cx + d)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Molly is expanding these two brackets.

What should she get when she multiplies the two terms indicated by the arrows? ![The brackets shown are (2p-1)(3p-4). The arrows are pointing at the 2p in the first bracket and the -4 in the second bracket.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( +8 p \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide two decimals with the same number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.4 \div 0.6= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing, ignores any remainders</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide two decimals with the same number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 0.4 \div 0.6= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Express pictorial representations of objects as a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
![A group of six squares and three circles]() What is the ratio of squares to circles?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2: 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When writing ratio from diagram, writes total as one side</Misconception>

<Construct>Express pictorial representations of objects as a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
![A group of six squares and three circles]() What is the ratio of squares to circles?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6: 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When writing ratio from diagram, writes total as one side</Misconception>

<Construct>Express pictorial representations of objects as a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
![A group of six squares and three circles]() What is the ratio of squares to circles?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3: 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up sides of a ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the relationship between parts of a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Kate and Isaac share some biscuits in the ratio \( 1: 4 \). Isaac has  \( _____ \) times as many biscuits as Kate.
What number completes the sentence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that in a ratio 1:n that one part of the ratio would be n times bigger than the one part</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the relationship between parts of a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
Kate and Isaac share some biscuits in the ratio \( 1: 4 \). Isaac has  \( _____ \) times as many biscuits as Kate.
What number completes the sentence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that in a ratio 1:n that one part of the ratio would be n times bigger than the one part</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve missing number problems involving the median</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
The median of these four numbers is \( 5 \).
\(
\begin{array}{cccc}
3&12&1&?
\end{array}
\)
Find the value of the missing number.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the mean instead of the median</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
What is the \( 6 \) th pattern in this sequence? ![Three consecutive patterns in a sequence. The first pattern is one orange square. The second pattern is 3 orange squares arranged in an incomplete 2 by 2 square shape with the top left orange square missing. The third pattern is 5 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle with base 3 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![6 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 4 and height 2, with the top left and top right orange squares missing.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not notice all changes in a sequence of visual patterns</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
What is the \( 6 \) th pattern in this sequence? ![Three consecutive patterns in a sequence. The first pattern is one orange square. The second pattern is 3 orange squares arranged in an incomplete 2 by 2 square shape with the top left orange square missing. The third pattern is 5 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle with base 3 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![10 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 6 and height 2, with the top left and top right orange squares missing.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not notice all changes in a sequence of visual patterns</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 3 or more decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
Convert \( \frac{97}{250} \) into a decimal
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.97 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by using only the numerator after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 3 or more decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
Convert \( \frac{97}{250} \) into a decimal
</Question>
<Answer>\( 97.25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by placing a decimal point between the numerator and denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of the shaded section of this composite shape made from rectangles? ![A composite shape made from two rectangles that form an "L" shape.  The base of the shape is horizontal and is 13cm long. The vertical height of the whole shape is 14cm. The horizontal width of the top part of the shape is 6cm. The vertical height of the top rectangle is 8cm. The top rectangle is shaded red.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 14 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds when calculating area instead of multiplying</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of the shaded section of this composite shape made from rectangles? ![A composite shape made from two rectangles that form an "L" shape.  The base of the shape is horizontal and is 13cm long. The vertical height of the whole shape is 14cm. The horizontal width of the top part of the shape is 6cm. The vertical height of the top rectangle is 8cm. The top rectangle is shaded red.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 78 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating the area of a rectilinear compound shape, calculates the are of the surrounding rectangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of the shaded section of this composite shape made from rectangles? ![A composite shape made from two rectangles that form an "L" shape.  The base of the shape is horizontal and is 13cm long. The vertical height of the whole shape is 14cm. The horizontal width of the top part of the shape is 6cm. The vertical height of the top rectangle is 8cm. The top rectangle is shaded red.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 28 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Calculates perimeter when asked for area</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons</Construct>
<Subject>2D Names and Properties of Shapes-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing regular polygons.
Tom says if all the angles are Katie says if all the sides are equal equal then the polygon must be length then the polygon must be regular regular
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that only the angles need to be the same for a polygon to be regular</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons</Construct>
<Subject>2D Names and Properties of Shapes-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing regular polygons.
Tom says if all the angles are Katie says if all the sides are equal equal then the polygon must be length then the polygon must be regular regular
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that only the sides need to be equal for a polygon to be regular</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons</Construct>
<Subject>2D Names and Properties of Shapes-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing regular polygons.
Tom says if all the angles are Katie says if all the sides are equal equal then the polygon must be length then the polygon must be regular regular
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that all angles and sides must be equal for regular shapes</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to percentages containing 1 decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \frac{17}{40} \) written as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 34 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a fraction out of a number other than 100 represents a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to percentages containing 1 decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \frac{17}{40} \) written as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 68 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a fraction out of a number other than 100 represents a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions to percentages containing 1 decimal place</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Fractions and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( \frac{17}{40} \) written as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>17%</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a fraction out of a number other than 100 represents a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Construct a pictogram involving fractions of symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
This pictogram shows the different types of music Bob has in his music collection.
Bob has \( 2 \) rave CDs.

How would he display this on the pictogram? ![A pictogram showing the number of CDs Bob has in his musical collection. Pop has 3 and a half symbols, rock has 2 symbols, blues has 2 and a quarter symbols, jazz has 3 and a quarter symbols and classical has 1 and three-quarter symbols. Each symbol represents 4 CDs.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![\( 00 \)]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When interpreting a pictogram, thinks each symbol stands for 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate speed-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
Sunita accelerates quickly, then travels at a constant speed, then slowly comes to rest. Which of the following velocity \( (v) \) time \( (t) \) graphs is most likely to illustrate Sunita's journey?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph with time on the horizontal axis and distance on the vertical axis. The graph starts at the origin, travels right and up in a straight line, travels horizontally right, then travels right and down in a more steep straight line than the start, until it reaches the horizontal axis.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a steeper downwards line on a graph means a slower decrease</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify non-unit fractions when part of a shape</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
What mixed number fraction is represented below? ![Four bars, each split into six equal parts. In three of the shapes, all six parts are shaded. In the fourth shape, five out of six parts are shaded.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \frac{3}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When converting from an improper fraction to a mixed number, just writes the tens digit as the number of wholes</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify non-unit fractions when part of a shape</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
What mixed number fraction is represented below? ![Four bars, each split into six equal parts. In three of the shapes, all six parts are shaded. In the fourth shape, five out of six parts are shaded.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{23}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confused mixed numbers with improper fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
What is the 7th pattern in this sequence? ![Three consecutive patterns in a sequence. The first pattern is 1 orange square. The second pattern is 3 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 2 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing. The third pattern is 5 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 3 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![7 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 4 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence just gives the next term</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
What is the 7th pattern in this sequence? ![Three consecutive patterns in a sequence. The first pattern is 1 orange square. The second pattern is 3 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 2 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing. The third pattern is 5 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 3 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![9 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 5 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives a different term, which is not the next</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
What is the 7th pattern in this sequence? ![Three consecutive patterns in a sequence. The first pattern is 1 orange square. The second pattern is 3 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 2 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing. The third pattern is 5 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 3 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![11 orange squares arranged as an incomplete rectangle of base 6 and height 2, with the top left orange square missing.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives a different term, which is not the next</Misconception>

<Construct>Find another power of 10 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 10,000 \) more than \( 298,603 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 398,603 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding powers of 10 adds onto the wrong column</Misconception>

<Construct>Find another power of 10 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 10,000 \) more than \( 298,603 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2,986,030,000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than adds when given the command word 'more'</Misconception>

<Construct>Find another power of 10 more than a given number</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What number is \( 10,000 \) more than \( 298,603 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 208,603 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles in a scalene triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( p \) ? ![A triangle with angles labelled 49 degrees, 51 degrees and p [not to scale]]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 51^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks angles which look the same on diagram will be equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles in a scalene triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of angle \( p \) ? ![A triangle with angles labelled 49 degrees, 51 degrees and p [not to scale]]()
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that angles in a triangle sum to 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a positive non-integer</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{8}^{\boldsymbol{x}} \) \begin{tabular}{|l|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( \frac{1}{3} \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{8}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the index</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a positive non-integer</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{8}^{\boldsymbol{x}} \) \begin{tabular}{|l|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( \frac{1}{3} \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{8} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up square rooting and cube rooting</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a positive non-integer</Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{8}^{\boldsymbol{x}} \) \begin{tabular}{|l|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( \frac{1}{3} \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides by the index</Misconception>

<Construct>Write numbers between 0 and 1 in standard form</Construct>
<Subject>Standard Form</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following number in standard form:
\[
0.0003001
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.001 \times 10^{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think we can have negative powers in standard form</Misconception>

<Construct>Write numbers between 0 and 1 in standard form</Construct>
<Subject>Standard Form</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following number in standard form:
\[
0.0003001
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.1 \times 10^{-4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When changing a number to standard form omits zero's of significance </Misconception>

<Construct>Write numbers between 0 and 1 in standard form</Construct>
<Subject>Standard Form</Subject>
<Question>
Write the following number in standard form:
\[
0.0003001
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.1 \times 10^{-7} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of adds when answering worded problems </Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from mixed number fractions to improper fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Convert this into an improper fraction:
\(
4 \frac{2}{3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{42}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the number of wholes in a mixed number represents the tens from the numerator of an improper fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from mixed number fractions to improper fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Convert this into an improper fraction:
\(
4 \frac{2}{3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{11}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you multiply by the numerator and add the denominator when converting a mixed number to an improper fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert from mixed number fractions to improper fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Convert this into an improper fraction:
\(
4 \frac{2}{3}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{12}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to add the numerator when converting from a mixed number to an improper fraction </Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of vertical lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
![A set of axes with a vertical line going through 3 on the x axis]() What is the equation of this line?
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the equations of vertical and horizontal lines</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of vertical lines from a diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Horizontal and Vertical Lines</Subject>
<Question>
![A set of axes with a vertical line going through 3 on the x axis]() What is the equation of this line?
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=3 x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses lines of the form y = a and y= ax</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of length</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
George has answered a question on perimeter and worked out an answer of \( 310 \).

Behind the star he has written the units that he used.

Which of the following units is definitely wrong? \( 310 \color{yellow} \bigstar\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( m \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise metres as a unit of length</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of length</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
George has answered a question on perimeter and worked out an answer of \( 310 \).

Behind the star he has written the units that he used.

Which of the following units is definitely wrong? \( 310 \color{yellow} \bigstar\)
</Question>
<Answer>\(mm \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise millimetres as a unit of length</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of length</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
George has answered a question on perimeter and worked out an answer of \( 310 \).

Behind the star he has written the units that he used.

Which of the following units is definitely wrong? \( 310 \color{yellow} \bigstar\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( f t \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise feet (ft) as a unit of length</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Isaac's book. Isaac always records what operation he has done to both sides of the equation.
What operation should replace the star? ![The image shows two lines of working and an arrow from the top line to the bottom line with a star next to it where the operation would be labelled. The top line of working is x + 7 = ..., and the bottom line is x = ...]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( +7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Isaac's book. Isaac always records what operation he has done to both sides of the equation.
What operation should replace the star? ![The image shows two lines of working and an arrow from the top line to the bottom line with a star next to it where the operation would be labelled. The top line of working is x + 7 = ..., and the bottom line is x = ...]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \times 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of addition is multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Isaac's book. Isaac always records what operation he has done to both sides of the equation.
What operation should replace the star? ![The image shows two lines of working and an arrow from the top line to the bottom line with a star next to it where the operation would be labelled. The top line of working is x + 7 = ..., and the bottom line is x = ...]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \div 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of addition is division</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sketch of a curve in the form (x + a)(x + b), work out its factorised form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following could be the equation of this curve? ![A graph of a quadratic curve that crosses the x axis at (1,0) and (3,0) and crosses the y axis at (0,3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x+1)(x+3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to swap the sign of roots when placing into brackets</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sketch of a curve in the form (x + a)(x + b), work out its factorised form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following could be the equation of this curve? ![A graph of a quadratic curve that crosses the x axis at (1,0) and (3,0) and crosses the y axis at (0,3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x+1)(x-3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the link between the sign of the root and the sign in the bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sketch of a curve in the form (x + a)(x + b), work out its factorised form</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following could be the equation of this curve? ![A graph of a quadratic curve that crosses the x axis at (1,0) and (3,0) and crosses the y axis at (0,3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=(x-1)(x+3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the link between the sign of the root and the sign in the bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a bar model to express a ratio problem</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie share \( £ 30 \) in the ratio \( 3\;: 2 \).
Which of the following diagrams best represents this situation?
</Question>
<Answer>![A bar split into 3 pink blocks and 2 blue blocks. All the blocks are the same size and each block is labelled £30.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>In ratio where total is given, treats that as one part without dividing</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a bar model to express a ratio problem</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie share \( £ 30 \) in the ratio \( 3\;: 2 \).
Which of the following diagrams best represents this situation?
</Question>
<Answer>![A pink bar split into 3 blocks, and below it a shorter blue bar split into 2 blocks. All the blocks are the same size. The difference in length between the pink bar and the blue bar is labelled £30.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When drawing bar diagram for ratio, shows the total as the difference between parts</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a bar model to express a ratio problem</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie share \( £ 30 \) in the ratio \( 3\;: 2 \).
Which of the following diagrams best represents this situation?
</Question>
<Answer>![A pink bar split into 3 blocks, and below it a shorter blue bar split into 2 blocks. All the blocks are the same size. The length of the pink bar is labelled £30.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When drawing bar diagram for ratio, shows the total amount as the total of one side</Misconception>

<Construct>Add proper fractions with the same denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{2}{7}+\frac{1}{7}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{7} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies the numerators when adding fractions with a common denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Add proper fractions with the same denominator</Construct>

<Question>

\(
\frac{2}{7}+\frac{1}{7}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{49} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to add fractions, multiplies instead</Misconception>

<Construct>Add proper fractions with the same denominator</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{2}{7}+\frac{1}{7}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{3}{14} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding fractions, adds the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square root of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of the missing number? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{\( 15^{2} \)} \\
\hline\( \square^{2} \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the sum of 2 numbers, each squared first, is the same as adding the two numbers and then squaring the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square root of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of the missing number? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline \multicolumn{2}{|c|}{\( 15^{2} \)} \\
\hline\( \square^{2} \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Halves when asked to find the square root</Misconception>

\(
\square -7806=1253
\)
What is the \( 4^{\text {th }} \) digit of the number that belongs in the box?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of adds</Misconception>

\(

\)

<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>does not know the meaning of the word digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete missing number mental subtraction problems with numbers over 1000</Construct>

<Question>
A \( 4 \) digit number belongs in this box to make the calculation true
\(
\square -7806=1253
\)
What is the \( 4^{\text {th }} \) digit of the number that belongs in the box?
</Question>
<Answer>Not possible</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that addition is the inverse operation of subtraction</Misconception>

\( (-9)+(-4)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that adding a negative will increase the value of the original number</Misconception>

\( (-9)+(-4)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 13 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes adding two negatives gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate a descending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing sequences Tom says \( (2 n+1)^{2} \) would produce a linear sequence Katie says \( 1-\frac{n}{2} \) would produce a linear sequence Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate a descending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing sequences Tom says \( (2 n+1)^{2} \) would produce a linear sequence Katie says \( 1-\frac{n}{2} \) would produce a linear sequence Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Generate a descending integer linear sequence from the nth term rule</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing sequences Tom says \( (2 n+1)^{2} \) would produce a linear sequence Katie says \( 1-\frac{n}{2} \) would produce a linear sequence Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes linear sequences cannot include fractions</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 5.27 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When two digits sum to 10 or more during an addition problem, does not add one to the preceding digit</Misconception>

</Question>

What is the equation of the \( x \) axis?

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the range of this set of data?
\[
4 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 22 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 5 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 7 \mathrm{~cm}
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 22 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies the biggest value for the range</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the range of this set of data?
\[
4 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 22 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 5 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 7 \mathrm{~cm}
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the range is just the first value subtracted from the last value, without ordering</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the range of this set of data?
\[
4 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 22 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 5 \mathrm{~cm}, \quad 7 \mathrm{~cm}
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 26 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>To find the range adds the biggest and smallest number rather than subtract</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe an ascending linear sequence in words</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the most accurate way to describe this sequence?

\[
4,10,16,22,28, \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>The first term is \( 6 \) and the common difference is positive \( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the definition of term or term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems involving converting between fractions, decimals and percentages</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a percentage by writing the numerator followed by the denominator</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 2 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by 10 instead of 100 when converting decimal to percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a linear expression by taking out a single numeric common factor (e.g. 6)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the star and triangle when this expression is fully factorised? \( 8 m - 10 \equiv {\bigstar}(\triangle m-\bigcirc) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}{\bigstar}=8 \\ \Delta=1\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising, finds a factor that goes into only the first term of the expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a linear expression by taking out a single numeric common factor (e.g. 6)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the star and triangle when this expression is fully factorised? \( 8 m - 10 \equiv {\bigstar}(\triangle m-\bigcirc) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}{\bigstar}=5 \\ \Delta=3\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes factors add to give a number</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the \( x \)-axis
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 8, y-axis from -5 to 6. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 0), (4, 0), (2, 3). Point (2, 3) is labelled with the letter "P". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when a shape touches the mirror line, all of its vertices will stay the same when reflected</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a horizontal line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the \( x \)-axis
What are the new coordinates of point \( P \) ? ![A set of axes: x-axis from -1 to 8, y-axis from -5 to 6. Three points are plotted and joined to make a triangle: (2, 0), (4, 0), (2, 3). Point (2, 3) is labelled with the letter "P". ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3,2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that reflection always switches the x and y coordinates</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the equations of horizontal lines from a diagram</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x=4 y \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the equation of a horizontal line is in the form x = ay, where a is the y intercept</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( y=4 x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Includes the x variable when giving the equation of a horizontal line</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 90° and 180°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
Which diagram shows an angle of \( 135^{\circ} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, anti-clockwise, to the red line that is half way between 120 and 130 (inner scale) and halfway between 60 and 50 (outer scale).]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Chooses the correct scale when measuring angles on a protractor but starts from the wrong number when the angle is in between two labelled dashes</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 90° and 180°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
Which diagram shows an angle of \( 135^{\circ} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, anti-clockwise , to the red line that is half way between 40 and 50 (inner scale) and halfway between 140 and 130 (outer scale).]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring obtuse angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>

<Question>
The data is in ascending order.
\(
\begin{array}{llllll}
x & 5 & 8 & y & 19 & 25
\end{array}
\)
Write an expression for the range.
</Question>
<Answer>\( x-25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>subtracts the highest from the lowest when calculating the range</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>

\(
\begin{array}{llllll}
x & 5 & 8 & y & 19 & 25
\end{array}
\)
Write an expression for the range.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{57+y+x}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the mean instead of the range</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>The mass of sand in the bucket</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that gradient represents rate of change</Misconception>

<Question>

The second shape is also an L but with a bottom line of three squares. The fourth shape is the same but the bottom line is four squares long.  ]() Katie says this is a linear sequence: ![Three shapes made of squares. The first is an L-shape made of 3 squares. The second shape is an L made of 5 squares, two on the top row and three on the bottom row. The third shape is an L made of 7 squares, 3 on the top row and four on the bottom. ]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

Katie</Answer>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for reciprocal graphs</Construct>
<Subject>Cubics and Reciprocals</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\frac{\mathbf{1}}{\boldsymbol{x}} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a number divided by itself equals 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for reciprocal graphs</Construct>
<Subject>Cubics and Reciprocals</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\frac{\mathbf{1}}{\boldsymbol{x}} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a reciprocal equation is defined when the denominator is 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the midpoint between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( (5,3.5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes midpoint calculation is just half of the difference</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the midpoint between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
What is the midpoint of these two coordinates? ![A set of axes with two points (-4,5) and (6,2) plotted.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,7) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when finding midpoint</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring a scaling of both expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
If three cups of tea and two cups of coffee cost \( £ 2.40 \), and two cups of tea and five cups of coffee cost £3.80, what is the cost of a cup of tea and a cup of coffee?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}\text { Tea }=80 p, \\ \text { coffee }=44 p\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Form expressions from situations described in words</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
I think of a number. I add on five and then multiply the result by four. The answer I get is \( 17 \).
Which of the following equations represents this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( n+5 \times 4=17 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Form expressions from situations described in words</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
I think of a number. I add on five and then multiply the result by four. The answer I get is \( 17 \).
Which of the following equations represents this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 n+5=17 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not include brackets when attempting to multiply an expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>

<Question>
![An image of a function machine. The input is 20 and the function is squared.]() What is the output of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 40 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 22 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and addition</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>

<Question>
![An image of a function machine. The input is 20 and the function is squared.]() What is the output of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing ways to calculate \( 21 \times 12 \) mentally Tom does \( 12 \times 7 \) and then multiplies his answer by \( 3 \) Katie does \( 21 \times 6 \) and then doubles her answer Who would get the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the distributive property of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing ways to calculate \( 21 \times 12 \) mentally Tom does \( 12 \times 7 \) and then multiplies his answer by \( 3 \) Katie does \( 21 \times 6 \) and then doubles her answer Who would get the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the distributive property of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing ways to calculate \( 21 \times 12 \) mentally Tom does \( 12 \times 7 \) and then multiplies his answer by \( 3 \) Katie does \( 21 \times 6 \) and then doubles her answer Who would get the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the distributive property of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by dividing by a single letter</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Algebraic Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about simplifying fractions. Tom says \( \frac{3 p-1}{p} \equiv 2 \) Katie says \( \frac{3 p-1}{p} \equiv 3-\frac{1}{p} \) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Only applies a division to one of multiple terms in a numerator when simplifying an algebraic fraction</Misconception>

\[
0.6 \times 11
\]

<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>

\[
0.6 \times 11
\]

<Answer>\( 66 \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( 0.65 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses cl and ml</Misconception>

<Construct>Use inequality notation to order a negative and a positive integer</Construct>

<Question>
One of these pairs of numbers does not fit 
the inequality \( d \geq h \)

Can you find which pair?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}d=1 \\ h=-4\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( -6 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1 </Construct>

\(
5 h^{2}-3 h-2=0
\)

<Answer>\( -9 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Interpret the gradient on a linear section on a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
Jadon decides to go for a run starting from home.
The graph on the right shows Jadon's distance in metres \( (d) \) over time in seconds
\( (t) \).

The gradient of the negative sloping section of the graph is \( 0.5 \).

Which of the following does that \( 0.5 \) best represent? ![A sketch of a graph with d on the y axis and t on the x axis. A straight line slopes upwards from the origin 2/3 of the way up the graph, 1/5 across the graph. It then becomes horizontal for the next 1/5 of the graph, before sloping downwards in a straight line for the remainder of the graph. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Jadon is travelling away from home at a speed of \( 0.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a downward slope on a distance-time graph means travelling away</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret the gradient on a linear section on a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
Jadon decides to go for a run starting from home.
The graph on the right shows Jadon's distance in metres \( (d) \) over time in seconds
\( (t) \).

The gradient of the negative sloping section of the graph is \( 0.5 \).

Which of the following does that \( 0.5 \) best represent? ![A sketch of a graph with d on the y axis and t on the x axis. A straight line slopes upwards from the origin 2/3 of the way up the graph, 1/5 across the graph. It then becomes horizontal for the next 1/5 of the graph, before sloping downwards in a straight line for the remainder of the graph. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Jadon is decelerating at a rate of \( 0.5 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the gradient of a distance-time graph is the acceleration</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
What does the following equal?
\[
3-5+4 \times 2
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Question>
What does the following equal?
\[
3-5+4 \times 2
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( -12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Performs addition ahead of subtraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to draw angles between 0° and 90° </Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
When drawing an angle, which step will you complete last?
</Question>
<Answer>Make sure the centre of the protractor is at the end of the line segment.</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recall the steps required to draw an angle</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to draw angles between 0° and 90° </Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
When drawing an angle, which step will you complete last?
</Question>
<Answer>Draw a marker to show where the angle needs to be drawn.</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recall the steps required to draw an angle</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to draw angles between 0° and 90° </Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
When drawing an angle, which step will you complete last?
</Question>
<Answer>Draw a line segment</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recall the steps required to draw an angle</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to draw angles between 0° and 90° </Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
Which diagram shows an angle of \( 55^{\circ} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, anti-clockwise to the red line that is half way between 130 and 140 (inner scale) and halfway between 50 and 40 (outer scale).]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring obtuse angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to draw angles between 0° and 90° </Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
Which diagram shows an angle of \( 55^{\circ} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, anti-clockwise to the red line that is half way between 120 and 130 (inner scale) and halfway between 60 and 50 (outer scale).]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring obtuse angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to draw angles between 0° and 90° </Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
Which diagram shows an angle of \( 55^{\circ} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A 180 degree protractor (straight edge at the bottom) with 2 red lines and a blue sector marking out an angle being measured by the protractor. The angle is between the red line that is at 0 (inner scale) and 180 (outer scale) on the right of the protractor, anti-clockwise to the red line that is half way between 40 and 50 (inner scale) and halfway between 140 and 130 (outer scale).]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Chooses the correct scale when measuring angles on a protractor but starts from the wrong number when the angle is in between two labelled dashes</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following answers shows a correct expansion of the expression below? \( (x+5)(x-2) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}-2 x+5 x+3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the midpoint between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Points \( P, Q \) and \( R \) are equally spaced along the line segment, as shown in the sketch.

The coordinates of \( \mathrm{P} \) and \( \mathrm{R} \) are marked on the diagram.

What are the coordinates of \( Q \) ? ![A graph with 4 quadrants showing a line joining points R(2, 7), Q (unknown coordinate in 3rd quadrant) and P (-4, -10)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-2,-3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when finding midpoint</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the mode from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
The frequency table shows the grade achieved by some students in a maths exam.
What was the modal grade? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Grade & Frequency \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mode is the most common frequency rather than the highest frequency</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the mode from a frequency table</Construct>
<Subject>Averages and Range from Frequency Table</Subject>
<Question>
The frequency table shows the grade achieved by some students in a maths exam.
What was the modal grade? ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline Grade & Frequency \\
\hline \( 1 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 2 \) & \( 7 \) \\
\hline \( 3 \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline \( 4 \) & \( 9 \) \\
\hline \( 5 \) & \( 1 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mode is the frequency rather than the value/group</Misconception>

<Construct>Express pictorial representations of objects as a ratio</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
\( \square \square \square \triangle \square \square \square \triangle \square \square \square \triangle \) For every \( 3 \) triangles there are \(___\) squares
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds one part of a ratio but doesn't multiply that by the number of parts needed</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems that combine addition or subtraction with multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 8 \) shelves of plates. Four of the shelves hold \( 15 \) plates each. Two of the shelves hold \( 23 \) plates each. The other shelves hold \( 17 \) plates each.
How many plates are there in total?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 55 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores numbers written as words in worded questions, and just calculates using those written in digits</Misconception>

<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
For every \( 3 \) green squares there are \( 1 \) red squares.

How many squares should be coloured green in the grid on the right? \begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|}
\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\
\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\
\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\
\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Divide a quantity into two parts for a given a ratio, where each part is an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Ratios</Subject>
<Question>
For every \( 3 \) green squares there are \( 1 \) red squares.

How many squares should be coloured green in the grid on the right? \begin{tabular}{|l|l|l|l|}
\hline \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) & \(\;\) \\

\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Shares equally instead of in given ratio</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving brackets</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
6-3+2
\]
Tom and Katie are trying to make the calculation above equal to \( 5 \).
Tom says you can write it like this: \( (6-3)+2 \)
Katie says you can leave it like this: \( 6-3+2 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data</Construct>

\( 1, \quad 0.1, \quad 0.01,\quad 0.001 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.22 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when finding midpoint</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the median as an average from an even numbered list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the median of the following numbers?
\( 1, \quad 0.1, \quad 0.01,\quad 0.001 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the median from a even dataset does not understand we must find the midpoint of the two values in the middle</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a Fibonacci sequence expressed as a pattern</Construct>
<Subject>Other Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the best way to describe this sequence: ![A pattern with 6 terms made of green and red dots. The first term is a green dot, the second a red dot, the third is one red and one green dot. The fourth term is made of one green and two red dots. The fifth term is made from two green dots and three red dots. The sixth term is made of five red dots and three green dots. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Linear</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise a Fibonacci sequence expressed as a pattern</Construct>

The first term is a green dot, the second a red dot, the third is one red and one green dot. The fourth term is made of one green and two red dots. The fifth term is made from two green dots and three red dots. The sixth term is made of five red dots and three green dots. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Quadratic</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the term quadratic</Misconception>

The first term is a green dot, the second a red dot, the third is one red and one green dot. The fourth term is made of one green and two red dots. <Construct>Represent the solution to a graphical inequality involving a combination of vertical, horizontal and diagonal lines</Construct>
<Subject>Graphing Linear Inequalities (Shading Regions)</Subject>
<Question>
Which letter describes the region where \( \boldsymbol{x}+\boldsymbol{y} \leq \mathbf{3} \) and \( \boldsymbol{y} \leq \mathbf{1} \) ? ![A set of axes with two straight lines drawn on. The line x+y=3 goes through points (3,0) and (0,3). The line y=1 is a horizontal line going through (0,1). The lines intersect one another at (2,1).
A is the region below x+y=3 and above y=1.
B is the region above both lines.
C is the region below y=1 but above x+y=3.
D is the region below both lines. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>

\[
(5,-2) \text { to }(0,1)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>Left \( 5 \) squares, down \( 1 \) square</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses negative and positive coordinates when working with graphs in four quadrants</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Describe the movements to get from

\[
(5,-2) \text { to }(0,1)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>Left \( 5 \) squares, up \( 4 \) squares</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the distance between coordinates, includes the starting number</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles using vertically opposite angles</Construct>

<Answer>\( 137^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes vertically opposite angles sum to 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute negative integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Amy is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (1,-6) \) and \( (-5,2) \) She labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{rrrr}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (1, & -6) & (-5, & 2)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) What does the second bracket equal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-8)^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute negative integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Amy is trying to work out the distance between these two points: \( (1,-6) \) and \( (-5,2) \) She labels them like this: \( \begin{array}{rrrr}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (1, & -6) & (-5, & 2)\end{array} \) And then decides to use this formula: \( \sqrt{\left(x_{2}-x_{1}\right)^{2}+\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)^{2}} \) What does the second bracket equal?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-4)^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative number from a positive number, uses a method which assumes one of the negative signs can be ignored </Misconception>

<Construct>Add decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
How should you line up the digits to calculate \( 0.7+0.54 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A column addition of 0.7 + 0.54. The 0 of 0.7 is directly above the decimal point of 0.54, the decimal point of 0.7 is directly above the 5 of 0.54 and the 7 of 0.7 is directly above the 4 of 0.54.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that when adding decimals with a different number of decimal places, you should line up the digits to the right </Misconception>

<Construct>Add decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>![A column addition of 0.07 + 0.54 with the decimal points lined up.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the value of zeros as placeholders</Misconception>

Tom</Answer>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows the temperature in Dan's garden in a \( 24 \) hour period.

In which \( 4 \) hour period did the temperature fall the most? ![A graph showing the temperature in Dan's house over a 24 hours period. At 00:00 the temperature is -2 degrees, at 04:00 it is -4 degrees, at 08:00 it is 0 degrees, at 12:00 it is 5 degrees, at 16:00 it is 8 degrees, at 20:00 it is 3 degrees and at 00:00 it is 0 degrees.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}00: 00 \text { to } \\ 04: 00\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a steeper downwards line on a graph means a slower decrease</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows the temperature in Dan's garden in a \( 24 \) hour period.

In which \( 4 \) hour period did the temperature fall the most? ![A graph showing the temperature in Dan's house over a 24 hours period. At 00:00 the temperature is -2 degrees, at 04:00 it is -4 degrees, at 08:00 it is 0 degrees, at 12:00 it is 5 degrees, at 16:00 it is 8 degrees, at 20:00 it is 3 degrees and at 00:00 it is 0 degrees.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}08: 00 \text { to } \\ 12: 00\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up colder and hotter when comparing temperatures</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This graph shows the temperature in Dan's garden in a \( 24 \) hour period.

In which \( 4 \) hour period did the temperature fall the most? ![A graph showing the temperature in Dan's house over a 24 hours period. At 00:00 the temperature is -2 degrees, at 04:00 it is -4 degrees, at 08:00 it is 0 degrees, at 12:00 it is 5 degrees, at 16:00 it is 8 degrees, at 20:00 it is 3 degrees and at 00:00 it is 0 degrees.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{aligned} 20 & : 00 \text { to } \\ 00 & : 00\end{aligned} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a steeper downwards line on a graph means a slower decrease</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that probabilities must lie between 0, impossible, and 1, certain</Construct>

<Question>

Which of the following most accurately describes the likelihood of the event occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>Certain</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a probability of 0 represents something that is impossible</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that probabilities must lie between 0, impossible, and 1, certain</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of an event occurring is \( 0 \).

Which of the following most accurately describes the likelihood of the event occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>Unlikely</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a probability of 0 represents something that is impossible</Misconception>

<Construct>Know that probabilities must lie between 0, impossible, and 1, certain</Construct>
<Subject>Probability of Single Events</Subject>
<Question>
The probability of an event occurring is \( 0 \).

Which of the following most accurately describes the likelihood of the event occurring?
</Question>
<Answer>Even chance</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that a probability of 0 represents something that is impossible</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 8-7 \div 6^{3}= \) Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \div 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is carried out before a power</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 8-7 \div 6^{3}= \) Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8-7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 8-7 \div 6^{3}= \) Which calculation should you do first?
</Question>
<Answer>It doesn't matter: you get the same answer</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes order of operations does not affect the answer to a calculation</Misconception>

<Construct>Form expressions from situations described in words</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which expression correctly represents the following description?
"Subtract five from \( \mathrm{h} \) and then multiply by six."
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6(5-h) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts from left to right, ignoring the word ‘from’</Misconception>

<Construct>Form expressions from situations described in words</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which expression correctly represents the following description?
"Subtract five from \( \mathrm{h} \) and then multiply by six."
</Question>
<Answer>\( (5-h) \times 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts from left to right, ignoring the word ‘from’</Misconception>

<Construct>Form expressions from situations described in words</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which expression correctly represents the following description?
"Subtract five from \( \mathrm{h} \) and then multiply by six."
</Question>
<Answer>\( (h-5) \times 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realize we can omit the multiplication symbol in algebraic expressions</Misconception>

Katie says it could be: \( 2 f \)
Who is correct? ![A diagram showing 3 rows of boxes. the bottom row has 3 boxes, containing a star, 3g and 2g from left to right. The next row up contains two boxes, overlapping the joins of the boxes below. Both are empty. The top row is one box, centered over the join of the two below, containing 2f + 8g.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes an addition pyramid works in a different way to how it actually does</Misconception>
