<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\(
y=x^{2}
\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic inequalities from the graph of the quadratic</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Quadratic Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Using the graph of
\(
y=x^{2}-3 x-10
\)

What is the correct way to write the solution to
\(
x^{2}-3 x-10 \leq 0 ?
\) ![A quadratic parabola which crosses the x axis at (-2,0) and (5,0) and crosses the y axis at (0, -10)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{x \leq-2\} \cup\{x \geq 5\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic inequalities from the graph of the quadratic</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Quadratic Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Using the graph of
\(
y=x^{2}-3 x-10
\)

What is the correct way to write the solution to
\(
x^{2}-3 x-10 \leq 0 ?
\) ![A quadratic parabola which crosses the x axis at (-2,0) and (5,0) and crosses the y axis at (0, -10)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{-2 \geq x \geq 5\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand inequality notation</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic inequalities from the graph of the quadratic</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Quadratic Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Using the graph of
\(
y=x^{2}-3 x-10
\)

What is the correct way to write the solution to
\(
x^{2}-3 x-10 \leq 0 ?
\) ![A quadratic parabola which crosses the x axis at (-2,0) and (5,0) and crosses the y axis at (0, -10)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{x \geq-2\} \cup\{x \leq 5\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes inequalities cannot be combined</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe how many degrees you would turn, and in what direction, to move between North, South, East and West on a compass</Construct>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other</Construct>

\( \frac{5}{9}-\frac{1}{3} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{6} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\( \frac{5}{9}-\frac{1}{3} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{9} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not consider the denominator when adding/ subtracting fractions. Adds/subtracts the numerator and makes the denominator the one with the highest value.</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators where one is a multiple of the other</Construct>

<Question>

\( \frac{5}{9}-\frac{1}{3} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{8}{9} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of subtracts</Misconception>

<Question>
What is \( 29.156828 \) rounded to \( 3 \) decimal places?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 29.156 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( t+\frac{1}{2} \)</Answer>

<Misconception>Thinks you can divide terms by different factors when simplifying an algebraic fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Construct a triangle using Angle-Side-Angle</Construct>
<Subject>Construct Triangle</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following best describes how to construct a triangle with side length \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) with angles of \( 40^{\degree} \) and \( 50^{\degree} \) either side?
</Question>
<Answer>- Draw a line \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) long
- Place a protractor at one end of the line, measure \( 40^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Place a protractor at the same end of the line, measure \( 50^{\degree} \) and place a dot
- Draw straight lines through the end of the lines through the dots
- Where these lines cross completes the triangle</Answer>
<Misconception>Draws both angles at the same end of the line when constructing a triangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1 </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which option gives a correct substitution into the quadratic formula to solve the quadratic equation? \( 2 x^{2}-8 x+7=0 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -8 \pm \frac{\sqrt{(-8)^{2}-4(2)(7)}}{2(2)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misremembers the quadratic formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1 </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which option gives a correct substitution into the quadratic formula to solve the quadratic equation? \( 2 x^{2}-8 x+7=0 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \pm \frac{\sqrt{(-8)^{2}-4(2)(7)}}{2(2)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misremembers the quadratic formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1 </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which option gives a correct substitution into the quadratic formula to solve the quadratic equation? \( 2 x^{2}-8 x+7=0 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{-8 \pm \sqrt{(-8)^{2}-4(2)(7)}}{2(2)} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misremembers the quadratic formula</Misconception>

<Construct>Express one quantity as a percentage of another mentally</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 6 \) out of \( 25 \) as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks they double the numerator to turn a fraction into a percentage</Misconception>

<Construct>Express one quantity as a percentage of another mentally</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 6 \) out of \( 25 \) as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 62.5 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a percentage by writing the numerator followed by the denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 3+6 \div 2+1= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the order of operations, believes addition comes before division</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( 3+6 \div 2+1= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Find \( d \) in the following equation \( \frac{5 d-2}{3}=2 d-1 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( d=-1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation where there is a negative sign in front of the variable and its equivalent value, assumes the variable has a negative value</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a decimal by an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
Work out:
\[
0.04 \times 21
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8.4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a decimal less than 1 by an integer, gives an answer 10 times bigger than it should be</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a decimal by an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
Work out:
\[
0.04 \times 21
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8.04 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying decimals, does not realize that the order and position of the digits (relative to each other) has to remain constant.</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply a decimal by an integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
Work out:
\[
0.04 \times 21
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.084 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a decimal less than 1 by an integer, gives an answer 10 times smaller than it should be</Misconception>

<Construct>Read values from piecewise functions</Construct>
<Subject>Other Graphs-Others</Subject>
<Question>
Tom has correctly drawn the graph of the following function:
\(
y=\left\{\begin{array}{c}
P \text { for } 0 \leq x<Q \\
2.5 \text { for } 2 \leq x<4 \\
1 \text { for } 4 \leq x \leq 6
\end{array}\right.
\)

What are the values of \( P \) and Q? ![The graph is three separate horizontal lines. It goes from (0,3.5) to (2, 3.5), then (2, 2.5) to (4, 2.5) and the last section is from (4, 1) to (6, 1)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}P=2 \\ Q=3.5\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading value from graph, reads from the wrong axes.</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving roots</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( \sqrt{8^{2}}= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 64 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has completed only one of the two operations.</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving roots</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( \sqrt{8^{2}}= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving roots</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\( \sqrt{8^{2}}= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling, and not square rooted</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
In a bakery \( \frac{2}{5} \) of the cakes are chocolate, \( \frac{3}{8} \) of the cakes are vanilla and \( \frac{13}{40} \) are lemon.
Which flavour cake is there more of?
</Question>
<Answer>Vanilla</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not find a common denominator when comparing fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
In a bakery \( \frac{2}{5} \) of the cakes are chocolate, \( \frac{3}{8} \) of the cakes are vanilla and \( \frac{13}{40} \) are lemon.
Which flavour cake is there more of?
</Question>
<Answer>Lemon</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not find a common denominator when comparing fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
In a bakery \( \frac{2}{5} \) of the cakes are chocolate, \( \frac{3}{8} \) of the cakes are vanilla and \( \frac{13}{40} \) are lemon.
Which flavour cake is there more of?
</Question>
<Answer>There is the same amount of each.</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not find a common denominator when comparing fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about working out percentages of amounts.

Tom says to find \( 30 \% \) you divide by \( 3 \).

Katie says to find \( 30 \% \) you divide by \( 100 \) and multiply by \( 3 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand a percentage is out of 100</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about working out percentages of amounts.

Tom says to find \( 30 \% \) you divide by \( 3 \).

Katie says to find \( 30 \% \) you divide by \( 100 \) and multiply by \( 3 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Error finding percentage value after finding 1%</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate percentage of an amount mentally where the percent is a multiple of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Percentages of an Amount</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about working out percentages of amounts.

Tom says to find \( 30 \% \) you divide by \( 3 \).

Katie says to find \( 30 \% \) you divide by \( 100 \) and multiply by \( 3 \).

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand a percentage is out of 100</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
John walks from home at a constant speed to a bench, stops for a rest, and then runs home at a constant speed. Which of the following displacement \( (d) \) time \( (t) \) graphs is most likely to illustrate John's journey?
</Question>
<Answer>![The graph has three sections.
The first section starts at (0, 0) and is a sloped line with steep, positive, uphill gradient, then a horizontal line. The third section is a sloped line with gentle, negative gradient that ends when it touches the horizontal axis.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a less steep gradient corresponds to a faster speed</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
John walks from home at a constant speed to a bench, stops for a rest, and then runs home at a constant speed. Which of the following displacement \( (d) \) time \( (t) \) graphs is most likely to illustrate John's journey?
</Question>
<Answer>![The graph has three sections.
The first section starts at (0, 0) and is a sloped line with positive, uphill gradient, then a horizontal line. The third section is another sloped line with a steeper positive gradient.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes displacement continues to increase even when returning to starting point</Misconception>

<Answer>One million</Answer>

How many millimetres in \( 100 \) kilometres?

<Answer>One billion</Answer>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving non-linear variables</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is a correct simplification of: \( 4 x^{2}+2 x-x \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 x^{2}+3 x \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When collecting like terms, treats subtractions as if they are additions</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a linear sequence expressed as a pattern to make a prediction about another term in the sequence other than the next one</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing this sequence. ![3 consecutive patterns of a sequence are shown. The first pattern is a green triangle inside a square shape that is made from 4 separate red sticks. The second term is Pattern 1 but with 1 more green triangle and 3 more red sticks so that the 2 triangles are enclosed by squares made from red sticks. The third term is Pattern 2 but with 1 more green triangle and 3 more red sticks so that the 3 triangles are enclosed by squares made from red sticks.]() Tom says the number of triangles in the \( 6^{\text {th }} \) term will be 
double the number of triangles in the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term.

Katie says the number of sticks in the \( 6^{\text {th }} \) term will be 
double the number of sticks in the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term.

Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes there is a multiplicative relationship between values of terms in a linear sequence e.g. 10th term is double 5th term</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify vertical reflections in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions</Construct>
<Subject>Transformations of functions in the form f(x)</Subject>
<Question>
What transformation maps the graph of
\(y=3 x-7\)
to the graph of
\(y=7-3 x\)
</Question>
<Answer>Reflection in the line
\[
y=x
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes y=-f(x) is a reflection in y=x</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify vertical reflections in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions</Construct>

\(y=3 x-7\)
to the graph of
\(y=7-3 x\)

<Answer>Reflection in the line
\[

\]</Answer>

<Construct>Identify vertical reflections in the form f(x) = for non-trigonometric functions</Construct>
<Subject>Transformations of functions in the form f(x)</Subject>
<Question>
What transformation maps the graph of
\(y=3 x-7\)
to the graph of
\(y=7-3 x\)
</Question>
<Answer>Reflection in the
\[
y \text {-axis }
\]</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes y=-f(x) is a reflection in the y-axis</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate missing lengths of shapes by geometrical inference, where the lengths involve algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Missing Lengths</Subject>
<Question>
What length replaces the \( \color{green}\bigstar \) ? ![A diagram showing a compound shape. It is an L shape rotated 90 degrees clockwise. The top full width is 3x+4, the partial width to the right is x+4. The left full height is 5, the partial height on the right is 3. There is a green star on the left partial width at the bottom of the diagram.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that two letters together, or a number and letter together, are multiplying</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate missing lengths of shapes by geometrical inference, where the lengths involve algebraic expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Missing Lengths</Subject>
<Question>
What length replaces the \( \color{green}\bigstar \) ? ![A diagram showing a compound shape. It is an L shape rotated 90 degrees clockwise. The top full width is 3x+4, the partial width to the right is x+4. The left full height is 5, the partial height on the right is 3. There is a green star on the left partial width at the bottom of the diagram.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Not enough information</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a bar chart</Construct>
<Subject>Block Graphs and Bar Charts</Subject>
<Question>
![A bar chart with blue bars. The x-axis is labelled with fruits and the y-axis is titled "Number of Children" and its scale is from 0 to 60 in steps of 10. The bars represent the following numbers of children: Banana, 20; Apple, 40; Kiwi Fruits, 50; Orange, 30; Pineapple, 25.]() Which of the following statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>Banana is the most popular fruit</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the smallest bar in a bar chart is the mode</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise if two linear expressions are in an appropriate form to be added or subtracted</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing whether simultaneous equations are in an appropriate form to be added or subtracted, or whether they need transforming first. Tom says these equations are in an appropriate form
\(
\begin{array}{l}
2 x-3 y=10 \\
5 x+3 y=18
\end{array}
\) Katie says these equations are in an appropriate form
\(
\begin{array}{l}
2 x-3 y=10 \\
2 x+y=4
\end{array}
\) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations, believes the terms must be of opposite signs in order to be eliminated.</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise if two linear expressions are in an appropriate form to be added or subtracted</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing whether simultaneous equations are in an appropriate form to be added or subtracted, or whether they need transforming first. Tom says these equations are in an appropriate form
\(
\begin{array}{l}
2 x-3 y=10 \\
5 x+3 y=18
\end{array}
\) Katie says these equations are in an appropriate form
\(
\begin{array}{l}
2 x-3 y=10 \\
2 x+y=4
\end{array}
\) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving simultaneous equations, believes the terms must have the same sign in order to be eliminated.</Misconception>

<Question>
\( p \) increases slowly at first, then quickly, then slowly again
Which of the following sketches best shows this?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph with time on the horizontal axis and p on the vertical axis. The graph starts at the origin and curves right and upwards very steeply, then begins to level off slightly, then travels more steeply again.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a less steep gradient corresponds to a faster speed</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - bx - c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
When \( x^{2}-x-12 \) is factorised, what will appear in the box below ![\( (x+3) \)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (x-15) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the constant in an expanded quadratic comes from adding the two numbers in the brackets</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{11}{35} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of adds</Misconception>

<Answer>EGCE</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses more than 3 letters to describe an angle</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just two linear variables</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following by collecting like terms.
\[
10 t-4 h-15 t+4 h
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0-5 t \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying, thinks they write 0 in front of a negative number in the final answer, instead of just writing the negative number</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just two linear variables</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Expressions by Collecting Like Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify the following by collecting like terms.
\[
10 t-4 h-15 t+4 h
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( h-5 t \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think that a variable with no coefficient has a coefficient of 1.</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic terms, where both are linear versions of different letters (e.g. 4a x 2b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
What is the answer to \( 4 c \times 5 d \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 45 c d \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying just writes the numbers next to each other</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic terms, where both are linear versions of different letters (e.g. 4a x 2b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
What is the answer to \( 4 c \times 5 d \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 c d^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks any 2 values multiplied together can be denoted with a squared symbol</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic terms, where both are linear versions of different letters (e.g. 4a x 2b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
What is the answer to \( 4 c \times 5 d \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 c d \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplies when multiplying algebraic terms</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the shorter one</Construct>

<Question>
These two shapes are similar (not drawn to scale).
What should replace the star? ![Two scalene triangles. The bigger one has sides 9 cm and 7.5 cm. On the smaller triangle, the side corresponding to the 9 cm is 6 cm, and the side corresponding to the 7.5 cm is marked with a star.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.75 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Doubles side length for similar shape instead of using correct scale factor</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 4.5 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks adding the same value to each side makes shapes similar</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Ron calculates the answer to \( 46+28 \) mentally ![Cartoon picture of a boy's head with 2 thought bubbles:
First thought bubble says: "46+20 is equal to 66"
Second thought bubble says: "Then I am going to add on the 8.  66+8=74"]() Ron uses the same method to calculate \( 38+45 \). 
Which of the following shows how he would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}38+5=43 \\ 43+40=83\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not copy a given method accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Ron calculates the answer to \( 46+28 \) mentally ![Cartoon picture of a boy's head with 2 thought bubbles:
First thought bubble says: "46+20 is equal to 66"
Second thought bubble says: "Then I am going to add on the 8.  66+8=74"]() Ron uses the same method to calculate \( 38+45 \). 
Which of the following shows how he would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}38+40=78 \\ 78+5=83\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not copy a given method accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Ron calculates the answer to \( 46+28 \) mentally ![Cartoon picture of a boy's head with 2 thought bubbles:
First thought bubble says: "46+20 is equal to 66"
Second thought bubble says: "Then I am going to add on the 8.  66+8=74"]() Ron uses the same method to calculate \( 38+45 \). 
Which of the following shows how he would do this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}8+5=13 \\ 30+13=43 \\ 43+40=83\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not copy a given method accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Natalie is working out the distance between these two points. She has worked out the lengths of the triangle.
What is the distance? ![The image is of two points (-7, -3) and (4,2) joined by a sloped straight line, and then a horizontal and vertical line to create a right-angled triangle. The horizontal line is marked 11 and the vertical line is marked 5.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 55 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not link Pythagoras Theorem to finding distance between two points</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Natalie is working out the distance between these two points. She has worked out the lengths of the triangle.
What is the distance? ![The image is of two points (-7, -3) and (4,2) joined by a sloped straight line, and then a horizontal and vertical line to create a right-angled triangle. The horizontal line is marked 11 and the vertical line is marked 5.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{32} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Distance Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Natalie is working out the distance between these two points. She has worked out the lengths of the triangle.
What is the distance? ![The image is of two points (-7, -3) and (4,2) joined by a sloped straight line, and then a horizontal and vertical line to create a right-angled triangle. The horizontal line is marked 11 and the vertical line is marked 5.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{96} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not rearrange the Pythagoras' Theorem formula accurately</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide integers of 3 or more digits using long division</Construct>
<Subject>Written Division</Subject>
<Question>
When using long-division to solve this problem, what digit should replace the rectangle to give the correct answer (quotient)? ![Division sum written out in Bus Stop format with dividend = 771, divisor = 3, the digits of the quotient are represented by a yellow star, a purple triangle and a blue rectangle.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing, ignores any remainders</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify reflex angles</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
An angle measures \( 192^{\degree} \).
This means it is...
</Question>
<Answer>Acute</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that an acute angle is between 0 and 90 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify reflex angles</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
An angle measures \( 192^{\degree} \).
This means it is...
</Question>
<Answer>Obtuse</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that an obtuse angle is between 90 and 180 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify reflex angles</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
An angle measures \( 192^{\degree} \).
This means it is...
</Question>
<Answer>A right angle</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that a right angle is 90 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean as an average from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the mean of the following numbers?

\[
2,2,3,5,8
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating the mean from a list of data, adds up the numbers but does not divide</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean as an average from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the mean of the following numbers?

\[
2,2,3,5,8
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for the mean of a list of data, gives the median</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the mean as an average from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the mean of the following numbers?

\[
2,2,3,5,8
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for the mean of a list of data, gives the mode</Misconception>

<Construct>Order decimals with a different number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to order decimals
Tom says \( 0.06 \) is greater than \( 0.006 \)
Katie says \( 0.5 \) is greater than \( 0.6087 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the more digits a number has the greater it is, regardless of place value</Misconception>

<Construct>Order decimals with a different number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to order decimals
Tom says \( 0.06 \) is greater than \( 0.006 \)
Katie says \( 0.5 \) is greater than \( 0.6087 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>When ordering integers, orders from the digits at the end of the number instead of the digits at the start</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a parallelogram where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of this shape? ![A parallelogram drawn on a square grid in purple with an area of 9 square units. The base is length 3 squares and the perpendicular height is also length 3 squares.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts half-squares as full squares when calculating area on a square grid</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a parallelogram where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of this shape? ![A parallelogram drawn on a square grid in purple with an area of 9 square units. The base is length 3 squares and the perpendicular height is also length 3 squares.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Underestimates the area of shapes when counting squares when some squares are neither wholes nor halves</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a parallelogram where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of this shape? ![A parallelogram drawn on a square grid in purple with an area of 9 square units. The base is length 3 squares and the perpendicular height is also length 3 squares.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only includes fully shaded squares when counting area</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pie chart</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
People from Iceland were asked to pick their favourite from: lamb, fish and hotdog. A pie chart was made and \( 90 \) degrees represented fish.
What does this mean?
</Question>
<Answer>Fish are the least preferred food from the list</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can make assumptions about size of pie chart sectors without enough information</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pie chart</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
People from Iceland were asked to pick their favourite from: lamb, fish and hotdog. A pie chart was made and \( 90 \) degrees represented fish.
What does this mean?
</Question>
<Answer>Lamb is the most preferred food from the list</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can make assumptions about size of pie chart sectors without enough information</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pie chart</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
People from Iceland were asked to pick their favourite from: lamb, fish and hotdog. A pie chart was made and \( 90 \) degrees represented fish.
What does this mean?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 90 \% \) of the people prefer fish</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a pie chart makes 360% not 360 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is part of a table of values for
\[y=x^{2} -2 x+1\] \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( -1 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is part of a table of values for
\[y=x^{2} -2 x+1\] \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( -1 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the square of a negative will also be negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1 </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
One of these quadratic equations will give exactly one solution.
Which one?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{11}}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think a square root can be negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1 </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
One of these quadratic equations will give exactly one solution.
Which one?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{-16}}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can square root a negative number</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using the quadratic formula where the coefficient of x² is not 1 </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
One of these quadratic equations will give exactly one solution.
Which one?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{16}}{-5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think a square root can be negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the notation for powers</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
To calculate \( 47^{2} \) you need to do...
</Question>
<Answer>\( 47 \div 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides by the index</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the notation for powers</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
To calculate \( 47^{2} \) you need to do...
</Question>
<Answer>\( 47+2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds the index to the number</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the notation for powers</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
To calculate \( 47^{2} \) you need to do...
</Question>
<Answer>\( 47 \times 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the index</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the perimeter of a rectilinear shape by adding lengths expressed in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
What is the perimeter of this composite shape made from rectangles? ![A composite shape made from three rectangles that form upside down step structure.  The base of the shape is horizontal and is 12m long. The vertical height of the whole shape is 27m. The horizontal width of the top part of the shape is 32m. The horizontal width of the top step is 15m. The vertical height of the top rectangle is 9m. The vertical height of the bottom rectangle is 10m. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 121 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the perimeter of a rectilinear shape by adding lengths expressed in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
What is the perimeter of this composite shape made from rectangles? ![A composite shape made from three rectangles that form upside down step structure.  The base of the shape is horizontal and is 12m long. The vertical height of the whole shape is 27m. The horizontal width of the top part of the shape is 32m. The horizontal width of the top step is 15m. The vertical height of the top rectangle is 9m. The vertical height of the bottom rectangle is 10m. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 105 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating perimeter, only adds the marked lengths</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Kate and Isaac share some sweets in the ratio \( 3: 2 \)

Kate receives \( 60 \) sweets.

How many sweets does Isaac receive?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds one part of a ratio but doesn't multiply that by the number of parts needed</Misconception>

<Construct>Given information about one part, work out other parts</Construct>
<Subject>Sharing in a Ratio</Subject>
<Question>
Kate and Isaac share some sweets in the ratio \( 3: 2 \)

Kate receives \( 60 \) sweets.

How many sweets does Isaac receive?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>In ratio question where one side of ratio is given, treats that as the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out, interpret and represent subtraction using the part-whole model</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
8+12 \div 4 \square(8+12) \div 4
\]
Which symbol belongs in the box?
</Question>
<Answer>\( < \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out, interpret and represent subtraction using the part-whole model</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
8+12 \div 4 \square(8+12) \div 4
\]
Which symbol belongs in the box?
</Question>
<Answer>\( = \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out, interpret and represent subtraction using the part-whole model</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
\[
8+12 \div 4 \square(8+12) \div 4
\]
Which symbol belongs in the box?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \geq \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand inequality notation</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 80^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes an angle has been split into equal parts</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 140^{\circ} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Describe the meaning algebraic terms with powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following means the same as
\(a^{2} b\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \times a \times b \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe the meaning algebraic terms with powers</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following means the same as
\(a^{2} b\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( a \times b \times a \times b \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When a variable in an expression has a power, thinks the power applies to the whole expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are not multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which diagram represents the largest fraction?
</Question>
<Answer>![A rectangle divided horizontally into 3 smaller rectangles that are identical to each other in size and shape. The top rectangle, of the 3, is shaded orange, the rest are white.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that a larger shaded area represents a larger fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are not multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Which diagram represents the largest fraction?
</Question>
<Answer>![A rectangle divided into a grid of 30 smaller rectangles (5 high by 6 wide) that are identical to each other in size and shape. 8 of these smaller rectangles are shaded orange, the rest are white.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a greater number of shaded parts represents a greater fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify when rounding a calculation will give an over or under approximation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are discussing how to estimate the answer to
\[
188.945 \div 15.3382
\]

Jo says \( 200 \div 15.3382 \) would give an overestimate.

Paul says \( 188.945 \div 15 \) would give an overestimate.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the smaller a divisor is, the smaller the answer will be</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify when rounding a calculation will give an over or under approximation</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are discussing how to estimate the answer to
\[
188.945 \div 15.3382
\]

Jo says \( 200 \div 15.3382 \) would give an overestimate.

Paul says \( 188.945 \div 15 \) would give an overestimate.

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the larger the dividend, the smaller the answer.</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiplication law of indices with positive integer powers and a different base number</Construct>
<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about \( 4^{2} \times 2^{2} \)
Tom says \( 4^{2} \times 2^{2}=64 \)
Katie says \( 4^{2} \times 2^{2}=8^{4} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying numbers with different bases, multiplies the powers and multiplies the base numbers.</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute into simple formulae given in words</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
A quick way to change approximately from miles to kilometers is to divide the number of miles by \( 3 \) and then multiply by \( 5 \).
Using this method, how many kilometres are equal to \( 15 \) miles?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 17 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of divides</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute into simple formulae given in words</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
A quick way to change approximately from miles to kilometers is to divide the number of miles by \( 3 \) and then multiply by \( 5 \).
Using this method, how many kilometres are equal to \( 15 \) miles?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Think 1km = 1 mile</Misconception>

<Construct>Order numbers in standard form that are between 0 and 1 </Construct>
<Subject>Standard Form</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing standard form.

Tom says \( 9.3 \times 10^{5}>2.3 \times 10^{6} \)

Katie says \( 9.3 \times 10^{-5}>2.3 \times 10^{-6} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>When ordering numbers in standard form just looks at the decimal without multiplying by a power of 10</Misconception>

<Construct>Find missing angles in an isosceles triangle</Construct>
<Subject>Angles in Triangles</Subject>
<Question>
This is an isosceles triangle.
Calculate the size of angle \( p \). ![An isosceles triangle with one angle labelled 56 degrees and one angle labelled p [not to scale]]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 56^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes there is only one orientation for the isosceles triangle base angles</Misconception>

<Misconception>Forgets to subtract sum of angles we know from 180 to find missing angle in a triangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between l and  cm³</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
Complete this statement:
\( 5 \) litres \( = \) ________\( \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks 1l = 1 cubic centimetre</Misconception>

<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
Complete this statement:
\( 5 \) litres \( = \) ________\( \mathrm{cm}^{3} \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 500 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks 1l = 100 cubic centimetres</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie want to share £2 between \( 4 \) people.
Tom says you would calculate the amount each person gets by doing \( 4 \div 2 \)
Katie says you would calculate the amount each person gets by doing \( 2 \div 4 \)
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the non-commutativity of division</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie want to share £2 between \( 4 \) people.
Tom says you would calculate the amount each person gets by doing \( 4 \div 2 \)
Katie says you would calculate the amount each person gets by doing \( 2 \div 4 \)
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Both of them</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate missing lengths of shapes by geometrical inference, where the lengths given are in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
What is the area of the shaded section of this composite shape made from rectangles? ![A composite shape that makes a backwards "L" shape from 2 rectangles.  The base of the shape is horizontal and is 11cm long. The vertical height of the whole shape is 12cm. The horizontal width of the top part of the shape is 5cm. The vertical height of the bottom rectangle is labelled 4cm. The left handed rectangle is shaded blue.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 44 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses an incorrect side length when splitting a composite shape into parts</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
Which is the correct point for \( \mathrm{E} \) when reflected in the line \( x=0 \) ? ![A 4 quadrant, coordinate grid with a triangle drawn on it with the coordinates (-4,1) (-1,1) and (-2,3). E is the point (-2,3)]()
</Question>
<Answer>B is the coordinate (-2,-3)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks x = 0 is the x axis</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a vertical line with the line of reflection given as an equation, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
Which is the correct point for \( \mathrm{E} \) when reflected in the line \( x=0 \) ? ![A 4 quadrant, coordinate grid with a triangle drawn on it with the coordinates (-4,1) (-1,1) and (-2,3). E is the point (-2,3)]()
</Question>
<Answer>C is the coordinate (2,-3)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rotates instead of reflects</Misconception>

Tom says rectangle
Katie says rhombus
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a rectangle has four equal sides</Misconception>

Tom says rectangle
Katie says rhombus
Who do you agree with?

<Question>
Tom and Katie have been asked to give the name of a quadrilateral with four equal sides
Tom says rectangle
Katie says rhombus
Who do you agree with?

<Construct>Identify congruence in shapes other than triangles</Construct>
<Subject>Congruency in Other Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing congruent shapes Tom says these two shapes are congruent ![Two identical 6-sided "L shape" polygons. One of the polygons has been rotated through 90 degrees.]() Katie says these two shapes are congruent ![Two 6-sided "L shape" polygons. One of the polygons has a wider upright section than the other.]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify congruence in shapes other than triangles</Construct>
<Subject>Congruency in Other Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing congruent shapes Tom says these two shapes are congruent ![Two identical 6-sided "L shape" polygons. One of the polygons has been rotated through 90 degrees.]() Katie says these two shapes are congruent ![Two 6-sided "L shape" polygons. One of the polygons has a wider upright section than the other.]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify congruence in shapes other than triangles</Construct>
<Subject>Congruency in Other Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing congruent shapes Tom says these two shapes are congruent ![Two identical 6-sided "L shape" polygons. One of the polygons has been rotated through 90 degrees.]() Katie says these two shapes are congruent ![Two 6-sided "L shape" polygons. One of the polygons has a wider upright section than the other.]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that shapes are congruent if they have the same size and shape</Misconception>

Which of the following units is definitely wrong? \( 120 \color{yellow}\bigstar \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( m \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise metres as a unit of length</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \mathrm{km} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving positive fractions</Construct>

\(20 t-5=0\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( t=4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Swaps the dividend and divisor in order to get an integer answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, involving positive fractions</Construct>

<Question>
Solve the equation:
\(20 t-5=0\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( t=-\frac{1}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the midpoint between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Cara is trying to work out the midpoint of these two points: \( (-5,7) \) and \( (-2,-1) \) She labels them like this: \( \left.\begin{array}{cccc}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (-5, & 7) & (-2, & -1) \end{array}\right.\) And then decides to use this formula: \( \left(\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}}{2}, \frac{y_{1}+y_{2}}{2}\right) \) What is the \( \boldsymbol{y} \) value of the midpoint?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when finding midpoint</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the midpoint between two coordinates in 2D, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Cara is trying to work out the midpoint of these two points: \( (-5,7) \) and \( (-2,-1) \) She labels them like this: \( \left.\begin{array}{cccc}x_{1} & y_{1} & x_{2} & y_{2} \\ (-5, & 7) & (-2, & -1) \end{array}\right.\) And then decides to use this formula: \( \left(\frac{x_{1}+x_{2}}{2}, \frac{y_{1}+y_{2}}{2}\right) \) What is the \( \boldsymbol{y} \) value of the midpoint?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that adding a negative will increase the value of the original number</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² - c</Construct>

\(
p^{2}-9
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p-3)(p-3) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Factorises difference of two squares with the same sign in both brackets</Misconception>

\(
p^{2}-9
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( p(p-9) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes only the first term needs to be divided when factorising an expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute numbers into a SUVAT equation to work out distance</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
\( s=u t+\frac{1}{2} a t^{2} \) What is the value of \( s \) when
a=6 
u=3 
t=4

</Question>
<Answer>\( 156 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When a variable in an expression has a power, thinks the power applies to the whole expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Determine the input of a double function machine used to create an algebraic expression</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The next rectangle has "− 4" written inside it, the next rectangle has "✕ 4" written inside it and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "8m − 20" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 m-16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you apply one inverse operation to one term and the other inverse operation to the other term</Misconception>

<Construct>Determine the input of a double function machine used to create an algebraic expression</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. The next rectangle has "− 4" written inside it, the next rectangle has "✕ 4" written inside it and the final rectangle on the right has "output" written above it and "8m − 20" written inside it.]() What is the input of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 m-20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not apply the inverse function to every term in an expression</Misconception>

<Construct>Determine the input of a double function machine used to create an algebraic expression</Construct>

<Question>
![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and says "input" above it. </Question>
<Answer>\( 2 m-5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has completed only one of the two operations.</Misconception>

<Construct>Determine if a given point lies on a line</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about points on the line
\(4 x-5 y=20\)

Jo says \( (10,-4) \) lies on the line \( \mathbf{4 x}-\mathbf{5 y}=\mathbf{2 0} \)

Paul says \( (-4,10) \) lies on the line \( \mathbf{4} \boldsymbol{x}-\mathbf{5 y}=\mathbf{2 0} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting a negative number from a positive number, uses a method which assumes one of the negative signs can be ignored </Misconception>

<Construct>Identify corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
\( \mathrm{M} \) and \( \mathrm{N} \) are the intersections of the line \( X Y \) with the lines \( P Q \) and RS.
Which angle is corresponding to angle MNS? ![A pair of parallel lines pointing up to the left. PQ and RS are the ends of the parallel lines. PQ is on the left of the diagram with Q being the top left.
A red straight line, XY, crosses the parallel lines. X is on the left of the diagram.
Line XY crosses line PQ at a point marked M.
Line XY crosses line RS at a point marked N.
The angle MNS is marked in red.]()
</Question>
<Answer>YNR</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses corresponding and vertically opposite angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>

Line XY crosses line RS at a point marked N.
The angle MNS is marked in red.]()
</Question>
<Answer>QMN</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses co-interior and corresponding angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q s \) in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations?
 Pair \( 1 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p+2 q=12 \\
3 p+2 q=8
\end{array}
\) Pair \( 2 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p-2 q=12 \\
3 p-2 q=8
\end{array}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Add Pair \( 1 \)
Subtract Pair \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we do the operation matching the sign (+ if positive, - if negative)</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q s \) in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations?
 Pair \( 1 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p+2 q=12 \\
3 p+2 q=8
\end{array}
\) Pair \( 2 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p-2 q=12 \\
3 p-2 q=8
\end{array}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Add Pair \( 1 \)
Add Pair \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we add the equations.</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
What do you need to do to eliminate the \( q s \) in each of these pairs of simultaneous equations?
 Pair \( 1 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p+2 q=12 \\
3 p+2 q=8
\end{array}
\) Pair \( 2 \)
\(
\begin{array}{l}
5 p-2 q=12 \\
3 p-2 q=8
\end{array}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Subtract Pair \( 1 \)
Add Pair \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when eliminating a variable, if the signs of the terms with matching coefficients are the same, we do the operation inverse to the sign (- if positive, + if negative)</Misconception>

<Construct>Read values off a displacement-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
How far away from home was Rachel at 10:15? ![A line graph with title "A graph to show the distance Rachel travels from her home on her daily run." 
The x-axis is titled "Time" and is labelled with times from 0800 to 1300 in steps of 1 hour, with the axis going half an hour beyond 1300.
The y-axis is titled "Distance from home (Km)" and the scale is from 0 to 8 in steps of 1km. The following points are plotted and joined together: (0800, 0), (0830, 2), (0900, 3.5),(1000, 6), (1030, 7), (1100, 7.5),(1230, 7.5),(1300, 4.5), (1330, 0).    ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6.5 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading values from graphs, writes down the wrong units</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 650 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
Johan wants to plot a graph to show the distance a ball travels over time.

After \( 2 \) seconds the ball has travelled \( 3 \) metres.

Where on the graph should Johan plot this?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph with time (sec) on the horizontal axis and distance (m) on the vertical axis. B is plotted above 3 on the horizontal axis and right of 2 on the vertical axis.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading value from graph, reads from the wrong axes.</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
Johan wants to plot a graph to show the distance a ball travels over time.

After \( 2 \) seconds the ball has travelled \( 3 \) metres.

Where on the graph should Johan plot this?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph with time (sec) on the horizontal axis and distance (m) on the vertical axis. C is plotted below 3 on the horizontal axis and right of -2 on the vertical axis.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading value from graph, reads from the wrong axes.</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
Johan wants to plot a graph to show the distance a ball travels over time.

After \( 2 \) seconds the ball has travelled \( 3 \) metres.

Where on the graph should Johan plot this?
</Question>
<Answer>![A graph with time (sec) on the horizontal axis and distance (m) on the vertical axis. D is plotted below 2 on the horizontal axis and right of -3 on the vertical axis.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses negative and positive coordinates when working with graphs in four quadrants</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the volume of a cube</Construct>

What is the volume of this cube? ![A cube with one side labelled 5 cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 120 \mathrm{~cm}^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Calculates perimeter when asked for area</Misconception>

<Misconception>Does not recognise that all lengths on a cube are equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{1}{9} \times \frac{1}{5}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{14} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, adds the numerators and the denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{1}{9} \times \frac{1}{5}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5}{9} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>when multiplying fractions multiplies by the reciprocal of the 2nd fraction instead</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{1}{9} \times \frac{1}{5}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{14} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying fractions, multiplies the numerator and adds the denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left has "input" written above it and "30" written inside it. The middle rectangle has "squared" written inside it and the final rectangle is empty and has "output" written above it.]() What is the output of this function machine?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 60 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the square of a number</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>

![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left has "input" written above it and "30" written inside it. </Question>
<Answer>\( 15 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and halving</Misconception>

\)

<Answer>\( \frac{2}{5} \)</Answer>

<Misconception>When dividing fractions, does the reciprocal of the first fraction instead of the second</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form ax² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise \( 9 x^{2}-24 x+16 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (3 x+4)^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic with a coefficient of x squared, believes the signs and/or positions of the constants are interchangeable</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form ax² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise \( 9 x^{2}-24 x+16 \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (9 x-4)^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic with a non-unit coefficient of x squared, believes that coefficient will be in front of both x terms in the factorised form</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise you can use equivalent fractions to break fractions up into smaller divisions</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \frac{3}{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading a dash on a number line does not take into account the number at the start or the width of each division</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers to an appropriate degree to estimate the answer to a calculation</Construct>

<Answer>\( 0.48 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following describes how to get from point \( P \) to point \( Q \) ? ![Point P and Point Q are marked on a grid. Q is 4 squares to the right and 2 squares above P]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \) squares right \( 3 \) squares up</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares.</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following describes how to get from point \( P \) to point \( Q \) ? ![Point P and Point Q are marked on a grid. Q is 4 squares to the right and 2 squares above P]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \) squares left \( 2 \) squares down</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, goes from the image to the original</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 80 \mathrm{~mm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not half sum of parallel sides when finding area of a trapezium</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 300 \mathrm{~mm}^{2} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Identify a transversal</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>Skew</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the term transversal</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a transversal</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Line JK is.. ![A pair of parallel lines are drawn with the arrow on each pointing to the right.
A straight red line, KJ, is drawn so that diagonally crosses both parallel lines.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Perpendicular</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes any lines that cross are perpendicular</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>They are straight</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the signs for straight lines as being dashes</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the terms equilateral and regular, and recognise the notation for regular polygons</Construct>
<Subject>2D Names and Properties of Shapes-Others</Subject>
<Question>
What do the dashes tell you about the sides of this polygon? ![A hexagon with a dash on each side.]()
</Question>
<Answer>They are the midpoints</Answer>
<Misconception>Misunderstands dashed lines as being the midpoint</Misconception>

The graph starts at (0,6) travels in a straight line to (8,15), then a straight line to (16,-15) then a straight line to (24,0). ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 14.5 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes that a graph always starts at the origin</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify where negative non-integers lie on a number line</Construct>

<Question>
Here is a number line: ![A horizontal number-line with 13 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. The 1st dash is labelled with "-6", the 3rd dash is labelled "-4", the 5th dash is labelled "-2", the 7th dash is labelled "0", the 9th dash is labelled "2", the 11th dash is labelled "4" and the 13th dash is labelled "6"    A red arrow, labelled with a question mark is pointing halfway between the 3rd and 4th dashes. ]() Which of the following numbers could be indicated by the arrow?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads the position of a number from the space between the line marked, rather than the line marked</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention? \( c \div(h+4) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{c+4}{h+4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the distributive property of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention? \( c \div(h+4) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{c}{h}+4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which answer shows the following calculation using the correct algebraic convention? \( c \div(h+4) \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{h+4}{c} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a fraction means dividing the denominator by the numerator</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic inequalities from the graph of the quadratic</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic inequalities on Number Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Use the graph to approximate the solution to \( x^{2}<2 \) ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2 drawn on.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x<-1.4, x>1.4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Selects y>a solutions instead of y<a solutions for a quadratic inequality</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify algebraic expressions to maintain equivalence by collecting like terms involving just one linear variable</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Single Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
\(
2(5 x+4)-4(x-7) \equiv A x+B
\)

What is the value of \( A \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the numerical terms when expanding a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a single bracket containing a non-linear expression by taking out a single algebraic common factor (e.g. a)</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Single Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about factorising 

Tom says \( p^{2}+9 p \equiv(p+3)(p+3) \) 

Katie says \( p^{2}+9 p \equiv p(p+9) \) 

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>When factorising a quadratic without a non variable term, tries to double bracket factorise</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for an ascending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
\[
7,10,13,16,19, \ldots
\]

When calculating the nth-term rule of this sequence, what should replace the star? nth-term rule: ![\( \hat{\omega}^{n} \)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the nth term of a linear sequence, thinks the the first term is the coefficient in front of n.</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the index</Misconception>

What is the value of \( 1^{2} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds the index to the number</Misconception>

<Subject>Squares, Cubes, etc</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of \( 1^{2} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes the index as a digit on the end of a number</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 0.28 \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Prove statements involving positive and negative numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Algebraic Proof</Subject>
<Question>
"If \( n \) is a positive integer, then \( (2 n-13)^{3} \) is negative"

Is the above statement always true, sometimes true, or never true?
</Question>
<Answer>Never true</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes raising a negative number to an odd power will give a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is trying to solve the equation on the right. \( 15=\frac{1+k}{4} \) Here are his steps. Step \( 1: \) \(
60=1+k
\)

Step \( 2: \) \(
61=k
\) Which steps, if any, are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only ste.p \( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is trying to solve the equation on the right. \( 15=\frac{1+k}{4} \) Here are his steps. Step \( 1: \) \(
60=1+k
\)

Step \( 2: \) \(
61=k
\) Which steps, if any, are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both steps are correct</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is trying to solve the equation on the right. \( 15=\frac{1+k}{4} \) Here are his steps. Step \( 1: \) \(
60=1+k
\)

Step \( 2: \) \(
61=k
\) Which steps, if any, are correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both step.s are incorrect</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to solve linear equations involving fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out addition problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Diagram of a thermometer showing positive and negative temperatures, with an arrow labelled +5 going from -1 up to 4]() Which of the following calculations is represented on the thermometer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4+5=-1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes we move down a number line when we add</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out addition problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Diagram of a thermometer showing positive and negative temperatures, with an arrow labelled +5 going from -1 up to 4]() Which of the following calculations is represented on the thermometer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -1+4=5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the number of jumps between two numbers on a numberline represents the sum of those 2 numbers </Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out addition problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
![Diagram of a thermometer showing positive and negative temperatures, with an arrow labelled +5 going from -1 up to 4]() Which of the following calculations is represented on the thermometer?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1+4=5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a negative number can be replaced with its positive equivalent when answering an addition problem from a numberline</Misconception>

<Construct>Can write Roman numerals between 100 and 1000</Construct>

<Answer>DCCCC</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes four symbols after rather than one before in Roman numerals</Misconception>

<Construct>Can write Roman numerals between 100 and 1000</Construct>

<Answer>IXOO</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that we can use O as zero for place value in Roman numerals</Misconception>

<Construct>Can write Roman numerals between 100 and 1000</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>ССССССССС</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to combine different symbols in Roman numerals</Misconception>

<Construct>Round non-integers to the nearest 10</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about rounding.
Jo says \( \mathbf{1 2 0 6 . 9 7 8} \) rounded to the nearest hundred is \( \mathbf{1 2 0 0} \)
Paul says \( \mathbf{1 2 0 6 . 9 7 8} \) rounded to the nearest ten is \( \mathbf{1 2 0 0} \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places</Construct>

<Question>
\( 0.51-0.202= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.151 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places</Construct>

<Question>
\( 0.51-0.202= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.312 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you subtract the smaller digit from the larger digit in column subtraction, regardless of position</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places</Construct>
