<Question>
\( 0.51-0.202= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.318 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When “borrowing” during a subtraction problem, does not subtract one from the preceding digit</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise whether you need to add or subtract linear equations in order to eliminate a variable</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing simultaneous equations Tom says you need to add these equations to eliminate \( y \)
\(\begin{array}{r}
4 x-3 y=12 \\
x+3 y=15
\end{array}\) Katie says you need to add these equations to eliminate \( y \)
\(\begin{array}{r}
4 x+3 y=12 \\
x-3 y=15
\end{array}\) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think that -n + n = 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Sketch, or identify a sketch, of a line given in the form y = mx + c, where m is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Equation of a Line</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following sketches could represent \( y=1-4 x ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>![2 axes showing a positive gradient, crossing the y axis at a positive number]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When given the equation of a straight line, believes the first term always gives the gradient, even when the first term is actually c</Misconception>

<Construct>Sketch, or identify a sketch, of a line given in the form y = mx + c, where m is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Equation of a Line</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following sketches could represent \( y=1-4 x ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>![2 axes showing a positive gradient with a negative y intercept ]()</Answer>
<Misconception>When given the equation of a straight line, believes the first term always gives the gradient, even when the first term is actually c</Misconception>

<Construct>Sketch, or identify a sketch, of a line given in the form y = mx + c, where m is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Finding the Equation of a Line</Subject>

Which of the following sketches could represent \( y=1-4 x ? \)
</Question>
<Answer>![2 axes with a negative gradient and a negative y intercept]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that in y=mx+c, m is the y-intercept</Misconception>

<Construct>Form expressions from situations described in words</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
I think of a number. I take away six and then divide the result by three. The answer I get is \( 21 \).
Which of the following equations represents this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( n-6 \div 3=21 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Form expressions from situations described in words</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
I think of a number. I take away six and then divide the result by three. The answer I get is \( 21 \).
Which of the following equations represents this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3(n-6)=21 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that a number in front of a bracket means divide</Misconception>

<Construct>Form expressions from situations described in words</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
I think of a number. I take away six and then divide the result by three. The answer I get is \( 21 \).
Which of the following equations represents this?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{n}{3}-6=21 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the order of a worded calculation should be changed to follow BIDMAS </Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sector angle on a pie chart, calculate the frequency of a group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
A class of students were surveyed about how many siblings they have.

A selection of results are shown in the table. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Number of siblings & Frequency & Angle on a pie chart \\
\hline  0  & \( 5 \) & \( \) \\
\hline 1  & \( \bigstar \) & \( 165 \degree \) \\
\hline 2  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 3  & \( 2 \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 4 or more  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline  TOTAL  & 24  & \(  \) \\
\end{tabular} Jenny wants to draw a pie chart of the information.

Which of the following calculations would work out what replaces the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 165 \div 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you find the frequency for a pie chart sector by calculating its angle divided by the total frequency</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the sector angle on a pie chart, calculate the frequency of a group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
A class of students were surveyed about how many siblings they have.

A selection of results are shown in the table. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Number of siblings & Frequency & Angle on a pie chart \\
\hline  0  & \( 5 \) & \( \) \\
\hline 1  & \( \bigstar \) & \( 165 \degree \) \\
\hline 2  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 3  & \( 2 \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 4 or more  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline  TOTAL  & 24  & \(  \) \\
\end{tabular} Jenny wants to draw a pie chart of the information.

Which of the following calculations would work out what replaces the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{165}{360} \div 24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides rather than multiplies </Misconception>

<Construct>Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{3}{11} \div 3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{9}{11} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>when dividing a fraction by an integer, multiplies the numerator by the integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{3}{11} \div 3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{9}{33} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing a fraction by an integer, multiplies both the numerator and denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Substitute positive integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots</Construct>
<Subject>Substitution into Formula</Subject>
<Question>
When \( h=15 \) and \( j=3 \)
Which of the following pairs of statements is true?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}h(j+2)=75 \\ h(2+j)=-75\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise addition is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c</Construct>

<Question>
This is a table of values for \( 3 x+2 y=6 \) 
What should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 0 \) & \( 1 \) & \( 2 \) & \( 3 \) & \( 4 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \color{gold}\bigstar \) &   \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up the value of two terms when substituting</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
How many months have an average temperature above 23⁰C ? ![A line graph with title "Monthly Average temperatures for Zakynthos, Greece. (⁰C)". 
The x-axis is labelled with the first letter of every month of the year and is titled "Months". 
The y-axis is titled "Average temperature (⁰C)" and the scale is labelled from 18 to 34 in steps of 2. The following points are plotted and joined together: (J, 18), (F, 20), (M, 21), (A, 22), (M, 23), (J, 25), (J, 29), (A, 32), (S, 27), (O, 22), (N, 20), (D, 18).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to find data points above a certain value, gives the number of data points below this value</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret continuous data using a line graph</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Includes a data point with the value, when asked to find the number of data points above a value</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance travelled using a speed-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Speed, Distance, Time</Subject>
<Question>

A?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 200 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the shape of the graph does not affect the area calculation</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance travelled using a speed-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Speed, Distance, Time</Subject>
<Question>
The velocity-time graph shows the velocity of a car during a journey ![A velocity-time graph. Section A goes from (0,0) to (10,20). With the 10 being 10 seconds and the 20 being 20 m/s.]() What was the distance travelled during section
A?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes distance = speed/time</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance travelled using a speed-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Speed, Distance, Time</Subject>
<Question>
The velocity-time graph shows the velocity of a car during a journey ![A velocity-time graph. Section A goes from (0,0) to (10,20). With the 10 being 10 seconds and the 20 being 20 m/s.]() What was the distance travelled during section
A?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 22.36 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the length of the line in a velocity time graph gives the distance (rather than the area underneath that line).</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph, f(x), write down the solutions to f(x) = a</Construct>

\(x^{2}-3 x-6=2\) ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2-3x-6 drawn on.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( x=-1.4, \quad x=4.3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Solves for y=0 instead of given y-value when reading from a quadratic graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a sketch of a quadratic graph, f(x), write down the solutions to f(x) = a</Construct>

<Question>

\(x^{2}-3 x-6=2\) ![A set of axes with the quadratic graph y=x^2-3x-6 drawn on.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( y=-6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the y intercept when asked to read the solution to a quadratic equation from a graph</Misconception>

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to identify common factors from algebraic terms</Misconception>

<Construct>Compare real life graphs</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing graphs that show the volume of water
(V) flowing from a kitchen tap over time (t). Tom says this graph shows water flowing at a constant rate ![A sketch of a graph showing V on the y axis and t on the x axis. A line starts at the origin and slopes upwards getting gradually steeper. ]() Katie says this graph shows water flowing at a constant rate ![A sketch of a graph showing V on the y axis and t on the x axis. A horizontal straight line goes from halfway up the y axis straight across the graph. ]() Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a curve can show a constant rate</Misconception>

\]

<Answer>\( 10 a b \)</Answer>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic terms, where both are linear versions of different letters (e.g. 4a x 2b)</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify, if possible:
\[
6 a \times 4 b
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 24+a b \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies coefficients and letters separately and writes as an addition</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply algebraic terms, where both are linear versions of different letters (e.g. 4a x 2b)</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify, if possible:
\[
6 a \times 4 b
\]
</Question>
<Answer>Does not simplify</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand how to multiply algebraic terms</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
6(m+4)=24
\)
Jo says you can write: \( m+4=4 \)
Paul says you can write: \( 6 m=20 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can subtract from inside brackets without expanding when solving an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve two-step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(
6(m+4)=24
\)
Jo says you can write: \( m+4=4 \)
Paul says you can write: \( 6 m=20 \)
Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they must expand brackets before solving an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Upper and Lower Bounds</Subject>
<Question>
Round \( 0.0735 \) to \( 1 \) significant figure
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to wrong degree of accuracy (decimal places rather than significant figures)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Upper and Lower Bounds</Subject>
<Question>
Round \( 0.0735 \) to \( 1 \) significant figure
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Changes wrong place value column when rounding</Misconception>

<Construct>Round numbers between 0 and 1 to one significant figure</Construct>
<Subject>Upper and Lower Bounds</Subject>
<Question>
Round \( 0.0735 \) to \( 1 \) significant figure
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name an identity</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing identities
Tom says an identity sign should replace the star here: \( 5 y+7 \underset{\star}{2} 7+5 y \) Katie says an identity sign should replace the star here: \( 5 y-7 \underset{\star} 7-5 y \) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of the word identity </Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name an identity</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing identities
Tom says an identity sign should replace the star here: \( 5 y+7 \underset{\star}{2} 7+5 y \) Katie says an identity sign should replace the star here: \( 5 y-7 \underset{\star} 7-5 y \) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores the negative sign when thinking about the value of a term</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and name an identity</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing identities
Tom says an identity sign should replace the star here: \( 5 y+7 \underset{\star}{2} 7+5 y \) Katie says an identity sign should replace the star here: \( 5 y-7 \underset{\star} 7-5 y \) Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise addition is commutative</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve coordinate geometry questions involving quadrilaterals</Construct>

Tom says \( (1,8) \) and \( (5,8) \)
Katie says \( (3,6) \) and \( (3,2) \)
Who is correct? ![A pair of axes with no labels, 1st quadrant only. 2 points are marked with red dots and are labelled with co-ordinates: (1, 4) and (5, 4).]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the sides of a square must be horizontal and vertical, not diagonal</Misconception>

\(-3<2 x+1<7\)

<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

\)

<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Subtract integers with more than 4 digits using a written method where carrying is not needed</Construct>

How much money does Colm keep?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 81000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of adds when answering worded problems </Misconception>

Colm wins \( £ 55750 \) on the lottery and gives \( £ 25250 \) to charity.
How much money does Colm keep?
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 80000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds rather than subtracts when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer</Construct>

<Question>
\( \frac{1}{6} \times 6=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{6}{36} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a fraction by an integer, multiplies both numerator and denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Question>
\( \frac{1}{6} \times 6=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{36} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a fraction by an integer, multiplies the denominator instead of the numerator</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply proper fractions in the form: Fraction × Integer</Construct>

<Question>
\( \frac{1}{6} \times 6=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks converting an integer to a fraction means both the numerator and denominator are equal</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the limitations of the mean</Construct>

\[
5,6,7,8,8,9,11,12,320
\]
</Question>
<Answer>Median</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes extreme values can affect the median</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the limitations of the mean</Construct>

<Question>
Which of the following would not be representative of this data?
\[
5,6,7,8,8,9,11,12,320
\]
</Question>
<Answer>Mode</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes extreme values can affect the mode</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand the limitations of the mean</Construct>
<Subject>Averages (mean, median, mode) from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following would not be representative of this data?
\[
5,6,7,8,8,9,11,12,320
\]
</Question>
<Answer>All are representative</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the mean is always representative</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>Opposite</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a line segment can be opposite an axis</Misconception>

<Construct>Understand key loci terms like equidistant and perpendicular</Construct>

![A set of axes: x-axis from -4 to 4, y-axis from -4 to 4. A red line is drawn from (-2,2) to (2,2).]() The red line is _________ to the y axis.
</Question>
<Answer>Equidistant</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of perpendicular</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve length problems involving similar shapes where the missing length is the longer one</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 1: 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that in the ratio 1:n the total number of parts would be 1+n </Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( p q+3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks two letters next to each other is a division</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{p}{q+3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not account for grammar when writing algebra e.g. ,then making a group</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Writing Expressions</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the correct way of writing: \( p \) divided by \( q \), then add \( 3 \) using algebraic convention?
</Question>
<Answer>\( p-q+3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has used a subtraction sign to represent division</Misconception>

Tom</Answer>

<Construct>Sort and class quadrilaterals into hierarchical families</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not believe a shape can have two correct names e.g. rectangle and parallelogram</Misconception>

<Construct>Complete the square for expressions that end up in the form (x + a)² + b</Construct>

<Question>
When Sarah completes the square, what should replace the triangle?
\[
p^{2}-10 p-1 \equiv(p-5)^{2}  \Delta
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \Delta=+24 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When completing the square in the form (x - a)^2 + b, believes b = a^2 + the original constant</Misconception>

\[
p^{2}-10 p-1 \equiv(p-5)^{2}  \Delta
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \Delta =-11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Rotate an object or point 180° about a point, where the point lies on the edge or outside of the object </Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
![A pair of axes: x-axis is from -2 to 4; y-axis is from -2 to 4. A 6-sided polygon, labelled "P", is made by joining the following points, in order, with straight lines: (1, 2), (2, 2), (2, 3), (4, 3), (4, 4), (1, 4) and back to (1, 2).
The point (2, 2) is marked with a red dot.
Also, the following points are plotted and labelled with the following letters: A (-2, -2); B (2, -2); C (-1, -2); D (-2, -1).]() Shape \( \mathrm{P} \) is rotated \( 180^{\circ} \) through the origin.

Where will the red point be on the rotated shape?
</Question>
<Answer>B</Answer>
<Misconception>Reflects instead of rotates</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for reciprocal graphs</Construct>
<Subject>Cubics and Reciprocals</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( y=\frac{3}{x} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets that a number divided by itself is 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for reciprocal graphs</Construct>
<Subject>Cubics and Reciprocals</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( y=\frac{3}{x} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a fraction with equal numerator and denominator cancels to 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the sector angle on a pie chart for a given group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
A class of students were surveyed about how many siblings they have.

A selection of results are shown in the table. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Number of siblings & Frequency & Angle on a pie chart \\
\hline  0  & \( 7 \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline 1  & \( \) & \( 144 \degree \) \\
\hline 2  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 3  & \( 4 \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 4 or more  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline  TOTAL  & 30  & \(  \) \\
\end{tabular} Jenny wants to draw a pie chart of the information.

Which of the following calculations would work out what replaces the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{30}{360} \times 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that to find an angle for a pie chart sector you divide the total frequency by 360 and multiply by its frequency</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the sector angle on a pie chart for a given group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
A class of students were surveyed about how many siblings they have.

A selection of results are shown in the table. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Number of siblings & Frequency & Angle on a pie chart \\
\hline  0  & \( 7 \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline 1  & \( \) & \( 144 \degree \) \\
\hline 2  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 3  & \( 4 \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 4 or more  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline  TOTAL  & 30  & \(  \) \\
\end{tabular} Jenny wants to draw a pie chart of the information.

Which of the following calculations would work out what replaces the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{30}{7} \times 360 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that a fraction means dividing the denominator by the numerator</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the sector angle on a pie chart for a given group</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
A class of students were surveyed about how many siblings they have.

A selection of results are shown in the table. \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline Number of siblings & Frequency & Angle on a pie chart \\
\hline  0  & \( 7 \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline 1  & \( \) & \( 144 \degree \) \\
\hline 2  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 3  & \( 4 \) & \(  \) \\
\hline 4 or more  & \(  \) & \(  \) \\
\hline  TOTAL  & 30  & \(  \) \\
\end{tabular} Jenny wants to draw a pie chart of the information.

Which of the following calculations would work out what replaces the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \times 30 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you find the angle for a pie chart sector by doing its frequency multiplied by total frequency</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert decimals less than 1 with 2 decimal place to percentages</Construct>
<Subject>Converting between Decimals and Percentages</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 0.03 \) written as a percentage?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplied by 1000 instead of 100</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 a-3 b \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you add all the bricks in a row in an addition pyramid.</Misconception>

<Misconception>Selects y>a solutions instead of y<a solutions for a quadratic inequality</Misconception>

<Misconception>Solves for y=0 instead of given y-value when reading from a quadratic graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Add surds in the form mva + nvb</Construct>
<Subject>Operations with Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\(
2 \sqrt{5}+2 \sqrt{45} \equiv d \sqrt{5}
\)

What is the value of \( d \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying surds, does not multiply the number in front of the surd with the square root of the largest square number that has been removed from the surd</Misconception>

<Construct>Add surds in the form mva + nvb</Construct>
<Subject>Operations with Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\(
2 \sqrt{5}+2 \sqrt{45} \equiv d \sqrt{5}
\)

What is the value of \( d \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying surds, does not square root the largest square number that goes into the number under the surd before putting it in front of the surd</Misconception>

<Construct>Add surds in the form mva + nvb</Construct>
<Subject>Operations with Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\(
2 \sqrt{5}+2 \sqrt{45} \equiv d \sqrt{5}
\)

What is the value of \( d \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding or subtracting surds, does not simplify the surd before adding the numbers in front of the surd</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(\frac{5 x-1}{3}=2\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( 5 x-1=6 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{5 x}{3}=3 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds or subtracts from numerator first when solving an equation with a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(\frac{5 x-1}{3}=2\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( 5 x-1=6 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{5 x}{3}=3 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds or subtracts from numerator first when solving an equation with a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(\frac{5 x-1}{3}=2\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( 5 x-1=6 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{5 x}{3}=3 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the concept of inverse operations in algebra</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 14 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Identify the regions on a double Venn diagram given in set notation</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
Which element(s) is/are in \( P^{\prime} \) ? ![A diagram showing a Venn diagram of 2 circles. The left cicle is for Set P and contains cat in its left part, horse in the intersection. The right circle is for set Q and contains goat in its right part, horse in the intersection. Outside of the circles it says toad.]()
</Question>
<Answer>cat</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand set notation for complement (eg. A')</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the regions on a double Venn diagram given in set notation</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
Which element(s) is/are in \( P^{\prime} \) ? ![A diagram showing a Venn diagram of 2 circles. The left cicle is for Set P and contains cat in its left part, horse in the intersection. The right circle is for set Q and contains goat in its right part, horse in the intersection. Outside of the circles it says toad.]()
</Question>
<Answer>horse, goat
& toad</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the complement of a set includes any elements which are also in another set.</Misconception>

<Construct>Order integers with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
Which of these options show the numbers
\[
8,605,527 \quad 8,605,572 \quad 8,650,527 \quad 8,605,752
\]
in order from smallest to largest?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}8,605,752 \\ 8,605,572 \\ 8,650,527 \\ 8,605,527\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When ordering integers, orders from the digits at the end of the number instead of the digits at the start</Misconception>

Which face should she work out the area of to help her? ![The diagram shows a right angled triangular prism with arrows pointing to one of the right angled triangle faces and the three rectangular faces.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![A points to 'the slope' which is the rectangular face coming off the hypotenuse of the right angled triangle]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Think cross section of a prism is the biggest face</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the volume of a triangular-based prism when the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Volume of Prisms</Subject>

Amy wants to calculate the volume of this shape.

Which face should she work out the area of to help her? ![The diagram shows a right angled triangular prism with arrows pointing to one of the right angled triangle faces and the three rectangular faces.]()
</Question>
<Answer>![C points to 'the back' which is the rectangular face coming off the short vertical side of the right angled triangle]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks cross section of a prism can be any face</Misconception>

<Misconception>Thinks cross section of a prism can be any face</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find the Lowest Common Multiple to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
A hot tap drips every \( 12 \) seconds
A cold tap drips every \( 8 \) seconds
They both drip at exactly the same time
After how many seconds will they next drip at the same time?
To solve this problem you need to work out the  \( _____ \) of \( 12 \) and \( 8 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Highest Common Factor</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses factors and multiples</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find the Lowest Common Multiple to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
A hot tap drips every \( 12 \) seconds
A cold tap drips every \( 8 \) seconds
They both drip at exactly the same time
After how many seconds will they next drip at the same time?
To solve this problem you need to work out the  \( _____ \) of \( 12 \) and \( 8 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Product</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds a common multiple but not the lowest common multiple</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise when to find the Lowest Common Multiple to solve a problem</Construct>
<Subject>Multiples and Lowest Common Multiple</Subject>
<Question>
A hot tap drips every \( 12 \) seconds
A cold tap drips every \( 8 \) seconds
They both drip at exactly the same time
After how many seconds will they next drip at the same time?
To solve this problem you need to work out the  \( _____ \) of \( 12 \) and \( 8 \)
</Question>
<Answer>Sum</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes adding two numbers finds their lowest common multiple</Misconception>

<Answer>\( (x+8)(x+8) \)</Answer>

The horizontal axis is labelled Time (seconds) and the scale is 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 in even steps.
The graph consists of two sloped lines. The first is from (0,0) to (2, v) and the second is from (2, v) to (4, 0).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 100 \mathrm{mph} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes speed is distance multiplied by time</Misconception>

The horizontal axis is labelled Time (seconds) and the scale is 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 in even steps.

</Question>
<Answer>\( 12.5 \mathrm{mph} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Write a formula to describe a situation</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>

Her father was \( 43 \) years old. This year Jodie is half her father's age.
Which answer does not correctly represent this scenario?
</Question>
<Answer>![A bar model showing a bar for Jodie's age as y + 3 which is half the width of her father's bar.  Her father's bar is shown as 2 lots of y + 3, where the first y + 3 + y total to 43.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand bar modelling in algebra</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation</Construct>

Inequality \( 1 \) & Inequality 2 \\
\( 2 d>11 \) & \( 11>d+2 \)
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>Only Inequality \( 1 \)</Answer>

<Misconception>Rounds up instead of down</Misconception>

<Construct>Round decimals to the nearest whole number</Construct>
<Subject>Estimation</Subject>
<Question>

<Misconception>Rounds up rather than to one significant figure</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems involving adding a period of time on to a given start time</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
A coach takes \( 2 \) hours \( 40 \) minutes to complete a journey from Manchester to Milton Keynes.

If the coach leaves Manchester at 10:45, what time does it arrive in Milton Keynes?
</Question>
<Answer>01:25</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes times in the afternoon as if they are morning on a 24 hour clock</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve problems involving adding a period of time on to a given start time</Construct>
<Subject>Time</Subject>
<Question>
A coach takes \( 2 \) hours \( 40 \) minutes to complete a journey from Manchester to Milton Keynes.

If the coach leaves Manchester at 10:45, what time does it arrive in Milton Keynes?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12: 85 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Answers as if there are 100 minutes in an hour when changing from hours to minutes</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a negative y value, find an x value in a table of values for lines in the form y = c - x </Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\[
y=3-x
\] ![\begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \(\bigstar\)  \\
\hline\( y \) & \( -9 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

]() What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation where there is a negative sign in front of the variable and its equivalent value, assumes the variable has a negative value</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract decimals where the numbers involved have a different number of decimal places</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
\( 5.39-2.1= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.38 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Hasn't lined up the place value columns when writing out the calculation</Misconception>

\( 5.39-2.1= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7.49 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of subtracts</Misconception>

<Construct>Express a division as a fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Samia has \( 12 \) cakes to share between \( 5 \) people.
What fraction of a cake does each person get?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5}{12} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up the numerator and denominator when writing a division as a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Express a division as a fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Converting Mixed Number and Improper Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Samia has \( 12 \) cakes to share between \( 5 \) people.
What fraction of a cake does each person get?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the fraction 1/n can express sharing any number of items between n people</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract decimals from integers</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>![A column subtraction written as 0.007 - 0.612 with the decimal points lined up.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the units column is before the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract decimals from integers</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
How should you line up the digits to calculate \( 7-0.612 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>![A column subtraction written as 7.0 - 0.612 The 7 is above the 6, the decimal point in 7.0 is above the 1 and the 0 of 7.0 is above the 2.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Lines up the digits incorrectly when doing a subtraction involving two numbers with a different amount of digits</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a decimal on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of A? ![A horizontal number-line with 11 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "-6" below the 2nd dash and "3" below the last dash are the only numbers marked on the line. An arrow, labelled "A" is pointing halfway between the 4th and 5th dashes. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -4.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Student thinks that negative decimals behave the same as positive decimals when positioning a decimal between two consecutive negative integers, placing the decimal with a greater absolute value to the right. </Misconception>

<Construct>Read a decimal on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>

What is the value of A? ![A horizontal number-line with 11 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "-6" below the 2nd dash and "3" below the last dash are the only numbers marked on the line. An arrow, labelled "A" is pointing halfway between the 4th and 5th dashes. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -8.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When placing a negative number on a number line student assumes numbers with a greater absolute value are placed to the right.</Misconception>

<Construct>Read a decimal on a scale where the required measurement is marked by a dash between two numbers</Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of A? ![A horizontal number-line with 11 vertical, equally spaced, dashes representing the position of numbers. "-6" below the 2nd dash and "3" below the last dash are the only numbers marked on the line. An arrow, labelled "A" is pointing halfway between the 4th and 5th dashes. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading integers on a number line, assumes each dash is 2</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a missing term of an ascending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
The \( 1^{\text {st }} \) term in a linear sequence is \( 8 \). The \( 4^{\text {th }} \) term of the sequence is \( 41 \). What is the \( 8^{\text {th }} \) term of the sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 82 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes there is a multiplicative relationship between values of terms in a linear sequence e.g. 10th term is double 5th term</Misconception>

<Construct>Write a missing term of an ascending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
The \( 1^{\text {st }} \) term in a linear sequence is \( 8 \). The \( 4^{\text {th }} \) term of the sequence is \( 41 \). What is the \( 8^{\text {th }} \) term of the sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 88 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you multiply the constant difference by the term number to get the term value</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{7}{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confused mixed numbers with improper fractions</Misconception>

\( 2 \frac{4}{5}-1 \frac{2}{5}= \) Leave your answer as a mixed number
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \frac{2}{0} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Answer>\( \frac{1}{8} \)</Answer>

A group of \( 8 \) friends share \(  £6 \) equally.
What fraction of the money do they each get?

<Answer>\( \frac{8}{6} \)</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{33}{40} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of subtracts</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>

<Answer>\( \frac{4}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When subtracting fractions, subtracts the numerators and denominators</Misconception>

<Construct>Subtract proper fractions with different denominators which do not share a common factor</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Work out: \( \frac{5}{8}-\frac{1}{5} \) Give your answer in the simplest form.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{10} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding fractions, changes to common denominator but leaves numerators the same</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}+25 p+100
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p+25)(p+4) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when factorising a quadratic, they can choose any two numbers that multiply to give the constant</Misconception>

<Construct>Factorise a quadratic expression in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Factorising into a Double Bracket</Subject>
<Question>
Factorise this expression, if possible:
\(
p^{2}+25 p+100
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (p+5)(p+5) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the coefficent of x in an expanded quadratic comes from multiplying the two numbers in the brackets</Misconception>

\( \frac{5}{15}= \)

<Answer>\( 0.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by using only the numerator after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between l and ml</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>

What is this in litres?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3.3 \) litres</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 100 ml in a litre</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing reflections ![Tom says this reflection will create a rectangle. There is a diagonal dashed line with a square sitting on the line.]() ![Katie says this reflection will create a square. There is a diagonal dashed line with a rectangle sitting on the line.]() Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot reflect shape when line of symmetry is diagonal </Misconception>

<Construct>Write a missing term of a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>

<Question>

The first box contains a star, the second is empty, the third contains the number 488 and the fourth and fifth boxes are also empty.]() A descending linear sequence has a constant difference of \( 17 \) and the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term is \( 488 \).
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 471 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you subtract rather than add when finding the previous term in a descending linear sequence</Misconception>

The first box contains a star, the second is empty, the third contains the number 488 and the fourth and fifth boxes are also empty.]() A descending linear sequence has a constant difference of \( 17 \) and the \( 3^{\text {rd }} \) term is \( 488 \).
What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 454 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks you subtract rather than add when finding the previous term in a descending linear sequence</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a description of a descending linear sequence in words, write some terms of that sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
If the first term of a sequence is \( 100 \) and the term-to-term rule is \( -5 \), what is the \( 10^{\text {th }} \) term in this sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 95 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence just gives the next term</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a description of a descending linear sequence in words, write some terms of that sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
If the first term of a sequence is \( 100 \) and the term-to-term rule is \( -5 \), what is the \( 10^{\text {th }} \) term in this sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 50 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the term after</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a description of a descending linear sequence in words, write some terms of that sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Sequences-Others</Subject>
<Question>
If the first term of a sequence is \( 100 \) and the term-to-term rule is \( -5 \), what is the \( 10^{\text {th }} \) term in this sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 45 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies how much repeated use of the term-to-term rule changes a number but does not apply to the sequence</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve positive quadratic inequalities by balancing e.g x² ≤ a</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Quadratic Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the correct solution to the inequality?
\(
x^{2}<64
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{-32<x<32\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve positive quadratic inequalities by balancing e.g x² ≤ a</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Quadratic Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the correct solution to the inequality?
\(
x^{2}<64
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{x<8\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think a square root can be negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve positive quadratic inequalities by balancing e.g x² ≤ a</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Quadratic Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is the correct solution to the inequality?
\(
x^{2}<64
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \{x<-8\} \cup\{x>8\} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up greater than and less than symbols</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide two decimals with the same number of decimal places</Construct>

<Question>
\( 0.9 \div 0.3= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing decimals with the same number of decimal places as each other, assumes the answer also has the same number of decimal places</Misconception>

<Question>
\( 0.9 \div 0.3= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0.333 \ldots \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes division is commutative </Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find a y value in a table of values for lines in the form ax + by = c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Lines from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\[
10 x-6 y=30
\] \begin{tabular}{|l|l|}
\hline\( x \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( 0.5 \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out division  problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\(
n-2 \geq \frac{n}{2}
\)

If \( n \) can represent any number, is the statement above...
</Question>
<Answer>always true</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out division  problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\(
n-2 \geq \frac{n}{2}
\)

If \( n \) can represent any number, is the statement above...
</Question>
<Answer>never true</Answer>
<Misconception>Assumes a fact without considering enough examples</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}+x-5 \leq 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a dashed line marking a region means the line is included</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe an enlargement, with no centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1</Construct>
<Subject>Enlargement</Subject>
<Question>
Shape A has been enlarged to get shape B. What is the scale factor of the enlargement? ![Triangle A is two squares across one square up. Triangle B is six squares across and three squares up.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides length of original by length of image rather finding length of image divided by length of original to find an enlargement scale factor.</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe an enlargement, with no centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1</Construct>
<Subject>Enlargement</Subject>
<Question>
Shape A has been enlarged to get shape B. What is the scale factor of the enlargement? ![Triangle A is two squares across one square up. Triangle B is six squares across and three squares up.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides length of original by length of image rather finding length of image divided by length of original to find an enlargement scale factor.</Misconception>

\(

\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( (-9,1) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes squaring a negative number just changes the sign</Misconception>

\]

<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 18,000-3,000 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Interpret a pictogram involving fractions of symbols</Construct>
<Subject>Pictogram</Subject>
<Question>
This pictogram shows the different types of music Bob has in his music collection.

Which of the following numbers of CDs could Bob represent with whole symbols? ![A pictogram showing the number of CDs Bob has in his musical collection. Pop has 3 and a half symbols, rock has 2 symbols, blues has 2 and a quarter symbols, jazz has 3 and a quarter symbols and classical has 1 and three-quarter symbols. Each symbol represents 4 CDs.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When interpreting a pictogram, thinks each symbol stands for 1</Misconception>

\[
105, \quad 97, \quad 89, \quad \ldots
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Identifies the term-to-term rule rather than the next term in a sequence</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve quadratic equations using factorisation in the form x(x + b) </Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Solve this equation, giving all solutions:
\[
k^{2}=4 k
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( k=4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they can divide by a variable without checking whether it could equal zero</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a 90° or 270° rotation giving the angle and direction of rotation, and the coordinates of the centre of rotation, where the centre of rotation lies on the edge or outside of the object </Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about how to fully describe the rotation from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \)

Tom says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) about point \( (1,1) \) "

Katie says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) clockwise"

Who is correct? ![A coordinate grid with two pentagons drawn on it labelled P and Q. Pentagon P has the coordinates: (-3,-1) (-3,0) (-2,3) (-1,0) and (-1,-1). Pentagon A has the coordinates: (-1,5) (0,5) (3,4) (0,3) and -1,3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you do not need to give the direction when describing a rotation</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a 90° or 270° rotation giving the angle and direction of rotation, and the coordinates of the centre of rotation, where the centre of rotation lies on the edge or outside of the object </Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about how to fully describe the rotation from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \)

Tom says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) about point \( (1,1) \) "

Katie says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) clockwise"

Who is correct? ![A coordinate grid with two pentagons drawn on it labelled P and Q. Pentagon P has the coordinates: (-3,-1) (-3,0) (-2,3) (-1,0) and (-1,-1). Pentagon A has the coordinates: (-1,5) (0,5) (3,4) (0,3) and -1,3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to give the centre of rotation</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a 90° or 270° rotation giving the angle and direction of rotation, and the coordinates of the centre of rotation, where the centre of rotation lies on the edge or outside of the object </Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about how to fully describe the rotation from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \)

Tom says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) about point \( (1,1) \) "

Katie says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) clockwise"

Who is correct? ![A coordinate grid with two pentagons drawn on it labelled P and Q. Pentagon P has the coordinates: (-3,-1) (-3,0) (-2,3) (-1,0) and (-1,-1). Pentagon A has the coordinates: (-1,5) (0,5) (3,4) (0,3) and -1,3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you do not need to give the direction when describing a rotation</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
If you use the grid method to calculate \( 35 \times 26 \) what should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline\( \times \) & \( 30 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 20 \) &   & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline \( 6 \) &  \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying a multiple of 10, just multiplies the non-zero digits</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
If you use the grid method to calculate \( 35 \times 26 \) what should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline\( \times \) & \( 30 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 20 \) &   & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline \( 6 \) &  \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When multiplying by a multiple of 10, gives an answer 10 times bigger than it should be</Misconception>

<Construct>Multiply 2 digit integers by 2 digit integers using the grid method</Construct>
<Subject>Written Multiplication</Subject>
<Question>
If you use the grid method to calculate \( 35 \times 26 \) what should replace the star? \begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|}
\hline\( \times \) & \( 30 \) & \( 5 \) \\
\hline \( 20 \) &   & \(\bigstar\) \\
\hline \( 6 \) &  \\
\hline
\end{tabular}
</Question>
<Answer>\( 25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplies when using grid method</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>

<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{6}{9} \div 3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{6}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing a fraction by an integer, divides the denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{6}{9} \div 3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{18} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>when dividing a fraction by an integer, both multiplies the denominator and divides the denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Divide proper fractions in the form: Fraction ÷ Integer</Construct>
<Subject>Dividing Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Calculate:
\(
\frac{6}{9} \div 3
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing a fraction by an integer, divides both the numerator and denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Know the functionality of other non-numeric buttons on a calculator</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>![The number 3, then a calculator button labelled \( x^{-1} \), then the number 7]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the reciprocal button writes a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Know the functionality of other non-numeric buttons on a calculator</Construct>

<Question>
Which of the following would allow you to type \( \frac{3}{7} \) on your calculator? ![A scientific calculator]()
</Question>
<Answer>![The number 3, then a calculator button labelled \(\cdot\), then the number 7]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the decimal point button writes a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Know the functionality of other non-numeric buttons on a calculator</Construct>

Which of the following would allow you to type \( \frac{3}{7} \) on your calculator? ![A scientific calculator]()
</Question>
<Answer>![The number 3, then a calculator button labelled \(-\), then the number 7]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the subtraction button writes a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)(x + c)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
When you multiply out the brackets and simplify, what replaces the triangle?
\(
(3 m+2)(m-2) \equiv \bigstar \ m^{2} \triangle \  m \bigcirc
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\(
\triangle=+0
\)
(no \( \mathrm{m} \) term)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they can ignore the coefficient when expanding double brackets </Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)(x + c)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
When you multiply out the brackets and simplify, what replaces the triangle?
\(
(3 m+2)(m-2) \equiv \bigstar \ m^{2} \triangle \  m \bigcirc
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \triangle=+8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (ax + b)(x + c)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
When you multiply out the brackets and simplify, what replaces the triangle?
\(
(3 m+2)(m-2) \equiv \bigstar \ m^{2} \triangle \  m \bigcirc
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \triangle=+4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks signs are interchangeable when adding or subtracting positive and negative numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is a correct first step to solve this equation:
\(\frac{5 r+6}{6 r}=7\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5 r}{6 r}=1 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds or subtracts from numerator first when solving an equation with a fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is a correct first step to solve this equation:
\(\frac{5 r+6}{6 r}=7\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 r+1=7 r \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand how to maintain equivalence in fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving positive fractions</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following is a correct first step to solve this equation:
\(\frac{5 r+6}{6 r}=7\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5}{6}+r=7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand equivalent fractions</Misconception>

\(
(x-3)^{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}-6 x-9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

\(
(x-3)^{2}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( x^{2}+9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they only need to multiply the first and last pairs of terms when expanding double brackets</Misconception>

<Answer>Twelve</Answer>

<Answer>\( 1 \)</Answer>

\[
2,2,4,17,-10
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 12 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating the range does not reorder the data to find the largest number minus the smallest number</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the range of the following numbers?
\[
2,2,4,17,-10
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>To find the range adds the biggest and smallest number rather than subtract</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert between m and mm</Construct>

A \( 2 \) metre long rope has \( 0.5 \) centimetres chopped off the end.
What is the length of the rope that remains?
Give your answer in millimetres
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1950 \mathrm{~mm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks there are 100mm in a centimetre</Misconception>

\triangle=+0
\)
(no \( m \) term)</Answer>

<Construct>Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring a scaling of both expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
If five cups of tea and two cups of coffee cost \( £ 3.70 \), and two cups of tea and five cups of coffee cost \( £ 4.00 \), what is the cost of a cup of tea and a cup of coffee?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}\text { Tea }=0.5 \\ \text { coffee }=0.6\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not include units in answer.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear simultaneous equations requiring a scaling of both expressions</Construct>
<Subject>Simultaneous Equations</Subject>
<Question>
If five cups of tea and two cups of coffee cost \( £ 3.70 \), and two cups of tea and five cups of coffee cost \( £ 4.00 \), what is the cost of a cup of tea and a cup of coffee?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{l}\text { Tea }=30 p, \\ \text { coffee }=£ 1.10\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked to solve simultaneous equations, believes they can just find values that work in one equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify that a problem needs to be solved using addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would solve this problem?
Harvey is monitoring the growth of his plant. The plant was \( 35 \mathrm{~cm} \) tall. It grew \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) more.
How tall is the plant now?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 35 \div 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Divides rather than adds when answering worded problems</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify that a problem needs to be solved using addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would solve this problem?
Harvey is monitoring the growth of his plant. The plant was \( 35 \mathrm{~cm} \) tall. It grew \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) more.
How tall is the plant now?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 35-7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of adds when answering worded problems </Misconception>

<Construct>Identify that a problem needs to be solved using addition</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Addition and Subtraction</Subject>
<Question>
Which of the following calculations would solve this problem?
Harvey is monitoring the growth of his plant. The plant was \( 35 \mathrm{~cm} \) tall. It grew \( 7 \mathrm{~cm} \) more.
How tall is the plant now?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 35 \times 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies rather than adds when given the command word 'more'</Misconception>

<Question>
This is the net of a.. ![An image of a square with shapes attached to each of its sides. To the left hand side are three identical squares all connected, in a row. On the top side is a hexagon. On the right hand side are two squares identical to the central square and the squares on the left. So there is a row of 5 squares along the middle of the image. On the bottom side is an identical hexagon to the top.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Hexagonalbased pyramid</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses pyramid with prism</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify the net of a prism</Construct>
<Subject>Nets</Subject>
<Question>
This is the net of a.. ![An image of a square with shapes attached to each of its sides. To the left hand side are three identical squares all connected, in a row. On the top side is a hexagon. On the right hand side are two squares identical to the central square and the squares on the left. So there is a row of 5 squares along the middle of the image. On the bottom side is an identical hexagon to the top.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Hexagon</Answer>
<Misconception>Names one of the faces of a 3D shape rather than the 3D shape name</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve three or more step linear equations, with the variable on one side, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing how to solve:
\(
 \frac{3 x}{2} + 1 =5 
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{3 x}{2}=4 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( 3 x+1=10 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

 \frac{3 x}{2} + 1 =5 
\)

Tom says a correct next line of working could be: \( \frac{3 x}{2}=4 \)

Katie says a correct next line of working could be: \( 3 x+1=10 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that when multiplying both sides of an equation by an amount every term must be multiplied by the same amount</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret what the numbers in each region of a double Venn diagram mean</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
All the students in a class were asked if they have a brother, sister, both or none.

The Venn Diagram shows the results. ![A Venn diagram with two sets, one labelled Brother and one labelled Sister. The number 11 is written in Brother without the intersection , number 7 is in Sister without the intersection, the number 4 is in the intersection of Brother and Sister. The number 6 is outside the circles.]() How many students are in the class?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the number of regions in a Venn diagram as the total number of entries in the diagram</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret what the numbers in each region of a double Venn diagram mean</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
All the students in a class were asked if they have a brother, sister, both or none.

The Venn Diagram shows the results. ![A Venn diagram with two sets, one labelled Brother and one labelled Sister. The number 11 is written in Brother without the intersection , number 7 is in Sister without the intersection, the number 4 is in the intersection of Brother and Sister. The number 6 is outside the circles.]() How many students are in the class?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 22 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to include values outside of the Venn diagram when finding the total</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Dora calculates the answer to \( 12.3+4.5 \) mentally Dora uses the same method to calculate \( 2.7+35.9 \). Which of the following shows how she would do this? ![A diagram showing 3 thought bubbles from Dora's head. The first bubble says "I added the whole part first 12 + 4 = 16". The second bubble says "I then added the decimal part 0.3 + 0.5 = 0.8". The third bubble says "I then added 16 and 0.8 to get 16.8. So 12.3 + 4.5 = 16.8".]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}2.7+35=37.7 \\ 37.7+0.9=38.6\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not interpret the correct order of operations from a worded problem</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient strategies for mental addition</Construct>
<Subject>Adding and Subtracting with Decimals</Subject>
<Question>
This is how Dora calculates the answer to \( 12.3+4.5 \) mentally Dora uses the same method to calculate \( 2.7+35.9 \). Which of the following shows how she would do this? ![A diagram showing 3 thought bubbles from Dora's head. The first bubble says "I added the whole part first 12 + 4 = 16". The second bubble says "I then added the decimal part 0.3 + 0.5 = 0.8". The third bubble says "I then added 16 and 0.8 to get 16.8. So 12.3 + 4.5 = 16.8".]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}2+35=37 \\ 0.7+0.9=1.6 \\ 37+1.6=37.16\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores place value when adding a whole number and a decimal</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities in one variable that require three or more steps where the variable appears on one side of the equation </Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve
\[
42 \geq 6(2 n+1)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( n \geq 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the sides of an inequality can be switched without changing the direction of the sign</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities in one variable that require three or more steps where the variable appears on one side of the equation </Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve
\[
42 \geq 6(2 n+1)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{35}{12} \geq n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When expanding brackets, multiplies out the first term correctly but adds together the number outside the bracket with the second term inside the bracket.</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for ascending quadratic sequences in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\[
-1,4,11,20,31, \ldots
\]

When calculating the nth-term rule of this sequence, what should replace the square? nth-term rule:
\(
n^{2}+2 n \) \(\square\)

</Question>
<Answer>\[
+0
\]
(no number term)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up term in a sequence and position of a term</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for ascending quadratic sequences in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\[
-1,4,11,20,31, \ldots
\]

When calculating the nth-term rule of this sequence, what should replace the square? nth-term rule:
\(
n^{2}+2 n \) \(\square\)

</Question>
<Answer>\( -6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses only the first two terms of a sequence to work out a term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for ascending quadratic sequences in the form x² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Quadratic Sequences</Subject>
<Question>
\[
-1,4,11,20,31, \ldots
\]

When calculating the nth-term rule of this sequence, what should replace the square? nth-term rule:
\(
n^{2}+2 n \) \(\square\)

</Question>
<Answer>\( +4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtraction is commutative </Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( a b \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating perimeter, multiplies instead of adds</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( a+b \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating perimeter, only adds the marked lengths</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify reflex angles</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>Obtuse</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that an obtuse angle is between 90 and 180 degrees</Misconception>

An angle measures \( 212^{\degree} \). This means it is...
</Question>
<Answer>Acute</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that an acute angle is between 0 and 90 degrees</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify reflex angles</Construct>
<Subject>Types, Naming and Estimating</Subject>
<Question>
An angle measures \( 212^{\degree} \). This means it is...
</Question>
<Answer>A right angle</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that a right angle is 90 degrees</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>alternate angles</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses corresponding and alternate angles</Misconception>

<Misconception>Confuses co-interior and corresponding angles</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( y=-3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the y-intercept with the turning point of a curve</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise that a sequence is quadratic when expressed as a pattern</Construct>

Pattern 1 is three small squares on top of one another, so the dimensions of the rectangle are 1 across and 3 up. Pattern 2 is a rectangle of dimensions 2 squares across and 6 up. Pattern 3 is a rectangle of dimensions 3 squares across and 9 squares up.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Linear</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

What percentage of the original amount do I have now?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 170 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has taken the percentage from the original </Misconception>

<Answer>\( 166 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has taken the percentage from the original </Misconception>

<Construct>Express one quantity as a percentage of another mentally</Construct>

Then, I increase the new amount by \( 10 \% \).
What percentage of the original amount do I have now?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 264 \% \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks they had to give the new amount rather than the total percentage that the original has been increased by.</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance travelled using a speed-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Speed, Distance, Time</Subject>
<Question>
Here is a speed-time graph for a car.

Which of the following gives the best estimate for the distance travelled between \( 8 \) and \( 10 \) seconds? ![A graph showing time in seconds on the x axis and speed in metres per second on the y axis. The curve passes through the points (8,15) and (10,24)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 48 m \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that when finding area under graph you can use the upper y value rather than average of upper and lower</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the distance travelled using a speed-time graph</Construct>
<Subject>Speed, Distance, Time</Subject>
<Question>
Here is a speed-time graph for a car.

Which of the following gives the best estimate for the distance travelled between \( 8 \) and \( 10 \) seconds? ![A graph showing time in seconds on the x axis and speed in metres per second on the y axis. The curve passes through the points (8,15) and (10,24)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 120 m \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand that area under a speed time graph gives distance because distance = speed x time</Misconception>

\(

\)

<Answer>\( (2 y-3)(2 y-3) \)</Answer>

\)

<Misconception>When using a function machine, confuses the input and the output.</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pie chart</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>The fraction of the different uses of water</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes percentages cannot be converted into fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pie chart</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>
This pie chart shows how an average American household uses water.

Which of the following can not be found from this pie chart? ![A pie chart showing multiple sections: Toilet 26.7%, Leaks 13.7%, Other 5.3%, Clothes Washer 21.7%, Faucet 15.7%, Shower 16.8% ]()
</Question>
<Answer>The angle of each of the sectors</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you cannot find the angle size in a pie chart when given its percentage value</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a pie chart</Construct>
<Subject>Pie Chart</Subject>
<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>The modal use of water</Answer>

<Construct>Add surds in the form va + vb</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\( \sqrt{12}+\sqrt{27} \) Simplify, if possible.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \sqrt{5} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When simplifying surds, leaves the square root of the biggest square number under the root and puts the other number on the outside</Misconception>

<Construct>Add surds in the form va + vb</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\( \sqrt{12}+\sqrt{27} \) Simplify, if possible.
</Question>
<Answer>\( \sqrt{39} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding or subtracting surds, just adds or subtracts the numbers under the surd rather than first trying to simplifying to find like surds</Misconception>

<Construct>Add surds in the form va + vb</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Surds</Subject>
<Question>
\( \sqrt{12}+\sqrt{27} \) Simplify, if possible.
</Question>
<Answer>Cannot be simplified</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise when a surd can be simplified</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 180° and 270°</Construct>

<Question>
