The outer scale goes from 0 to 360 clockwise. The angle is between one red line that is at 0 (outer scale) and 180 (inner scale), clockwise  to the other red line that is half way between 210 and 220 (outer scale) and halfway between 330 and 320 (inner scale).
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 335^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring reflex angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 180° and 270°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of the marked angle? ![A 360 degree protractor with 2 red lines and a pink sector marking out a reflex angle being measured by the protractor. The outer scale goes from 0 to 360 clockwise. The angle is between one red line that is at 0 (outer scale) and 180 (inner scale), clockwise  to the other red line that is half way between 210 and 220 (outer scale) and halfway between 330 and 320 (inner scale).
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 345^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Reads the wrong scale on the protractor when measuring reflex angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Use a protractor to measure angles between 180° and 270°</Construct>
<Subject>Measuring Angles</Subject>
<Question>
What is the size of the marked angle? ![A 360 degree protractor with 2 red lines and a pink sector marking out a reflex angle being measured by the protractor. The outer scale goes from 0 to 360 clockwise. The angle is between one red line that is at 0 (outer scale) and 180 (inner scale), clockwise  to the other red line that is half way between 210 and 220 (outer scale) and halfway between 330 and 320 (inner scale).
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 210^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Correct scale but wrong value on protractor reading.</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
How would you describe the movement to get from the star to the triangle? ![A set of axes: x-axis from 0 to 5, y-axis from 0 to 5. A purple triangle symbol is at point (2,1) and a yellow star symbol is at point (1, 4).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \) square left, \( 3 \) squares up</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, goes from the image to the original</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
How would you describe the movement to get from the star to the triangle? ![A set of axes: x-axis from 0 to 5, y-axis from 0 to 5. A purple triangle symbol is at point (2,1) and a yellow star symbol is at point (1, 4).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \) square down, \( 3 \) squares right</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses left and right</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe simple directions to translate a shape or object using words not vectors</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
How would you describe the movement to get from the star to the triangle? ![A set of axes: x-axis from 0 to 5, y-axis from 0 to 5. A purple triangle symbol is at point (2,1) and a yellow star symbol is at point (1, 4).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1 \) squares right,\( 4 \) squares down</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares.</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret discrete data using a line graph</Construct>
<Subject>Time Series and Line Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
![A line graph with title "Goals scored in the UK". 
The x-axis scale is labelled: Aug, Sept, Oct, Nov, Dec, Jan, Feb, Mar, Apr, May. 
The y-axis is titled "Number of goals" and the scale is labelled from 0 to 3000 in steps of 500. The following points are plotted and joined together: (Aug, 500), (Sept, 850 approx.), (Oct, 950 approx.),(Nov, 1000), (Dec, 1175 approx.), (Jan, 1200 approx.), (Feb, 500), (Mar, 1000), (Apr, 1500), (May, 2000).
]() What was the total number of goals scored in the winter season (Dec, Jan, Feb)?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3375 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has used the wrong data point on the graph</Misconception>

<Construct>Determine the function of a single function machine used to create an algebraic expression</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing this function machine ![A function machine with an input of a+4, the function is not labelled and then an output of 4a+4]() Tom says the function could be \( +3 a \)
Katie says the function could be \( \times 4 \)
Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Translate a shape given vector notation where all values are positive</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Sam has translated the red flag \( \left(\begin{array}{l}2 \\ 3\end{array}\right) \) ![Image showing two identical shapes on a coordinate grid. The red shape has the point (2,1) and the corresponding point on the blue shape is (4,3).]() What error has Sam made?
</Question>
<Answer>Sam has gone left when he should have gone right</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks a positive x value in a column vector means to move left rather than right</Misconception>

<Construct>Translate a shape given vector notation where all values are positive</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Sam has translated the red flag \( \left(\begin{array}{l}2 \\ 3\end{array}\right) \) ![Image showing two identical shapes on a coordinate grid. The red shape has the point (2,1) and the corresponding point on the blue shape is (4,3).]() What error has Sam made?
</Question>
<Answer>Sam has not moved right the correct number of places</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares.</Misconception>

<Construct>Translate a shape given vector notation where all values are positive</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Sam has translated the red flag \( \left(\begin{array}{l}2 \\ 3\end{array}\right) \) ![Image showing two identical shapes on a coordinate grid. The red shape has the point (2,1) and the corresponding point on the blue shape is (4,3).]() What error has Sam made?
</Question>
<Answer>Sam has started counting from his initial position when counting right</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, counts the corners of squares (including the starting one) rather than the number of jumps between squares.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities in one variable that require three or more steps where the variable appears on one side of the equation </Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve
\[
36 \leq 4(5 n-1)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( n \leq 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the sides of an inequality can be switched without changing the direction of the sign</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities in one variable that require three or more steps where the variable appears on one side of the equation </Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
Solve
\[
36 \leq 4(5 n-1)
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{37}{20} \leq n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Only multiplies the first term in the expansion of a bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Isaac's book. Isaac always records what operation he has done to both sides of the equation.
What operation should replace the star? ![The image shows two lines of working and an arrow from the top line to the bottom line with a star next to it where the operation would be labelled. The top line of working is x - 7 = ..., and the bottom line is x = ...]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \times 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of subtraction is multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Isaac's book. Isaac always records what operation he has done to both sides of the equation.
What operation should replace the star? ![The image shows two lines of working and an arrow from the top line to the bottom line with a star next to it where the operation would be labelled. The top line of working is x - 7 = ..., and the bottom line is x = ...]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \div 7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the inverse of subtraction is division</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve one-step linear equations requiring addition or subtraction, with all positive integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Isaac is solving an equation. This is the left-hand side of two lines of working from Isaac's book. Isaac always records what operation he has done to both sides of the equation.
What operation should replace the star? ![The image shows two lines of working and an arrow from the top line to the bottom line with a star next to it where the operation would be labelled. The top line of working is x - 7 = ..., and the bottom line is x = ...]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Subtracts instead of divides</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(5-2 v=3-6 v\)

Jo says you can write: \( 2 v=8-6 v \)

Paul says you can write: \( 5+8 v=3 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Ignores the negative signs when adding positive and negative numbers</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret what the numbers in each region of a double Venn diagram mean</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
All the students in a class were asked if they have a brother, sister, both or none.

The Venn Diagram shows the results. ![A Venn diagram with two sets, one labelled Brother and one labelled Sister. The number 10 is written in Brother without the intersection , number 5 is in Sister without the intersection, the number 7 is in the intersection of Brother and Sister. The number 9 is outside the circles.]() How many students are in the class?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the number of regions in a Venn diagram as the total number of entries in the diagram</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret what the numbers in each region of a double Venn diagram mean</Construct>
<Subject>Venn Diagrams</Subject>
<Question>
All the students in a class were asked if they have a brother, sister, both or none.

The Venn Diagram shows the results. ![A Venn diagram with two sets, one labelled Brother and one labelled Sister. The number 10 is written in Brother without the intersection , number 5 is in Sister without the intersection, the number 7 is in the intersection of Brother and Sister. The number 9 is outside the circles.]() How many students are in the class?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 21 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to include values outside of the Venn diagram when finding the total</Misconception>

\[
6 \times \square=108
\]

<Answer>\( 102 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving a problem that requires an inverse operation (e.g. missing number problems), does subtraction when division is required</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the area of a trapezium where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>

<Question>
Sally wants to calculate the area of this trapezium using the formula: Area \( =\left(\frac{a+b}{2}\right) h \) ![A trapezium with the parallel sides labelled 5cm and 1cm, the slant height labelled 6cm and the perpendicular height labelled 4cm.]() What is the values of \( h \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise the height of a trapezium as the perpendicular length between the parallel sides</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses slant height instead of perpendicular height to find area of a trapezium</Misconception>

\hline
\end{tabular}

<Answer>\( 5 a \) and \( 4 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Given the area of a trapezium, calculate a missing dimension</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( h=8 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes h in the formula for area of a trapezium stands for half the sum of the parallel sides</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest other power of 10</Construct>

<Question>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 870,000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest other power of 10</Construct>
<Subject>Rounding to the Nearest Whole (10, 100, etc)</Subject>
<Question>
What is \( 875,599 \) rounded to the nearest \( 10,000 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 900,000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest other power of 10</Construct>

<Answer>\( 876,000 \)</Answer>

<Construct>Interpret a bar chart</Construct>
<Subject>Block Graphs and Bar Charts</Subject>
<Question>
The bar chart shows the drinks sold in Caroline's Café on Monday and Tuesday last week.

Approximately how many Hot Chocs were sold on Tuesday? ![Composite bar chart with four bars, labelled Tea, Coffee, Hot Choc and Cans. Each bar has two sections, the lower one shows how many sold on Monday and the upper one showing Tuesdays sales. The vertical scale has 5 ticks between 0 and 50, 50 and 100 etc.
The Hot Chocs bar's lower section is 5 ticks high, and the whole bar is 2 ticks above 100 on the vertical scale.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 110 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When reading a composite bar chart, just reads total height of bar</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a bar chart</Construct>
<Subject>Block Graphs and Bar Charts</Subject>
<Question>
The bar chart shows the drinks sold in Caroline's Café on Monday and Tuesday last week.

Approximately how many Hot Chocs were sold on Tuesday? ![Composite bar chart with four bars, labelled Tea, Coffee, Hot Choc and Cans. Each bar has two sections, the lower one shows how many sold on Monday and the upper one showing Tuesdays sales. The vertical scale has 5 ticks between 0 and 50, 50 and 100 etc.
The Hot Chocs bar's lower section is 5 ticks high, and the whole bar is 2 ticks above 100 on the vertical scale.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 51 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misreads scale</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
Imran slept really well until a car alarm woke him up and he couldn't get back to sleep.

Which of the following sketches best shows Imran's sleep?
</Question>
<Answer>![This graph shows depth of sleep increasing quickly and then maintaining a consistent level until it starts to gradually decrease until the end of the night when it reaches 0.]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes infinite gradient is not possible in real life. </Misconception>

\]

<Construct>Recognise the place value of each digit in integers</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of the \( 3 \) in the number
\[
7,359,250 \text { ? }
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30,000 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the hundred thousands column is the ten thousands column</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise the place value of each digit in integers</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
What is the value of the \( 3 \) in the number
\[
7,359,250 \text { ? }
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 300 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the hundreds and hundred thousands place value columns</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use associativity of multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\(
(-20) \times(-5)=2 \times(-10) \times(-5)
\)
Is this...
</Question>
<Answer>true because of distributivity</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not correctly apply the distributive property of multiplication</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use associativity of multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\(
(-20) \times(-5)=2 \times(-10) \times(-5)
\)
Is this...
</Question>
<Answer>true because of commutativity</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand the meaning of the word commutative </Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Calculates perimeter when asked for area</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the area of the whole grid instead of the shaded shape</Misconception>

<Answer>sometimes true</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand bar modelling in algebra</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>

<Question>
\[
20,14,8,2,-4, \ldots
\]

</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Goes the wrong direction in the sequence when identifying term-to-term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for a descending integer linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
\[
20,14,8,2,-4, \ldots
\]

When calculating the nth-term rule of this sequence, what should replace the star? nth-term rule: \(\color{gold}\bigstar\)n  \(\square\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the nth term of a linear sequence, thinks the the first term is the coefficient in front of n.</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 0.7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by using only the numerator after the decimal point</Misconception>

<Construct>Convert fractions less than 1 to terminating decimals of 3 or more decimal places</Construct>

<Question>
Convert \( \frac{7}{40} \) into a decimal
</Question>
<Answer>\( 7.40 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Converts a fraction to a decimal by placing a decimal point between the numerator and denominator</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of volume or capacity</Construct>
<Subject>Volume and Capacity Units</Subject>
<Question>
Sally has answered a question on volume. Her answer is \( 500 \).
Behind the star she has written the units that she used.
Which of the following units is definitely wrong?

\( 500 \,\bigstar \)


</Question>
<Answer>\( \mathrm{mm}^{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that units of volume are usually cubed</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify a unit of volume or capacity</Construct>

Which of the following units is definitely wrong?

\( 500 \,\bigstar \)


</Question>
<Answer>\( m^{3} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Identify a unit of volume or capacity</Construct>

Which of the following units is definitely wrong?

</Question>
<Answer>\( l \)</Answer>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{P} \) ? ![A coordinate grid with a reflection line drawn and a triangle. The reflection line passes through the coordinates: (-1,-1) (0,0) (1,1) (2,2) etc. The triangle has coordinates: (2,2) (3,3) and (4,2). P is the coordinate (4,2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>

<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{P} \) ? ![A coordinate grid with a reflection line drawn and a triangle. The reflection line passes through the coordinates: (-1,-1) (0,0) (1,1) (2,2) etc. The triangle has coordinates: (2,2) (3,3) and (4,2). P is the coordinate (4,2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (2,0) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Fails to reflect across mirror line</Misconception>

<Construct>Reflect an object or a point in a diagonal line with the line of reflection drawn, where the line of reflection lies on the edge or outside the object</Construct>
<Subject>Reflection</Subject>
<Question>
The triangle is reflected in the dashed line.
What are the new coordinates of point \( \mathrm{P} \) ? ![A coordinate grid with a reflection line drawn and a triangle. The reflection line passes through the coordinates: (-1,-1) (0,0) (1,1) (2,2) etc. The triangle has coordinates: (2,2) (3,3) and (4,2). P is the coordinate (4,2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( (0,2) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Counts the squares rather than the diagonals when reflecting in y=x or y=-x </Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities involving two inequality signs</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
What is the solution to the following inequality?
\(
-5<2 x+1<5
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -9<x<11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When solving an equation, uses the same operation rather than the inverse.</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities involving two inequality signs</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
What is the solution to the following inequality?
\(
-5<2 x+1<5
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -2<x<2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes subtracting a positive number from a negative number makes the answer less negative</Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear inequalities involving two inequality signs</Construct>
<Subject>Solving Linear Inequalities</Subject>
<Question>
What is the solution to the following inequality?
\(
-5<2 x+1<5
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( -3.5<x<1.5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not reverse the order of operations when solving an equation</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
In a bakery \( \frac{3}{7} \) of the cakes are chocolate, \( \frac{5}{14} \) of the cakes are vanilla and \( \frac{6}{28} \) are lemon.
Which flavour cake is there more of?
</Question>
<Answer>Vanilla</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not find a common denominator when comparing fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Order fractions whose denominators are multiples of the same number </Construct>
<Subject>Ordering Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
In a bakery \( \frac{3}{7} \) of the cakes are chocolate, \( \frac{5}{14} \) of the cakes are vanilla and \( \frac{6}{28} \) are lemon.
Which flavour cake is there more of?
</Question>
<Answer>There is the same amount of each.</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not find a common denominator when comparing fractions</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = ax² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\(y=\frac{1}{2} x^{2}\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( \frac{2}{3} \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{1}{9} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When substituting a value into a non-linear term with a coefficient, multiplies by the coefficient then calculates the power.</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a positive x value, find the corresponding y value for curves in the form y = ax² + bx + c</Construct>
<Subject>Plotting Quadratics from Tables of Values</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation
\(y=\frac{1}{2} x^{2}\) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( \frac{2}{3} \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \( \bigstar \) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{2}{3} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks numbers are a multiple of their index</Misconception>

<Question>
What is the smallest odd cube number?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 8 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up odd and even numbers</Misconception>

<Answer>\( p q^{3} \)</Answer>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the circle when these two brackets are expanded and simplified?
\(
(p-3)(p+1) \equiv p^{2} \triangle p \bigcirc
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \bigcirc=+3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Expand two brackets with linear terms in the form (x + a)(x + b)</Construct>
<Subject>Expanding Double Brackets</Subject>
<Question>
What should replace the circle when these two brackets are expanded and simplified?
\(
(p-3)(p+1) \equiv p^{2} \triangle p \bigcirc
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \bigcirc=-2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a bar chart</Construct>
<Subject>Block Graphs and Bar Charts</Subject>
<Question>
The bar chart shows the number of students in each year group who study French, Spanish and Chinese.

How many more Year 8s than Year 7s study French? ![An image of a vertical bar chart with bars striped red and white for French, solid blue for Spanish and solid white for Chinese (a key shows this). The x-axis is titled 'year group' with labels for Years 7 to 11. The y-axis is titled 'number of children' and its scale is from 0 to 80 in steps of 10. The following data is shown on the bar chart.
Year 7: French 42, Spanish 35, Chinese 60; Year 8: French 80, Spanish 27, Chinese 25; Year 9: French 35, Spanish 70, Chinese 12; Year 10: French 12, Spanish 35, Chinese 0; Year 11: French 33, Spanish 26, Chinese 0.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 122 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds total instead of difference when asked 'How many more'</Misconception>

<Construct>Construct a triangle using Side-Side-Side</Construct>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2.5 \mathrm{~cm} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Estimates a measurement on a diagram rather than working it out</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a midpoint and a coordinate work out the position of the other coordinate, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Here are two points and their midpoint. What should replace the star? ![A set of axis showing all four quadrants. Three points are marked in a straight line with a negative gradient. One lilac circle marks a point in the 1st quadrant and is labelled (-5, 5). One red circle marks a point in the 1st quadrant and is labelled (-2,1). Another lilac circle marks a point in the 4th quadrant and is labelled (gold star icon, green triangle icon) as the coordinates are unknown. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\(\color{gold}\bigstar\) = 5</Answer>
<Misconception>Given a line segment with a midpoint that is not the origin, assumes that the two end points will still have the same absolute value</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a midpoint and a coordinate work out the position of the other coordinate, where all the values are integers but at least one is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Midpoint Between Two Co-ordinates</Subject>
<Question>
Here are two points and their midpoint. What should replace the star? ![A set of axis showing all four quadrants. Three points are marked in a straight line with a negative gradient. One lilac circle marks a point in the 1st quadrant and is labelled (-5, 5). One red circle marks a point in the 1st quadrant and is labelled (-2,1). Another lilac circle marks a point in the 4th quadrant and is labelled (gold star icon, green triangle icon) as the coordinates are unknown. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\(\color{gold}\bigstar\) = -7</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes adding coordinates of endpoint and midpoint of a line will give the other endpoint</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the area of non-rectilinear shapes by counting squares, where all squares are either whole or exactly half-squares</Construct>

<Question>
Each square is \( 1 \mathrm{~cm} \) by \( 1 \mathrm{~cm} \)

What is the area of this shape? ![A 6 by 5 centimetre squared grid. A purple right angled triangle is drawn on the grid with a base of 3cm and a perpendicular height of 3cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Underestimates the area of shapes when counting squares when some squares are neither wholes nor halves</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the area of non-rectilinear shapes by counting squares, where all squares are either whole or exactly half-squares</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Each square is \( 1 \mathrm{~cm} \) by \( 1 \mathrm{~cm} \)

What is the area of this shape? ![A 6 by 5 centimetre squared grid. A purple right angled triangle is drawn on the grid with a base of 3cm and a perpendicular height of 3cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds when calculating area instead of multiplying</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the area of non-rectilinear shapes by counting squares, where all squares are either whole or exactly half-squares</Construct>
<Subject>Area of Simple Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Each square is \( 1 \mathrm{~cm} \) by \( 1 \mathrm{~cm} \)

What is the area of this shape? ![A 6 by 5 centimetre squared grid. A purple right angled triangle is drawn on the grid with a base of 3cm and a perpendicular height of 3cm.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 9 \mathrm{~cm}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not divide by 2 when calculating the area of a triangle</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing ways to calculate \( 49 \times 9 \) mentally
Tom multiplies \( 49 \) by \( 10 \) and then subtracts \( 49 \) from the answer.
Katie does \( 50 \times 9 \) and then subtracts \( 9 \) from the answer
Who would get the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the compensation strategy for the multiplication of 2 numbers can only be used one way round.</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing ways to calculate \( 49 \times 9 \) mentally
Tom multiplies \( 49 \) by \( 10 \) and then subtracts \( 49 \) from the answer.
Katie does \( 50 \times 9 \) and then subtracts \( 9 \) from the answer
Who would get the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the compensation strategy for the multiplication of 2 numbers can only be used one way round.</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise and use efficient methods for mental multiplication</Construct>
<Subject>Mental Multiplication and Division</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing ways to calculate \( 49 \times 9 \) mentally
Tom multiplies \( 49 \) by \( 10 \) and then subtracts \( 49 \) from the answer.
Katie does \( 50 \times 9 \) and then subtracts \( 9 \) from the answer
Who would get the correct answer?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not think that the compensation strategy for the multiplication of 2 numbers is valid.</Misconception>

<Construct>Raise a positive integer to the power of 0</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
\( (16)^{0}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgotten that anything to the power of 0 equals 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Raise a positive integer to the power of 0</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
\( (16)^{0}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgotten that anything to the power of 0 equals 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Raise a positive integer to the power of 0</Construct>
<Subject>Laws of Indices</Subject>
<Question>
\( (16)^{0}=? \)
</Question>
<Answer>You cannot have a power of \( 0 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgotten that anything to the power of 0 equals 1</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify fractions that simplify to a non-unit fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about how to leave answers to some fractions questions they are working on.

Tom says he is going to leave one of his answers as \( \frac{143}{2} \)

Katie says she is going to leave one of her answers as \( \frac{4.2}{9} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can have decimals in a simplified fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify fractions that simplify to a non-unit fraction</Construct>
<Subject>Simplifying Fractions</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about how to leave answers to some fractions questions they are working on.

Tom says he is going to leave one of his answers as \( \frac{143}{2} \)

Katie says she is going to leave one of her answers as \( \frac{4.2}{9} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes you can have decimals in a simplified fraction</Misconception>

<Construct>Simplify fractions that simplify to a non-unit fraction</Construct>

<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about how to leave answers to some fractions questions they are working on.

Katie says she is going to leave one of her answers as \( \frac{4.2}{9} \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know that you can leave a fraction in improper form</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
\( \mathrm{M} \) and \( \mathrm{N} \) are the intersections of the line \( X Y \) with the lines \( P Q \) and \( R S \).
Which angle is corresponding to angle QMY? ![A pair of parallel lines pointing up to the left. PQ and RS are the ends of the parallel lines. PQ is on the left of the diagram with Q being the top left.
A red straight line, XY, crosses the parallel lines. X is on the left of the diagram.
Line XY crosses line PQ at a point marked M.
Line XY crosses line RS at a point marked N.
The angle QMY is marked in red.]()
</Question>
<Answer>XMP</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses corresponding and vertically opposite angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
\( \mathrm{M} \) and \( \mathrm{N} \) are the intersections of the line \( X Y \) with the lines \( P Q \) and \( R S \).
Which angle is corresponding to angle QMY? ![A pair of parallel lines pointing up to the left. PQ and RS are the ends of the parallel lines. PQ is on the left of the diagram with Q being the top left.
A red straight line, XY, crosses the parallel lines. X is on the left of the diagram.
Line XY crosses line PQ at a point marked M.
Line XY crosses line RS at a point marked N.
The angle QMY is marked in red.]()
</Question>
<Answer>SNX</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses co-interior and corresponding angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Identify corresponding angles</Construct>
<Subject>Angle Facts with Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
\( \mathrm{M} \) and \( \mathrm{N} \) are the intersections of the line \( X Y \) with the lines \( P Q \) and \( R S \).
Which angle is corresponding to angle QMY? ![A pair of parallel lines pointing up to the left. PQ and RS are the ends of the parallel lines. PQ is on the left of the diagram with Q being the top left.
A red straight line, XY, crosses the parallel lines. X is on the left of the diagram.
Line XY crosses line PQ at a point marked M.
Line XY crosses line RS at a point marked N.
The angle QMY is marked in red.]()
</Question>
<Answer>XNR</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses corresponding and alternate angles</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a translation using vector notation where at least one value is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Which vector correctly describes the translation that maps object \( P \) onto object \( Q \)? ![The image shows a pair of axes and two congruent trapezia labelled P and Q. Trapezium P has vertices at (1, 7), (2, 9), (4, 9), (5, 7). Trapezium Q has vertices at (3, 3), (4, 5), (6, 5), (7, 3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \left(\begin{array}{c}-4 \\ 2\end{array}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the movement of the top number in a column vector is vertical, and the bottom number is horizontal rather than the other way round</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a translation using vector notation where at least one value is negative</Construct>
<Subject>Translation and Vectors</Subject>
<Question>
Which vector correctly describes the translation that maps object \( P \) onto object \( Q \)? ![The image shows a pair of axes and two congruent trapezia labelled P and Q. Trapezium P has vertices at (1, 7), (2, 9), (4, 9), (5, 7). Trapezium Q has vertices at (3, 3), (4, 5), (6, 5), (7, 3).]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \left(\begin{array}{c}-2 \\ 4\end{array}\right) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When describing a translation, goes from the image to the original</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise perpendicular lines</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
![An image of 8 line segments on a square grid. AB is a vertical line measuring 4 units. CD is a vertical line measuring 2 units. EF is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 4. GH is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -4. IJ is a horizontal line measuring 3 units. KL is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -1. MN is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 1. OP is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 4.]() Which line segment is perpendicular to \( \mathrm{MN} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \mathrm{GH} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of perpendicular</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise perpendicular lines</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
![An image of 8 line segments on a square grid. AB is a vertical line measuring 4 units. CD is a vertical line measuring 2 units. EF is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 4. GH is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -4. IJ is a horizontal line measuring 3 units. KL is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -1. MN is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 1. OP is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 4.]() Which line segment is perpendicular to \( \mathrm{MN} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( C D \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses the meaning of perpendicular and vertical </Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise perpendicular lines</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
![An image of 8 line segments on a square grid. AB is a vertical line measuring 4 units. CD is a vertical line measuring 2 units. EF is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 4. GH is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -4. IJ is a horizontal line measuring 3 units. KL is a diagonal line with a negative gradient of -1. MN is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 1. OP is a diagonal line with a positive gradient of 4.]() Which line segment is perpendicular to \( \mathrm{MN} \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>OP</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know the meaning of perpendicular</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret a bar chart</Construct>
<Subject>Block Graphs and Bar Charts</Subject>
<Question>
The bar chart shows the number of students in each year group who study French, Spanish and Chinese.

How many more Year \( 7 s \) than Year 8s study Chinese? ![An image of a bar chart with bars striped red and white for French, blue for Spanish and white for Chinese. The x-axis is marked 'year group' with options 7-11, and the y-axis is marked 'number of children'. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 85 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds total instead of difference when asked 'How many more'</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise perpendicular lines</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing this pair of lines
Tom says they are parallel
Katie says they are perpendicular
Who do you agree with? ![Two blue lines, each with a small red line marked across them about halfway up. The two blue lines do not touch, but they are closer together at one end.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks that if two lines do not intersect on a diagram then they will never intersect and are therefore parallel</Misconception>

<Construct>Recognise perpendicular lines</Construct>
<Subject>Parallel Lines</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing this pair of lines
Tom says they are parallel
Katie says they are perpendicular
Who do you agree with? ![Two blue lines, each with a small red line marked across them about halfway up. The two blue lines do not touch, but they are closer together at one end.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes any lines that cross are perpendicular</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a negative integer </Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2}^{\boldsymbol{x}} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( -5 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -32 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a negative power results in a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a negative integer </Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2}^{\boldsymbol{x}} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( -5 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -\frac{1}{32} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a negative power results in a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate coordinates of points on the graph of y = ax, where x is a negative integer </Construct>
<Subject>Graphs of Exponentials and Other Powers of x</Subject>
<Question>
This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\mathbf{2}^{\boldsymbol{x}} \) \begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( -5 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & \(\color{gold}\bigstar\) \\
\hline
\end{tabular} What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( -10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Multiplies by the index</Misconception>

<Construct>Write the next term of a descending decimal linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
\( \begin{array}{llll}7.5, & 6.6, & 5.7, & ?\end{array} \)

What is the next term in this linear sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4.7 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for the next term in the sequence subtracts one from the last term given, despite the sequence not going down in ones.</Misconception>

<Construct>Write the next term of a descending decimal linear sequence</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Sequences (nth term)</Subject>
<Question>
\( \begin{array}{llll}7.5, & 6.6, & 5.7, & ?\end{array} \)

What is the next term in this linear sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 4.9 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that a linear sequence must increase or decrease by same amount</Misconception>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 60^{\circ} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Misinterprets the meaning of angles on a straight line angle fact</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 120^{\circ} \)</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>a right angle.</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses isosceles and right angle triangles</Misconception>

<Question>
An isosceles triangle must have ...
</Question>
<Answer>three equal side lengths.</Answer>
<Misconception>Confuses isosceles and equilateral triangles</Misconception>

<Construct>Determine the function of a single function machine used to create an algebraic expression</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing this function machine ![A function machine with 3 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left has "input" written above it and "m" written inside it. The middle rectangle is empty and the final rectangle has "output" written above it and "4m" written inside it.]() Tom says the function could be \( +3 m \)

Katie says the function could be \( \times 4 \)

Who do you agree with?
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that two letters together, or a number and letter together, are multiplying</Misconception>

Katie says the function could be \( \times 4 \)

<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>

<Construct>Use inequality notation to order integers with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
Which symbol makes the following statement correct?
\[
1,959,909 \quad
 \square \quad
1,995,902
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( > \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When ordering integers, orders from the digits at the end of the number instead of the digits at the start</Misconception>

<Construct>Use inequality notation to order integers with the same number of digits</Construct>
<Subject>Place Value</Subject>
<Question>
Which symbol makes the following statement correct?
\[
1,959,909 \quad
 \square \quad
1,995,902
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( = \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand inequality notation</Misconception>

\[
1,959,909 \quad
 \square \quad
1,995,902
\]
</Question>
<Answer>None of these</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand inequality notation</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Currency Conversions</Subject>
<Question>
\( £ 1 \) is \( 1.5 \) US dollars.
Which of these graphs shows the value of up to \( £ 10 \) in US dollars?
</Question>
<Answer>![A straight horizontal line graph from 15 on the y axis. Y axis labelled US dollars extending to 15, x axis labelled pounds extending to 10]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a direct proportion graph is a horizontal line</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a situation sketch an appropriate real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Currency Conversions</Subject>
<Question>
\( £ 1 \) is \( 1.5 \) US dollars.
Which of these graphs shows the value of up to \( £ 10 \) in US dollars?
</Question>
<Answer>![A straight line graph from approx 5 on the y axis. Y axis labelled US dollars extending to 15, x axis labelled pounds extending to 10]()</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a direct proportion graph does not have to start at the origin</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 4 \) red balls and \( 3 \) yellow balls in a cup ![A cup with 4 red and 3 yellow balls in it. The balls are all the same size.]() Kate picks out two balls at the same time.

What is the probability at least one ball is red?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{12}{42} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not work out all possibilites when given an 'at least' question in probability</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 4 \) red balls and \( 3 \) yellow balls in a cup ![A cup with 4 red and 3 yellow balls in it. The balls are all the same size.]() Kate picks out two balls at the same time.

What is the probability at least one ball is red?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{24}{42} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not work out all possibilites when given an 'at least' question in probability</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the probability of two dependent events occurring without drawing a tree diagram</Construct>
<Subject>Tree Diagrams with Dependent Events</Subject>
<Question>
There are \( 4 \) red balls and \( 3 \) yellow balls in a cup ![A cup with 4 red and 3 yellow balls in it. The balls are all the same size.]() Kate picks out two balls at the same time.

What is the probability at least one ball is red?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{37}{42} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds the numerators when working out a combined probability</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Calculator Use</Subject>
<Question>
What answer would your calculator give if you typed in \(-5^{2}\) ![A scientific calculator]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 25 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the negative of a positive squared (where there are no brackets) gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving powers</Construct>
<Subject>Basic Calculator Use</Subject>
<Question>
What answer would your calculator give if you typed in \(-5^{2}\) ![A scientific calculator]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( -10 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Has multiplied the base number and the power</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the gradient on a linear section on a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
The cost of a taxi-ride is shown on the graph.

What is the cost per mile? ![The graph is Cost (£) on the vertical axis and Distance (miles) on the horizontal axis. The graph is a straight line from (0, 2) to (5, 6)]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( £ 1.20 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes change in y for gradient is always calculated from the origin, regardless of the y-intercept of the line</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the gradient on a linear section on a real life graph</Construct>

<Construct>For a given input find the output of a function machine</Construct>
<Subject>Function Machines</Subject>
<Question>
Cally wants to use the function machine below to solve this problem:

I think of a number, double it, subtract 5, and the answer is \( 23 \).

Which of the following should replace the star? ![A function machine with 4 rectangles in a row, joined by arrows pointing from left to right. The first rectangle on the left is empty and has "input" written above it. The next 2 rectangles are empty and the final rectangle on the right has a purple star inside it and has "output" written above it.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( n \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When using a function machine, confuses the input and the output.</Misconception>

<Construct>For a given input find the output of a function machine</Construct>

The first rectangle on the left is empty and has "input" written above it. The next 2 rectangles are empty and the final rectangle on the right has a purple star inside it and has "output" written above it.]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( \times 2 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand where to place inputs/ operations/ outputs when drawing a function machine</Misconception>

\)

<Construct>Simplify an algebraic fraction by factorising both the numerator and denominator</Construct>

<Question>
Simplify the following, if possible
\(
\frac{5 m-10}{m^{2}+3 m-10}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{5 m}{m^{2}+3 m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Simplifies a fraction by adding or subtracting the same amount from the numerator  and denominator</Misconception>

\(
\frac{5 m-10}{m^{2}+3 m-10}
\)
</Question>
<Answer>Does not simplify</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to simplify algebraic fractions</Misconception>

\(

\)

<Answer>\( \frac{4}{5} \)</Answer>

\(
\frac{2}{5} \div 2
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( \frac{4}{10} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When dividing a fraction by an integer, multiplies both the numerator and denominator by the integer</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret the gradient on a linear section on a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
Jadon decides to go for a run.
The graph on the right shows Jadon's speed in metres per second \( (s) \) over time in seconds
\( (t) \).

The gradient of the negative sloping section of the graph is \( 0.8 \).

Which of the following does that \( 0.8 \) best represent? ![A sketch of a graph with s on the y axis and t on the x axis. A straight line slopes upwards from the origin 2/3 of the way up the graph, 1/5 across the graph. It then becomes horizontal for the next 1/5 of the graph, before sloping downwards in a straight line for the remainder of the graph. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Jadon is travelling at a speed of \( 0.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes the gradient of a speed-time graph is the speed</Misconception>

<Construct>Interpret the gradient on a linear section on a real life graph</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
Jadon decides to go for a run.
The graph on the right shows Jadon's speed in metres per second \( (s) \) over time in seconds
\( (t) \).

The gradient of the negative sloping section of the graph is \( 0.8 \).

Which of the following does that \( 0.8 \) best represent? ![A sketch of a graph with s on the y axis and t on the x axis. A straight line slopes upwards from the origin 2/3 of the way up the graph, 1/5 across the graph. It then becomes horizontal for the next 1/5 of the graph, before sloping downwards in a straight line for the remainder of the graph. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>Jadon is accelerating at a rate of \( 0.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes a downward slope on a speed-time graph shows positive acceleration</Misconception>

<Construct>Sketch curves in the form (x + a)(x + b) indicating where they cross the axes</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
\( y=(x-8)(x-6) \) \( y=(x-8)(x-6) \) Where does this curve intercept the \( y \) axis? Where does this curve intercept the \( y \) axis?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (0,-14) \) \( (0,-14) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket</Misconception>

<Construct>Sketch curves in the form (x + a)(x + b) indicating where they cross the axes</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
\( y=(x-8)(x-6) \) \( y=(x-8)(x-6) \) Where does this curve intercept the \( y \) axis? Where does this curve intercept the \( y \) axis?
</Question>
<Answer>\( \begin{array}{c}(0,8) \\ \text { and } \\ (0,6)\end{array} \) \( \begin{array}{c}(0,8) \\ \text { and } \\ (0,6)\end{array} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes that the y intercept is where y = 0</Misconception>

<Construct>Sketch curves in the form (x + a)(x + b) indicating where they cross the axes</Construct>
<Subject>Sketching from Factorised Form</Subject>
<Question>
\( y=(x-8)(x-6) \) \( y=(x-8)(x-6) \) Where does this curve intercept the \( y \) axis? Where does this curve intercept the \( y \) axis?
</Question>
<Answer>\( (0,-48) \) \( (0,-48) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving roots</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing calculations involving square roots.

Tom says \( \sqrt{16}+\sqrt{9}=5 \)

Katie says \( \sqrt{16+9}=5 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>When adding roots, adds the numbers under the roots</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving roots</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing calculations involving square roots.

Tom says \( \sqrt{16}+\sqrt{9}=5 \)

Katie says \( \sqrt{16+9}=5 \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not understand square root</Misconception>

<Construct>Find the nth term rule for an ascending fractional linear sequence</Construct>

<Question>
\( \frac{1}{24}, \frac{1}{12}, \frac{1}{8}, \frac{1}{6}, \ldots \) When calculating the nth-term rule of this sequence, what should replace the rectangle? ![nth-term rule:
\[
\frac{1}{24} n
\] followed by a purple rectangle. ]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( +\frac{1}{24} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Uses first term as numerical part of nth term rule</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out a subtraction problem with positive integers where the answer is less than 0</Construct>

Tom and Katie are trying to write calculations based on the diagram below.

Tom writes: \( 15-20=-5 \)

Katie writes: \( (-5)+20=15 \)

Who is correct? ![Number line with an arrow marked -20 going from 15 to -5]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that addition is the inverse operation of subtraction</Misconception>

Katie writes: \( (-5)+20=15 \)

Who is correct? ![Number line with an arrow marked -20 going from 15 to -5]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not recognise that subtracting a larger number from a smaller number will give a negative answer</Misconception>

What is the third term in the sequence?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Mixes up squaring and multiplying by 2 or doubling</Misconception>

<Construct>Given a description of an ascending sequence using quadratics in words, write some terms of that sequence</Construct>

Square the position and add \( 5 \)

What is the third term in the sequence?

<Answer>\( 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When asked for a specific term in a sequence gives the next term</Misconception>

\hline\( x \) & \( 2 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & W \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]() What should replace the star?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Adds the index to the number</Misconception>

\hline\( y \) & W \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]() What should replace the star?

<Construct>Calculate distance where speed and time are in the appropriate units</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This displacement-time graph shows \( 10 \) seconds of Mo's journey home.

During that time he travelled at a speed of \( 15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).

What distance should replace the star? ![The graph has its vertical axis labelled Distance (m) and it has no scale written except for a star three squares up.
The horizontal axis is labelled Time (secs) and has the scale 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 in even steps.
The graph is a straight line sloping down from (0, star) to (10, 0).
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 6 m \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes scales on graphs must match on both axes</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate distance where speed and time are in the appropriate units</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This displacement-time graph shows \( 10 \) seconds of Mo's journey home.

During that time he travelled at a speed of \( 15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).

What distance should replace the star? ![The graph has its vertical axis labelled Distance (m) and it has no scale written except for a star three squares up.
The horizontal axis is labelled Time (secs) and has the scale 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 in even steps.
The graph is a straight line sloping down from (0, star) to (10, 0).
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 30 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Makes an assumption about the squares on a scale representing either 1 or 10</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate distance where speed and time are in the appropriate units</Construct>
<Subject>Real Life Graphs</Subject>
<Question>
This displacement-time graph shows \( 10 \) seconds of Mo's journey home.

During that time he travelled at a speed of \( 15 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s} \).

What distance should replace the star? ![The graph has its vertical axis labelled Distance (m) and it has no scale written except for a star three squares up.
The horizontal axis is labelled Time (secs) and has the scale 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, 10 in even steps.
The graph is a straight line sloping down from (0, star) to (10, 0).
]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 1.5 \mathrm{~m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes distance = speed/time</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 12 \% \)</Answer>

</Question>
<Answer>\( 2 \% \)</Answer>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>

<Question>

\(
a \times 4
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( a 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Writes the variable before the coefficient in an algebraic term</Misconception>

<Construct>Write algebraic expressions with correct algebraic convention</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying Terms</Subject>
<Question>
Simplify, if possible:
\(
a \times 4
\)
</Question>
<Answer>\( a^{4} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks multiplying a variable by a number is the same as raising that variable to the power of that number</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
The formula for the area of a triangle, \( A \), is ![Triangle with base labelled b and perpendicular height labelled h]() \( A=\frac{1}{2}(b \times h) \) Rearrange this to make the base, \( b \), the subject.
</Question>
<Answer>\( b=\frac{1}{2}(h \times A) \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes they can change the subject of a formula just by swapping two letters</Misconception>

<Construct>Rearrange formulae to change the subject where the subject appears once and two steps are needed</Construct>
<Subject>Rearranging Formula and Equations</Subject>
<Question>
The formula for the area of a triangle, \( A \), is ![Triangle with base labelled b and perpendicular height labelled h]() \( A=\frac{1}{2}(b \times h) \) Rearrange this to make the base, \( b \), the subject.
</Question>
<Answer>\( b=\frac{A}{2 h} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes dividing by a unit fraction is equivalent to dividing by its reciprocal</Misconception>

<Construct>Given the distance travelled, complete missing values on a speed-time graph</Construct>

<Question>
![A speed-time graph. The vertical axis is labelled Speed (mph), with no scale labelled but 4 squares up is marked v.
The horizontal axis is labelled Time (hours) and the scale is 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 in even steps.
The graph first has a horizontal line from (0,v) to (2,v) and then a sloped line from (2,v) to (4,0).]() Work out the speed \( v \) if the distance travelled is \( 90 \) miles.
</Question>
<Answer>\( 22.5 \mathrm{mph} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks the shape of the graph does not affect the area calculation</Misconception>

<Answer>\( 5.5 \)</Answer>

<Answer>\( 0.5 \ \text{m} \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When finding the difference between two points on a time series graph, only uses one of the points. </Misconception>

<Construct>Solve linear equations with the variable appearing on both sides, involving negative integers</Construct>
<Subject>Linear Equations</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are arguing about a first step to solve this equation:
\(1-4 v=3-9 v\)

Tom says you can write: \( 1+5 v=3 \)

Katie says you can write: \( -4 v=2-9 v \)

Who is correct?
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not realise that to maintain balance in an equation they must add or subtract the same amount from both sides</Misconception>

<Construct>Round integers to the nearest 10</Construct>

<Question>
What is \( 326 \) rounded to the nearest \( 10 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 300 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Question>
What is \( 326 \) rounded to the nearest \( 10 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 320 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds down instead of up</Misconception>

What is \( 326 \) rounded to the nearest \( 10 \) ?
</Question>
<Answer>\( 350 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
Paige, Kaci and David want to find the area of the school playground. They each do it a different way. Who is correct? ![A compound shape made up of two rectangles.  Dimensions are 6 metres by 12 metres and also 4 metres by 8 metres. Two sides do not have measurements so need to be deduced]()
</Question>
<Answer>Kaci: \( 10 \times 6+4 \times 6 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Cannot identify the correct side lengths to use when asked to find the area of a face</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units</Construct>
<Subject>Compound Area</Subject>
<Question>
Paige, Kaci and David want to find the area of the school playground. They each do it a different way. Who is correct? ![A compound shape made up of two rectangles.  Dimensions are 6 metres by 12 metres and also 4 metres by 8 metres. Two sides do not have measurements so need to be deduced]()
</Question>
<Answer>David: \( 12 \times 10-6 \times 4 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape</Misconception>

<Construct>Carry out division  problems involving one negative integer</Construct>
<Subject>Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers</Subject>
<Question>
\( 12 \div(-4)= \)
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Believes dividing a positive by a negative gives a positive answer</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the range of the following numbers?
\[
1,5,5,17,-6
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 5 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Finds the mode rather than the range</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the range of the following numbers?
\[
1,5,5,17,-6
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>To find the range adds the biggest and smallest number rather than subtract</Misconception>

<Construct>Calculate the range from a list of data</Construct>
<Subject>Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data</Subject>
<Question>
What is the range of the following numbers?
\[
1,5,5,17,-6
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 16 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not include negative numbers when calculating a range</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe an enlargement, with no centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1</Construct>
<Subject>Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Shape \( Q \) is an enlargement of shape \( P \).
What calculation works out the constant of proportionality from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \) ? ![To similar star shapes labelled P and Q. They have the same side labelled for P it is 3cm and for Q it is 11cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \div 11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating a scale factor, thinks the division is the other way around.</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe an enlargement, with no centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1</Construct>
<Subject>Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Shape \( Q \) is an enlargement of shape \( P \).
What calculation works out the constant of proportionality from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \) ? ![To similar star shapes labelled P and Q. They have the same side labelled for P it is 3cm and for Q it is 11cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 3 \times 11 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating a scale factor, multiplies instead of dividing.</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe an enlargement, with no centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1</Construct>
<Subject>Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Shape \( Q \) is an enlargement of shape \( P \).
What calculation works out the constant of proportionality from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \) ? ![To similar star shapes labelled P and Q. They have the same side labelled for P it is 3cm and for Q it is 11cm]()
</Question>
<Answer>\( 11-3 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>When calculating a scale factor, thinks they need to subtract rather than divide.</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
What does the following equal?
\[
8-7+10 \times 3
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( -29 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)</Misconception>

<Construct>Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division</Construct>
<Subject>BIDMAS</Subject>
<Question>
What does the following equal?
\[
8-7+10 \times 3
\]
</Question>
<Answer>\( 33 \)</Answer>
<Misconception>Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order</Misconception>

<Construct>Distinguish between congruency and similarity</Construct>
<Subject>Congruency in Other Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing congruence and similarity. Who is correct? Tom says these two squares are congruent ![An image of two squares. A little one and a big one. They are enlargements of each other.]() Katie says these two squares are similar ![An image of two squares. A little one and a big one. They are enlargements of each other.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Tom</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes</Misconception>

<Construct>Distinguish between congruency and similarity</Construct>
<Subject>Congruency in Other Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing congruence and similarity. Who is correct? Tom says these two squares are congruent ![An image of two squares. A little one and a big one. They are enlargements of each other.]() Katie says these two squares are similar ![An image of two squares. A little one and a big one. They are enlargements of each other.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Both Tom and Katie</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes</Misconception>

<Construct>Distinguish between congruency and similarity</Construct>
<Subject>Congruency in Other Shapes</Subject>
<Question>
Tom and Katie are discussing congruence and similarity. Who is correct? Tom says these two squares are congruent ![An image of two squares. A little one and a big one. They are enlargements of each other.]() Katie says these two squares are similar ![An image of two squares. A little one and a big one. They are enlargements of each other.]()
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a 90° or 270° rotation giving the angle and direction of rotation, and the coordinates of the centre of rotation, where the centre of rotation lies on the edge or outside of the object </Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about how to fully describe the rotation from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \)

Jo says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) anticlockwise"

Paul says: "a rotation of \( +270^{\degree} \) about \( (-1,1)^{\prime \prime} \)

Who is correct? ![A coordinate grid with two trapeziums drawn on it and a centre of rotation marked on, one space to the right and one space up from the origin. Trapezium P has the coordinates: (-4,4) (-2,4) (-2,3) and (-4,1). Trapezium Q has the coordinates: (-4,-2) (-4,0) (-3,0) and (-1,-2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>Only
Jo</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to give the centre of rotation</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a 90° or 270° rotation giving the angle and direction of rotation, and the coordinates of the centre of rotation, where the centre of rotation lies on the edge or outside of the object </Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about how to fully describe the rotation from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \)

Jo says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) anticlockwise"

Paul says: "a rotation of \( +270^{\degree} \) about \( (-1,1)^{\prime \prime} \)

Who is correct? ![A coordinate grid with two trapeziums drawn on it and a centre of rotation marked on, one space to the right and one space up from the origin. Trapezium P has the coordinates: (-4,4) (-2,4) (-2,3) and (-4,1). Trapezium Q has the coordinates: (-4,-2) (-4,0) (-3,0) and (-1,-2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>Both Jo and Paul</Answer>
<Misconception>Forgets to give the centre of rotation</Misconception>

<Construct>Describe a 90° or 270° rotation giving the angle and direction of rotation, and the coordinates of the centre of rotation, where the centre of rotation lies on the edge or outside of the object </Construct>
<Subject>Rotation</Subject>
<Question>
Jo and Paul are arguing about how to fully describe the rotation from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \)

Jo says: "a rotation of \( 90^{\degree} \) anticlockwise"

Paul says: "a rotation of \( +270^{\degree} \) about \( (-1,1)^{\prime \prime} \)

Who is correct? ![A coordinate grid with two trapeziums drawn on it and a centre of rotation marked on, one space to the right and one space up from the origin. Trapezium P has the coordinates: (-4,4) (-2,4) (-2,3) and (-4,1). Trapezium Q has the coordinates: (-4,-2) (-4,0) (-3,0) and (-1,-2).]()
</Question>
<Answer>Neither is correct</Answer>
<Misconception>Does not know about the + notation for directions in rotations</Misconception>
